Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Fermented in 75% stainless and 25% neutral oak, this clean, simple wine mixes flavors of apple and pear. There are light hints of vanilla and water cracker. It's a pleasant wine at a modest price.
Wine: David Hill 2017 Estate Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Folie à Deux
Review: Robust on the palate, this wine opens in floral aromatics of jasmine and apple blossom. It follows flavorfully in Meyer lemon zest, tangerine and pineapple, combining firm structure with rounded approachability.
Wine: Folie à Deux 2017 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tangy red-cherry aromas are lifted by anise and nutmeg on the nose of this bottling, which features a whimsical but accurate geographic label. Bay leaf and thyme flavors give depth to the sharp pomegranate fruit flavors of the palate.
Wine: Inconceivable 2015 The Fog Prince Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: J. McClelland
Review: Blended with 14% Cabernet Franc, this succeeds in its light-bodied palate of red currant, cranberry and plum, with secondary characteristics of pencil shavings and graphite. The midpalate is thick and concentrated, finishing with elegance.
Wine: J. McClelland 2014 Merlot (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Lucas & Lewellen
Review: Ripe cherry aromas meet with cinnamon and sagebrush on the rustic yet approachable nose of this bottling. Tart red-fruit and turned earth flavors are framed by a clay-like texture on the palate.
Wine: Lucas & Lewellen 2016 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The pine-forest aromas are strong in this bottling, with some blackberry, tobacco and eucalyptus also at play on the nose. Cedary, cigar-box flavors consume the palate, along with touches of blackberry and peppercorn.
Wine: Martin Ranch 2014 Therese Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Candied blackberry, tangy black plum and cedar show on the nose of this single-variety Petit Verdot, which is a slowly growing category. Robust black-currant and violet flavors are juicy if somewhat simple on the palate.
Wine: Midnight 2014 Synnove Petit Verdot (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Clements Hills, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This is a very good, easy-drinking wine that smells and tastes generously fruity. It has a smooth and lightly tannic texture that will help it pair well with food. Graciano grapes made 74% of the blend, followed by Tempranillo, Grenache and Zinfandel in descending proportions.
Wine: Riaza 2014 Diablo Rojo Red (Clements Hills)

Appellation: Lake Chelan, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas leap out of the glass, displaying notes of slightly wilted white flower, ginger, mandarin orange zest and spice. This is a hair off-dry, with plenty to like.
Wine: Rocky Pond 2017 Clos CheValle Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Lake Chelan)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aromas of extracted kirsch and loamy soils show on the nose of this rich bottling. Ripe cherry, oak and nutmeg aromas are evident on the palate.
Wine: Sarah's Vineyard 2016 Estate Pinot Noir (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Sean Minor
Review: This is a smoky oaky wine with a touch of reduction that opens into a juicy approachable world of soft rich blueberry and plum. It offers good value with a light-bodied approach to ripeness.
Wine: Sean Minor 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine opens in floral element of rose before unleashing smoky edges and a leathery texture. Inside its full-bodied concentration lies earthy oak and black-cherry vanilla.
Wine: Sonoma-Loeb 2016 Sangiacomo Vineyard Fedrick Ranch Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: There's no mistaking the variety, with its aromas of fresh herb, black cherry, dark fruit and baking spice. Ripe fruit flavors follow, threaded with green herb notes throughout. Firm tannins provide support. The concentration isn't always there but what is is quite nice.
Wine: Structure 2016 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark blackberry juice, wood spice, charred beef and tar aromas show on the nose of this clonal expression, which remains quite young and tight. Stiff tannins and sharp acidity carry flavors of roasted meat in elderberry reduction sauce.
Wine: Zaca Mesa 2015 Estrella Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Streaks of grass and flowers mix with a candied ginger and citrus core in this single-vineyard wine. Semidry in style, the light-bodied palate is shot through with flavors of sweet-tart candy and green apple.
Wine: Bellangelo 2017 Gibson Vineyard Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: Soft and thick, this blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot has a wealth of raspberry, chocolate and clove flavor. The secondary characteristics dip into cedar, tobacco and black pepper, the finish starting to fade.
Wine: Bravante 2013 Estate Reserve Red (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is half Grenache, with the rest equal parts Mourvèdre and Cabernet Sauvignon, all aged in neutral oak. The aromas are generous, with notes of plum, freshly peeled orange, tar, black pepper and spice. Juicy, ripe, fresh fruit flavors follow, tapering ever so slightly toward the finish. There's a lot to like.
Wine: Brook & Bull 2016 Come Hell or High Water Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Bright blueberry, plum and cherry aromas open this affordable red, which is soft and supple in approachability. Clove and a touch of mocha round out the light-bodied experience.
Wine: Ca' Momi 2016 Heartcraft Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Castle Rock
Review: Ripe orchard fruit, apple blossoms and warm melon flesh show on the nose of this widely available bottling. Rounded flavors of lemon cream and salted cashew show on the palate, where acidity is prime.
Wine: Castle Rock 2017 Chardonnay (Central Coast)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a 50-50 blend of Grenache Blanc and Viognier, made in a lighthearted light-bodied style. A floral earthy nose of jasmine opens the wine, before fleshy aspects of nectarine and dried apricot figure onto the palate, boosted by uplifted acidity.
Wine: Domenica Amato 2017 Gusto Bianco White (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very floral aromas of honeysuckle, apple cream and tuberose show on the nose of this bottling from the Gallo-owned winery. There is also intense florality on the sip, where honeysuckle cream flavors meet with a chalky mouthfeel.
Wine: Edna Valley Vineyard 2017 Fleur de Edna Winemaker Series Chardonnay (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Encanto
Review: Thick and syrupy, this wine offers a wealth of tannic density and ripeness. Black cherry and cola dominate around a support of toasted oak.
Wine: Encanto 2014 Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Sourced from the Les Gosses Vineyard, this wine offers aromas of blackberry, fruit leather, vanilla, Band-Aid and spice. The palate is light in feel, with a reserved approach.
Wine: Hedges 2014 Descendants Liégeois Dupont Estate Grown and Bottled Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Reduced and meaty, this is a richly built, robust and earthy wine, with grabby tannins that grip the palate with force.
Wine: Hendry 2016 Hendry Vineyard Malbec (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark red currant and concentrated rose elements meet with crushed slate and a pinch of herbs on the nose in this bottling from the eastern slope of the appellation. Flavors of pencil shavings, tomato leaf and dried oregano are prominent on the palate, where tart berries and persistent acid round out the experience.
Wine: Left Bend 2015 Raines Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Light in color for the variety and appellation. Faint aromas of dried cherry, café au lait and spice lead to elegant but juicy fruit flavors. The concentration seems light but it still brings a pretty sense of appeal.
Wine: Palencia 2016 El Viñador Syrah (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Weighty tannins and broad flavors of strawberry that take on a jammy quality dominate in this wine, brimming in sweet cherry.
Wine: Roadhouse Winery 2016 Blue Label Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is rich and round in blue fruit, cola and root-beer flavors, the body weight thick and concentrated in full-bodied ripeness. It finishes in toasty oak.
Wine: Roadhouse Winery 2016 Yellow Label Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sculpterra
Review: Vanilla, sweet cherries and intense red currants make for an approachably ripe nose on this bottling. The palate is also quite ripe with boysenberry and extracted cranberry-sauce flavors.
Wine: Sculpterra 2016 Pinot Noir (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling is quite ripe on the nose with yellow-peach and melon aromas, but they are cut by a sharp lemon-spray element. Yellow-pear and poached apple flavors show on the palate, finishing on a touch of marshmallow.
Wine: McClain Cellars 2016 Summer Breeze Grenache Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Brook & Bull
Review: The aromas are quiet on first pour, with notes of apple and pear. A light, somewhat linear palate follows, capped off by a tart finish. It doesn't seem to have fully settled in but has some interesting things going on.
Wine: Brook & Bull 2017 Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Rockpile, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is minty and intense in tannin, which contributes to a grippy texture around its full-bodied weight. A brightness of red currant and cranberry give it a lasting tartness on the finish.
Wine: Carol Shelton 2014 Rockpile Vineyard Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Rockpile)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This limited release is ripened and finished with 14 g/L residual sugar, enough to qualify as off-dry. That said, it's disjointed, with sugary fruit hitting a soft center within a shell of pea vine. The finish conjures up lemon zest, but this wine clearly needs a bit more bottle aging to pull its components together.
Wine: Chehalem 2016 Ridgecrest Vineyards Riesling (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is 58% Cabernet Sauvignon, with the balance 16% Petit Verdot, 15% Merlot and 11% Malbec. Aromas of Fig Newton, mint and dried blackberry are followed by well-balanced dark fruit flavors. The fruit seems a bit dried out but still brings appeal.
Wine: Co Dinn 2015 Elephant Mountain Red (Rattlesnake Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a mild-mannered white, lemony in apple and pear. It has an intensity that finishes dry and oaky with a strong finish of tropical richness.
Wine: Dutton Estate 2016 Kyndall's Reserve Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Erath
Review: This widely available wine opens with a burst of spiced pear. The flavors flatten out on the palate, giving a one-dimensional feel to the wine.
Wine: Erath 2016 Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Garden herb aromas are at the fore, along with mint, cherry, vanilla, green and dried fruit. The blue fruit flavors are lighter styled, painting around the edges, with grainy tannins and light smoky flavors on the lip-smacking finish. It's interesting, but all comes off as a bit green.
Wine: Gård 2015 The Don Lawrence Estate Wines Lawrence Vineyards Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Shy aromas of citrus, yellow apple and crushed stone are an enjoyable start. The palate is broad in feel, boasting more exuberance than the nose suggests, giving way to juicy stone- and tree-fruit flavors before a brisk finish.
Wine: Glenora 2017 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot make up near equal parts of this wine, with a pinch of Petit Verdot. Aromas of blackberry, bittersweet chocolate, flower and spice lead to a medium-bodied palate that houses a dark fruit flavor. The concentration at times seems a bit light, especially for the listed alcohol, which occasionally pokes through.
Wine: Gorman 2016 The Devil You Know Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is mostly Cabernet Sauvignon (80%), with the balance Syrah (15%) and Petit Verdot. Aromas of dried herb, flower and slightly dried out cherry are followed by lighter-styled fruit flavors that have a slightly candied, dried-out note. The concentration doesn't all seem to be there.
Wine: Gorman 2016 Zachary's Ladder Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Hedges
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon makes up the majority of this wine, with the balance Merlot, Syrah and pinches of other varieties. Baking spice, dried cherry, cinnamon, Band-Aid and licorice aromas are out front, with the fruit seeming slightly dried out. There's a nice sense of elegance to the palate, which is full of medicinal flavors.
Wine: Hedges 2014 Red (Red Mountain)

Appellation: High Valley Vineyard
Review: A slight earthy, dusty accent accompanies ripe, raisiny, plummy flavors in this soft-textured and full-bodied wine. It's big, smooth and mouth filling.
Wine: High Valley Vineyard 2016 Zinfandel (High Valley)

Appellation: Jockey Club
Review: This dry wine is medium bodied, seems Rhône-like in its combo of ripe berry and spice flavors but it's made from 75% Zinfandel and 25% Barbera. A broad mouthfilling texture adds to its appeal.
Wine: Jockey Club 2015 Red (Amador County)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Baking spice, black fruit and medicinal aromas are followed by somewhat lighter-styled fruit flavors. Grainy tannins provide support. The concentration seems a bit light.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2016 Red Path Vineyard Merlot (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Murphy-Goode
Review: This is a value red made in a big full-bodied style that's thick, rich and chocolatey. Substantial heat and oak push the fruit forward with no hesitation.
Wine: Murphy-Goode 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This new vintage is soft to the point of being almost soapy in the mouth. It's easy drinking, with simple fruit and barrel flavors of toast and butter.
Wine: Rain Dance 2016 Nicholas Vineyard Chardonnay (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: River's Edge
Review: This was fermented and aged in used oak barrels, counterpointing the ripe tree fruits with hints of toasted coconut. It shows good power and length throughout.
Wine: River's Edge 2017 Pinot Gris (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is 70% Merlot, with the balance equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec, coming from a new growing region referred to as Rocky Reach. Aromas of baking spice, cherry, green pepper, graphite, green herb and whiffs of tire rubber are followed by tart, elegant fruit flavors that pique the interest.
Wine: Rocky Pond 2016 La Domestique Double D Vineyard Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Apricot, herb and a lightly earthy aroma lead to a full-bodied palate with a stone fruit flavor. It doesn't all come off, but it's interesting.
Wine: Structure 2017 Olsen Vineyard Roussanne (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: The Federalist
Review: This wine has classic aromas of apple and butter, then good and ripe fruit flavors accented by vanilla and caramel and surrounded by a rich soft texture.
Wine: The Federalist 2017 Chardonnay (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Villa San Juliette
Review: Very extracted aromas of cassis and burnt caramel show on the nose of this bottling, which is already revealing its age. Plum-pudding flavors meet with a curiously zippy acidity on the palate.
Wine: Villa San Juliette 2014 Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Naches Heights, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of slightly overripe apple, pineapple and pear are followed by sweet, rich, drawn-out fruit flavors. The palate is enjoyable, but the aromas don't entirely sync up.
Wine: Wilridge 2016 Late Harvest Estate Dessert Wine Wilridge Vineyard Pinot Gris (Naches Heights)

Appellation: Burnside Road
Review: This medium- to full-bodied wine has plenty of fruit flavor, light spicy oak accents and an almost silky texture that makes it easy to sip. It's a good choice to please a crowd.
Wine: Burnside Road 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Hills)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Blossomy peach and yellow apple aromas fill the nose. The palate is off-dry in style, delivering juicy stone-fruit and apple flavors that finish balanced yet short.
Wine: Chateau Lafayette Reneau 2017 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Dark Horse
Review: Floral and citrus aromas get this wine off to a start before crisp grapefruit and herb flavors kick in on the palate. It is light in weight and has a fresh, tangy texture, giving it a good, crisp finish.
Wine: Dark Horse 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (California)

Appellation: Del Rio
Review: This new vintage is less ripe than the 2016, and tasted side-by-side with the winery's Rock Point bottling it's almost indistinguishable. It's a simple, easy-drinking example of the variety—fruit-driven with flavors of apple and pear.
Wine: Del Rio 2017 Pinot Gris (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Brawny broad shouldered notions of earthy strawberry, rose petal and Asian baking spice define this medium-bodied wine from an estate-farmed block. It has plenty of tannic power.
Wine: Dutton Estate 2016 Jewell Block Vineyard Dutton Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Vanilla, biscuit, graphite, cherry and spice aromas lead to ripe, extracted cherry flavors. The tannins bring a lightly gritty feel.
Wine: Henry Earl 2015 Homesteader Red (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas show notes of herb, spice, black licorice and cherry. The medium-bodied fruit flavors paint around the edges, with the tannins bringing a lightly chalky feel. It seems a bit overripe, but the concentration is not quite right at the same time.
Wine: Henry Earl 2015 Shaw Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Husch
Review: This is a nervy red wine that packs plenty of ripe fruit onto a taut frame of firm tannins and acidity. It has impressive grip on the palate, good cherry and cranberry flavors and a tannic finish.
Wine: Husch 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Mendocino)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: This is an attractive hearty dry wine with tasty blackberry and black-cherry flavors, and a firm layer of tannins to give it grip. Based on 53% Syrah, it should be good to pair with bold meat or pasta dishes.
Wine: Jigar 2014 Raja Cuvée Red (North Coast)

Appellation: Line 39
Review: This full-bodied wine has an earthy savory slant and good appley flavors as a base. Aromas of mineral water and broth give way to rich-tasting fruit flavors and a rounded texture.
Wine: Line 39 2017 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Rancho Sisquoc
Review: There's a very strong woody element to the nose of this bottling, starting with cedar and grainy oak, as well as blackberry. The wood spice shows strong on the palate too, along with berry and caramel flavors.
Wine: Rancho Sisquoc 2016 Merlot (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: A soft entry leads a midpalate that's fully ripe and fleshy. Moderate tannins lend support to fruity notes of blueberry and black cherry dipped in dark chocolate.
Wine: Raymond 2014 Signature Collection Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Honeysuckle and pear-flesh aromas make for a slightly sweet aromatic entry to this bottling. The palate dries up with chalk and lime-rind flavors before ripe melon touches take over.
Wine: SeaGlass 2017 Unoaked Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sebastiani
Review: This wine is overtly oaky in aroma and flavor and quite tannic to boot. Yet it has a sense of concentration and creaminess on the midpalate that redeems it for those who like their Zins brawny.
Wine: Sebastiani 2016 Zinfandel (North Coast)

Appellation: Sequoia Grove
Review: Jammy blueberry and cherry contrast against substantial smoky oak and leather in this medium-bodied smoothly rounded red. The tannin weight makes it seem heavier than it is.
Wine: Sequoia Grove 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Shooting Star
Review: This gentle medium-bodied wine is smooth, almost soft in texture. It offers red-fruit aromas and warm plummy flavors. It is engaging and easy to appreciate.
Wine: Shooting Star 2016 Pinot Noir (Lake County)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Light-bodied in approach, this is bright in black-cherry and strawberry flavors with a twist of orange helping to lift the acidity. A touch of cola spice softens the substantial tannin and toasted oak.
Wine: Steele 2016 Sangiacomo Vineyard Green Acres Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Vino La Monarcha
Review: The aromas are light and hard to tease out, with whiffs of herb and spice. The flavors are light but juicy and ripe, painting around the edges with firm tannins in the middle. Give it time to open.
Wine: Vino La Monarcha 2015 Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of two-thirds Cabernet Sauvignon and one-third Syrah. The aromas bring notes of cherry, raspberry, herb, café au lait and pencil eraser. The medium-bodied fruit flavors are fresh and focused, with gritty tannins backing them up.
Wine: Vital 2016 The Given Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Volunteer
Review: Creamy, round and lush in strong flavors of vanilla, baked apple and pear, this white is powerfully tannic and grippy as it finishes.
Wine: Volunteer 2016 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Barnard Griffin
Review: Aromas of chamomile, cut lime and white flower lead to lightly spritzy, off-dry fruit flavors. It's straight down the fairway.
Wine: Barnard Griffin 2017 Riesling (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Cedar + Salmon
Review: An easy-drinking wine in a lightly fruity style, this pushes no boundaries, but delivers clean flavors of apple and peach. Taste carefully and you may detect a streak of lemon custard sneaking through the finish.
Wine: Cedar + Salmon 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Del Rio
Review: Just ripe enough, this simple, straightforward example of a fruit-driven Chardonnay shows a clean apple flavor and an interesting hint of banana. Drink over the next couple of years.
Wine: Del Rio 2017 Chardonnay (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Sanguine in red currant although accented a light seasoning of black pepper and clove, this wine is on the lighter side of ripeness and imparts a delicacy that appeals, but leaves the fruit subdued.
Wine: Domenica Amato 2016 Cherry Camp Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Concentrated aromas of black currant, blackberry syrup, licorice and dried herbs show on the nose of this blend of Sangiovese, Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah. There is a zip to the sip and a flash of minerality, but the extracted and thick dark-fruit flavors and searing acidity dominate the experience.
Wine: Figge 2014 Vaquero Red (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Initially closed on the nose, after a few swirls in the glass this wine reveals aromas of thyme, citrus and crushed stone. The light-bodied palate offers flavors of ripe yellow apple and tangerine, with a soft peach note lingering on the finish.
Wine: Heron Hill 2017 Ingle Vineyard Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine is heavy-handed with the oak, showing bold wood char and smoke aromas followed by smoky, black-peppery flavors that dominate the blackberry and cherry notes underneath. Firm tannins give a good tight mouthfeel.
Wine: Lewis Grace 2014 Estate Tempranillo (El Dorado)

Appellation: Mercer
Review: The aromas offer notes of baking spice, plum and blue fruit. Plump feeling but quite light. Grainy-feeling black currant and plum flavors follow. The concentration seems very light.
Wine: Mercer 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This is a medium-weight wine that balances subtle floral and orange-zest characters against suggestions of vanilla and butter that build on the palate and add richness on the finish.
Wine: Oak Grove 2017 Family Reserve Viognier (California)

Appellation: Rainstorm
Review: Made by Pacific Rim (now owned by Banfi), this is a serviceable white wine. It's varietally true, displaying tones of crisp apple and pear that finish balanced and clean.
Wine: Rainstorm 2017 Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Rock Point
Review: Pleasantly fruity, with standard apple and pear flavors, this has not achieved the ripeness of past vintages, and it thins out quickly in the finish. That said, it would be fine with unfussy preparations of seafood and poultry.
Wine: Rock Point 2017 Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 45% Grenache, 36% Syrah and 19% Mourvèdre. Aromas of freshly squeezed Mandarin orange, raspberry, black pepper and plum lead to light, juicy, fresh fruit flavors on the palate, with the tannins bringing a slightly scraping feel. Mouthwatering acidity and a light smoky note linger in the background. It brings a pleasing sense of delicacy.
Wine: Rocky Pond 2016 Stratastone Double D Vineyard Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This big, rigidly structured wine is full in body, firm with tannins, and shows blunt-edged blackberry flavors that are tightly wrapped by the texture.
Wine: Sobon Estate 2016 ReZerve Petite Sirah (Amador County)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Tangy and tart in acidity and jolts of forest floor, this wine shows a generosity of body, richness and oak, while remaining reserved in fruit.
Wine: WindVane 2015 Reserve Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This dessert wine is quite sweet, with candied flavors of peach, apricot and papaya. It shows a decent balance between concentrated fruit tones and bright acidity.
Wine: Apolloni 2014 Dolce Vino Viognier (Oregon)

Appellation: Barnard Griffin
Review: The aromas pop, with notes of orange peel, apple, tropical fruit and peach. Plentiful stone fruit and kiwi flavors follow. It delivers a lot of appeal.
Wine: Barnard Griffin 2017 Pinot Gris (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas come out of the gate lightly reduced, followed by notes of graphite, blackberry jam, plum and spice. The palate brings a pretty sense of styling, with the concentration light in the middle, but otherwise delivering a sense of appeal.
Wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2016 Indian Wells Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: As before, this was fermented in concrete (dolia is the plural of dolium, a large earthenware vessel used in ancient Rome), but somehow this time the wine has been flattened out. There's a flinty character, and skin flavors more than the flesh of the fruit.
Wine: Keeler 2017 Concrete Dolia Pinot Gris (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Subdued tones of stone fruit and lemon zest carry the nose and palate. While labeled dry, this is slightly off dry in feel, yet it ends crisp and clean come the finish.
Wine: Knapp 2017 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Palencia
Review: Raspberry and plum jam, black pepper, cigar ash and cherry gummy aromas lead to ripe, but lightly concentrated fruit flavors. The intensity isn't all there, but there is still a lot to like.
Wine: Palencia 2016 Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Tightly tannic and youthfully robust, this is full bodied, highly ripe and brimming in red and blue fruit. A velvety texture is accented in black tea and forest notes, leading to a mild finish.
Wine: Peter Paul Wines 2016 Live Free or Die Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This fresh and jammy-tasting wine shows generous red-cherry and strawberry flavors and a soft, non-tannic texture. It's relatively light in mouthfeel, but technically full bodied considering its ripeness.
Wine: Precision Wine 2016 The Xtrovert Zinfandel (Lodi)

Appellation: Unparalleled
Review: Crushed rock aromas meet with charred wood, vibrant blackberry and black pepper spice on the nose of this bottling. The tannins are rigid on the palate, where dried herbs, more peppercorn and light black-plum flavors arise.
Wine: Unparalleled 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Central Coast)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made in the classic Champagne method, this young, racy bubbly is a 50/50 blend of Pinot Blanc and Pinot Noir. It's tart and tangy, with flavors principally of grapefruit and lemon.
Wine: Winter's Hill 2016 Ninebark Sparkling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Vanilla aromas are out front on first pour, along with notes of baking spice and cream, with the wood seeming prominent. Somewhat-lighter-styled stone fruit flavors follow, with the flavors focused around the middle.
Wine: Chateau Ste. Michelle 2016 Canoe Ridge Chardonnay (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This new release is still a bit tight, so give it a chance to breathe. It's herbal and lightly peppery, as befits this variety. Highlights of lemon zest frame crisp yellow fruits, and the alcohol barely crosses 12%.
Wine: Chehalem 2017 Ridgecrest Vineyards Grüner Veltliner (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A pale copper color, this offers full-bodied, roundly fruity flavors of peach and pear. There's a suggestion of overripe fruit as the wine finishes, with flavors already past optimal freshness. Drink up.
Wine: Cubanisimo Vineyards 2017 Rosado de Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a thick full-bodied white with structured tangy acidity that tries to keep up with the oak. A nutty profile defines its flavor. The palate is viscous and lush.
Wine: Dutton Estate 2016 Dutton Palms Vineyard Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Ferguson Crest
Review: Relatively light in body, this bottling offers pomegranate and asphalt on the fresh but simple nose. Plum and dried herbs make for an almost Pinot Noir-like experience on the sip, which is easy to enjoy.
Wine: Ferguson Crest 2016 Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This wine is plenty oaky but backs it up with nice rich and ripe fruit flavors too. A deep color leads to aromas of wood char and baking spices. Blackberry jam and blueberry flavors seem to fill the mouth and light tannins add some good structure.
Wine: Leese-Fitch 2016 Firehouse Red (California)

Appellation: Mokelumne River, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine has plenty of ripe fruit character, and moderate tannins in the texture. Light smoky earthy accents follow good raspberry and blackberry flavors.
Wine: Riaza 2014 Old Soul Carignane (Mokelumne River)

Appellation: Ruby
Review: Though the initial entry is soft, the wine quickly stiffens up with sharp fruit flavors emphasizing green apple. It remains tight through the finish, with crisp acidity. It's a pleasant wine that seems to be still pulling itself together.
Wine: Ruby 2016 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from Destiny Ridge, Upland, Stillwater Creek and Red Willow vineyards. Seeing no new oak, the aromas bring notes of green herb, orange rind, dark fruit, flower and spice. The palate is ripe and juicy feeling, with the concentration light. The tannins seem somewhat bunched up.
Wine: Structure 2016 Foundation Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is 100% varietal and was aged in 43% new French oak. Baking spice, graphite, green pepper and black fruit aromas are at the fore. Ripe but light fruit flavors follow on the well-balanced palate.
Wine: Structure 2016 Foundation Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: A blend of fruit from Olsen (60%) and Boushey vineyards. Spice, dark plum and cherry aromas are followed by ripe, saturated fruit flavors, with the oak (all second fill) pulled back. A cranberry-filled finish follows. It shows a pleasing sense of purity, though the concentration is light.
Wine: Structure 2016 Spire Merlot (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: Spicy and smooth, this full-bodied blend based around Merlot and Zinfandel shows ample oak influence and good ripe raspberry and cherry flavors. Notes of brown sugar and maple provide a hint of bourbon in the aroma and lead to nice fruit on the palate.
Wine: The Federalist 2016 Honest Red (North Coast)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine is mild and mellow, on the light side in terms of body, and shows warm plum and sandalwood flavors that offer some maturity and complexity. It's very smooth and has just a touch of light tannins.
Wine: Via Romano 2014 Tuscan Style Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Axios
Review: Big black fruit and cedar wrap around a stock of toasted oak and tannin in this integrated wine that is in decline.
Wine: Axios 2012 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Brook & Bull
Review: Starting out slightly reduced, aromas of plum, cedar, spice box, tobacco and orange peel are followed by medium-bodied plum flavors. There are some interesting things going on, but they don't all come together.
Wine: Brook & Bull 2016 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Brook & Bull
Review: The aromas are brooding, with notes of toast, flower, soil, citrus, hay and coffee. The palate is fresh and acid driven, with lighter-styled fruit flavors backed by firm tannins. It doesn't stand up on its own but still provides interest.
Wine: Brook & Bull 2016 Petit Verdot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an oily viscous white, nutty with floral elements of jasmine and rose. A dense dry texture rides below lemon verbena and stone-fruit flavors.
Wine: Domenica Amato 2017 Salomon Vineyard Viognier (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Honey and graham cracker are the richer elements of this otherwise bold, ripe and concentrated white, which has a hearty helping of oak and Gravenstein apple.
Wine: Dutton Estate 2016 Warren's Collection Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Golden
Review: Cranberry and grape-seed aromas meet with wet wood and anise on the nose of this bottling. The acidity is extremely aggressive on the palate, where cranberry-orange juice flavors arise.
Wine: Golden 2017 Pinot Noir (Monterey County)

Appellation: Grochau
Review: This Oregon take on a French Muscadet is sharply herbal, with a mix of cucumber, tomatillo and gooseberry flavors. It was aged in a mix of acacia, stainless steel, neutral oak and cement; this last vessel seems to dominate the texture, although the overall effect is to flatten out the flavors and dull the finish.
Wine: Grochau 2016 Melon de Bourgogne (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Havens
Review: This wine holds back on its aromatics, but not on its generous grip of oak and tannin. The flavors lean into dried cherry, cassis and mint.
Wine: Havens 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very ripe, vaguely plummy and full bodied, this wine tastes rich and feels soft, almost syrupy, on the tongue. It has light tannins and elevated alcohol, which combine for a fat mouthfeel and finish.
Wine: Kreck 2016 Del Barba Old Vine Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Owl Ridge
Review: Sanguine in red currant and tangy acidity, this wine is robust in tannin with a finish of mint.
Wine: Owl Ridge 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Pendulum
Review: This wine is mostly Merlot, with the rest Syrah and Malbec. Plum, tar, herb, tire rubber, smoked meat and spice aromas are followed by lightly sweet coffee and cocoa flavors that persist through the finish.
Wine: Pendulum 2016 Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a thick densely concentrated red, ripely driven by tannin and oak, with an elusive underbelly of red fruit.
Wine: Peter Paul Wines 2016 Mille Frere Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Monterey-Sonoma-San Benito, California Other, California, US
Review: Ripe and baked red-fruit aromas meet with rust and baking spice on the very extracted nose of this bottling. The palate is very ripe with baked red fruit and nutmeg spice.
Wine: Reata 2016 Three County Pinot Noir (Monterey-Sonoma-San Benito)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine has an intensity of heat and bold flavor, a mix of baked apple and honey that's both rich and complementary.
Wine: Replica 2016 Sempre e Per Sempre Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine smells mellow and mature, tastes leathery and spicy and has a smooth lightly textured mouthfeel. It will be good for everyday occasions. Best to drink it soon.
Wine: Riaza 2014 Outsider 2.0 Tempranillo (California)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Jammy, thick and sweetly viscous, this wine is smoothly layered in dense black cherry with secondary elements of smoky oak and black tea.
Wine: Roadhouse Winery 2016 Pink Label Leras Martini Clone Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Fruit for this wine hails from a new growing region near Lake Chelan referred to as Rocky Reach. The aromas offer notes of raspberry, pencil eraser, fresh tobacco, herb, strawberry and cherry gummy bear. The palate is elegant, with the concentration seeming a bit light. Tart acidity provides the frame. It's interesting but doesn't all come off.
Wine: Rocky Pond 2016 Double D Vineyard Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Rombauer
Review: Thickly built, spritzy in acidity and brightly citrus-driven in lemon zest, grapefruit and apricot, this is the fourth vintage of this wine from the longtime Napa Valley producer. It delivers flavor and texture within integrated oak, within which just a portion is fermented.
Wine: Rombauer 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sera Fina
Review: Nicely crisp and dry, this medium-bodied wine smells floral and tastes a bit leesy like it just came out of a barrel. It has tangy lemon and green-apple flavors.
Wine: Sera Fina 2017 Viognier (Amador County)

Appellation: Bookshelf
Review: This is a good middle-of-the-road wine, with fairly rich fruit flavors and a pleasant broad texture. Mild plum and strawberry notes and soft tannins add to the wine's mellow appeal.
Wine: Bookshelf 2016 Zinfandel (El Dorado)

Appellation: Carpe Diem
Review: This full-bodied wine is smooth in texture and plummy in flavor, offering wet earth and farmyard aromas to start off with, followed by baked black-cherry flavors. The funky earthy character persists through the finish.
Wine: Carpe Diem 2015 Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: CULT
Review: This is a spicy, full-bodied wine that lets oakiness overlay good ripe fruit flavors and has a nice, firm texture. It has maple and brown-sugar aromas and tasty blackberry flavors.
Wine: CULT 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a soft, simple wine, with lightly spicy melon fruit. Not much else to note, other than a slight soapiness to the mouthfeel, suggesting high pH and a shortened lifespan. Drink up.
Wine: R. Stuart & Co. 2016 Love, Oregon Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Previously named the Nicholas Vineyard, this seems to lack the ripeness of the previous vintage. Rather thin, tart flavors of apple and pear convey an impression of being just a bit underripe. Drink this with foods that favor a high-acid style.
Wine: Rain Dance 2017 Grand Oak Vineyard Riesling (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: There is no indication as to what sort of rosé this might be (last year's was all Pinot Noir). It's softly fruity, with peach and lemon flavors. Ample acidity keeps it lively. Drink up.
Wine: Rainstorm 2017 Silver Linings Rosé (Oregon)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Full bodied and jammy tasting, this wine also has a layer of astringency—possibly from the bourbon barrels—so it comes off more dry and puckery than many others. Raspberry and red cherry combine with floral and mineral accents.
Wine: The Federalist 2016 Bourbon Barrel Aged Zinfandel (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Vital
Review: The aromas are reticent, with notes of graphite, vanilla, raspberry jam and cherry, with the oak out front. Dark fruit flavors follow, with the oak taking over the show.
Wine: Vital 2015 Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: The bourbon barrel-aged trend is a weird twist in fine wine circles, and this boozy bottling won't convince many connoisseurs otherwise. Sour black-plum and burned caramel aromas lead into a slightly sweet palate with ripe red fruit and vanilla spice throughout.
Wine: Wilson Creek 2016 Bourbon Barrel Aged Zinfandel (California)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Touches of wet earth and farmyard in the aroma don't keep this medium-bodied wine from being enjoyable, but they do add a funky accent to the ripe red-berry character. A smooth and mouthfilling texture makes it very easy to sip.
Wine: Block Nine 2017 Caiden's Vineyards Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: While heady and ripe on the nose in aromas of mango, passion fruit and tangerine, the palate is substantially less intense, creating a bit of a disconnect. Overall, it shows good structure on the palate, ending short but clean.
Wine: Buttonwood Grove 2017 Riemer Block Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Castle Rock
Review: This oaky wine starts with spicy, earthy and wood-smoke aromas followed by decent plummy flavors that are also accented by spicy oak notes. It has a full body and a mouthfilling texture.
Wine: Castle Rock 2017 Pinot Noir (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Crush 8
Review: This jammy-tasting wine is very ripe, very smooth, full bodied and almost syrupy in texture. It tastes pruney and raisiny and leaves a sweet impression on the finish.
Wine: Crush 8 2017 Zinfandel (California)

Appellation: Figge
Review: Sour lemon rinds and strong papaya aromas show on the nose of this bottling. There is a sharp, citrus-driven acidity to the palate, with slightly harsh lemon-rind and melon-scrap flavors.
Wine: Figge 2016 Grenache Blanc (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Figge
Review: Black-plum paste and concentrated lilacs show on the nose of the bottling. The palate is quite sour and tangy with plum-skin flavors.
Wine: Figge 2016 Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Barrel aromas are out front, with notes of baking spice and vanilla extract followed by cumin, dried parsley and medicine cabinet. Dried black cherry flavors follow with grainy tannins for support.
Wine: Henry Earl 2015 Quintessence Vineyard Malbec (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 34% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Merlot, 25% Cabernet Franc, 10% Malbec and 6% Petit Verdot from Scooteney Flats and Redpath vineyards. Elusive aromas of cherry, licorice, vanilla and celery stalk are followed by ripe fruit flavors that are focused in the middle but seem missing on the edges. The tannins come off as quite gruff.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2016 Bud Burst Reserve Red (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine starts delicately in a light-bodied fashion, bearing blue and red berry fruit that presents as bright. There's a hint of vanilla that sparks on the finish.
Wine: MacRostie 2016 Cummings Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This bears little resemblance to previous versions; though listed as a dessert wine, it is only passingly sweet. Perhaps orange wine is a better description, with some 21 grapes in the blend, principally various Muscat clones. It's an odd mix of grainy sugar and astringent phenolics, and will not readily accompany any desserts with the possible exception of bitter chocolate.
Wine: Maragas 2016 Tootsie White (Oregon)

Appellation: Maryhill
Review: Graphite, exotic spice, herb, vanilla and plum aromas lead to light but well-balanced fruit and herb flavors that persist through the coffee-filled finish.
Wine: Maryhill 2016 Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Peju
Review: A broad, concentrated and 100% varietal wine, this is smoky in meat and blackberry jam, its tannic weight substantial and grippy.
Wine: Peju 2015 Merlot (Napa Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This is a soft, lightly sweet wine with delicate peach and honeysuckle flavors. It's very smooth and creamy in mouthfeel.
Wine: Reata 2017 Aurelius White (California)

Appellation: Sweet Heart
Review: With a closed-in aroma and being almost monolithic on the palate, this wine is full-bodied, moderately tannic and subtle in flavor. Touches of wood char and black pepper in the aroma meet mild blackberry on the palate.
Wine: Sweet Heart 2015 Tempranillo (Yolo County)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This roughly equal, co-fermented mix of Marsanne and Viognier is finished dry, though doesn't quite touch just 12% alcohol. Unsurprisingly, it feels thin and watery, with light flavors of melon and kiwi. Best tasted as a springtime aperitif.
Wine: Troon 2017 Kubli Blench Blanc Marsanne-Viognier (Applegate Valley)

Appellation: Twisted Cedar
Review: This medium-bodied wine from a native American-owned winery has a sweet maple aroma, and flavors that are very fruity as well as quite oaky. It is well-saturated in terms of color and has smooth tannins for a pleasant mouthfeel.
Wine: Twisted Cedar 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Apolloni produces both a Pinot Gris and a Pinot Grigio. While made of the same grape, they are produced in a different style. This one is done in all stainless, though the differences between the two styles seem to center more on ripeness than on vessel. A light tree-fruit tone shows on the nose and palate, giving this a pleasant, simple nature.
Wine: Apolloni 2017 Estate Pinot Grigio (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Crosby Roamann
Review: This is a big effusive white, intensely full bodied and ripe in floral, earthy matchstick and pineapple. It finishes in a voluptuous embrace of crème brûlée.
Wine: Crosby Roamann 2015 Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: With all of the fruit coming from Cockburn Ranch Vineyard, the aromas offer raspberry jam, crushed nut and spice along with what appears to be a light oxidative note. Jammy but still elegant fruit flavors follow.
Wine: Eternal 2016 Optimism G-S-M (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Grochau
Review: Simple, light flavors of bruised apples are complemented with a hint of toasted nuts. Just 8% was aged in new oak. This wine should be consumed over the next year or so.
Wine: Grochau 2015 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A quiet nose of both brined and ripe apples starts this off. The slightly off-dry palate turns more fresh, delivering a juicy tree-fruit flavor that's balanced by cleansing citrus acidity. The finish is short but clean.
Wine: Lakewood 2017 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Made as an orange wine, this offers aromas of floral soap, lychee and spice. The palate is bone dry, with a bitter note on the finish.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2017 Ranch at the End of the Road Gewürztraminer (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of baking spice, braised bell pepper, jalapeño, graphite, green herb and cherry lead to somewhat lighter-styled fruit flavors that paint around the edges, tapering toward the finish.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Elephant Mountain Vineyards Carmenère (Rattlesnake Hills)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Dried blackberry, cherry candy, wood spice and licorice aromas are followed by high octane fruit flavors with coffee notes on the finish. It comes off as quite hot.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 McKinley Springs Vineyard Cinsault (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine is brimming in apple and lemon crispness, with a dryness on the palate that detracts from its time in bottle.
Wine: Mumm Napa 2013 Reserve Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Interesting aromas of tamarind and cedar get this wine off to a complex start, while spicy savory cooked-fruit flavors give it an unusual but enjoyable character.
Wine: Sweet Heart 2015 Courtship Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas start out fruit forward, with notes of raspberry, rose hips, peppermint and cherry along with barrel spices that become more prominent over time. Light but juicy flavors follow, displaying cranberry-like tartness and a pleasing sense of acidity. It doesn't quite stand up on its own but should show well at the dinner table.
Wine: Wilridge 2016 Ribbon Ridge Barbera (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a thick leathery blend of Cabernet Franc and Merlot, with moderate acidity and a depth of chocolate, mocha and black-cherry flavors.
Wine: Wine Spots 2014 Cuvée 38 Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's nothing wrong with this 100% stainless steel Chardonnay, but there's nothing at all distinctive or particularly interesting here. This is a grape that can easily become generic, with a simple apple fruit flavor, here framed in light skin flavors.
Wine: Apolloni 2017 Estate Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Austerity
Review: Honey-laced red cherries, spice-cake, molasses and cola aromas show on the nose of this widely available bottling. It's a bit sweet and simple on the palate, with cherry-brioche flavors.
Wine: Austerity 2017 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: Tart high-strung acidity meets generous tannins in this plummy full-bodied wine, robustly rich in red currant and cherry.
Wine: Bravante 2013 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Though this was made in the méthode Champenoise, it's a foamy devil, seemingly bottled at unusually high pressure. Those bubbles cover up much of the subtlety from a cuvée that is principally (possibly entirely) Pinot Noir-based. Cherry candy fruit flavors are here, but the bubbles override everything.
Wine: Château Bianca 2016 Wetzel Estate Sparkling Wine Sparkling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine boasts jammy aromas, seemingly sweet flavors of strawberry and red cherry and a rather soft, lazy texture.
Wine: Criss Cross 2016 Old Vine Estate Zinfandel (Lodi)

Appellation: Henry Earl
Review: Aromas of green herb, graphite, underripe cherry and baking spice are followed by ripe, dried-out, seemingly high octane fruit flavors backed by gritty tannins. It's a strange mixture of overripe and underripe.
Wine: Henry Earl 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: The aromas are quite light, with notes of herb and apple. Lightly styled guava flavors follow. It comes off as a bit faint, but the palate provides some interest.
Wine: Marion-Field 2017 The Marion Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
Review: Vanilla oak and cola flavors are given additional richness by way of jammy blueberry fruit and toast. The structure is muddled and fleshy.
Wine: Materra Cunat Family Vineyards 2015 After Midnight Malbec (Oak Knoll District)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has a nice layering of white peach and pea shoot and retains a light-hearted texture and body weight on the palate. It finishes grainy with a nutty element.
Wine: Quivira 2017 Alder Grove Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from Stillwater Creek and Wallula Vineyards. The nose offers aromas of orange peel, green pepper and cherry. On the palate, the concentration comes off as quite light, although what's there is pretty.
Wine: Structure 2016 Craftsman Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aged in neutral oak, this is mostly Olsen (82%) fruit with the balance Upland. The aromas pop, with notes of freshly peeled tangerine, citrus, black pepper and plum. Light fruit flavors follow. It's interesting, but the concentration isn't all there. Put it on the dinner table to see it at its best.
Wine: Structure 2016 Foundation Malbec (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Twisted Cedar
Review: This is a well-made moderately flavorful wine that captures the varietal's apple and butter character along with decent balance and a smooth texture.
Wine: Twisted Cedar 2016 Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Vino La Monarcha
Review: The aromas are perfumed, with notes of dried orange peel, violet, plum and raspberry. The raspberry and orange flavors are light, with a chalky feel. It piques the interest, though not fully delivering.
Wine: Vino La Monarcha 2016 Malbec (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Warr-King
Review: Blackberry, black cherry, herb and volatile aromas are at the fore. The flavors come off as light for the listed alcohol level, trailing toward the warm finish.
Wine: Warr-King 2014 Merlot (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Black Ink
Review: A touch of sweetness softens this fruity and herbaceous medium-bodied wine. It has strawberry aromas, a veggie note in the flavors and very little tannin in the texture.
Wine: Black Ink 2016 Red (California)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon makes up just over three-quarters of this wine, with the rest Merlot and Syrah. Whole green and jalapeño pepper aromas are out front, followed by a light smoky note and blackberry. The palate shows the same, with the flavors coming off as extremely light.
Wine: Hedges 2016 The Bourgeoisie Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Smoky oak and a dip of char dominate the palate of this wine, which offers subtle, crunchy red fruit and a touch of dried herb.
Wine: Karah Estate 2016 Estate Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: All coming from Gunkel Vineyards, this wine is a blend of Tinta Cao, Tempranillo, Saousa and Touriga Nacional. Extremely quiet aromas are followed by ripe, slightly hot-seeming fruit flavors. One wants more aromatically, but the palate provides appeal.
Wine: Maryhill 2014 Vintage Port Proprietor's Reserve Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Peter Paul Wines
Review: This wine is brawny and shy in fruit, exhibiting a touch of red cherry in the background. Sticky tannins make themselves felt, dotted in leather and clove.
Wine: Peter Paul Wines 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Lighter-styled aromas of herb and flower are followed by medium-sweet fruit flavors, with wilted flower notes on the finish. There's not enough acid to balance the sugar.
Wine: Wilridge 2017 Broetje Vineyard Viognier (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Ca' Momi
Review: Leathery and tobacco dominate in this wine, which is marked by a robust aspect of oak and mild structure.
Wine: Ca' Momi 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: High-toned aromas of dark cherry and black licorice lead to black fruit flavors that are centered around the middle, seeming to be missing on the edges. The variety seems hard to find, and the volatiles a bit amped up.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2016 Scooteney Flats Vineyard Malbec (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This is a blend of numerous disparate white varieties, but principally Muscat. The result is a generic white wine with jumbled tree fruit flavors and a hint of caramel. It finishes with a burst of alcoholic burn.
Wine: Maragas 2016 Bianco White (Oregon)

Appellation: Mokelumne River, Central Valley, California, US
Review: An earthy meaty element goes along with very ripe grapey raisiny fruit flavors in this full-bodied wine. It is ripe enough to seem slightly sweet and sugary, and has light tannins for a smooth texture.
Wine: Riaza 2015 Standard Zinfandel (Mokelumne River)

Appellation: Schmidt
Review: Dry Riesling rarely if ever reaches such stratospheric alcohol levels, and here it burns away all aromatics, details and typicity. Basically it tastes like bone-dry apple cider.
Wine: Schmidt 2017 Riesling (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: With additions of 12% Malbec, 7% Cabernet Franc and 6% Petit Verdot, this red is spicy and full of heat, with an astringent note of dried herb. The tannins are substantial and fruit dull.
Wine: Spann Vineyards 2014 Mayacamas Range Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Twisted Cedar
Review: This dessert-style wine smells sweet and tastes sweeter. It has abundant floral nutty honeyed flavors, a soft texture and low acidity.
Wine: Twisted Cedar 2017 Moscato (Clarksburg)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is equal parts Malbec and Syrah. The aromas are light, with notes of black currant, smoke, citrus twist and cherry, showing a bit of reduction and not seeming entirely harmonious out of the gate. Plummy, tangy, citrusy flavors follow, with a grainy feel to the tannins. It's an unusual offering.
Wine: Vital 2016 Gratitude Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 80% Syrah, 15% Grenache and 5% Mourvèdre. Aromas of Band-Aid, licorice, flower, herb and cherry are followed by lighter-styled tangerine and dried cherry flavors. It finishes quite warm.
Wine: Gorman 2016 The Devil You Don't Know Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Rattlesnake Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 54% Cinsault and 46% Counoise. It's very light in color, looking like a Pinot Noir. Cherry gummy, pencil eraser and spice aromas lead to faint fruit flavors that trail on the coffee-filled finish. It doesn't seem all there.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Indira Elephant Mountain Red (Rattlesnake Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Extracted black-currant, grape-seed and licorice aromas show on the nose of this table wine. It's quite thick and nearly sweet on the palate with blackberry-sauce flavors.
Wine: Midnight 2014 Full Moon Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Half made of Merlot, the other half a mix of Cabernet Franc, Petit Verdot and Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a thick wine with mild structure, tasting of leather, tobacco and dark cherry. The finish is diluted and the nose slightly sweet.
Wine: Stonehedge 2015 Grand Reserve Meritage (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This fleshy medium-bodied red from the Westside Road site tastes of cherry liqueur, cassis, stemmy black tea and forest floor. This is a pretty wine that's also powerful, with undeniable balance.
Wine: Merry Edwards 2016 Bucher Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Ancien
Review: Layered and expertly textured, this impressive wine offers focused flavors of apple, pear and more exotic earth and spice components of anise and nutmeg. Medium bodied, it's defined in complex acidity and a marked length of integrated oak.
Wine: Ancien 2015 Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This vineyard, planted in 2007, is still delivering young, fresh and fruity wines, well ripened here to a flavor of raspberry jam. There's a suggestion of orange marmalade also, the fruit concentrating through the midpalate, and exiting with a light touch of tobacco and barrel spices.
Wine: Archery Summit 2015 Archer's Edge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From an estate-grown property, this is acid-driven and beautifully tart, persistent on the palate in whirls of blueberry and boysenberry. It offers the right amount of ripeness for its frame, finishing with complex structure and freshness.
Wine: Balletto 2016 Burnside Road Vineyard Estate Grown Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Benovia
Review: From several of the producer's estate sites, as well as the Zio Tony Ranch farmed by the Martinelli family, this wine exudes rich, velvety blue and black fruit flavors within a context of firm tannins and integrated oak. Dots of white pepper and cardamom complete the complex experience.
Wine: Benovia 2016 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The overall balance and underlying minerality in this wine are a good start, indicating a wine that is built to last. There's a delicate aspect to the brambly fruit, plus hidden seams of lemon curd and salted caramel. Drink 2022–2032.
Wine: Duck Pond 2016 Back Yard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe black cherry kicks off the nose of this bottling from the family's westernmost property, but then comes the more elegant touches of clove, chaparral and bay leaf. The palate is savory and complex, showing shiitake mushroom, sour cherry, ripe cranberry and a pinch of oregano.
Wine: Fess Parker 2016 Parker West Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine opens thick and rich, but evolves to show an underlying spark of brightness that persists through the midpalate and onto the finish. Raspberry and sage contrast against each other as a fleshy element of wild strawberry comes into play.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2015 Bacigalupi Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very plump aromas of dark strawberry, lilacs, jasmine and a hint of gingerbread show on the nose of this blend of 33% Merlot, 28% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Cabernet Franc, 7% Malbec and 7% Petit Verdot. The elegant palate rolls out flavors of candied raspberry, elderflower and black plum, growing more intense with acidity and tannins into the finish.
Wine: Happy Canyon Vineyard 2014 Piocho Red (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Kessler-Haak
Review: This study of Clone 2A begins with big aromas of boysenberry jam, black tea and minty chocolate elements. There is decent weight to the palate, where rich and ripe flavors of blackberry meet with firm tannins and buoyant acidity. Dashes of star anise and all spice give further depth.
Wine: Kessler-Haak 2014 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Lynmar
Review: This delicious appellation wine is a tremendous testament to all it has to offer, from juicy strawberry and blueberry fruit to savory edges of black tea and cardamom. It excels in its depth of evolved flavor and complex balance and approachability.
Wine: Lynmar 2016 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has an ethereal quality to it, buoyed by thickets of bright citrus, pomegranate and strawberry. Full bodied, it retains a heightened grip of acidity that remains beneath earthy characteristics of forest floor and clove.
Wine: Lynmar 2016 Summit Block Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Red cherry, dried rose petal and cinnamon-spiced melon show on the unique and alluring nose in this bottling. The palate offers a complex blend of earth and fruit, combining sour cherry with wild thyme, red flowers and dried sage.
Wine: Melville 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From a vineyard planted in 1986, this twist-top bottling is fresh and lovely, starting with aromas of grapefruit pith, nectarine, Pink Lady apple, orange and chalky minerality. The sip is bright, energetic and snaps with flavors of tangerine, chilled peach and light hazelnut, all wrapped in citrusy freshness and taut tension.
Wine: Pali 2016 Huber Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Farmed by the grande dame Dorothy Rossi, this wine opens with a touch of matchstick reduction and smoky wood. Rustic, concentrated layers of leather, tobacco and crushed rock provide a savory core of depth and complexity, buoyed by a richness of graham cracker and blackberry jam.
Wine: Robert Biale 2016 Grande Vineyard Zinfandel (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Extremely concentrated, flavorful and full bodied, this brawny wine has an inky dark color, exotic aromas of cedar, clove and blackberry followed by dense, ripe fruit flavors and mouth-coating tannins. It will be fun to drink soon with a fatty chop or steak but will easily age and improve through at least 2023.
Wine: Ruby Hill Winery 2013 Jewel Collection Series Estate Reserve Petite Sirah (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Steely on the nose, this always impressive bottling by a San Francisco accountant-turned-winemaker shows delicate aromas of lime blossom, chalk, sea salt, Asian pear and blanched almond. There is a tense grip to the palate and laser-sharp acidity, delivering flavors of lime sorbet and nectarine with a flash of light marshmallow on the deep finish.
Wine: Ryan Cochrane 2016 Solomon Hills Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Townley
Review: Perfumed and floral in rose petal, this is a soft, supple and plush red with ample acidity to support and complement the texture. Strawberry, rhubarb, clove and black tea are met by a rewarding dash of white pepper.
Wine: Townley 2015 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Calistoga, Napa, California, US
Review: This blends 35% Cabernet Sauvignon, 28% Cabernet Franc, 23% Zinfandel and 14% Petite Sirah. Together, they harmonize into one whole of broad, leathery and complex texture and flavor. There's both softness and grip beneath the dark-black fruit and peppery spice.
Wine: Vermeil 2015 XXXIV Frediani Vineyard Red (Calistoga)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The outstanding examples of Oregon Rieslings keep coming, this being the latest. Sappy lemon, tangerine and melon flavors are swathed in juicy acidity. Though it's fermented dry, the wine retains plenty of sweet fruit deliciousness. It's the sort of wine that is too good to keep your hands off, so enjoy it while it remains young and fresh.
Wine: Argyle 2016 Nuthouse Riesling (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Bennett Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Blending 80% Syrah with 20% Grenache, this fine wine is earthy and velvety in violet, black plum and a bright thread of integrated acidity. Soft, supple tannins provide power and quiet grip, while the finish is textured in a lasting tease of leather and white pepper.
Wine: Burt Street Cellars 2014 Judge's Verdict Judge Vineyard Red (Bennett Valley)

Appellation: Chalk Hill, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is another stellar blend from the estate. At 47%, the Cabernet Sauvignon dominates, but the wine also has 20% Merlot, 19% Cabernet Franc, 10% Petit Verdot and 4% Malbec. Balanced and moderate in ripeness, it doesn't hold back in concentrated black fruit, earthy spice, robust oak and tannin, the varieties finding harmony and structure.
Wine: Calluna 2015 Estate Red (Chalk Hill)

Appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: Sanguine and earthy, this is a thick, concentrated wine marked by its ash-laden soils—the texture and taste influenced mightily by this fact. Leathery on the palate, it offers a mix of mountain-grown berry and plum, with a twist of cassis and violet. This shows aging potential; enjoy best from 2025–2035.
Wine: Diamond Creek 2015 Volcanic Hill Cabernet Sauvignon (Diamond Mountain District)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Among the winery's numerous Chardonnays, this may be the tangiest of all. It offers up delicious, tongue-tickling flavors of pineapple, Meyer lemon and grapefruit that penetrate deeply. The French oak influence remains in the background, allowing the acid-driven fruit flavors to hold center stage.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2016 Clos de Lune Vineyard Chardonnay (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a layered, concentrated wine, richly woven with flavors of blueberry, strawberry, rose and lavender. Medium in weight, the palate feels compressed and thick but lifted by a lingering floral element.
Wine: Donum 2015 Year of the Ram Single Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Hometown musician and vintner Mark Adams delivers an impressively elegant yet forceful estate blend of 86% Syrah, 11% Grenache and 3% Roussanne, starting with aromas of Luxardo cherry, roasted black plum, charred beef, pepper dust and wet rocks. Elderberry and elderflower flavors arise on the well-balanced sip as do lilacs and violets, so much that the experience is like drinking the color purple.
Wine: Ledge 2016 Adams Ranch Vineyard Red (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Violets, lilacs, ripe alpine strawberries and intense purple fruits are packed in wet clay aromas on the nose of this blend of 64% Grenache, 21% Syrah, 11% Mourvèdre and 4% Roussanne. Strong acid and chalky tannins hold flavors of roasted boysenberry and violet on the palate, which will last for years. Drink 2020–2031.
Wine: Ledge 2016 James Berry Vineyard Red (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Note that the winery, the project of second generation Beaux Frères founders Jared Etzel and Marc-André Roy, makes a Petite Incline as well as two Incline Pinots from different AVAs. This dark, dense wine, packed with deep black fruit flavors, perfectly captures the classic signature of the Dundee Hills AVA. Subtle notes of iron ore, coffee grounds, tar and tobacco add complexity and length.
Wine: Maison Roy 2015 Incline Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Matias Wines
Review: There is a tightly wound dairy quality to the nose of this appellation blend, which combines yogurt-like aromas with lime pith and ash. It's zippy, fresh and bright with acidity on the palate, where tightly woven tannins carry hints of sandalwood, oak and citrus flavors.
Wine: Matias Wines 2015 Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lemon balm, pink grapefruit pith and a touch of sour cream show on the nose of this bottling, which quickly freshens up into more citrus elements as it sits open. There is strong tightness to the palate, where fresh lemon, nectarine and warmer pineapple tones are dusted with acidity and sea salt.
Wine: Matias Wines 2015 Soberanes Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Focused aromas of lemon, daffodil, sea salt, golden hazelnuts and tangerine cream show on the wondrous nose of this bottling from above the San Francisco Bay in Portola Valley. The palate's nutty flavors are framed by a tannic tension, chalky texture and solid acidity, leading into a sea-salt finish. Drink 2019–2026.
Wine: Neely 2016 Amphitheater Block Spring Ridge Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From the 50-acre vineyard the winery planted in 2012, this bottling shows a purity of aroma and flavors, starting with sea salt, russet apples and light marshmallow on the nose. The palate shows pan-seared apples with a touch of sea salt, white peach and a hint of hazelnut, with a flash of crème brûlée on the finish.
Wine: Pali 2016 Pali Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: The producer's third vintage from this relatively cool site, this wine is beautifully wrapped in lavender and smoky grilled meat. There is 6% Viognier cofermented with the Syrah. Turned earth, game and white pepper give it varietal complexity and integrity, with a powerfully bright thread of acidity and silky freshness.
Wine: Ramey 2014 Cole Creek Vineyard Syrah (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe red cherry compote, turned earth and chaparral spice aromas of sagebrush and wild mint converge for a very complex and inviting nose on this clonal selection. Tart cherry and cranberry flavors grow tangier with a hint of orange rind on the palate, which is dusted with peppery spice and finishes on a rounded strawberry kick.
Wine: Riverbench 2016 Pommard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The blend is 70% Pinot Noir and 30% Chardonnay, within spitting distance of the 2014 cuvée. Made in the traditional méthode Champenoise, it's a savvy, sexy bottle of bubbly. Lightly candied fruit flavors of orange peel, pineapple and poached pear penetrate deeply into the palate, with a fine bead and a burst of toast.
Wine: Roco 2015 RMS Brut Sparkling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Sultry and elegantly integrated aromas of purple flower and black raspberry decorate the nose of this single-vineyard expression by veteran Adam Lee. Pungent fruit shows on the palate, where baked black cherry and boysenberry are lifted by wild thyme and chaparral spice.
Wine: Siduri 2016 Soberanes Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe aromas of blackberry, black plum, spice cake, white pepper and cola show strongly on the nose of this bottling from the Stolpman family's original block of vineyard. Strong and mouth-filling tannins provide ample structure to the clean, peppery, pure purple flavors of the expertly balanced palate. Drink 2020–2036.
Wine: Stolpman 2016 Originals Syrah (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Hearty, deep and polished aromas of black currant, black plums and blackberry-laced fudge are thick and impressive on the nose of this bottling, which includes 3% Viognier. Power is the message on the palate, where booming black-currant and charred beef flavors ride firm tannins that tighten on the finish. Drink 2019–2030.
Wine: Westerly 2015 Cote Blonde Syrah (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Forest floor, clove, black tea and ash mark this lush, full-bodied and textured wine. It offers plenty of red and black cherry flavors atop a delicate undercarriage of freshness and grace.
Wine: Bob Cabral Wines 2015 Troubadour Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: From one of the appellation's great vineyards, this wine does the site justice in a quiet, expressive opening note of spicy fruit. A light, high-toned lift of acidity complements the bolder notions of oak and tannin, allowing all to open slowly in the glass.
Wine: Davies 2016 Hyde Vineyards Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: Exotically earthy, this block designate is defined in graphite, tobacco and cocoa powder, with a gritty, grippy profile of tannin at its core. Savory, soft and supple in nature, it also shows concentration and structure within a full-bodied frame of mountain ripeness.
Wine: Diamond Creek 2015 Red Rock Terrace Cabernet Sauvignon (Diamond Mountain District)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
