Review: This barrel-fermented wine from an Anderson Valley institution has very nice balance, lots of juicy, fresh and ripe apple and peach flavors and a lightly tangy texture due to good acidity. It's medium bodied, easy to sip and will please a lot of different palates.
Wine: Navarro 2016 Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Omen
Review: This California producer jumps into Southern Oregon with a bright, spicy bottle of Pinot Noir, blending grapes from the Wooldridge Creek Vineyard and the Rock'N R Ranch. Big, broad flavors of cranberry, pineapple, vanilla and toast deliver plenty of pleasure. Drink while it retains its freshness, now–2020.
Wine: Omen 2017 Pinot Noir (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Oregon Territory
Review: An outstanding value, this is the second label from Tempranillo specialist Paul O'Brien. It offers a boatload of mixed flavors and accents, with citrus, fig, cherry tobacco and bourbon tea all well represented and supported with lively acidity.
Wine: Oregon Territory 2015 Tempranillo (Oregon)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Generous tannins present as chalky and grippy in this wine, which offers an herbal wrapping of cedar, graphite and red currant. Boldly flavored and built, it's substantial on the palate.
Wine: Paraduxx 2014 X2 Estate Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aromas of pencil shavings, black peppercorn, oregano and elderberry frame the nose of this blend of 32% Merlot, 28% Cabernet Sauvignon, 18% Petit Verdot, 12% Cabernet Franc and 10% Malbec. It's tightly wound on the palate, where a dried cherry flavor meets with dried herbs and cracked pepper, lifted by a dash of acidity.
Wine: Rancho Sisquoc 2015 Cellar Select Meritage (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is the estate vineyard bottling from Maison Jadot's Oregon project. As 2018 will mark the first vintage made in the new Résonance winery, it's not surprising that some variation will be found in previous vintages, which were made in a borrowed facility. The 2015 is sharp and peppery, with dark fruits, supple acids and hints of char and smoke. The tannins, at first a bit gritty, smooth out with some hours of breathing time. Best drinking window here may be 2020–2025.
Wine: Résonance 2015 Résonance Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Calistoga, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a tiny production wine for the producer. It's also among the producer's lightest and most delicate. High-toned cherry and strawberry fruit support a floral, herbal entry of beautiful perfume, the texture soft and in balance.
Wine: Robert Biale 2016 Falleri Vineyard Zinfandel (Calistoga)

Appellation: Round Pond
Review: Soft and supple in milk chocolate and cherry, this wine contains 2% Petit Verdot. Dried herb, sage and pencil shavings contribute a savory complement to the richness of the ripe fruit.
Wine: Round Pond 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Good fruit concentration meets firm structure in this very full-bodied well-extracted wine for a winning, bold personality. Blackberry, boysenberry and wood smoke meld with ample, soft tannins for a mouthful of flavor and a generous texture to boot.
Wine: Ruby Hill Winery 2015 Grapeful Red (California)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Now approaching 40 years of age, this single clone, block selection is quite pretty, with Bing cherry fruit cascading into even sweeter maraschino territory. The body of the wine has a streak of cola and a nice hint of caramel.
Wine: Hyland 2016 Wädenswil Old Vine Pinot Noir (McMinnville)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: An estate-grown blend of 55% Cabernet Sauvignon and 45% Syrah, this wine is soft, supple and offers lasting structure. Blackberry and black currant combine for a jammy entry that's both sanguine and mineral in tone.
Wine: Kunde 2014 Dunfillan Cuvée Red (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Juicy and tart with flavors of fresh-squeezed pomegranate and raspberries, this tangy effort carries an impression of lemon rind also. It may remind you, at least at this stage, of a particularly ripe cru Beaujolais. Drink now for its youthful zip, or cellar for another year or two to ameliorate those tongue-tickling acids.
Wine: Lingua Franca 2016 Estate Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Soft, supple and earthy, with robust tannin structure and ripeness, this wine impresses in its interwoven layers of baked rhubarb, strawberry and cranberry. It lives up to its reserve-level billing and finishes dry.
Wine: Meiomi 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Migration
Review: Tannic and full bodied, this wine holds its weight and grip well. On the palate, it offers a dense expression of cherry cola, warm baking spices and toasted oak.
Wine: Migration 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This is a rich, tempting and full-bodied wine with enticing oak spices in the aroma, and tongue-drenching blackberry and boysenberry in the flavor. An extra dark color, moderate tannins and extreme ripeness all combine to amp up the experience.
Wine: Prospect 772 2016 Black Tie Charlie Red (California)

Appellation: Rancho Sisquoc
Review: Stewed red plum, pepper, dried herbs and baked earth show on the nose of this bottling. The palate starts quite zesty in a snappy raspberry-jam flavor, lifted by a hint of white pepper and solid acidity.
Wine: Rancho Sisquoc 2016 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Rock Wall
Review: Thick dense layers of mocha and baked cherry pie accent a rounded, richly ripe and well-made varietal wine that's full bodied and memorably expressive.
Wine: Rock Wall 2016 Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Produced and bottled by Aberrant Cellars, this Southern Oregon Bordeaux-style blend is made from 35% Carmenère, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% Cabernet Franc and 15% Malbec. Blackberry fruit, cola and light details of earth and wood are set in a well-structured, polished frame.
Wine: Sidecar 2016 Off the Wagon Red (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Black cherry fruit and barrel notes of dark chocolate come together in this medium-bodied vineyard selection. There's a thin streak of cola, and the tannins are annotated with a suggestion of Mediterranean herbs, often found in wines from this AVA. It spent 10 months in 63% new French oak.
Wine: Soléna 2016 Zena Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Juicy, smoky and exuberantly fruity on the nose, this wine is smooth and integrated, with rich lush layers of crushed rock, mocha and blackberry that burst on the robust full-bodied palate.
Wine: St. Francis 2015 Tres Viejos Old Vines Zinfandel (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe cherry, star anise and boiled plum aromas show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate is also rather ripe but enjoyable, showing cranberry, hibiscus and a hint of orange rind, wrapped in compelling structure and acidity.
Wine: Stasis 2015 Murmur Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Suisun Valley, North Coast, California, US
Review: Richness of flavor and an especially creamy, melting texture help this wine stand out in a crowd. The wine is 80% barrel fermented and aged on the lees. It has concentrated and ripe pear, peach and apple flavors and a silky mouthfeel.
Wine: Vezer Family Vineyard 2017 Arlene Chardonnay (Suisun Valley)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: There's a dried fennel note that shows on many Temecula Valley wines, but this blend of 48% Grenache, 34% Syrah and 18% Mourvèdre uses that spice note to its advantage. Plump red-plum and hickory-smoke aromas touch on that anise-like note on the nose, while the palate shows cherry wood, elegant red-fruit and roasted fennel-bulb flavors.
Wine: Wilson Creek 2016 Family Reserve G-S-M (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Ziata
Review: This medium-bodied white brings a stony mineral texture, with fleshy flavors of guava and mango. It offers complexity and nuance against a full embrace of ripeness.
Wine: Ziata 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Coombsville, Napa, California, US
Review: Fleshy in defined flavors of peach and pear, this is a bright white wine, defined by perfumed aromas of jasmine and white flower. Fresh acidity supports a moderate structure of balanced ripeness.
Wine: Ancien 2016 Musque Chardonnay (Coombsville)

Appellation: Argyle
Review: The production of this well-made wine keeps bumping up, while the price and quality remain consistent. Pungent, peppery fruit flavors center around bright cranberry and plenty of citrus. There's a gentle touch of cinnamon candy also, adding extra life to the finish.
Wine: Argyle 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine opens with a nutty, woody nose that delves quickly into a brazen blue-fruit flavor. Clove and pepper season it well and contribute to its length and depth.
Wine: Au Contraire 2014 Dutton Ranch Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A departure for this producer who tends to focus on its single-vineyard sites, this wine combines the best of several sites, with longevity and complexity in mind. It showcases the best of the coast's savory qualities, offering muted spice, firm tannins, orange, currant and a velvety midpalate.
Wine: Balletto 2015 18 Barrel Estate Grown Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Juicy, grippy and expansive in red and black cherry, this medium-bodied wine is smooth and seductive, an ideal representative of its reasonably warm site. It finishes on tones of black tea and rose petal.
Wine: Balletto 2016 Winery Block Estate Grown Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Mountain, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from grapes grown at 1,000-foot elevation, this wine is velvety thick and concentrated, with a decadence and grip to it that intrigues. Black licorice, black cherry and blackberry dance around each other with intent, providing a warm, full-bodied explosion of flavorful beauty.
Wine: Belden Barns 2016 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Sonoma Mountain)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Taut flavors of fresh strawberries, along with a gentle squeeze of grapefruit, introduce this young, snappy wine. Firm tannins support the overall structure, and the balance suggests that this should continue to improve over the next three to five years, and keep for another five after that.
Wine: Blakeslee 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Muscular and ripe, this cuvée mixes cranberry and cherry fruit over a lightly earthy foundation. Barrel aging adds textural flavors of halvah (tahini-based candy). It's not at all sweet, but lovely and detailed.
Wine: Blakeslee 2015 Estate Reserve Select Cluster Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: With a slight edge of reduction on the nose, and a leathery, earthy entry, this wine opens nicely into waves of soft, round and rich black-cherry, strawberry and blueberry. It maintains its exuberance through the succulent midpalate and quiet finish.
Wine: Bouchaine 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: While labeled Willamette Valley, this block selection is entirely estate-grown McMinnville AVA fruit. Spicy blackberry jam, cinnamon and chocolate flavors carry this wine, along with a pretty streak of candied violets. It shows medium concentration and high-toned brightness.
Wine: Coeur de Terre 2015 Sarah Jane's Block Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This blend is nearly a third each of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot, with a deep, dark oak profile and plenty of firm, chalky tannins. The flavors lean toward licorice and cherry, with a bit of coffee and toffee richness.
Wine: Corley 2014 Proprietory Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Mountain, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made in a Sauternes-like method, this dessert wine is balanced and smooth, its interwoven layers a celebration of salted caramel, green apple and dried apricot. Not too sweet nor rich, it will classically reward with blue cheeses, spiced nuts or on its own.
Wine: Covenant 2016 Zahav Late Harvest Botrytis Chardonnay (Sonoma Mountain)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Relative to the rest of Fullerton's 2016 Pinots, the Croft seems the most tannic, with a thicker presence in the mouth. Blackberry, black cherry and cola components are the defining flavors, with black olive and dark chocolate highlights running through the tannins.
Wine: Fullerton 2016 Croft Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Geyser Peak
Review: Excellent fruit concentration and very good balance make this full-bodied wine a winner. Minty cedary aromas accent the vivid black-cherry and pomegranate flavors as moderate tannins and fresh acidity add appetizing structure.
Wine: Geyser Peak 2015 Merlot (California)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Crisp waves of cherry vanilla are complemented by citrus-driven acidity in this light bright wine that's well made and memorable. Textured, it is lengthy and has ample body to work on its own or with food.
Wine: Gloria Ferrer 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Red-cherry compote, balsamic-glazed berries and a pinch of dried sage show on the nose of this bottling from a new label that's made by a secret group of winemakers. It's relatively light on the palate but full of flavors, from sour cherry and cranberry to pepper dust and dried marjoram.
Wine: Grace + Vine 2014 Reserve Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: South Coast, South Coast, California, US
Review: Deep, dark and lush aromas of blackberry, black plums, lilac and smoked meat show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is well rounded and cohesive, showing berry, plum and espresso-bean flavors.
Wine: Hawk Watch Winery 2015 Solo Barrique Malbec (South Coast)

Appellation: Jordan
Review: This is a tense, tart and crisply mineral-laden white wine, thick on entry in peach and melon flavor. The midpalate finds peace and balance, allowing a slight bit of reduction to linger and the finish to focus in acidity.
Wine: Jordan 2016 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This vineyard used to be called the Floodgate Vineyard and has been a consistent source of grapes to the producer. Soft, plush and brimming in dark rustic cherry and cardamom, this wine is also plenty earthy, a mix of turned earth and dried herb. The tannins are thick and strong.
Wine: Joseph Jewell 2014 Starscape Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The front label picture of Sigmund Freud underscores the punny name for this new entry into the winery's lineup. The wine was treated to 18 months in 30% new French oak. Its generous, fruit-driven flavors of raspberry and cherry come with a streak of cola, while the tannins are lightly dusty and proportionate.
Wine: King Estate 2016 Pinot Envy Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Koehler
Review: Cranberry, white pepper, dried herbs and wet gravel make for a complex aromatic entry to the nose of this bottling. Bright flavors of red cherry, oregano and rose petals give depth to the lighter-bodied style and make it quite easy to quaff.
Wine: Koehler 2015 Sangiovese (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Martinelli
Review: Amped up in gritty texture and a big tannin profile, this is robust, richly concentrated red wine, able to deliver expertly on its style. Rich dark cherry, toasted oak and a thick thread of earthiness combine effortlessly and with a tenacity that's impressive.
Wine: Martinelli 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: The tasty fruit flavors ring clear as a bell in this berry- and cherry-drenched and mouth-filling wine. It's grapey in a good way, very open and generous in character, and there's little or no oak to mask the fruit.
Wine: Naggiar 2016 Estate Grown Root 49 Barbera (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Pambrun
Review: This is the first release from a new winery from Willamette Valley Vineyards that will be located on the Oregon side of Walla Walla Valley. The aromas bring a sense of purity, with notes of black currant, raspberry, plum and fresh tobacco. The palate offers a sense of delicacy and restraint. There's structure here, but it relies less on overt tannins than most Cabernets. It's a unique offering of the variety.
Wine: Pambrun 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Pambrun
Review: This is the first release from a new winery from Willamette Valley Vineyards that will be located on the Oregon side of Walla Walla Valley. The aromas bring a sense of purity, with notes of black currant, raspberry, plum and fresh tobacco. The palate offers a sense of delicacy and restraint. There's structure here, but it relies less on overt tannins than most Cabernets. It's a unique offering of the variety.
Wine: Pambrun 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The latest version is more widely available through expanded production and offers a price drop as well. In fact, it's a fine value in a sappy, sexy style. Raspberry, blueberry, blackberry and cherry fruits are here in abundance—the whole spectrum, reflecting a variety of top vineyard sources. The tasty fruit is backed with fine-tuned tannins—and 42% new French oak.
Wine: Panther Creek 2016 Winemaker's Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Well balanced and medium bodied, this wine from a unique mountainside vineyard combines good elements of natural acidity for freshness with ripe apple and pear for flavor. A smooth, layered mouthfeel wraps it all up nicely.
Wine: Townley 2015 Alder Springs Vineyard Chardonnay (Mendocino)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A blend of grapes from the pioneering family's properties in Livermore and Arroyo Seco, this starts with aromas of pear flesh, lime skin, bright tangerine, honeydew and a touch of chalk. There is a tropical streak to the palate, but it's energetic and balanced, showing flavors of guava, mango and ripe red apple, all honed in by a tight pink-grapefruit-pith structure.
Wine: Wente 2016 Coastal Selection Chardonnay (Central Coast)

Appellation: 50 Harvests
Review: This blend of 75% Cabernet Sauvignon and 25% Petit Verdot commemorates the number of consecutive harvests by the Scotto family of Steele Canyon Cellars. Candied red fruit gives it broad, lasting richness that lingers across the structured palate.
Wine: 50 Harvests 2014 Meritage (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Winemaker Daniel Kraft, whose primary work is at Washington's Kevin White winery, has named his solo project after the Native American name for Mount Jefferson. This Pinot, from a vineyard owned by Mimi Casteel, opens with ripe flavors of strawberry preserves. It's lively, lightly herbal, medium bodied and finished with a smooth streak of café crême.
Wine: Seekseekqua 2016 Whitewater Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Pretty cherry fruit opens this wine and shows instant appeal. There's also a streak of rubber, suggesting that it remains a bit reductive and should be aggressively aerated. Hints of black olive and tar come up through the finish.
Wine: Soléna 2016 Grande Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Quite a few wineries purchase and feature Hyland Vineyard grapes, but here they lack a bit of presence. This is done in a light, easy-drinking style that might have come from anywhere. Strawberry fruit and suggestions of dried straw are the principal flavors, with a light dusting of cocoa powder from aging in 40% new French oak.
Wine: Soléna 2016 Hyland Vineyard Pinot Noir (McMinnville)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Stewed red-fruit flavors of strawberry-balsamic sauce and red and black licorice show on the nose of this bottling. Intense gingerbread flavors meet with ripe red cherry and mulberry on the palate, which is very ripe.
Wine: Alara 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Central Coast)

Appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Brambly raspberry fruit is wrapped in a thicket of peppery herb. The tannins lead into an astringent finish with suggestions of green tea. This should benefit from aggressive aeration and/or further bottle aging. Optimal drinking window is 2020–2026.
Wine: Brandborg 2014 Ferris Wheel Estate Vineyard Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This single vineyard selection spends time in half new, 40% once-used barrels. The oak influence is muted, just as well since the low alcohol translates into light fruit flavors of strawberry and raspberry. The tannins have a green tea character, and the acids seem a bit chalky, but as it's done in a lighter style, if paired with a simple salmon preparation, it suits the bill.
Wine: Chehalem 2016 Stoller Vineyards Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is 100% Barbera. A pretty pale salmon color, with aromas of watermelon and sour cherry that lead to quite tart, full-feeling flavors with a kiss of sweetness but more than enough acidity to keep it in check.
Wine: Coyote Canyon 2017 Life is Rosé (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Opaque in the glass, this bottling shows extremely dense and extracted aromas of kirsch, chocolate syrup, caramel and a hint of mint on the nose. It is suave and creamy on the palate, yet rather thick with unctuous flavors of roasted black plum and coffee liqueur. Acid arises on the finish.
Wine: Dunning Vineyards 2014 4 Hearts Vineyard Reserve Petite Sirah (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: An attractive oak element in the aroma leads to good, satisfying fruit flavors on the palate and some oak spice accents like vanilla and nutmeg. The wine is a Bordeaux-style blend with noticeable acidity and tannins and is full bodied.
Wine: Easton 2014 Three of a Kind Ridgewood Vineyard Old Vine Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Light and forward, this fills the mouth with texture more than rich flavor. Gentle highlights of raspberries and cherries come with a wash of chocolate malt and a streak of cola. Drink now and over the next three years.
Wine: Ermisch 2016 Erendira's Rise Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This is a very good dry wine that's quite fresh, well balanced and thirst quenching. Raspberry and watermelon flavors are buoyed by good fruit acidity for a tangy mouthfeel.
Wine: Jessie's Grove 2017 Jessie's Collection Estate Grown Dry Rosé of Carignane (Lodi)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Velvety thick and pleasantly concentrated, this is a burly, big-boned and richly defined wine. It's also a celebration of blackberry jam that's accented in smoke and leather.
Wine: Kokomo 2016 Pauline's Vineyard Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Heady in vanilla brioche and sugary aromas, this wine has a steely midpalate that takes on a lushness toward the finish, a mix of baked apple and sweet cinnamon.
Wine: Mahoney 2016 Gavin Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon and 50% Merlot offers aromas of blackberry, purple flowers and a fig balsamic glaze on the nose. The palate is extremely tangy, offering fresh flavors of blackberry and peppery spice.
Wine: Oso Libre 2013 Querida Red (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Given its youth, it's not at all surprising that this wine is still pulling itself together. There are streams of tart citrus, wild berry, tobacco and earth, all flowing in the right direction but not yet coalesced into a seamless whole. Barrel aging for 17 months in half new French oak brings a touch of vanilla to the finish.
Wine: Panther Creek 2016 Schindler Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A delightfully integrated nose of canned peach, yellow apple and potpourri spice translates to the rounded yet succulent palate. It's juicy and persistent in feel, with a healthy vein of acidity that extends the floral finish.
Wine: Silver Thread 2016 STV Estate Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a single site, this is a saignée of wine that is stainless-steel fermented and retentive in high-toned acidity. Peach-skin and lemon-peel flavors highlight a dry austere style that doesn't overwhelm.
Wine: Terragena 2017 Abbassi Vineyard Rosé of Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of Mourvèdre (55%) and Grenache. The aromas of white pepper, herb and red cherry seem quite reticent out of the gate. The red and black fruit flavors are on the lighter side of medium bodied, tapering toward the finish. It's equal parts intrigue and delivery.
Wine: Upsidedown 2016 The Artist Collection Dead Poplar Estate Vineyard Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Some 60% of the grapes are estate grown, and all of this value-priced Pinot is sourced from the Willamette Valley (most inexpensive Oregon Pinots are not). With solid winemaking throughout, it's a splendid mix of black cherry, baking spices and barrel hints of toasted coconut and almond paste.
Wine: Coeur de Terre 2015 Oregon Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This coferments 30% Viognier, 40% Marsanne and 30% Roussanne, somewhat different proportions from the previous vintage. It spent three months in one-quarter new French oak, yielding a lightly spicy wine tasting of lemony herbs, lime, pineapple and gooseberry. More toward the yellow/green fruit spectrum, it's a pleasant quaffer with a hint of toast from the minimal time in barrel.
Wine: Cowhorn 2017 Spiral 36 White (Applegate Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This estate wine offers a tight-grained tension of tannin and oak that underlines a robust ripeness and sense of power. Bright red fruit is in there and youthfully evolving to have its own day in the sun.
Wine: Etude 2016 Grace Benoist Ranch Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: An oak-driven nose of toasted citrus carries to the the medium-bodied palate, along with a juicy flavor of grilled peach. Silky and soft in feel, yet balanced by a bright vein of acidity, this lingers on a browned marshmallow note.
Wine: Fox Run 2015 Reserve Kaiser Vineyard Chardonnay (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This fresh and inviting, value-priced wine is done in a lighter style, with strawberry fruit rather than darker black fruit flavors. It's lively with appealing accents of cola and mocha.
Wine: Fullerton 2016 Three Otters Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Blended and bottled by Joseph Carr, this is made in the style of inexpensive California Pinots, but benefits from a bit more grip and weight with its Oregon-sourced fruit. It hasn't been overmanipulated, and it offers cherry fruit, lightly earthy tannins and medium length.
Wine: Josh Cellars 2016 Oregon Reserve Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Here's a palate-friendly mix of blueberry and cherry fruit, set in a sweetly toasty frame. The vines are 20–30 years old, and the wine was aged for 10 months in one-quarter new French oak barrels. There's a hint of volatility despite the rather low listed alcohol.
Wine: Kramer 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Intense color, flavor and texture make this wine big and bold. It was made from 65% Petite Sirah along with Syrah and Zinfandel and has an inky appearance, plenty of grapey and plummy aromas, rich jammy flavors accented by chocolate and very firm tannins that grip the sides of the mouth.
Wine: Naggiar 2016 Black Beast Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Brooding aromas of blackberry, orange peel and spice lead to quite ripe, full-bodied fruit flavors with a slightly tacky feel. There are good things going on if the feel evens out.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Ciel du Cheval Vineyard Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: A Cabernet Sauvignon-dominant red blended with Merlot, Zinfandel and Petit Verdot, this presents as burly, brawny and smoky, with soft supple tannin and oak that are well integrated into the whole. Easy to enjoy, its fruit is black and meaty.
Wine: Paraduxx 2015 Proprietary Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is tightly wound in its youth and shows great potential for further development. A reduced entry shows generous oak, burnt sugar and pineapple aromas and flavors, a rich, decadent expression of the vineyard that still needs time to come around.
Wine: Patz & Hall 2016 Durell Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: Fresh aromas of citrus, peach and white blossom carry this invigorating Chardonnay. Crisp citrus and crunchy stone-fruit flavors meld with a soft lemon meringue tone on the medium-bodied palate, giving this an immensely likable personality.
Wine: Paumanok 2017 Festival Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Entirely barrel-fermented, then aged in French oak, this is a fully fleshy, robust white, plentiful in oak and power. The fruit-forward components are a mix of fig, mango and cinnamon toast.
Wine: Simi 2015 Reserve Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Produced entirely from Willamette Valley grapes, this has pretty red fruit flavors, lightly tasting of lollipop candy. It finishes with a touch of cola and leaves an impression of wintergreen mint. Enjoy this over the next year or two.
Wine: Sokol Blosser 2017 Evolution Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Vanilla, black licorice, herb, pencil lead and dried cherry aromas lead to somewhat lighter styled fruit flavors that trail on the finish. Fruit and barrel seem to tussle at times.
Wine: Sparkman 2014 Evermore Old Vines Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The winery reserve, priced significantly lower than its top cuvées, has more fruit and less charred wood flavors, all to its benefit. Raspberry and cherry fruit, backed with moderate acidity, sends it into a finish with lightly green tannins. Drink now–2022.
Wine: The Four Graces 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of ember, herb, black pepper, grilled asparagus and char lead to plentiful but still elegant fruit and savory flavors that persist on the finish. It provides a lot of intrigue, but the concentration doesn't all seem to be there at times.
Wine: Upsidedown 2016 The Artist Collection Candy Ridge Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Clean aromas of peach, lemon and pineapple move toward tropical ripeness on the nose of this bottling—a well-balanced white from the warm region. It's bright and fresh on the palate with guava, tuberose and sweet cream flavors.
Wine: Wilson Creek 2017 Yes Dear Happy Wife Vineyard Chardonnay (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rich aromas of pomegranate and cranberry are dusted with baking spice, pepper and dried herbs on the rather ripe nose of this bottling. The palate is also riper than usual for Pinots from this appellation, showing flavors of cooked berries, star anise, licorice, vanilla and cedar.
Wine: Martin Ranch 2015 Griva Vineyard Therese Vineyards Pinot Noir (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is mostly Ranch at the End of the Road and Arianses Vineyard fruit, along with dashes from Stone Tree and Marsala. Aromas of fresh flower and orange peel are in the lead, with the Viognier (6%) showing itself strongly. Blueberry pie aromas follow. The palate is interesting, with a lot of bass notes but seeming to be missing in the middle and top.
Wine: MCM Wine Co. 2015 Spectaculuxe Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: You have to lean into the glass to try and get at the aromas, with green herb notes starting to emerge over time. The dark cherry flavors are more giving, though not quite holding across the palate. Firm, not fully ripened tannins back it all up along with tart acidity.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Dineen Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The majority of this wine is 77% Grenache from StoneTree Vineyard, with the balance being Syrah and Mourvèdre. Dried orange peel and flower aromas are at the fore, with the lighter styled palate showing more of the same. There's a rough feel to the wine that seems distracting.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Una Notte Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Already showing some sunset colors, this wine seems to be moving quickly to maturity. It's lightly fruity with strawberries and a hint of sweet spice. Drink up.
Wine: Sean Minor 2015 Point North Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This blends sizable portions of Merlot and Petite Sirah with Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec, the varieties in tension with one another for dominance, with the Petite Sirah winning. Baked plum, cocoa powder and black pepper ride along a thick tannic frame.
Wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2015 The Investor Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The mouthfeel is quite chalky, and flavors of earth, tea, tobacco and charcoal dominate. The resulting astringency seems to thin out the fruit. This might best be drunk with a big, fatty protein entrée.
Wine: The Four Graces 2015 Doe Ridge Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Meaty, dry and light, this wine offers moderate length and body, with highlighted flavors of cherry, lemon peel and mint.
Wine: The Vice 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This is a 25 vineyard blend, with the word “Essence” in bold black script across the label. The wine is a rather insubstantial essence, delivering light berry fruit flavors, and a touch of tomato. It finishes with tart acidity.
Wine: A to Z 2016 The Essence of Oregon Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Full bodied and almost fat with all its unctuous flavors, this wine smells like butter and baking spices and tastes like pear syrup and nutmeg. It has a mouth-coating texture, plenty of oak influence and a sense of near-sweetness on the finish.
Wine: Barra of Mendocino 2017 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Mendocino)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Concentrated aromas of blackberry and balsamic glaze show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate is very tangy and thick with more berry-balsamic touches as well as peppery spice.
Wine: Bellante 2016 Jack McGinley Vineyard Syrah (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This wine is full bodied, dry, firm but smooth in texture and has a good array of berry and black-cherry flavors. It has nice weight and breadth and a good balance of body, moderate tannins and fruit acidity.
Wine: Campos Family Vineyards 2016 Estate Big Red (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a solid, seamless, but rather blocky wine. Flavors of black cherry come highlighted with scents and streaks of tobacco. The tannins are thick and fully ripened, with an earthy aspect that suggests Eola-Amity Hills fruit, though that remains unspecified.
Wine: Copper Belt 2015 Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Aromas of citrus rind, white blossoms and peach skin make for an enjoyably fresh nose. The palate is rounded in feel, with an integrated line of acidity that boasts creamy citrus and coconut flavors.
Wine: Glenora 2017 Barrel Fermented Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is rather tight and tannic for a grape that is more often fruity and forward. Flavors of blueberries and graphite come up, with hints of stem. The tannins retain some earthy astringency.
Wine: Lük 2016 Havlin Vineyard Upper Slope Gamay Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Raspberry jam, slightly candied fruit and barrel spice aromas are followed by ripe, luscious fruit flavors. The tannins bring a bit of grit on an otherwise enjoyable offering.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Proprietor's Reserve Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Whole-berry pressed, the estate fruit is farmed organically for this wine, which is a rich and relatively thick expression of candied strawberry and watermelon Jolly Rancher. It refreshes through the finish.
Wine: Merriam 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Dark fruits are at the core, wrapped in more dark flavors of chocolate, graphite and charcoal. There's plenty of oak influence, and a strong vanilla streak. It's a big, chewy wine but lacks any Pinot Noir finesse.
Wine: The Four Graces 2015 Foley Family Estate Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Cooked aromas of cherry, baking spice, vanilla and stewed plums show on the rather ripe and extracted nose of this bottling. Spice-cake and fruitcake flavors show on the sip, where the texture and acidity are decent but the flavors a bit heavy-handed.
Wine: Bianchi 2015 Garey Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Jammy raspberry and other red fruit aromas are followed by full-bodied, supple red and blue fruit flavors that linger on the finish. The tannins give a gentle squeeze.
Wine: Cana's Feast 2014 Destiny Ridge Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from esteemed Boushey, Red Willow and Alder Ridge vineyards. Aromas of sour cherry, herb and spice are followed by tart, bright fruit flavors backed by a firm lick of tannins.
Wine: Cavatappi 2014 Molly's Cuvée Sangiovese (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Done in a lighter style that might compare to some dry Portuguese reds, this offers tart cranberry fruit with ample, stiff tannins. A small percentage of new oak adds a hint of spice, and the tannins are backed with herbal highlights.
Wine: Coelho 2016 Coelho Estates Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This rosé is really a generic white wine blend colored with a splash of Pinot Noir. The blend is 47% Chardonnay, 35% Riesling and 16% Gewürztraminer, with just 2% of the red wine giving it a bit of a blush hue. It's floral, fruity and tart and tastes perfectly fine.
Wine: Hyland 2017 Single Vineyard Rosé (McMinnville)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: The aromas bring notes of vanilla, coconut, cranberry and wood spice. The palate shows a mixture of fruit and barrel, with the latter generally winning out. The oak is heavy-handed, obscuring the fruit and spice notes of the variety.
Wine: Marshall Davis 2016 Seven Hills Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Cherry-berry flavors are seasoned in pleasing accents of cinnamon and vanilla in this rich, highly ripe wine. The tannins are soft and supple, providing simple support without distraction.
Wine: Mount Peak 2015 Rattlesnake Zinfandel (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blended with 5% Viognier, which shows itself. Generous aromas of fresh orange peel, flower and boysenberry are followed by ripe, full-bodied fruit flavors. The tannins bring a gritty feel and some bitterness, too, on an otherwise enjoyable offering.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Stone Tree Vineyard Syrah (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: From the Union Wine Company, this value bubbly is 62% Pinot Noir and 38% Chardonnay. It's fresh, crisp and clean, with notes of apple, melon and citrus. It comes in full-size, crown-capped wine bottles and 375 ml cans.
Wine: Underwood 2017 The Bubbles Sparkling (Oregon)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark boysenberry aromas meet with peppery spice and herbs on the tangy nose of this bottling. The palate shows a bit of balsamic sourness, with hints of boysenberry and blackberry fruit.
Wine: Allegretto 2014 Ayres Family Reserve Malbec (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Relatively light and easy-drinking for the varietal, this wine is not too dark in color, has friendly berry and plum flavors and medium body. Some tannin does come through in the texture but the wine stays smooth.
Wine: Campos Family Vineyards 2016 Estate Petite Sirah (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Fresh herb and strawberry aromas are followed by vivid raspberry flavors in this medium-bodied smooth and rather soft-textured wine. Being made from the Rhône grape variety Mourvèdre, it's an interesting twist on rosé.
Wine: Cline 2017 Ancient Vines Mourvèdre Rosé (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A three vineyard blend, this is tightly wound and strongly herbal. Earthy beetroot and tart cranberry flavors dominate. The wine saw one-quarter new oak for 10 months, but the flavor impact was minimal.
Wine: Coelho 2016 Atração Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Smoky oak and a meaty component give this wine an interesting complexity amidst high-toned, tangy elements of rhubarb and strawberry. The tannins are thick and present.
Wine: Côte West 2016 La Cruz Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: An herbal nose, redolent with composted earth, leads into a thin wine with tart flavors of wild strawberry. It spent 10 months in barrel, but no indication of new oak is detectable.
Wine: Et Fille 2015 Heredity Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine has fresh fruit and baking-spice aromas that lead to a supple texture and tangy apple-skin flavors. This medium-bodied wine is a sure crowd-pleaser.
Wine: Husch 2016 Estate Bottled Chardonnay (Mendocino)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The back label posits this as a “dry” style, but there's plenty of fruit sweetness nonetheless. Peach and citrus rind flavors come with a sprinkling of powdered sugar. It's a fairly significant change from the aromatic and detailed 2016 version.
Wine: Hyland 2017 Old Vine Gewürztraminer (McMinnville)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Quite showing on the nose, this Grenache-based rosé offers strong aromas of passion fruit, orange and guava juice. It tightens a bit on the sip, but that tropical-juice combo remains, proving very flavorful and likable for those seeking a pink wine with clout.
Wine: J. Lohr 2017 Gesture Rosé of Grenache (Paso Robles)

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: A toasty popcorn note rides over a fresh core of citrus cream and cantaloupe in this barrel-aged wine. Medium in weight and boasting bright acidity, the palate is racy in flavors of citrus, rounded out by a creamed corn flavor and finishing on grilled lemon.
Wine: Lieb 2016 Reserve Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From two vineyards, this oddly blends Viognier, Carignan, Zinfandel, Petite Sirah and Grenache, cofermenting it all together before aging in French oak. The result is light in color and bright in acidity, with distinct flavors of sour cherry, cranberry and green apple.
Wine: Meeker 2015 Hone Series #1 Sakura Red (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Merlot makes up 40% of this wine, with the rest being equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot. Aromas of garden herb, soil, violet and cherry lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors that run straight down the middle, missing on the edges, with slightly gritty tannins throughout.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Arianses Vineyard Red (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas are light and difficult to get at, while the palate brings dark fruit flavors that are reserved in style, tapering on the finish. It doesn't all seem to come together.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Ciel du Cheval Vineyard Merlot (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of blackberry jam and fruit roll-up are followed by ripe dark fruit flavors, with the warmth of the vintage on display. The tannins bring a lightly tacky feel.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Dineen Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: A fine companion to Underwood's regular brut, this rosé is three-quarters Pinot Noir, the rest Chardonnay. Strawberry and cherry soda flavors suggest this as a great party starter. Or get creative and use it as a versatile mixer. It comes in full-size, crown-capped wine bottles and 375 ml cans.
Wine: Underwood 2017 Rosé Bubbles Sparkling (Oregon)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: This is a good medium-bodied wine that emphasizes fresh fruit flavors and a smooth, natural-feeling texture. There's not much oak or butter to trick it up, so pure apple and pear notes take the lead.
Wine: Abbeyville 2016 Tanner's Passage Chardonnay (North Coast)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Gamay Noir remains fairly rare in Oregon but occupies a useful niche; it's more of a simple country red great for midweek quaffing. High-toned plum and sour cherry fruit flavors are on display, with plenty of backing acidity.
Wine: Chehalem 2016 Ridgecrest Vineyards Gamay Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Mild wood smoke and black pepper aromas give this Rhône-style blend a spicy start, while good broad black-plum and roast-beef flavors are framed by moderate tannins and acidity for good balance.
Wine: Cline 2016 Cashmere Red (California)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Aromas of lemon rind, green pear and ginger spice offer a moderately concentrated nose. The palate shows a light impression of juicy apple and lemon-lime, ending brisk and clean.
Wine: Hermann J. Wiemer 2016 Semi-Dry Estate Bottled & Grown Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: All of Kramer's new Pinots are surprisingly low in alcohol, but then again, much of the winery's fruit goes into sparkling wines, which are always picked earlier. This Pommard/Dijon 115 blend shows light blue fruits and some of the same chicken yard funkiness as the Rebecca's Reserve.
Wine: Kramer 2015 Cardiac Hill Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A curious wine, which starts out aromatically intriguing with roses and raspberries. In the mouth some funky chicken yard flavors come in, closing down the finish. Hard to tell if further bottle aging will curtail or enhance that funky finish.
Wine: Kramer 2015 Rebecca's Reserve Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blackberry and black pepper aromas are followed by ripe but somewhat lighter styled fruit flavors that taper toward the cranberry filled finish. There are some interesting things going on, but they don't all come together.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Heart of the Hill Vineyard Mourvèdre (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of fresh plum, orange peel, tar and herb lead to quite light, tart fruit flavors backed by lightly grainy tannins. It's an intriguing interpretation of this variety, but the concentration doesn't seem all there.
Wine: Three of Cups 2016 La Monde Cameron Ridge Vineyard Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: A blend of 79% Sauvignon Blanc and 21% Sémillon. Light aromas of herb, citrus and grass are followed by medium-bodied, lemony fruit flavors with a tart finish. It's equal parts intrigue and delivery.
Wine: Three of Cups 2017 Stillwater Creek Vineyard White (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A Zin-based blend that offers the variety's friendly personality, this has seasonings of smoked oak and leather with maximum-level ripeness that presents as syrupy and sweet. Dark chocolate, blackberry jam and vanilla all figure in.
Wine: Truett Hurst 2016 The One Armed Man Red (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cocoa, herb, dark chocolate, vanilla and cherry aromas are out front. Fruit and barrel flavors play off each other and continue to intertwine through the finish. Grippy tannins back it up.
Wine: Waterbrook 2015 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine offers a rusty yellow gold, with scents of bruised apple. It seemed much older than its vintage, partially oxidized, but with plenty of fruit. A metallic note crept into the finish. Just one bottle was provided, so no chance to retaste.
Wine: Areté 2016 Brut Blanc de Noirs Sparkling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Smoky cherry, strawberry and vanilla combine to provide a fruity red with moderate structure and understated ripeness in this vineyard-designate.
Wine: Côte West 2015 La Cruz Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: A skin-fermented, 100% Sauvignon Blanc, this wine is dark and brooding with a slightly oxidative character that won't appeal to everybody. Concentrated and oaky, it tastes of honey and baked apple with a viscosity that lingers.
Wine: Crosby Roamann 2014 Reserve Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Here is a straightforward, rather earthy wine, without the supple muscularity of the previous vintage. The fruit thins out quickly, leading into a dilute, one-dimensional finish.
Wine: Dois Irmãos 2016 Two Brothers' Private Selection Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Sangiovese makes up three-quarters of this wine, with the balance being Cabernet Sauvignon. Tire rubber, cherry, armpit and spice aromas lead to lighter styled, straightforward fruit flavors. It doesn't all come together.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Tavolo Rosso Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Syrupy black fruit is liqueur-like in consistency and richness, the wine dusty in texture and wrap-around tannin. It has a burly ripeness that dominates in all aspects.
Wine: Truett Hurst 2016 Inconspicuous Zinfandel (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of vanilla, wilted flower and stone fruit are followed by full-bodied, dry, lightly creamy feeling peach flavors. The oak seems a bit heavy-handed.
Wine: Waterbrook 2017 Icon Viognier (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: There's a scent and flavor of leather running through this wine, along with pepper, bitter greens and tightly wound cranberry fruit. The earthy character continues in the tannins, and finishes with residual flavors of astringent green tea.
Wine: Brandborg 2016 Love Puppets Pinot Noir (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A sharp nose of crushed limestone, tomato leaf and citrus zest makes for a bracing start. The palate is equally stony and tense in feel, with a plethora of tart citrus flavors.
Wine: Fulkerson 2017 Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Knights Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has pretty floral elements that come to fore ahead of a heavier, riper style that's viscous and plush on the palate. Golden-apple flavors take on a baked note, accompanied by pineapple and crème brûlée.
Wine: Knights Bridge 2016 East Block Chardonnay (Knights Valley)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: An aroma of freshly sawn oak boards leads to equally spicy and bold flavors that tamp down the moderate plum flavors underneath. The wine is full bodied, moderately tannic and definitely full of oaky spiciness.
Wine: Pestoni Family 2016 1892 Field Blend Red (Lake County)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from a saignée of Zinfandel, this offers a briary berry-filled character that tastes somewhat diluted on the midpalate. The wine is easygoing and moderate in acidity, going for power over grace.
Wine: Pezzi King 2017 Angela's Estate Rosé (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Almost dark enough in color to be a red wine, this rosé is the antithesis of the pale Provençal-style wines that are in vogue. It shows effusive floral and raspberry aromas, and plum-skin and watermelon flavors on a medium-bodied frame.
Wine: Prospect 772 2017 Baby Doll Rosé (California)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: A strong earthy meaty aroma is followed by herb, tomato and green-olive flavors in this medium-bodied wine. It has a distinct personality that relies on savory characters and makes a fun change of pace.
Wine: Shenandoah Vineyards 2016 ReZerve Barbera (Amador County)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Quiet aromas of peaches and orchard blossoms offer a pleasing entry to this wine. It's rounded and juicy in feel, with a mild stone fruit concentration and a pleasantly crisp finish.
Wine: Swedish Hill 2016 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: Quiet aromas of tonic and citrus open up to a light-bodied palate driven by flavors of lemon-lime and apple. This is an easygoing blend of 65% Albariño, 15% Chardonnay, 10% Sauvignon Blanc and 10% Viognier.
Wine: Bedell 2016 Taste White (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This sweet-seeming medium-bodied wine blends vanilla aromas with milk chocolate and cherry flavors and a soft texture for a simple and soothing character.
Wine: Bell 2016 The Scoundrel Cabernet Sauvignon-Syrah (California)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a 100% whole-cluster pressed wine that is high-toned in flavors of lemon peel and grapefruit. The finish is quick and unfussy.
Wine: Educated Guess 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Napa Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Vivid toasted-oak aromas and flavors dominate this full-bodied mouth-filling wine. Along with a charred-wood aroma come buttery butterscotchy flavors from a complete malolactic fermentation and a pear nectar component that provides the fruity side.
Wine: Harken 2017 Barrel Fermented Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This good, easy-drinking wine gives a sweet first impression and builds fruity and savory notes through the flavors and finish. It adds chocolaty accents to herbal ones like bay leaf and fruity ones like black plum.
Wine: Navarro 2016 Navarrouge Red (Mendocino)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Merlot and Cabernet Franc each make up 40% of this wine, with the balance being Cabernet Sauvignon. Clove, vanilla and raspberry roll-up aromas are followed by slightly dried-out fruit flavors. The tannins bring an astringent squeeze.
Wine: :Nota Bene 2015 Ciel du Cheval Vineyard Red (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Thick tannins take on a leathery quality in this blend of 64% Zinfandel and 36% Cabernet Sauvignon, the Zin from high atop Howell Mountain. Tart acidity underlies the leather, black currant and dried herb.
Wine: Paraduxx 2015 Pintail Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine has a strong candied flavor of sugarcane and baked pineapple, allowing its ripeness and barrel-fermentation to speak loudly and with conviction.
Wine: Saddleback Cellars 2016 Barrel Fermented Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of tin, green pepper, herb, plum and cherry lead to plump but still light fruit flavors. Grainy tannins provide support.
Wine: Sparkman 2016 Kindred Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Washington, Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: Honeysuckle, jasmine, lime and ripe peach aromas are followed by sweet fruit flavors, speckled with abundant floral notes. It delivers sweet, easy-drinking appeal.
Wine: Washington Hills 2017 Late Harvest Riesling (Washington)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This plain and simple Pinot has light strawberry and thin raspberry fruit, with lemony acidity. It was whole berry fermented, but the overall impression is that the grapes either were picked early or simply ran out of ripening time.
Wine: Coelho 2016 Coelho Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Though many 2015s are evocative, balanced wines with good structure and tension, Et Fille has released wines with unusually low alcohol and concurrently green flavors. Acidity and chalk underscores light, wild berry flavors, with a burst of celery accenting the green character.
Wine: Et Fille 2015 Kalita Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Vanilla and milk chocolate aromas lead to jammy plum and strawberry flavors and a touch of maple syrup in this medium-bodied, soft and slightly sweet wine.
Wine: Josh Cellars 2015 Family Reserve Red (Lodi)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine is well-balanced, moderately flavorful and has a good, gripping texture. Light red cherry and cranberry are the flavor focal points.
Wine: Kendric 2015 Reward Ranch Sangiovese (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Cayuga Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Ripe yellow apple, canned lychee and rose water aromas carry to the medium-bodied palate. Balanced by a mild vein of acidity, this is dry in style, with a slightly bitter floral finish.
Wine: Knapp 2017 Dry Gewürztraminer (Cayuga Lake)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: A medium salmon color, with strawberry, herb and apple aromas that are followed by sleek fruit flavors, with pink grapefruit notes on the finish. The concentration doesn't hold together throughout.
Wine: Love That Red 2017 Love That Rosé (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Aromas of fuzzy apricot and steely lemon carry to the delicately framed palate. This is short on concentration but enjoyable with its crisp, dry finish.
Wine: Thirsty Owl Wine Company 2016 Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A squeeze of pink grapefruit melds with grass and brisk spice on the nose of this light-bodied semidry offering. The palate is more juicy in nature, with ripe apple and pear melding with of lime zest.
Wine: Benmarl 2016 Semi Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is stiffly tannic, and the thin cranberry fruit may not be up to the challenge of outdueling those tannins even with more bottle aging. Flavors are simple and crisp, but one-dimensional.
Wine: Coleman 2015 Cherry Cove Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Wisps of lime and tangerine in the aroma lead to some riper richer flavors in this medium-bodied and soft-textured wine. It has light butter and vanilla accents and low acidity.
Wine: Jessie's Grove 2017 Jessie's Collection Estate Grown Steel Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas pop, with notes of mandarin orange, fresh flower, musk, herb and ale. It drinks medium-plus sweet—a surefire crowd-pleaser.
Wine: Maryhill 2017 Moscato di Canelli Gunkel Vineyards Moscato (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: Restrained aromas of citrus, apple peel and limestone carry to the immensely zesty palate. Electric acidity carries from start to finish, ending on a sour lime note.
Wine: Paumanok 2017 Dry Chenin Blanc (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an old field blend of Zinfandel, Petite Sirah, Carignan, Cinsault and Grenache, cofermented together and aged nearly two years in French oak, a small percentage of it new. The wine is thick in muddled red fruit and possessed of a soft rich texture.
Wine: Spicy Vines 2015 Edge Red (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Big, oaky and already well aged, this full-bodied wine has plenty of structure filled in with spicy cedary aromas and vanilla and black-cherry flavors. Firm tannins give it a hefty mouthfeel.
Wine: Winery by the Creek 2015 Le Grand Vin Red (Fair Play)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A mild concentration of crisp yellow apple and pear melds with floral spice and canned peach on the nose and palate. Light in profile, this has a mild lift of acidity and a soft, savory finish.
Wine: Stony Lonesome 2016 Estate Reserve Gewürztraminer (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: You'll have to look closely to spot the Gemini designation on the front label, that differentiates this from the estate's Trouble cuvée. Leathery aromas and flavors dominate, along with sweet grape candy, but then the bitter tannins take over.
Wine: A Blooming Hill Vineyard 2016 Gemini Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The so-called Bunny Cuvée refers to the unnamed front label graphic of a rabbit, which adorns this new series of inexpensive Coelho wines. This is as light as a feather, with scents of mushrooms and flavors of salmonberry.
Wine: Coelho 2016 Bunny Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: This spontaneous ferment Chenin offers aromas of sauced apples and pears on the nose. Light in feel, the palate is straightforward in nature, displaying spiced tree fruit flavors carried along by a healthy vein of acidity.
Wine: Paumanok 2016 Minimalist Chenin Blanc (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Petaluma Gap, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine doesn't taste fully integrated, its marriage of fruit, oak and tannin still elbowing each other for space. The aromas are earthy and tinged in a flash of forest.
Wine: Burt Street Cellars 2016 Stony Point Vineyard Pinot Noir (Petaluma Gap)

Appellation: Game of Thrones
Review: Whether Game of Thrones watchers are Pinot Noir lovers remains to be seen, but this utterly ordinary, vanilla-soaked wine is not likely to make any converts. It was vinted and bottled in Hopland, California, from purchased Oregon fruit. Sweet berry, cocoa and vanilla flavors combine in a syrupy wine that bears little resemblance to mainstream Oregon Pinot Noir.
Wine: Game of Thrones 2016 Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Dramatic oaky aromas and flavors make this estate-grown wine a bit of a one-note song, as wood smoke and black pepper dominate. It is full bodied, moderately tannic and has a mouth-filling texture.
Wine: LangeTwins 2015 River Ranch Vineyard Montepulciano (Lodi)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Vanilla, tire rubber, char and cherry aromas are followed by ripe black fruit flavors with a lightly tacky feel. The tannins give a squeeze. It finishes warm.
Wine: Marshall Davis 2015 Seven Hills Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon makes up just over half of this wine, with the balance being Cabernet Franc, Merlot, Malbec and Petit Verdot. Dried herb, graphite and cherry candy aromas are followed by somewhat woody, straightforward fruit flavors.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Serendipity Proprietor's Reserve Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Original House Wine
Review: Aromas of green herb, sweet black currant and sugared plum are followed by lightly sweet fruit flavors. It's a straightforward, easy drinker.
Wine: Original House Wine 2016 Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This blends 52% Petit Verdot with 48% Zinfandel for an intensely tannic expression of dried herb and clove that overwhelms.
Wine: Paraduxx 2015 Rector Creek Block 4 Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Fairly rich and ripe tasting, this medium-bodied wine has strong oak aromas and flavors that register as cedar, tobacco, dill and pine. It is light in terms of tannin and acidity, has a touch of sweetness and feels very smooth in texture.
Wine: Sobon Estate 2015 Red A Premium Red (Amador County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: It's not clear what happened here, other than that the vegetal aromas and flavors suggest unripe fruit in the mix. The wine spent 14 months in 30% new oak, which can be detected in a certain toasty component, but sticks out from the herbal/vegetal core like a sore thumb. Maybe more bottle aging will smooth it over a bit.
Wine: Coelho 2016 Paciência Coelho Estate Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Lorimar
Review: Blatant oak aromas and flavors dominate whatever fruit flavors might lie underneath. It smells sweet and spicy, tastes spicy and has moderate tannins and high alcohol.
Wine: Lorimar 2015 Red (California)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This is a fruity, soft-textured and sweet wine with cherry and raspberry flavors. The mouthfeel is rich and plush and the acidity is quite low.
Wine: Naggiar 2017 Estate Rosé (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This wine is very fruity, smooth and polished, showing light oaky touches on ripe plum and black-cherry flavors that finish on the sweet side. The texture is soft and acidity feels low.
Wine: Trentadue 2016 Old Patch Red (California)

Appellation: Bedell
Review: Quiet tones of white flowers and citrus carry the nose and palate. This is a simple, straightforward white that would appeal to those looking for a light, crisp refresher.
Wine: Bedell 2016 Viognier (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Creamy thick with a candied midpalate of watermelon Jolly Rancher and strawberry jam, this has elements of dried herb and jalapeño.
Wine: Kenwood 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Ripe peach and apple aromas are out front, followed by whiffs of tropical fruit. The palate brings dried apple flavors with a lightly smoky finish.
Wine: Maryhill 2017 Tudor Hills Vineyards Pinot Gris (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This blends 67% Syrah with 33% Malbec to powerful effect. The wine is thick in nondescript red berry and blueberry notes and oaky tannin.
Wine: Spann Vineyards 2014 S & M Syrah-Malbec (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Cayuga Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A straightforward nose of citrus and orchard fruit carries to the delicately semidry palate. It's light in feel, with quiet impressions of apple, lemon and stone.
Wine: Treleaven 2016 Estate Bottled Semi-Dry Riesling (Cayuga Lake)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This is a light and lightly sweet wine that looks like a dark rosé, smells very fruity and tastes like cherry juice. It is simple and soft: something to please people who don't like dry wines.
Wine: Sepal Estate 2017 Soft Red (California)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: A strong aroma of cedar wood and fresh-cut oak lead to smoky cranberry, blackberry and wood-ash flavors and a flood of tannins. The wine is deep in color and aggressive in flavor.
Wine: French Bar 2016 Gold Dust Red (California)

Appellation: Bedell
Review: Faint aromas of citrus are covered by a bit of a soapy floral tone. Light in body and concentration, apple skin and citrus flavors are met with a mild vein of acidity.
Wine: Bedell 2016 Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: A mild nose of citrus and creamed corn carries to the medium-bodied palate. The flavors are fresher in nature, with broad citrus and melon carried by a soft vein of acidity.
Wine: Lieb 2017 Bridge Lane Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Maryhill
Review: The aromas don't seem entirely settled at present, showing some reductive notes. The palate is light, tart and tangy. It doesn't stand up on its own but might have a place at the dinner table, though the listed alcohol seems a bit high for that as well.
Wine: Maryhill 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 28% Cabernet Franc and 12% Merlot is very extracted on the nose with strong blackberry, pepper, roasted beef and balsamic aromas. It's tart and tangy on the palate, with a hint of black plum and mint chocolate chip.
Wine: Millésimé 2012 Bleu Saphir Red (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Merlot, Zinfandel, Petite Sirah and Syrah all make it into this moderately ripe blend, which is aged under a year in American oak. Herbal with a taste of black and red currant, it finishes with a mouthful of tannin.
Wine: Pedroncelli 2016 Barrel Select Classico Red (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: You'll have to look closely to spot the Trouble designation on the front label, which differentiates this from the estate's Gemini cuvée. There are mousy scents and flavors, some blackberry fruit, and a funky finish with sour tannins.
Wine: A Blooming Hill Vineyard 2016 Trouble Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Green aromas like pine needles and celery are followed by rather tangy apple and herb flavors in this medium-bodied, basic and refreshing wine.
Wine: Collier Creek 2016 Front Coach Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A sharp, strong and pervasive scent of some feral animal aroma takes away much of the potential pleasure here. There's cherry fruit as well, but the finish is short and muted. Two bottles were tasted with the same results.
Wine: Soléna 2016 Guadalupe Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This soft but full-bodied wine smells like maple syrup and brown sugar and tastes ripe, almost sweet, due to low acidity and plenty of oak treatment.
Wine: Gen5 2016 Ancestral Red (California)

Appellation: Melt
Review: This wine is buttery all the way through. It starts with an aroma of buttered popcorn, proceeds to Butterfinger candy flavors and has an almost sweet finish. Not for dry wine diehards, but it's a fun thing to sample.
Wine: Melt 2016 Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from Cabernet Sauvignon, Malbec, Syrah, Zinfandel and Graciano, all stainless-steel fermented, this wine is earthy and rough, with a diluted palate of peach fuzz and blueberry.
Wine: Simi 2017 Dry Rosé (Sonoma County)

Appellation: David Bruce
Review: This wine is creamy and hugely oaky, with a sweetness of candied marshmallow.
Wine: David Bruce 2016 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Braised green pepper, herb and tar aromas are followed by lightly sweet plum flavors. It's extremely green for the variety.
Wine: Original House Wine 2016 Mountain Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Winery by the Creek
Review: Earthy aromas and herbal, iron-like flavors of mineral and tomato highlight this medium-bodied, lightly tannic and mature wine.
Wine: Winery by the Creek 2012 Sangiovese (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: An intensely perfumed nose of grapefruit, white grape juice and candied lime zest turn more confected in nature the more you swirl. Immensely punchy on the palate, a flavor reminiscent of Pixy Stix offers a sweet-tart nature to the wine, ending on a sweet white grape finish.
Wine: Agness 2016 Semi-Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Millésimé
Review: Extremely extracted aromas of blackberry juice veer toward vinegar on the nose of this bottling. That balsamic aspect dominates the palate.
Wine: Millésimé 2014 Malbec (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A savory nose of nuts and smoke masks much of the fruit, yet the palate offers a bit more life with a juicy citrus core. This rounded in feel, with a tense line of acidity hiding behind that weight.
Wine: Heron Hill 2017 Unoaked Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Millésimé
Review: Extremely extracted and concentrated aromas of cherry syrup and grenadine show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is sweet and syrupy with cherry-balsamic flavors.
Wine: Millésimé 2014 Merlot (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Hound's Tree
Review: An oddly floral nose carries to an overripe, flabby palate. This is low-energy in feel, with flavors of pineapple and melon.
Wine: Hound's Tree 2016 Chardonnay (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of equal parts Morrison and Copeland vineyards. Aromas of lees, custard and butter are followed by lightly styled, herb and wilted flower flavors that taper on the finish. It doesn't all come off.
Wine: MCM Wine Co. 2017 Marveluxe Chardonnay (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Sagelands
Review: Aromas of lees, bruised apple and pear are followed by light, sleek fruit flavors with a tart finish.
Wine: Sagelands 2017 Pinot Gris (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 54% Merlot, 38% Cabernet Franc and 8% Cabernet Sauvignon is extremely dense and yet tangy on the nose, and cloudy in the glass. The palate is overly tangy and muddy.
Wine: Millésimé 2012 Lumiere Du Fleur Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Simi
Review: Reductive and sulfurous, this wine tastes of big oak, baked pineapple and hazelnut.
Wine: Simi 2016 Chardonnay (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Very light hints of strawberry fruit are more or less masked with high-toned aromas of nail polish. There's a gluey streak running through the wine and on into the finish.
Wine: Cathedral Ridge 2015 Dampier Vineyard Pinot Noir (Columbia Gorge (OR))

Appellation: Game of Thrones
Review: Whether Game of Thrones watchers are Pinot Noir lovers remains to be seen, but this utterly ordinary, vanilla-soaked wine is not likely to make any converts. It was vinted and bottled in Hopland, California, from purchased Oregon fruit. Sweet berry, cocoa and vanilla flavors combine in a syrupy wine that bears little resemblance to mainstream Oregon Pinot Noir.
Wine: Game of Thrones 2016 Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Dramatic oaky aromas and flavors make this estate-grown wine a bit of a one-note song, as wood smoke and black pepper dominate. It is full bodied, moderately tannic and has a mouth-filling texture.
Wine: LangeTwins 2015 River Ranch Vineyard Montepulciano (Lodi)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
