Review: A freshly sawn oak aroma and equally oaky flavors make this wine a one-note song. It is medium bodied and reasonably smooth in texture.
Wine: Leese-Fitch 2016 Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: From a single vineyard, this white is given six months to chill in stainless steel. It tastes concentrated and full, with an overt tartness to the underlying acidity.
Wine: Pestoni Family 2017 Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Rutherford)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas bring notes of cherry, exotic spice and whiffs of tire rubber. The cherry and cranberry flavors are tart and tangy, trailing on the back half with the tannins giving a light grip.
Wine: Spoken Barrel 2015 Bold & Complex #42 Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Wilson Creek
Review: Sweet aromas of peach and apple syrup show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is also quite sweet with fizzy lime-zest flavors than fall flat rather quickly.
Wine: Wilson Creek 2017 Riesling (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Creekside Cellars
Review: A rich white apricot aroma wafts from the glass. The palate starts ripe, with juicy flavors of donut peach, but quickly rushes into a bitter, pithy finish with white pepper spice and spoiled clementine.
Wine: Creekside Cellars 2016 Viognier (Colorado)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This wine tastes fully mature, with aromas like balsamic and cedar, and flavors that are more earthy and leathery than fruity.
Wine: Naggiar 2014 Nightshade Red (California)

Appellation: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey
Review: This straight-forward Syrah displays aromas of mulberry, cranberry, sweet oak and vanilla. The palate turns medicinal, with flavors of cherry and mixed berry tinged with menthol and touches of vanilla and cedar. Mild-mannered acidity is in balance with tannins that seem to settle on the tip of tongue, carrying some spice before slipping into the uninspired finish offering more of the same.
Wine: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey 2015 Syrah (America)
Winery: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey

Appellation: Eagle Foothills, Idaho, US
Review: Reduced out of the gate, it's a bit of a challenge to get at the varietal aromas. The flavors of lees, pear and star fruit provide intrigue, tapering toward the finish, with the concentration overall seeming a bit light.
Wine: 3 Horse Ranch Vineyards 2016 Single Vineyard Chardonnay (Eagle Foothills)

Appellation: Briceland
Review: This is a decent-quality wine that shows mild apple and canteloupe flavors, a rather soft texture and medium body.
Wine: Briceland 2017 Pinot Gris (Humboldt County)

Appellation: Kirkland Signature
Review: There's no question of the variety, with its notes of dried and fresh herb along with green pepper. The cherry flavors are light, with the tannins bringing a lightly gritty feel.
Wine: Kirkland Signature 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Randolph
Review: Aromas of baking spice, vanilla and anise are followed by sweet, lightly chalky-feeling fruit flavors. Coffee notes linger on the very warm finish. The oak influence is primary, making the sense of place hard to find.
Wine: Randolph 2015 Syrah (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A sweetness of vanilla is highlighted from the oak in this candied, fleshy and simple wine that finishes in a burst of overripe heat.
Wine: Spicy Vines 2015 Zin Master Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Washington, Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: The aromas are surprisingly light for the variety, seeming hard to get at. The palate seems light and dilute, with the flavors appearing washed out.
Wine: Washington Hills 2016 Dry Riesling (Washington)

Appellation: Washington, Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: Strong aromas of green pepper, herb and currant lead to quite lightly styled fruit flavors. It all seems quite underripe.
Wine: Charles Smith 2016 Velvet Devil Merlot (Washington)

Appellation: Creekside Cellars
Review: This Syrah shows aromas of campfire, charred meats and beef jerky, with red currant and violet laced around the edges. Any intrigue on the nose belies the flat palate that brings vanilla, green tobacco leaves and oak, with ripe red berries adding the only hint of life. Drying tannins are flavorless for the most part, building towards the finish and hinting at spice at its peek before sliding into the astringent dried-cranberry finish.
Wine: Creekside Cellars 2015 Syrah (Colorado)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: A blend of 80% Malbec and 20% Syrah, strong scents of vanilla, coconut shavings, green pepper, white pepper and dried cherry are followed by quite light fruit flavors that trail on the finish. There's not enough fruit to stand up to the oak.
Wine: Elsom 2011 Logan Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is unduly green and chalky on the palate, with a disjointed approach to acidity. Full bodied and robust, it struggles to maintain structure.
Wine: Kenwood 2014 Six Ridges Merlot (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Bumble & Boom
Review: Aromas of fruit cocktail, herb and plastic are followed by medium-sweet fruit flavors. The concentration seems quite light.
Wine: Bumble & Boom 2016 Riesling (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Cuda Ridge Wines
Review: Extreme aromas of garlic and onions lead to crisp lemon and garlic flavors that push the envelope of acceptability, but may suit some people's taste buds.
Wine: Cuda Ridge Wines 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Petaluma Gap, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This dry lean wine is medium bodied and has a sunbaked mature character. The fruit aromas and flavors are minimal, conceding to dusty dry-earth notes.
Wine: Kendric 2016 Proprietor Grown Pinot Noir (Petaluma Gap)

Appellation: Duck Pond
Review: The aromas bring a slightly tinny note that distracts. The palate seems to fall flat, without the concentration or structure to hold it together.
Wine: Duck Pond 2017 Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Quite light aromas lead to washed-out-seeming fruit flavors. The variety and vintage are hard to place.
Wine: Desert Wind 2017 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Oak Grove
Review: This is a drinkable but very bland wine showing almost neutral flavors, low alcohol and a soft texture.
Wine: Oak Grove 2017 Pinot Grigio (California)

Appellation: Grande River
Review: High-toned aromas of black cherry and blackberry dominate nose, with tones of rose, black pepper, herbs and vanilla in the background. This wine attacks the palate with metallic flavors of copper pennies, hickory and extremely underripe cranberry. Sharp and lacking in structue, dusty tannins make an appearance on the finish attempting to reign in the matallic and tart berry notes, but are ultimately outmatched.
Wine: Grande River 2015 Syrah (Grand Valley)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Once again, this is a standout wine. The Etzel block flavors are anchored in a deep core of black-cherry fruit, that dives into supporting notes of dark chocolate. The balance is exceptional, as is the length, with highlights of apple and orange.
Wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2016 Estate Vineyard Etzel Block Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: St. Helena, Napa, California, US
Review: This bold wine is the flagship of winemaker Pam Starr's small fleet. It boasts dramatic, dark-fruit flavors, a firm muscular structure of fine-grained tannins and subtle acidity and great length on the finish. The palate layers dark chocolate on blueberry and black cherry. It will be a minor shame to drink it before 10 years. Best from 2024–2034.
Wine: Crocker & Starr 2015 1 Post Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Here is top-tier Oregon fruit perfectly handled, so as to express place, variety and winemaker in equal balance. Tree fruits and apple skins, buoyed by a mouthfeel accented with creamy lees, follow up with a light pat of butter. The distinguishing minerality of past vintages is here as well, and as good as ever.
Wine: Bergström 2016 Sigrid Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Nutty and tart in acidity, this is complex in flavors of Granny Smith apple, lime and tangerine. The texture on the palate is lush yet structured in acidity, which gives this wine cellar-worthy potential. Enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2015 Westside Farms Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This offers concentrated flavors of fig, blueberry jam, blackberry and cassis. The tannins are ripe and polished, and the wine finishes strong, with notes of dark chocolate and baking spices.
Wine: Quady North 2014 Mae's Vineyard Flagship Syrah (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: St. Helena, Napa, California, US
Review: Rich and layered but not at all heavy, this beautifully polished estate-grown wine is made from the property's oldest vines. A taste starts with perfumed light oak spices in the aroma, wraps ripe black-cherry, blueberry and cola flavors around the palate and finishes with a moderate bite of tannin to carry the lingering cherry and baking spices. Best after 2024.
Wine: Crocker & Starr 2015 Stone Place Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Aromatically arresting, this mixes scents of mineral, steel, cinnamon and cranberry, moving into those flavors and adding much more. Hints of baking spices, and juicy acids that taste naturally of orange peel, lemonade and pineapple, keep layering on additional flavors. Drink 2020–2030.
Wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Coury Clone Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose on this luxury-level bottling is pure and refreshing, offering aromas of black cherry, loamy soil, dried mint and caramel-laced coffee. The palate is framed by upright tannins, yet is soft enough to enjoy now, showing deep flavors of black currant, dried herb, milk chocolate and toffee. Drink 2020–2040.
Wine: J. Lohr 2015 Signature Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Named after Jim and Mary Dierberg's grandson, this is part of a new reserve series, and the extra attention shows. Lush and candied aromas of red cherry, star anise and vanilla are lavish but focused and not overripe. The palate dries up a tad, adding lavender, violet, pepper and bergamot to the red fruit mix, proving extremely elegant and memorable.
Wine: Dierberg 2015 Steven Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Floral, reduced and mineral-driven, this blockbuster wine is tremendously complex and memorable. White peach, pineapple and white flowers intermingle with ease as teases of fennel, dried herb and ginger come to the fore. The oak lingers in wisps of salty caramel.
Wine: Arista 2015 Ritchie Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is an utterly delicious bottle—complex and sophisticated, it walks a flavor tightrope, carefully balancing crisp touches of lemon, lime, grapefruit, apple and pear with refreshing minerality. A lingering textural finish layers in citrus rind, cucumber and lemon curd.
Wine: Big Table Farm 2016 Elusive Queen Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Freshly pressed blackberry and açaí aromas meet with lilac and a touch of licorice powder on the nose of this bottling, which is bolstered by 13% Petite Sirah. The palate is loaded with black currant, blueberry and black-cherry flavors and finished on a hint of caramel and roasted plum, all wrapped in chalky tannins. Drink 2020–2031.
Wine: Levo 2016 E-99 No. 2 Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Another truly exceptional Chardonnay from Maison Jadot's Oregon project, this explosively aromatic wine offers a seamless mash-up of citrus, tree fruits and lemon verbena. Lighter suggestions of beeswax and a dash of pepper follow in succession through a finish with balance, length and precision.
Wine: Résonance 2016 Hyland Vineyard Chardonnay (McMinnville)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly woven on the nose, this single-vineyard expression shows aromas of Meyer lemon pith, tangerine spray, lime zest and almond cream. The palate is fresh and zesty in lime and grapefruit flavors, but a backdrop of smooth nut butter and poached nectarine brings it all together.
Wine: Roar 2016 Soberanes Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Baked cranberry, cherry, clove, vanilla bean and mossy earth show on the nose of this always much anticipated bottling from the region's first cult producer. The palate is tangy with rounded black-plum, star anise and black-peppercorn flavors. It's excellent now, but those tart elements will find more integration with patience. Drink 2019–2035.
Wine: Sea Smoke 2015 Ten Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Lavish black cherry makes for a very focused but rich nose on this bottling, which is enhanced with aromas of vanilla wafer, tart black plum skins and polished purple flowers. There's a breezy lightness to the palate at first, yet it shows powerful flavors of black plum, violet and baking spice, all riding a pretty ripping acidity.
Wine: Cattleya 2016 Cuvée Number One Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's a strong sense of tight black currant that's ready to pop on the nose of this bottling of Cabernet Sauvignon and Petit Verdot. The spice and mineral aspects are strong too, with aromas of black pepper, beef char, gravel and lava rock. The palate is dense in both charred and fresh dark-fruit flavors, finishing on a light touch of cocoa powder.
Wine: Daou 2015 Eye of the Falcon Reserve Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Pale copper orange in color, this is a tremendously delicious and thirst-quenching contemplation of 100% Grenache, whole-cluster pressed and fermented in both stainless steel and neutral oak. Lemon, grapefruit peel and green apple mingle around bristling, beautifully integrated acidity and a lasting burst of strawberry.
Wine: Hudson Vineyards 2017 Estate Grown Grenache Rosé (Carneros)

Appellation: Massican
Review: Floral and stony, this impressively complex and memorable white has a thirst-quenching grasp of gravelly minerality, a core element built around bold, beautiful flavors of fig, Meyer lemon and tangerine.
Wine: Massican 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose of this bottling is extremely compelling and layered, showing red cherry, pomegranate, crushed gravel, juniper, thyme and cracked white pepper. The delicate yet flavorful palate combines tangy fruit with earthy herbs, pepper spices and a woody hint of mescal.
Wine: Rideau 2016 La Encantada Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Mansfield-Dunne
Review: This appellation blend is better than the winery's single-vineyard expressions, at least right now. On the nose, loads of chaparral spice play against the cranberry, mulberry and roasted tomato backdrop, enhanced with a touch of shiitake mushroom. The palate packs strong sagebrush and eucalyptus flavors with salted plum fruits.
Wine: Mansfield-Dunne 2016 Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: These vines, planted in 1990, are the oldest for this variety in the Willamette Valley. At first the wine shows a textbook style, with vivid acidity and a luxurious mix of citrus fruits, with an emphasis on Key lime and grapefruit. But it continues to expand with hours of breathing time, adding flesh and detail, until finally it most resembles a dry Sauternes, complete with a lovely streak of honeysuckle.
Wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2016 Estate Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This concentrated and detailed wine brings black cherry, mocha and cinnamon toast flavors together on the precise palate. Fine-grained tannins provide the scaffolding for a long finish, with a pleasing lick of chocolate.
Wine: Raptor Ridge 2015 Shea Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This has proven to be a sensational site for Willamette Valley Riesling, and good as the dry version is, it blossoms into full glory with a bit of residual sugar. A fruit bowl of Meyer lemons and ripe peaches, it's dusted with powdered sugar and brings cotton candy highlights together in a strikingly delicious bottle.
Wine: Trisaetum 2017 Ribbon Ridge Estate Riesling (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Velvety and intense, this powerful wine shines in black raspberry, strawberry and a crispness of blood orange, melding the flavors together seamlessly into one whole. Rose petal aromas dot the landscape and add a floral component that complements the integrated Asian spice.
Wine: Della 2016 Graham Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Lemon peel, tangerine and grapefruit mark the entry of this bright, focused white, filled with tension and gravelly texture. Lithe in spirit, it holds on to plenty of underlying richness and concentration, finding balance within an undeniable embrace of power.
Wine: Flanagan 2016 Bacigalupi Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted black cherry, caramel, vanilla, coffee, cola and toasted oak all show on the inviting, lush and layered nose of this Cabernet Franc-led blend. The lush yet appropriately edgy palate combines black cherry, dark chocolate and violet flavors. It's soft in texture, but structured by enduring tannins and ample acidity.
Wine: J. Lohr 2014 Cuvée St. E Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Arista
Review: Soft, seductive and focused, this best of the best from the appellation is lengthy and complex, with tension on the palate. Dark cherry, wild cinnamon, crushed rock and black tea mingle effortlessly around a rich, dense roundness that never loses its balance or sense of delicious purpose.
Wine: Arista 2015 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Mt. Harlan, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep and meaty on the nose, this 40th anniversary bottling offers black plum, dried violet and roasted meat aromas. Mulberry, strawberry and plum flavors show on the wild palate, which is lifted by elements of pine needle, dried sage and mint.
Wine: Calera 2015 de Villiers Fortieth Anniversary Vintage Pinot Noir (Mt. Harlan)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This series of Syrahs by Bret Urness is an ode to vineyard owner Brook Williams, and this cool-climate expression is lovely, showing white pepper, dried purple flowers and boysenberry on the nose. The palate is jammy and candied in the background, but the foreground is all pepper, acid and florals, like sipping liquefied lavender and violets with a pinch of white pepper.
Wine: Levo 2016 Spot Duvarita Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Baked black-cherry and plum aromas meet with star anise, hot gingerbread and wet slate on the fairly opulent, very delicious nose of this bottling. It's more tightly wound on the palate, where cherry and black raspberry are lifted by baking spice. It's the pitch perfect acidity and tannic edge that are most impressive.
Wine: Dierberg 2015 Dierberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Thick, concentrated and rich, this vineyard-designate from the famous Oakville site is grippy on the midpalate, with a juicy backbone of black cherry and blackberry. A huge thread of crushed rock-like minerality sparkles through the finish.
Wine: Poetic Justice 2015 Beckstoffer To Kalon Vineyard Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This an edgy grippy wine from the heart of the appellation's Middle Reach. Dense and spicy, it has a sharpness to the palate that presents as full bodied and fairly tannic, etched in lengths of citrus, forest floor, cardamom and dark, brooding cherry.
Wine: Arista 2015 Harper's Rest Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: With an array of butter and cream elements on the nose, this bottling shows just enough richness to appease many Chardonnay fans, but not so much to overwhelm those seeking a brighter, lemony edge. It's crisp and clean on the palate, where butter takes a backseat to tangy lemon and mandarin orange flavors, with light crème brûlée on the finish.
Wine: Roar 2016 Sierra Mar Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Crisp black-plum and mulberry aromas meet with wild mint, baked earth and rosemary on the extremely elegant nose of this bottling by veteran Stephen Ross Dooley. There is a strong herbal kick to the palate of oregano and marjoram, but also floral hints of lavender and violets, all decorating the dark fruit in the background.
Wine: Stephen Ross 2015 Stone Corral Vineyard Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This blends three different cuvées—one in stainless steel, one in acacia barrel, and one in concrete egg. It's a deft bit of finessing the grape, adding layers of texture and minerality without diluting the varietal character. Herb and citrus components are perfectly balanced, and the wine has exceptional length.
Wine: J. Christopher 2016 Croft Vineyard Über-Sauvignon Sauvignon Blanc (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This unfiltered wine is spicy in ginger and nutmeg tones. It is completely intriguing in its combination of wet stone, tangy acidity and exotic spice tones. It sings in toasted oak and a wealth of concentrated apple and pear.
Wine: Jarvis 2016 Finch Hollow Estate Grown Cave Fermented Unfiltered Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Lombardi
Review: Robust in peach, apple and integrated oak, the flavors are well integrated and richly woven together, with bright underlying acidity helping to maintain freshness and focus. The brightness is met and complemented by a lingering taste of crème brûlée and vanilla.
Wine: Lombardi 2016 Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Lombardi
Review: Griffin's Lair and Sonoma Stage Vineyards, both within the new Petaluma Gap, provide the fruit for this stellar, smoothly textured, well-integrated red. High in acidity, it tastes of citrus and wild strawberry, with a lasting tease of black licorice.
Wine: Lombardi 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve-level selection is aged in 100% new French oak, and sports a green label that sets it apart from most of the winery's other Pinots. It's fairly tannic at first sip, and strongly scented with cinnamon toast, espresso and char. It's quite different from the more elegant wines elsewhere in the Patricia Green portfolio, with fruit bordering on blackberry jam, and plenty of baking spice highlights. Hold off a couple more years or decant aggressively if drinking sooner.
Wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2016 Notorious Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yountville, Napa, California, US
Review: Dark and inky, this is a burly wine, jammy to the core. Floral aromas meet spicy leather and white pepper alongside a strong streak of rosemary, recalling roast lamb, a pairing with which it would succeed.
Wine: Rocca 2014 Grigsby Vineyard Syrah (Yountville)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Light gold and subtly scented with hints of toasted coconut and olive oil, these vines date back to Eyrie's founding in the 1960s. It's rich, round and smooth, with ripe flavors of bruised apple and Bosch pear. A touch of white pepper enlivens the finish, along with a hint of minerality. Drink now through mid-2020s.
Wine: The Eyrie Vineyards 2016 Original Vines Chardonnay (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Chalone, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light rosewater, strawberry and cherry-juice aromas meet with rounded star anise and baking spice on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. There is great chalky tension to the palate and a ripping acidity, framing flavors of red fruit, orange rind and, on the finish, vanilla paste.
Wine: Betwixt 2016 Boer Vineyard Grenache (Chalone)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Snappy black raspberry, baked cherry and fragrant boysenberry are lifted by a touch of fennel on the nose of this bottling. Full flavors of smashed berry, sweet thyme and peppery spice show on the palate, which makes for a very big and powerful yet clean and fresh wine.
Wine: Cattleya 2016 Donum Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a bit of a sleeper vineyard—an exceptional site rarely featured outside of its home winery. Here it delivers the expected goods: a lush mix of blueberries, plums and cherries. Ample baking spices add more layers of flavor, the tannins are supple and polished, and the wine is already drinking like a dream.
Wine: King Estate 2015 Antiquum Farm Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a big, thick vintage for this vineyard select. It's lively and detailed, with a creamy mouthfeel. Tastes of caramel apples and apple-pie spices combine with a lightly buttery finish to make this virtually irresistible.
Wine: Lange 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Smoke, blood, roasted berries, crushed rose petals and clove show on the dynamic nose of this single-vineyard expression. Rounded flavors of mulberry, star anise and clove show on the palate, which grows even more complex toward the finish with roasted tomato and meat elements.
Wine: Mansfield-Dunne 2016 Peterson Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This may be the best white wine in Paso Robles, starting with powerfully chalky aromas of Gala apple and freshly plucked sweet herbs. It's zesty on the palate, with key lime and red-grapefruit flavors, all riding a laser-sharp acidity and a tremendously chalky grip.
Wine: Paix Sur Terre 2017 Kiler Grove Vineyard Ugni Blanc (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This value offering is also the winery's biggest production, and displays the same detail-oriented care as every other Pinot in the extensive lineup. Many winemakers work with Freedom Hill fruit, and this winery offers no less than four different bottlings from the vineyard. Here the bright raspberry fruit is showcased in such a way that every last nuance is on parade, seamlessly integrated with barrel notes of chocolate and coffee.
Wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Exceptionally rich, this off-dry wine offers honeyed, candied citrus fruits in a concentrated, almost decadent style. Tangerine and Key lime flavors abound, and the sweetness, though balanced against ample acidity, puts this close to dessert-wine quality. It's as decadently delicious a Pinot Gris as you'll find from anywhere in Oregon.
Wine: Seekseekqua 2017 Waldo Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: As in previous vintages, this young wine comes ready to drink with exceptional texture and mouthfeel. Apple butter, toast, roasted nuts, wet stone and a hint of popcorn are threaded together, in a lovely lively bottle with excellent length. Drink now and over the next half decade.
Wine: Shea 2016 Shea Vineyard Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Monterey, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling from a vineyard planted in 1982 shows aromas of buttered toast, lemon preserves and marmalade. There is a flash of lemon sorbet on the palate, which is surrounded by warm, oaky flavors, proving both savory and refreshing.
Wine: Talbott 2016 Diamond T Vineyard Estate Grown Chardonnay (Monterey)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Yummy Pommard strikes again, as this wine opens immediately into ripe round tangy berry fruit, backed with juicy acids. There's a touch of freshly cut apple as an added highlight, and the wine moves gracefully across and down the palate into an extended finish. The best drinking is yet to come: enjoy 2020–2030.
Wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2016 Freedom Hill Vineyard Pommard Clone Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Washington, Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: The aromas are thoroughly enchanting, with notes of peach, clarified butter, candle wax, mineral, chamomile and lemon rind. It's full bodied and textured, full of stone-fruit flavors with a tropical-fruit-filled finish.
Wine: Sixto 2015 Moxee Chardonnay (Washington)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This smooth, full-flavored, indulgent wine from a noted single vineyard adds baking spice top notes to a generous pear and apple base and builds a splash of savory minerality on the midpalate and finish. It is medium to full in body, mouth-filling and creamy.
Wine: Ten Acre 2015 Ritchie Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: One of a trio of Chardonnays from Trisaetum, this opens with a pretty floral top note, then continues in a richly fragrant vein. It mixes flavors of toasted nuts and apple pie with light hints of olive oil and fresh cream. Detailed and forceful, it's a beautifully proportioned and captivating wine.
Wine: Trisaetum 2016 Ribbon Ridge Estate Chardonnay (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is done in a medium-dry style, which translates into a mellow mix of ripe citrus, apple and peach with tart acidity still sharpening the edges. A wash of orange pekoe tea fills out the finish.
Wine: Trisaetum 2017 Wichmann Dundee Estate Riesling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Quite light in the glass, this bottling starts with tense aromas of fresh melon, chalk, Meyer lemon pith and chilled peach. There is a great chalky texture to the palate, where honeysuckle, ripe nectarine, tangerine and plum-flesh flavors make for a very tasty Chardonnay.
Wine: Zotovich 2016 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Suisun Valley, North Coast, California, US
Review: Quite an eye-opener, this bold, full-bodied wine is black in color with a dark-ruby rim, offers powerful dark-fruit aromas and opulent fruit and spice flavors. While labeled as a red blend, it has more than enough Cabernet Sauvignon to be a varietal wine. The concentration level is high enough that hints of blueberry, dark chocolate, blackberry jam and charcoal keep evolving on the finish.
Wine: GrapeHeart Vineyards 2013 The Beat Red (Suisun Valley)

Appellation: Mt. Harlan, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This was a tough vintage for the winery's 40th anniversary, amounting to just over a half-ton an acre from this vineyard, but the results are stunning. Aromas of cranberry compote, smoked pork, crushed slate, pine needle and roasted tomato lead into a clean palate of mulberry, red plum, white pepper and sumac.
Wine: Calera 2015 Reed Vineyard Fortieth Anniversary Vintage Pinot Noir (Mt. Harlan)

Appellation: Chappellet
Review: A tropical tease of guava permeates before citrusy green apple and cinnamon brioche introduce themselves on the midpalate in this well-made, memorable wine. The oak is subtle and well-integrated, allowing plenty of room for the freshness of lasting, vibrant acidity to take indelible hold.
Wine: Chappellet 2016 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: An opulent plush texture and luxurious flavors like those in a pear tart give more than enough personality to this full-bodied barrel-fermented wine. It has a mouth-filling presence, subtle oak accents and a surplus of richness in the pear, toasted almond and cream flavors. It will be delicious paired like to like with a buttery seafood dish or even osso buco.
Wine: Covenant 2017 The Tribe Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose of this impressive bottling is laced with both tangy fruit and rocky minerality, ranging from dark strawberry and morello cherry to crushed slate and dark-violet aromas. The energetic palate bursts with black raspberry and exotic dark plum, lifted by star anise, clove, waves of acidity and squeaky tannins. Drink 2019–2034.
Wine: Grassini 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Thick, rich and meaty, this is a dry, layered and balanced wine, textured in citrus peel and dark cherry. It shows off the variety and the vineyard, allowing room for an exotic complexity to speak and last on the finish.
Wine: Kobler 2017 Kobler Family Vineyard Rosé of Syrah (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded black plum and concentrated purple flowers make for a somewhat fruity although inviting entry to this blend of 56% Petit Verdot, 18% Cabernet Sauvignon, 18% Merlot and 8% Malbec. Boysenberry-juice flavors show on the palate, which is surprisingly lighter weight.
Wine: Paradise Springs 2015 The Roshi Red (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Pessimist
Review: Dense blueberry, purple-flower and caramel aromas are laid across a rocky gravelly minerality on the nose of this red blend. Fruity blueberry flavors meet with more bitter espresso beans on the palate, which benefits from well-layered tannins.
Wine: Pessimist 2015 Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Unusually low in alcohol for such a hot vintage, this vineyard designate is tart and sharp-toned. The berry-fruit flavors are set amidst lightly green-tea tannins and a gently earthy finish. The overall balance and composition make this a valuable and versatile wine for lighter entrées.
Wine: R. Stuart & Co. 2015 Lazy River Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Silver
Review: Dried carnations, tangy red fruit and a fruit-punch-like kick show on the nose of this bottling, which includes 14% Sangiovese, 5% Cabernet Sauvignon and 4% Petit Verdot. The palate is complex with candied cherry, tobacco leaf and juniper, feeling lighter weight but zesty on the palate.
Wine: Silver 2013 Cabernet Franc (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Stinson
Review: This Cabernet Franc has plenty of tart red currant, pomegranate and hibiscus notes that are juxtaposed by earth, red clay and honeybush tones. Its layers of flavors work well on a full-bodied frame, with well-integrated, tea-like tannins and lively acidity.
Wine: Stinson 2016 Cabernet Franc (Virginia)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Tangy and herbal, this shows cranberry fruit with orange highlights in a sharp-toned persistent style. It moves into a darker finish, with strong chocolatey tannins. The wine was aged 20 months in 20% new French oak barrels.
Wine: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2016 Founders' Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Light in color, the aromas are elusive, with notes of raspberry and cherry candy, along with earth accents. The flavors are elegant and pure, lingering on the finish. It doesn't quite stand up on its own but should absolutely shine at the dinner table.
Wine: Eight Bells 2015 Red Willow Vineyard Sangiovese (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine starts out ever so slightly reduced, opening to reveal aromas of raspberry, berry, vanilla and spice. The palate mixes fruit and barrel, showing a pretty sense of texture. Vanilla notes linger on the finish.
Wine: Januik 2015 Champoux Vineyard Merlot (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Effusive aromas of black raspberry, cherry, earth, vanilla and black licorice lead to supple, elegantly styled red and black-fruit flavors that seem ever so slightly dried out. It's an intriguing offering of the variety.
Wine: Januik 2015 Ciel du Cheval Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from Lange Estate, Freedom Hill and Yamhill vineyards, this was aged in 40% new French oak. It's packed with a solid mix of blackberry, black-cherry and cola flavors. The new oak is a bit muted, and shortens the finish a bit.
Wine: Lange 2015 Three Hills Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Loads of pear, nectarine and Meyer lemon peel show on the chalky nose of this blend of 42% Grenache Blanc, 21% Picpoul Blanc, 21% Viognier and 16% Roussanne. There is a great tightness to the palate, which carries flavors of pear preserves on toast and tangy citrus, leading into a creamy finish.
Wine: Midnight 2017 Aurora Reserve White (Paso Robles)

Appellation: North Gate
Review: High-toned aromas of cranberry, lavender, chocolate, jammy blackberry and gardenia carry the nose and palate of this Petit Verdot. It's extracted in feel and the tannins are mammoth, with balancing acidity and a long, velvety finish.
Wine: North Gate 2015 Petit Verdot (Virginia)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Floral aromas of red and purple petals lead into a juicy red-currant and raspberry streak that's cut by orange rind on the nose of this bottling. There's a hops-like herbal kick to the lighter bodied palate, which gives depth to the dark-red-fruit flavors.
Wine: Peachy Canyon 2016 Mustang Springs Zinfandel (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Made with 12% Sémillon, this wine is a blend of fruit from Summit View, Seven Hills and Les Collines vineyards. The aromas start out subdued, opening to reveal notes of tropical fruit, citrus peel and herb. In contrast, the palate is sleek but flavorful, loaded with papaya and kiwi flavors, with a citrus and tropical-fruit-filled finish.
Wine: Pepper Bridge 2017 Estate Vineyards Sauvignon Blanc (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Ponzi
Review: Lightly spicy, this crisp young wine delivers just-ripe mixed citrus fruit. There are hints of jicama and white radish also, giving it a peppery finish. Just a touch of residual sugar (5 g/L) offsets some of the piercing acidity.
Wine: Ponzi 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve was given 15 months in 40% new French oak. Raspberry tea, vanilla and a touch of tobacco come across. Good texture and medium length carry it, though it feels a bit light for the reserve designation in a warm ripe vintage.
Wine: Trinity Vineyards 2014 Winemaker's Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Veritas
Review: Lavender and elderberry meet up with clove on the nose. A pronounced berry flavor is struck against racy acidity and green tannins on the palate, with a long and dry finish.
Wine: Veritas 2017 Cabernet Franc (Monticello)

Appellation: Vino La Monarcha
Review: The aromas bring appeal, with notes of cherry and spice. The palate is plush with fruit flavors, with the tannins giving a (quite) dry squeeze. A warm finish caps it off.
Wine: Vino La Monarcha 2015 Sangiovese (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Done in a light tart refreshing style, this mixes strawberry fruit with hints of sliced orange peel. There's a snap to the finish suggesting wet stone. A change of owners (from King Estate to Foley Family) has not changed the success or style of this value rosé.
Wine: Acrobat 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black-cherry liqueur and a touch of brioche show on the nose of this promising bottling by students at Allan Hancock College. The palate's flavors of red cherry and earthy sagebrush are evenly distributed and framed by fresh acidity.
Wine: Allan Hancock 2015 Captain's Reserve Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is a blend of 53% Merlot, 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 2% Malbec. Somewhat lighter in color, the aromas show notes of wet penny, raspberry, wheat, herb stalk, cherry and spice. The flavors are light but juicy, tapering on the finish.
Wine: Alleromb 2015 Cuvée B Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dried herb and lavender highlight a smooth, rich and round palate of wild strawberry and blueberry in this well-made light-bodied wine.
Wine: Balletto 2015 Estate Grown Syrah (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Aromas of blackberry, leather and graphite lead to a palate that is driven by plum, tarragon and chai-spice flavors. This full-bodied wine offers parching tannins and racy acidity. The finish is long and dry, filled with sweet oak spices.
Wine: Barboursville Vineyards 2016 Reserve Cabernet Franc (Virginia)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 55% Grenache Blanc, 36% Roussanne and 9% Picpoul starts with broad aromas of Asian pear, tinges of Meyer lemon and tangerine rind and a lot of chalkiness. It's tightly wound on the palate and quite reserved in flavors, until a ripe yellow-pear element starts to come through toward the finish.
Wine: Bonny Doon 2015 Le Cigare Blanc Beeswax Vineyard White (Central Coast)

Appellation: Chester Kidder
Review: Principally a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah, aromas of cherry cola, underbrush and anise are followed by sweet rich black-fruit and licorice flavors that finish warm. The tannins bring quite a grip.
Wine: Chester Kidder 2014 Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Coeur de Terre
Review: Recently bottled, this wine has some faint traces of bottle shock, but offers plenty of potential for further improvement. Crisp apple, iceberg lettuce and wet stone flavors combine. A touch of lemon rind adds interest to the finishing acidity.
Wine: Coeur de Terre 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Crooked Path
Review: Dark plum, red currant and cocoa dust show on the very expressive, quite ripe nose of this bottling. There is thickness to the mouthfeel and the flavors are lush with dark red berries, peppery spice, a hint of sagebrush and a fresh acidity.
Wine: Crooked Path 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blended with 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, the black-pepper, clove, flower, herb and spice aromas are followed by light plump fruit flavors, with a tart finish. The concentration seems light for the variety but what's there is interesting.
Wine: Damsel 2015 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Wild strawberry dominates in this thick, concentrated wine, that is full bodied in mouthfeel and ripeness. The texture and weight is supported by moderate acidity and a finishing touch of Meyer lemon chiffon.
Wine: De Loach 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Crisp fruit flavors of apple and jicama, along with peppery notes of white radish, come up through this pleasant Chardonnay. It's young, bright, balanced and refreshing—a solid accompaniment to simple seafood dishes.
Wine: Domaine Loubejac 2017 Willamette Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a thick, dense white with earthy floral and herbal characteristics. Stone fruit and vanilla make themselves known on the palate, evolving in the glass to show a richness of tropical flavor.
Wine: Fulcrum 2016 Durell Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Strong flavors of crunchy apple with hints of cured meat ride along an unctuous texture in this estate-grown wine that holds its acidity well.
Wine: Hawley 2017 Hawley Vineyard Viognier (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Jefferson Vineyards
Review: Aromas of passionfruit and overripe apples are offset by a grassy, fiddlehead fern note. On the palate, an acidic lift of lemon-lime and candied grapefruit mingle with ginger spices. This feels zesty for a Viognier and its bright nature gives it a long, refreshing finish.
Wine: Jefferson Vineyards 2016 Viognier (Virginia)

Appellation: Lorenzi Estate
Review: This bottling is quite floral on the nose, but there are also strong aromas of juicy red fruits and a pinch of pepper. Tangy black-plum and dark-blackberry flavors show on the sip, where the tannins are still rather stiff.
Wine: Lorenzi Estate 2014 Grenache (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: Rich and fruity, this wine pours almost syrupy black-cherry flavors over the palate while hints of cocoa and nutmeg add complexity. It feels very smooth, is light on tannins and acidity but generous with pure Cabernet flavors.
Wine: Mt. Konocti Winery 2015 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Lake County)

Appellation: Newsprint
Review: Lighter in color, the aromas offer notes of flower, dried herb, grilled green pepper and red cherry. The flavors are somewhat lighter styled, but it still delivers a lot of enjoyment.
Wine: Newsprint 2016 Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Northstar
Review: Somewhat lighter in color for the variety, aromas of fresh herb, flower, tire rubber, mocha and cherry are followed by lighter-styled fruit flavors. The tannins bring a slightly gritty feel.
Wine: Northstar 2015 Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas offer notes of raspberry, spice, red apple and herb, not seeming entirely settled. The flavors are lighter in style, with a slightly stewed feel.
Wine: Northstar 2015 Premier Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Novelty Hill
Review: Cocoa, vanilla and red-fruit aromas are followed by supple, rich fruit and barrel flavors. The barrel influence seems primary but there are good things going on.
Wine: Novelty Hill 2015 Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's an appealing brightness to the aromatics here, and it's followed with spicy fruit flavors of raspberry and candied cherries. Bright acidity adds some welcome snap to the finish.
Wine: R. Stuart & Co. 2014 Lazy River Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Raptor Ridge
Review: Sourced from the Zenith vineyard and aged for 11 months in neutral oak, this is a little bit flabbier than the previous vintage, and should be served well chilled. When cold, it offers crisp grapefruit and mineral highlights, served up with a twist of lemon.
Wine: Raptor Ridge 2016 Auxerrois (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This is a good example of southern Oregon Tempranillo, with light pomegranate and salmonberry fruit and a wash of coffee liqueur. It sets up the finish against earthy tannins, but the overall balance works. About 4% Grenache is included in the blend.
Wine: Reustle 2015 Timnah Bloc Tempranillo (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Broad peachy aromas meet with a touch of crushed chalk on the nose of this blend of 43% Viognier, 28% Grenache Blanc, 15% Roussanne and 14% Marsanne. Nectarine flesh shows on the palate, but it clings to a compellingly steely edge.
Wine: Rideau 2016 Enchevetré White (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very shy on the nose, this bottling offers light pomegranate and cherry aromas. Dried herbs and turned earth flavors show on the palate against the cranberry background. It's a restrained take on the rich region.
Wine: Sarah's Vineyard 2016 Tondre Grapefield Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Saviah
Review: A blend of fruit from McClellan, Seven Hills, Dugger Creek and Anna Marie vineyards, the aromas are locked up out of the gate, with notes of asphalt, blackberry, mineral, dried herb and spice. The palate brings a big ball of fruit and tobacco flavors, concentrated around the center and tapering off quite a bit at the edges.
Wine: Saviah 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (WA), Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: Though labeled as a Syrah, this is truly a GSM blend, with 12% Grenache and 8% Mourvèdre blended in. The aromas are generous, with notes of café au lait, blue fruit, wood spice, orange peel and herb. The concentration is light, but the flavors show a pleasing sense of freshness and detail.
Wine: Saviah 2016 The Jack Syrah (Columbia Gorge (WA))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas draw you into the glass, with notes of plum, blackberry, spice and herb. The flavors bring a sense of purity with a tart finish.
Wine: Seven Hills 2015 McClellan Estate Vineyard Malbec (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of anise, Fruit Roll-Ups and medicine cabinet are followed by pitch-black fruit flavors. The tannins bring a sense of astringency—a surprise from this typically supple site. It all seems a bit dried out.
Wine: Seven Hills 2015 Seven Hills Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Child's Play is a new label from Tendril. This is a blend of Chardonnay and 30% white Pinot Noir, which works rather well. The fleshy Pinot plumps up the Chardonnay, adding hints of baking spices and cocoa to its fairly standard apple and peach fruit. The wine was released after just six months in stainless steel.
Wine: Tendril 2017 Child's Play Pinot-Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This barrel-fermented rosé spent three months in neutral oak. It's smooth and easily accessible, with watermelon and strawberry fruit, full flavored and front loaded.
Wine: Trinity Vineyards 2017 Pinot Noir Rosé (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Veritas
Review: Lavender and elderberry meet up with clove on the nose. A pronounced berry flavor is struck against racy acidity and green tannins on the palate, with a long and dry finish.
Wine: Veritas 2017 Cabernet Franc (Monticello)

Appellation: Vino La Monarcha
Review: The aromas bring appeal, with notes of cherry and spice. The palate is plush with fruit flavors, with the tannins giving a (quite) dry squeeze. A warm finish caps it off.
Wine: Vino La Monarcha 2015 Sangiovese (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This is done in a light and refreshing style, with plenty of juicy acidity under watermelon and strawberry fruit. It was all stainless-steel fermented, and fills out the finish with fresh citrus highlights.
Wine: Abacela 2017 Grenache Rosé (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Allan Hancock
Review: The college kids did well in this bottling, which offers Asian and Bosc pear on the delicate nose alongside hints of white flowers and toast. There is tension to the palate, showing flavors of toasted sourdough with lemon preserves.
Wine: Allan Hancock 2016 Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Templeton Gap District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded aromas of melon and pear are cut by a key-lime spritz and Meyer lemon pith, and a flash of tropical bubblegum comes out as well. The palate is pretty tight at first and then come the guava and banana flavors, all held up by racy acidity.
Wine: Barton 2017 River Clare Ranch Vineyard Viognier (Templeton Gap District)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a bottling for oak lovers, starting with aromas of smoked cantaloupe and lemon peels. That smoke element envelops the palate, where acidity lifts the lemon-and-herb-roasted-chicken flavors, which finish on caramel and pound cake.
Wine: Bellante 2017 Jack McGinley Vineyard New French Oak Cuvée Viognier (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Smoked blackberries and turned earth aromas show on the nose of this blend of 73% Zinfandel, 21% Petite Sirah and 6% Tempranillo. There is a compelling tightness and freshness to the palate, where boysenberry and licorice flavors converge.
Wine: Chronic Cellars 2016 Dead Nuts Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: CK Mondavi
Review: This is a trim, well-balanced wine that fills a nicely crisp frame with appealing lemon, green apple and butter notes. Light to medium in weight, it offers bright acidity to keep it refreshing while still delivering substantial flavor.
Wine: CK Mondavi 2017 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: On this 100% varietal wine, plentiful aromas of plum, tar and spice are followed by elegantly styled fruit flavors. It's a very pretty expression of the variety from this blazing hot appellation and vintage.
Wine: Col Solare 2015 Collector's Society Malbec (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: There's no question about the variety, with its notes of dried and fresh herb, flower and cherry, along with red-apple skin. There's a pleasing sense of balance to the palate, with the tannins bringing a lightly tacky feel. Give it some time in the decanter if opening in the near term.
Wine: Col Solare 2015 Component Collection Estate Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Red-apple-skin, blackberry and spice aromas lead to full-bodied cherry and cranberry flavors. The tannins give a firm, dry squeeze. Give it an extended decant if drinking in the near term.
Wine: Columbia Crest 2015 Reserve Heart of the Hill Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Earthfluence
Review: Poached pear aromas meet with crushed chalk on the pleasant nose of this bottling. The palate is framed by a chalky grip, which releases flavors of honeysuckle, pear and a hint of toast.
Wine: Earthfluence 2017 Grenache Blanc (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Flying Fox
Review: Charged aromas of black currant, raisin, violets, elderflower and smoke explode on the nose and palate. This is pleasantly parching in drying tannins yet untiring acidity extends the long, complex finish.
Wine: Flying Fox 2014 Petit Verdot (Monticello)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a barrel-fermented, barrel-selection, reserve-level effort. It's richly scented with Bourbon-barrel highlights, which carry into the flavors. Apple and peach fruit, only lightly ripened, completes the picture.
Wine: Fullerton 2016 Lux Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is lighter in color than the norm for this variety. It brings aromas of whole green pepper, olive, black cherry and exotic spice. The palate shows a lighter styling, with a pretty sense of balance between the fruit and herb flavors. It's all about sophistication.
Wine: Gård 2015 Lawrence Estate Wines Lawrence Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 48% Cabernet Sauvignon, 48% Merlot and 4% Petit Verdot. Aromas of green, leafy herb, coffee, cherry, dried tobacco and black licorice are followed by chocolate, cherry, tobacco and herb flavors. It comes off as pretty green.
Wine: Guardian 2015 Gun Metal Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: 100% Cabernet Sauvignon all biodynamically grown, the aromas offer notes of dried tobacco, barrel spice, medicine cabinet and dried cherry. The palate brings a sense of elegance and refinement, with enough tannic structure to reward time in the cellar.
Wine: Hedges 2015 La Haute Cuvée Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Horton
Review: This wine is bright on the nose, with aromas of apricot marmalade, hazelnuts and tarragon. The dry palate is carried by bracing acidity and flavors that echo the aromas, with a citrus pith bite cleaning up the long, appealingly nutty and tangy finish.
Wine: Horton 2016 Petit Manseng (Virginia)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Pleasant aromas of cut grass, aloe and grapefruit are abundant on the nose. More lush aloe shows on the palate with a dash of salt. This is medium in weight, with balanced acidity and finishes soft and flavorful.
Wine: Horton 2017 Private Release Albariño (Virginia)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of vanilla, cocoa, baking spice, anise and cherry are followed by well-proportioned fruit and barrel flavors. The oak plays a very large part in the show.
Wine: Januik 2015 Weinbau Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Hyland is often selected for single-vineyard wines, though results, as here, can be uneven. Juicy raspberry fruit feels just a bit underripe, as if from young vines. There's plenty of acidity, and a streak of cherry cola snaking through the finish.
Wine: King Estate 2015 Hyland Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: King Estate
Review: This standard-bearer is the winery's most widely-available wine. It's a solid, fruit-driven effort, with abundant flavors of apple, pear and melon. Crisp acidity adds freshness and definition to the finish.
Wine: King Estate 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Monticello, Virginia, US
Review: The nose is fairly intense in aromas of honeydew, apple acacia and ginger. The medium-weight palate boasts savory flavors of rosemary and thyme that linger on the finish.
Wine: King Family 2017 Roseland Chardonnay-Viognier-Petit Manseng White (Monticello)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Extremely light in the glass, this single-vineyard expression shows pear, chalk, honeysuckle and lily aromas on the clean focused nose. There is grippy texture and bright acidity on the palate, where the flavors are quite tropical, with guava being dominant.
Wine: Kitá 2017 Hilliard Bruce Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Koehler
Review: Quite light in the glass, this bottling shows plenty of poached pear and tuberose on the fairly exuberant nose. The palate is quite tropical with flavors of coconut, papaya, mango and much more pear.
Wine: Koehler 2017 Chardonnay (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is half from Ferguson Vineyard with the other half from Seven Hills. The aromas are light and high toned, with notes of red cherry, mocha, dark chocolate and spice. The flavors are medium bodied, with tart acidity and quite firm tannins that need some time to soften.
Wine: L'Ecole No. 41 2015 Estate Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Honey and chamomile aromas are prominent on the mellow nose of this single-vineyard bottling. The flavors are quite subdued, with touches of honeysuckle and squeezed lemon.
Wine: Mansfield-Dunne 2016 Peterson Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of freshly cut pear, white flowers, citrus and sweet herbs are followed by white and pink-grapefruit flavors. A tart lingering finish caps it off with a bright impression.
Wine: Maryhill 2017 Proprietor's Reserve Otis Vineyard Albariño (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: MCV
Review: Freshly pressed morello cherry, dried red flowers, rust and a hint of brown sugar show on the nose of this bottling. It's straight-ahead on the palate with clean red-cherry flavors, lifted by a touch of sandalwood.
Wine: MCV 2016 Grenache (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very juicy on the nose, this bottling smells of a black-cherry and pomegranate soda pop with a pinch of dried herbs. There are also lots of poppy qualities to the sip, where tangy plum juice meets with a touch of dried hop flavor.
Wine: Peachy Canyon 2016 Especial Zinfandel (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Fairly light in the glass, this bottling shows fresh aromas of sour cherry, dill and marjoram on the simple but likable nose. The palate delivers candied raspberry, cranberry and plum flavors, making a perfect table wine for a variety of foods.
Wine: Peachy Canyon 2016 Mustard Creek Zinfandel (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Knights Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dusty and briary in black cherry and berry, this wine offers moderate structure and ripeness within a context of soft round texture and approachability.
Wine: Pech Merle 2014 Angier Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Knights Valley)

Appellation: Refugio Ranch
Review: Lemon cream, sandy soils and yellow flowers show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard on the south side of the Santa Ynez River. It's tightly wound on the palate, with flavors of pear and apple cream, finishing on a lime-driven acid kick.
Wine: Refugio Ranch 2016 Roussanne (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: There's a great story behind this planting, which comes from grape cuttings that were grown more than 100 years ago on Santa Cruz Island, but the wine still struggles in the island breeze. Light aromas of red cherry and sweet cedar lead into a palate of tangy red fruit, wet soil and wood spice.
Wine: Rusack 2015 Santa Catalina Island Vineyards Zinfandel (California)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Made in a nouveau style, where whole cluster grapes are covered with carbon dioxide during fermentation, the aromas bring pure notes of strawberry, raspberry, green pepper, herb and fresh flower. The flavors are pure and elegant, bringing a sense of freshness along with a lightly smoky finish.
Wine: Savage Grace 2017 Cru Carbonic Red Willow Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Monterey, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Crushed purple flowers, leather, sarsaparilla and blue-fruit aromas show on the nose of this bottling. The palate, which is relatively medium bodied for this heavy grape, is very dry and tarry, offering flavors of grilled black plums and charcoal.
Wine: Scheid 2015 Hames Valley Vineyard Petite Sirah (Monterey)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 48% Cabernet Sauvignon, 30% Merlot, 14% Cabernet Franc and 8% Malbec. The aromas are generous, with notes of braised green pepper, fresh herb, cherry and flower, with the palate showing more of the same. It comes off as pretty green and a bit dried out. Drink now.
Wine: Spring Valley Vineyard 2015 Frederick Estate Grown Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Not fully resolved orange-peel, bacon-fat, mineral and herb aromas lead to quite elegantly styled fruit flavors. There are some interesting things going on but they don't all come together.
Wine: Stevens 2015 BlackTongue Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from the Dineen (70%) and Sheridan vineyards. Beguiling aromas of black plum, tar, clove, cigar box, dried orange peel, spice and whiffs of game are followed by elegant, slightly tangy fruit flavors backed by lightly grainy tannins.
Wine: Stevens 2015 StevensTimley Malbec (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This blends large amounts of Merlot and Zinfandel with Cabernet Sauvignon, Petite Sirah and Malbec. Together they form a thick, plummy core accented in dried herb and integrated oak, with a sweetness of milk chocolate on the finish.
Wine: Strala 2015 Proprietary Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: The Barns at Hamilton Station
Review: Boisterous aromas of dried blackberry, lavender, coffee, smoke and leather carry the nose. On the palate, there is an abundance of charred wood that overpowers the fruitiness. The finish is long and full of wood spices.
Wine: The Barns at Hamilton Station 2015 Petit Verdot (Virginia)

Appellation: The Four Graces
Review: Here's a sharp-edged mix of fruits, mainly pear, peach and yellow plum. It's forward and plump with those fruit flavors, and has seemingly been rounded off with residual sugar.
Wine: The Four Graces 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Monticello, Virginia, US
Review: The nose of this wine is full of red fruit, showing cranberry, red cherry and juicy red plum aromas. Savory, herbacious notes come through on the palate, with a medium-length finish that offers tones of jammy cherry and cedar.
Wine: The Williamsburg Winery 2016 Limited Release Petit Verdot (Monticello)

Appellation: Three Rivers
Review: Almost all of the fruit for this wine comes from esteemed Seven Hills Vineyard. The aromas are fruit forward, suggesting notes of blackberry, cassis, herb and dark coffee. The palate paints around the edges, with the tannins giving a slightly dry squeeze.
Wine: Three Rivers 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Pleasant cherry scents and flavors open and focus this well-balanced wine. It was fermented with wild yeast, and adds a streak of black licorice through the finish. Although it's on the lighter, herbal side, it should continue to drink well through the mid-2020s.
Wine: Vidon Vineyard 2015 3 Clones Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Prune and fig are met with walnuts and grape preserves on the nose. Blackberry pie shines on the sweet palate. Zippy acidity, silky tannins and a full body make this feel decadent.
Wine: Wild Boar 2014 Porton Norton (Virginia)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from a site along Petaluma Hill Road, this is an herbal, creamy and lush wine that was fermented in stainless steel and is now wrapped in good tight acidity. Lemon meringue and green-apple flavors balance each other and allow the wine to maintain lasting freshness.
Wine: Ledson 2017 Grove Vineyard Viognier (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Mesa Del Sol
Review: Black-plum jelly, blackberry ice cream and a hint of dried herbs show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard in the warm part of this appellation. Black-fruit and violet flavors show on the tangy palate.
Wine: Mesa Del Sol 2012 Syrah (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: An easygoing, enjoyable wine, this is integrated in good dark fruit and integrated oak, with soft tannins and a length of cinnamon and clove.
Wine: Michael Pozzan 2015 Annabella Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Midnight
Review: Quite spicy on the nose, this bottling shows myrrh and cedar against rich black plum aromas in the background. That wood spice and cigar box element plays on the palate too, wrapping up the carnation, rose water and soft plum and strawberry flavors, The tannins firm up on the finish.
Wine: Midnight 2014 Zinfandel (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Midnight
Review: Broad aromas of poached pear and coconut oil prove fairly ripe but clean and inviting on the nose of this bottling. Ripe apples and pears show on the palate, along with another flash of coconut flake.
Wine: Midnight 2017 Chardonnay (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Starting off reduced, aromas of burnt toast, pear, mineral and spice are followed by full-bodied oak-driven flavors that finish warm. The oak seems primary at present.
Wine: Morell-Peña 2016 Camylla Loren Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is clone 76 Chardonnay, aged in half new French oak. The aromas are pleasing, with notes of mineral, herb, citrus and peach. The flavors show a lot of elegance, with a pleasing sense of texture and warm finish. The concentration doesn't quite seem all there.
Wine: Morell-Peña 2016 Gemma Camaryn Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Northstar
Review: Merlot makes up 55% of this wine, with the balance Cabernet Sauvignon. Coming from the Anna Marie and Spring Valley vineyards, aromas of huckleberry, herb and spice lead to soft well-balanced blue-fruit flavors that persist on the finish. It shows a sense of elegance for such a warm vintage.
Wine: Northstar 2015 Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas and flavors show notes of vanilla, pear tart, flower and spice, with fruit and barrel playing off each other. There's plenty of enjoyment to be had.
Wine: Novelty Hill 2017 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Viognier (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This strikes a fine balance for this variety, right on the border of northern and southern Rhône as a reference. Black-cherry, lemon oil, Dr. Pepper and coffee extract flavors combine, and the wine finishes with a lively tangy burst of citrus.
Wine: Reustle 2015 Masada Bloc Syrah (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Concentrated aromas of cherry syrup, new leather and turned earth show on the nose of this blend of 54% Petite Sirah, 23% Grenache and 23% Mourvèdre. The palate is surprisingly quite light and shy, with red fruit and a hint of pepper.
Wine: Rideau 2015 Enchevetre Rouge Red (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Coming from an appellation where white wines are seldom seen, this wine is a blend of Marsanne (70%) and Roussanne. Vibrant notes of honeysuckle and white peach lead to a palate that is considerably more reserved than the aromas might suggest, with graceful citrus on the finish.
Wine: Rôtie Cellars 2017 Northern White (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sanford
Review: The somewhat shy nose in this appellation blend from a tough vintage shows earthy dried sage and sour red-cherry aromas. Fresh red fruit and red flowers arise on the mellow palate.
Wine: Sanford 2015 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Scenic Valley Farms
Review: Much like the previous vintage, this is packed with fresh and juicy flavors of cut pear. It's well defined with ample acidity adding notes of lime and grapefruit. It does seem to flatten out and tail off in the finish, so a little extra chill might be helpful.
Wine: Scenic Valley Farms 2017 Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This follows the winery style for robustly tannic and high-alcohol reds. In this instance, not as high as most of its companions, which allows the ripe fruit to show through with smooth flavors of chocolate and cherry. Drink now through 2021.
Wine: Spangler 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Oregon)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This follows the winery style for robustly tannic and high-alcohol reds. In this instance, not as high as most of its companions, which allows the ripe fruit to show through with smooth flavors of chocolate and cherry. Drink now through 2021.
Wine: Spangler 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Oregon)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Nuanced aromas of corn silk, peach and cream lead to lighter styled but nicely balanced fruit flavors. There are a lot of good things going on but the concentration seems quite light.
Wine: The Walls 2016 Martin's Gold French Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Veritas
Review: This wine displays aromas and flavors of peach, orange peel, pear drop and coconut. Round and fat in feel, this has a long, rich finish.
Wine: Veritas 2017 Viognier (Monticello)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This new vintage is spicy, with minty highlights around core flavors of lemon oil, orange peel, apple and white peach. It spent 10 months in one-quarter new French oak, and there's a gentle pat of buttery flavor in the finish.
Wine: Willamette Valley Vineyards 2016 Estate Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Chris James
Review: This is a blend of one-third Lagrein and two-thirds Dolcetto from the estate's Old Wagon Road vineyard. Light and fruity, it's quite appealing, drinking much like a Gamay, with flavors of ripe berries front and center. The tannins are just stiff enough to give it a bit of muscle through the finish.
Wine: Chris James 2016 Red (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cranberry, raspberry and cherry aromas are followed by medium-bodied fruit flavors with a short finish. It's an elegant interpretation of the variety.
Wine: Côte Bonneville 2014 Estate Bottled DuBrul Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of lime leaf, peach nectar, citrus and flower lead to plentiful, a medium-sweet lemon iced-tea flavor, with plenty of peach accents. There are a lot of good things going on, but it needs more acid to stand up to the sugar.
Wine: Côte Bonneville 2017 Estate Bottled DuBrul Vineyard Riesling (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine starts citrus-driven and bright in acidity before evolving in the glass to take on more power and richness, a mix of stone fruit and melon.
Wine: Covenant 2017 Red C Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: This wine offers baked plum, elderberry syrup and coffee on the nose. Blueberry, black pepper, licorice and cedar arise on the palate, with parching tannins and a long finish of cedar spice and bluberry.
Wine: Early Mountain 2015 Eluvium Red (Virginia)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This fresh zippy rosé is most definitely on the tart side, with tangy flavors of lemon and grapefruit, and puckery acidity all the way through the finish. Hints of strawberries can be found, but it most resembles a lightly fruity Sauvignon Blanc.
Wine: Elizabeth Chambers 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Fess Parker
Review: The nose on this bottling is gamy and dank, with tarry aromas coating the lilac and black-currant scents. There's a caramel-like touch to the tip of the sip, where solid acid and tannins deliver mellow and easy-to-enjoy blackberry flavors.
Wine: Fess Parker 2015 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Prominent aromas of pear, peach and flower are followed by sleek stone-fruit flavors. A zip of acidity on the finish heightens the interest. One wants more concentration but what is there impresses.
Wine: Gård 2017 Freyja Lawrence Vineyards White (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Loamy aromas, red plums and dried red flowers are rather restrained on the nose of this bottling, which includes 10% Malbec, 10% Petit Verdot and 5% Cabernet Franc. The palate is very clean and dense with red fruit and lifted by dried herbs.
Wine: Grey Wolf Cellars 2015 Alpha Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Holme Estate Cellars
Review: Relatively mellow on the nose, this bottling shows black-plum jam with hints of smoke, baking spice and crushed gravel aromas. Blackberry and more brown spice show on the palate, which is clean, fresh and easy to quaff.
Wine: Holme Estate Cellars 2014 Zinfandel (Adelaida District)

Appellation: J Wilkes
Review: A bit shy on the nose, this bottling of a rarely seen Italian grape offers earthy and rocky aromas as well as very dark fruit. The palate is very mineral-driven, with crushed black-rock flavors, dried berry fruit and tightly wound tannins that leave the mouth coated.
Wine: J Wilkes 2016 Lagrein (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Among an expansive lineup of almost a dozen vineyard-specific Pinots, this estate-grown example comes off just a bit on the thin side. Aged 14 months in 30% new French oak, it shows light leafy overtones around slightly muted cherry fruit. The finish resolves in peppery herbal flavors.
Wine: King Estate 2015 Blackjack 777 Clone Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Always one of the best Syrahs on the broad market for a fair price, this year's Tous les Jours is slightly less exciting than in years past, but still delivers the goods. Aromas of purple flowers and snappy boysenberry lead into a palate that's extremely fresh and vibrant with rounded berry flavors.
Wine: Andrew Murray 2016 Tous les Jours Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: This is an unoaky, medium-bodied wine that will please a lot of people. It has generous fruity flavors like blackberry and dark grapes, a nearly dry balance, soft tannins and a smooth texture.
Wine: B.R. Cohn 2016 Silver Label Cabernet Sauvignon (North Coast)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Merlot (38%) and Cabernet Franc (38%) make up the bulk of this wine, with the balance, Cabernet Sauvignon (22%) and Malbec. Somewhat high-toned aromas of black raspberry, anise and spice are followed by soft ripe black-fruit flavors. It brings appeal but seems ever so slightly dried out.
Wine: Baer 2015 Ursa Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
