Review: Aromas of medicine cabinet, dried fruit, dried tobacco and spice lead to elegantly styled fruit flavors. It shows a lot of restraint for the vintage and appellation.
Wine: Goedhart Family 2013 Bel' Villa Vineyard RMAVA Grand Class Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Kirkland Signature
Review: This is a tasty, dry, well-balanced wine that offers plenty of fruit flavor and a nice nip of tannin in the texture. It has a figgy aroma and ripe strawberry and plum flavors that will please a crowd.
Wine: Kirkland Signature 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Abacela
Review: This new vintage again hits the sweeter side of off dry at 33 g/L residual sugar. It's almost syrupy, but for the ample acidity that underscores flavors of lime and oranges. Despite all the sugar, the finish turns slightly bitter.
Wine: Abacela 2017 Muscat (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Ballard Lane
Review: A touch reductive even with plenty of time to breathe, this bottling offers ripe blackberry, tar and game aromas on the nose. Dried herbs, more game and sour black fruits show on the palate, which ends on a vanilla-cookie finish.
Wine: Ballard Lane 2014 Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Knights Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Nutty, metallic and tropical, this estate-grown white takes on a voluptuous, unctuous texture and sweet ripeness.
Wine: Lawer 2016 Betsy's Vineyard Viognier (Knights Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Turned earth, compost and dried herb greet the entry of this full-bodied, fully ripe wine, intense in compressed, jammy red and black fruit.
Wine: Ledson 2014 Estate Vineyard Syrah (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Magnolia Court Dorrian
Review: Bright red berries and slightly damp herbs show on the inviting nose of this bottling, which starts quite juicy. The mouthfeel is fairly light and fresh if simple and easy, with decent acidity though not much structure.
Wine: Magnolia Court Dorrian 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Charles Krug
Review: Grassy and herbal, this white is tart and tight in acidity, with a low level of ripeness that keeps it crisp and clean. Lemongrass and lime round out the finish.
Wine: Charles Krug 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (St. Helena)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lighter than most Petite Sirahs, this bottling shows a boysenberry-laced fruit-punch aroma on the nose alongside cola and black-cherry soda pop. The palate is very juicy with plum, violet and lavender touches.
Wine: Chronic Cellars 2016 Suite Petite Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Bright aromas of melon rind, lemon zest and toast lead to lighter-styled tropical-fruit flavors. The concentration seems quite light. Pink-grapefruit notes linger on the finish.
Wine: Columbia Crest 2016 H3 Sauvignon Blanc (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Écluse
Review: This Zinfandel is crafted in a more underripe style, which is a laudable effort, but falls a bit short. Aromas of tangy plum skin, mulberry and baked tomato lead into a earthy palate of moss, tobacco and tomato leaf.
Wine: Écluse 2015 Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: This blend of Petit Manseng, Seval Blanc and Riesling is shy on the nose, with just a whiff of lemon and pistachio. The palate is much more intense, boasting flavors of aloe vera, lychee and pear drop. Off dry and light in body, it's an easy-drinking wine perfect for a picnic.
Wine: James Charles 2017 Cuvée de la Reine White (Virginia)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from the Tudor, McKinley Springs and Clifton Hill vineyards. Aromas of maple sugar candy, boysenberry, fresh herb and barrel spice are followed by a mild concentration of fruit flavors.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Proprietor's Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Pale salmon in color, the aromas are light and lack a sense of clarity. The palate is dry with an assortment of strawberry, herb and cherry flavors, with ale notes on the finish. It doesn't quite seem to have fully settled in.
Wine: Primarius 2017 Pinot Noir Rosé (Oregon)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Lemon curd and pineapple aromas are melded together with wet stone and white peach in this Albariño. The flavors are tropical and savory with a salty aftertaste. Medium in body and acidity, the finish follows suit and ends on an overripe note.
Wine: The Williamsburg Winery 2017 Wessex Hundred Albariño (Virginia)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A strange wine, its dense aromatics smell like sweet hay. Those flavors are joined with a touch of mulberry, quickly turning dilute and fading away.
Wine: Torii Mor 2016 Hoy Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Watermelon, orange pith and lavender shine on the nose and carry through to the palate where it's met with a stony character. This is well balanced throughout, with a long and fresh finish.
Wine: Veramar 2017 JB Winemaker Series Rosé (Virginia)

Appellation: Ancient Lakes, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Pale-salmon colored, aromas of strawberry Jolly Rancher, watermelon and cherry lead to off-dry lightly spritzy fruit flavors that tingle the palate.
Wine: Vino La Monarcha 2017 Pinot Noir Rosé (Ancient Lakes)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: The aromas bring notes of roasted corn on the cob along with peach. The flavors come off as lightly sweet, with pineapple on the finish.
Wine: Watermill 2016 Chances R Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (OR))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Starting out a bit reduced, the aromas open to reveal notes of citrus zest and herb. The palate is quite light in style, not holding together on the finish.
Wine: Ambassador Vineyard 2017 Special Selection Sauvignon Blanc (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Lighter in color, blueberry, smoke and herb aromas lead to quite-light-seeming fruit flavors. The concentration doesn't seem all there but what is there is pleasant.
Wine: Apex 2016 The Catalyst Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Mountain, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Strong flavors and aromas of pea shoots, peach and sweet vanilla give this wine a richness and full-bodied, fleshy personality.
Wine: Belden Barns 2017 Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma Mountain)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The mint, green herb, vanilla and blackberry aromas are elusive. The flavors are lightly styled, with a sweet finish.
Wine: Columbia Crest 2015 Les Chevaux Red (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: DaMa
Review: This wine is quite light in color for the variety. Aromas of fresh tobacco, orange peel and herb are followed by lighter-styled fruit flavors. It all seems quite dialed back, not appearing to have fully ripened and fleshed out.
Wine: DaMa 2015 Tempranillo (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is made from nearly equal parts of Petit Verdot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec, with smaller amounts of Merlot and Cabernet Franc. Given more than two years in French oak, half of it new, this wine is largely defined by that oak, a mix of tannin and dried herb.
Wine: Hestan 2014 Stephanie Proprietary Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Eucalyptus and cranberry aromas are fresh on the nose, leading to a palate that is driven by oak spices. The tannins are thick and resinous in feel.
Wine: James Charles 2017 Arrivato 1913 Ameritage Merlot-Cabernet Sauvignon (Virginia)

Appellation: Line 39
Review: The ripe berry exuberance of this medium-bodied wine is undeniable as it oozes blackberry aromas and black-cherry flavors uncomplicated by much oak influence. A smooth texture, low acid and tannins make it easy to sip.
Wine: Line 39 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Floral and brimming in green apple on entry, this wine takes on a confectionery air of candied ginger and tropical mango as it opens in the glass.
Wine: MacLaren 2017 Aida Viognier (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Rascal
Review: The fruit is thin and some bitter components come through the tannins. It's built around quite light flavors of sweet cherry, with little depth. It's a simple wine suitable for every day consumption.
Wine: Rascal 2016 Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Baked lemon and orange meet with grassy aromas on the rather reductive nose of this bottling, which also shows lots of dried citrus pith. Tangy lemon peel and very ripe nectarine flavors arise on the palate.
Wine: Sevtap 2016 Leyla Semillon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Sevtap
Review: Citrus rinds, pear flesh and a hint of nectarine show on the nose of this bottling. Warm yellow-apple flavors meet with poached pear and blanched almond on the palate.
Wine: Sevtap 2016 Vermentino (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Spangler
Review: This is a spicy, peppery wine with sharply herbal scents and flavors. There are light hints of berry and a touch of leather. Overall, it's a rather green take on the variety, with little varietal specificity.
Wine: Spangler 2014 Cabernet Franc (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dark in color, this is a textured, tannic and dry wine, robust in rose petal, dark cherry and pomegranate.
Wine: Taft Street 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Pea shoots, lemon and wet stone contribute graceful flavors to this wine, which has a metallic edge to its medium-bodied texture.
Wine: Tamber Bey 2017 Lizzy's Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Oakville)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine includes 18% Roussanne, 3% Marsanne, 2% Viognier and 1% Picpoul. The aromas draw you into the glass, with notes of lees, lemon peel, herb, vanilla and barrel spice (aged in 75% new puncheons). The palate can't deliver on the promise, seeming quite light, with the concentration of the fruit not able to stand up to the barrel influence.
Wine: The Walls 2016 Lip Stinger French Creek Vineyard Grenache Blanc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Three Rivers
Review: Aromas of apricot, lime leaf, herb and gasoline lead to sweet fruit flavors. It's a straightforward easy drinker.
Wine: Three Rivers 2017 Riesling (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: High-toned aromas of cranberry, rubber and coconut lead to the palate. The acidity is bright and the tannins are bracing, giving way to a long, racy finish.
Wine: Veramar 2017 JB Winemaker Series Terracotta Sangiovese-Cabernet Sauvignon (Virginia)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Aromas of honeydew and fennel are pleasant on the nose, with the palate bringing flavors of lime zest and more herbs. Racy acidity brovides the backbone, leading to a long, zippy finish.
Wine: Veramar 2017 JB Winemaker Series Vidal Blanc (Virginia)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas show notes of fresh herb, plum, spice and orange peel. The flavors are light and sleek, not showing the variety's more generous side but still providing interest.
Wine: Waterbrook 2015 Reserve Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Watermill
Review: Dark raspberry, milk chocolate and coffee aromas lead to lightly sweet-seeming fruit flavors. Smoky notes linger on the finish. It doesn't seem to have fully settled in, and the concentration seems a bit light.
Wine: Watermill 2016 Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Allan Hancock
Review: Very light and quite bubbly in the glass, this bottling offers lots of chalky, key lime and botanical aromas. The bubbles are also very present on the sip, with lime rind and flint flavors.
Wine: Allan Hancock 2016 White (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Ballard Lane
Review: Apple flesh and watery lemon aromas show on the nose of this bottling. It's flat on the palate, offering lime zest and more sliced-apple flavors.
Wine: Ballard Lane 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Central Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: From the first sip on through, this wine just feels flat. There's varietally correct apple and pear fruit, but it's lifeless, and the finish is short and simple.
Wine: Lady Hill 2016 St. Columban Vineyard Pinot Blanc (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Merlot (65%) makes up most of this wine, followed by Cabernet Sauvignon (27%) and Syrah. Pale in color, aromas of raspberry, Muscat gummy candy and rubber band and lead to quite light fruit flavors, with the tannins giving a slightly astringent feel.
Wine: Hedges 2015 CMS Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: An odd wine to be labeled reserve, this is dark and chalky, with burnt flavors. There's not much fruit, and what's there is hidden in streaks of fish oil, metal and earth.
Wine: Kudos 2016 Reserve Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has a jalapeño spiciness on the nose that intensifies into the lush, round palate of buttery cream that accentuates the unctuous ripeness overall.
Wine: Pezzi King 2017 Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Rotation Vineyards
Review: This medium-bodied wine leans toward sweetness and offers flavors like grape jam and maple syrup. It is generally soft in texture but does have a touch of grippy tannin.
Wine: Rotation Vineyards 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: This wine is off dry, with aromas and flavors of honeysuckle, orange blossom and white peach. Very full in body and lacking acidity, this comes off as saccharine and cloying. The finish is sweet and warm.
Wine: Veramar 2017 JB Winemaker Series Petit Manseng (Virginia)

Appellation: Los Olivos District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose on this bottling is seriously tropical, with candied honeydew, coconut oil and guava paste. The palate is oily and also tropically heavy, with mango and banana flavors.
Wine: Bellante 2017 Camp 4 Vineyard Viognier (Los Olivos District)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is a blend of fruit from the Obelisco and Klipsun vineyards. Band-Aid, dried black-cherry, game and medicine-cabinet aromas are followed by light, dried-out-seeming dark-fruit flavors. It doesn't all come together.
Wine: Guardian 2015 The Rookie Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas offer initial notes of burnt toast, char and reduction. The palate brings medium-bodied fruit flavors with a citrus-filled finish. Fruit and barrel clash here.
Wine: Gunpowder Creek 2016 Conner Lee Vineyard Sémillon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Horton
Review: The nose of this wine comes off slightly medicinal, with notes of walnuts, red earth and smoked bacon. The tannins are parching and dry out most of the fruit tones.
Wine: Horton 2014 Nebbiolo (Virginia)

Appellation: Kudos
Review: There's an odd, fishy scent that runs through this wine, which also has strong scents and flavors of cilantro, lime and grapefruit.
Wine: Kudos 2017 Riesling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Leese-Fitch
Review: A matchstick aroma leads to crisp lemon and apple flavors in this tangy medium-bodied non-oaky wine.
Wine: Leese-Fitch 2016 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Maryhill
Review: Aromas of raspberry and dried cherry lead to tacky-feeling fruit flavors. The variety seems hard to place.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Not entirely appealing aromas of tire rubber, red apple and cherry lead to an astringent feeling palate. Bitter tannins cap it off.
Wine: Three Rivers 2014 Champoux Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon (65%) and Merlot (22%) make up most of this wine, with the balance Cabernet Franc, Malbec and Petit Verdot. Cherry, baking-spice, red-apple and herb aromas are followed by lighter styled fruit flavors. The concentration doesn't seem all there.
Wine: Three Rivers 2014 Svelte Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: In this blend of Cabernet Franc (51%) and Merlot, aromas of flower, blueberry pie, currant and green pepper lead to elegantly styled green-pepper flavors, with a squeeze of tannin at the end. The concentration seems quite dilute.
Wine: Three Rivers 2016 Trivulet Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine has a slight metallic edge to it, a twist that muddles the heartiness of its tropical fruit and creamy texture.
Wine: Provenance Vineyards 2016 Wildwood Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Rutherford)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Reserved at first on the nose, this bottling slowly shows red cherry, dried cranberry, spearmint and tarragon on the nose. The palate is tremendously ripe and thick with flavors of overcooked cranberry, more mint and a touch of anise.
Wine: Europa Village 2015 C'est La Vie Winemaker's Reserve Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: James Charles
Review: Honeysuckle, white peach and hazelnut are prominent on the nose and lead into flavors of stone fruit and geranium. Off dry and concentrated, it has a slight spritz on the finish.
Wine: James Charles 2017 Riesling (Virginia)

Appellation: Château Souverain
Review: This wine offers jammy aromas and a softly textured palate that boasts rich berry-fruit flavors. This is a simple, straightforward pour.
Wine: Château Souverain 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Shooting Star
Review: Thick in texture and more savory than fruity in flavor, this medium-bodied wine has a streak of sweetness like meringue on the palate
Wine: Shooting Star 2017 Chardonnay (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This is a thin wine that does not rise above generic white wine flavors. Cucumber and unripe melon finish with a twist of lemon. It was barrel fermented in neutral oak with no obvious impact.
Wine: Talent 2017 Easy Valley Alderbanks Vineyard Chardonnay (Oregon)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is mostly Cabernet Sauvignon (83%), along with pinches of Syrah, Cabernet Franc and Merlot. Aromas of medicine cabinet, dried cherry and spice are followed by medium-bodied fruit flavors, with medicine-cabinet notes on the finish. It doesn't all come together.
Wine: Ambassador Vineyard 2015 Estate Grown Diplomat Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Very faint aromas of lemon and wet stone lead to similarly indistinct flavors on the palate. This is well balanced yet demure, with a finish that is clean but drops off quickly.
Wine: Barboursville Vineyards 2017 Reserve Fiano (Virginia)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The name of this cuvée refers to the label graphic of a rabbit, which adorns this new series of inexpensive wines from Coelho. Initially intended for a sparkling wine program, this is quite light and tart, with a rather flat mouthfeel.
Wine: Coelho 2017 Bunny Cuvée Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Rascal
Review: This seems to be an unsettled mix of grassy, not-quite-ripe fruit, and enough residual sugar to hide or block some of that herbaceousness. Although the companion Rose City Pinot Gris has some of that same grassiness, here it's more obvious and the sweetness doesn't really help to hide it.
Wine: Rascal 2017 Pinot Gris (Oregon)

Appellation: Van Ruiten
Review: Fruit flavors take the lead in this medium-bodied, lightly sweet wine. It gushes cherry and raspberry aromas, coats the palate with a pleasant jammy character and feels soft in texture.
Wine: Van Ruiten 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of blueberry pie, tire rubber and flower lead to medium-sweet-seeming fruit flavors with a grip of tannin. It doesn't all come together.
Wine: 14 Hands 2015 Hot to Trot Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Green-olive tapenade makes for a zesty backbone against which a confounding confectionery flavor takes over on the palate in this uncertain wine.
Wine: Landmark 2016 Overlook Chardonnay (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas bring notes of mint, dried cherry, orange peel, cranberry and spice, all seeming a bit dried out. The fruit flavors are light and bunched up.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Otis Vineyard Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Monticello, Virginia, US
Review: This is an easy-drinking, fruit-driven rosé. A white grape tone dominates the nose and palate, with touches of ripe berry notes.
Wine: Stinson 2017 Rosé of Tannat (Monticello)

Appellation: 14 Hands
Review: Lighter in color, aromas of tire rubber, braised green pepper, herb and cherry are followed by lightly sweet, lightly concentrated fruit flavors. It doesn't all work.
Wine: 14 Hands 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Crooked Path
Review: Very pruney aromas kick off this quite over-extracted and overripe bottling. That leads into a palate dominated by raisin flavors as well as a roasted meat touch, while the acidity is persistent.
Wine: Crooked Path 2015 Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Aromas of tire rubber, green olive and cherry lead to lighter styled raspberry flavors. The concentration seems quite light, with herb and sweet barrel notes on the finish.
Wine: Watermill 2016 Chances R Red (Columbia Valley (OR))

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Aromas of chalk, pineapple and orange blossom are faint on the nose. The palate turns more salty in flavor, with a light body and mild acidity.
Wine: The Williamsburg Winery 2017 Limited Release Arneis (Virginia)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: This off-dry Vidal Blanc has overripe aromas of peach nectar and pear drop. The palate is equally tropical in a strong papaya note. It's an easy-drinker, with light acidity and a thin body.
Wine: CrossKeys 2016 Joy Vidal Blanc (Virginia)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Fruit-forward cranberry, cherry, blackberry and blueberry aromas are followed by quite light, ever so slightly sweet fruit flavors. It goes down easy, though the concentration is extremely faint.
Wine: Sagelands 2016 Riverbed Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Blackberry and cedar highlight this full-bodied but quickly aging wine. A sunbaked balsamic character in the aroma is followed by lots of fruit and moderate spices wrapped in firm tannins.
Wine: Suveg 2014 Problem Child Syrah (Lodi)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Lemon-lime aromas start off this straightforward wine. A decent vein of acidity carries the lemon-driven palate.
Wine: Veramar 2017 JB Winemaker Series Chardonnay (Virginia)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: This off-dry blend of Chardonnay and Seyval Blanc is lead by tropical fruit on the nose and palate. It's an easy drinker with a thin body and mild acidity.
Wine: Bogati 2017 Tango Blu White (Virginia)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: The nose of this dessert wine offers oxidative notes of dried apple, fresh nuts and marzipan. The acidity is high and the palate feels disjointed.
Wine: Veramar 2017 D'Ora Vidal Blanc (Virginia)

Appellation: Scott Family
Review: This wine has offbeat flavors of fig and green olive. It is full in body and ripe in feel.
Wine: Scott Family 2016 Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: James Charles
Review: Very faint aromas of lime zest show a bit more definition on the palate. The acidity is abrasive and high, leading to a long, tart finish.
Wine: James Charles 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Virginia)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas are light, with notes of blackberry and spice. The palate brings an astringent feel, with abundant bitter notes on the finish.
Wine: Claar 2014 White Bluffs Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has a harsh fuzziness to the texture and a strong aroma of grass and canned pea.
Wine: Merriam 2017 Danielle Vineyard Estate Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Veramar
Review: Intense aromas of charred lemon, overripe banana, papaya, butterscotch and cheese rind are a bit inharmonious. These tones feel heavy on the palate, with an oily, mouthcoating texture.
Wine: Veramar 2017 Chardonnay (Virginia)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: High-toned aromas of overripe melon, lychee, ginkgo nuts and Frosted Flakes are a bizarre blend on the nose. These tones carry to the palate, leading to a finish that is long and warm, with over-the-top tropical fruit flavors.
Wine: Jefferson Vineyards 2016 Reserve Petit Manseng (Virginia)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: The fruit flavors of this full-bodied wine are very ripe and also mature to the point of resembling balsamic. The wine shows earthy sage aromas, cherry and raspberry vinaigrette flavors.
Wine: Suveg 2014 Table Dancer Syrah (Lodi)

Appellation: Rotation Vineyards
Review: This light-bodied wine is drinkable in a pinch. It has a slightly murky, brownish tint in the color, earthy and herbal aromas and a light veggie flavor.
Wine: Rotation Vineyards 2016 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: The Williamsburg Winery
Review: Tropical and overripe on the nose with aromas of papaya, honeydew and geranium, this Sauvignon Blanc is equally tropical on the palate. Full in body and warm, this feels thick and coating and has a finish lingers on an overripe papaya note.
Wine: The Williamsburg Winery 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Virginia)

Appellation: Petaluma Gap, Sonoma, California, US
Review: There's something off-putting about the acidity in this wine—a disjointed experience that's bracing on the palate.
Wine: Barber 2017 Belle Marie Black Knight Vineyard Chardonnay (Petaluma Gap)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This is most disappointing after a good 2014. Flat to the point of dead in the mouth, it shows little fruit and a residual flavor of plastic and menthol.
Wine: Cathedral Ridge 2015 McDuffee Vineyard Reserve Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (OR))

Appellation: Horton
Review: Aromas of struck match and flint lead the nose. The palate is racy and metallic, giving way to a short finish.
Wine: Horton 2017 Vidal Blanc (Virginia)

Appellation: Sagelands
Review: Aromas of canned corn and peach are followed by quite dilute fruit flavors. It's a miss.
Wine: Sagelands 2016 Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Barrel-fermented in acacia wood, this wine is reduced and quite harsh. It lacks in fruit tones.
Wine: DeLorimier 2017 Spectrum Sauvignon Blanc (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Fort Ross-Seaview, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Even in its youth this wine packs a punch and delivers unbelievable beauty, opening in aromas of perfume and game. Seductive, supple and spicy, it is undoubtedly full figured and hauntingly complex, with layers of dark cherry, charcuterie, sea breeze and forest floor. The tannins are firm yet polished, intense yet behaved. The salty, briny, beguiling minerality is what lingers longest on the finish.
Wine: Wayfarer 2015 Wayfarer Vineyard Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Fort Ross-Seaview)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Extra time in bottle has benefited this wine and brought out its inner beauty. It's balanced and complex on the palate, with concentrated flavors of jammy blackberry, clove and white pepper that are supported by polished tannins. Hints of vanilla and nutmeg ring on the finish.
Wine: Venge 2012 DLCV Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Named for the producer's high-elevation on Pritchard Hill, this is 100% varietal from one clone, aged in a wealth of French oak. Juicy, extracted berry flavor (both red and black) make it expansive on the palate, with elements of cocoa powder, sage, crushed rock and gravel adding intrigue and invitation. The tannins are sweet and polished. Age a bit and enjoy 2024–2034.
Wine: David Arthur 2014 Elevation 1147 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a complex, concentrated and crowd-pleasing wine, blended with 7% Petit Verdot and 5% Malbec. Pencil shavings, crayon wax and a juicy core of blackberry pie give it a savory richness, succulence and length, with enough underlying acidity to keep it fresh and behaved despite its density and structure.
Wine: Plumpjack 2015 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: From Tom and Martha May's famous, organically farmed site in the heart of the appellation, this is a blockbuster vintage of the 100% varietal wine, immaculately structured and full of fresh acidity. The menthol is there, subtle, heightened by delicate, silky layerings of orange peel, red currant and cinnamon. Drink 2023–2033.
Wine: Heitz 2013 Martha's Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Winemaker Kirk Venge makes this small-production offering as a memoriam to his mother. Made in a robust, richly layered style, it's thick and rich in waves of soy, meat and blackberry jam on toast. The grippy, youthful tannins provide a firm structure, with finishing touches of coconut and milk chocolate.
Wine: Venge 2015 DLCV Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: A sinewy nose leads the way to extracted flavors of red cherry, sage and rocky mineral. Offering length and breadth for days, the minerality is accentuated by graphite and crushed stone, while a rich red-currant flavor rules the midpalate. The toasted oak imparts a taste of coconut macaroon. Best from 2024–2034.
Wine: Venge 2014 DLCV Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: From the producer's 45-acre estate vineyard in the heart of the appellation, this contains 16% Merlot and small handfuls of the other Bordeaux red varieties. Together, they offer a harmoniously racy, rich and round experience and soft silky tannin. Juicy up-front black and red raspberries linger into lilting spice components, sage and violet. This will age well. Enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Odette 2015 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Appellation: Calistoga, Napa, California, US
Review: Perfumed and pretty, this tastes of cherry cordial, with additional supple, well-integrated tones of fresh red cherry and cassis. Persistent in bright, underlying acidity, it has a powerful midpalate of weighty tannin and oak. The succulent finish is densely packed in black pepper and clove.
Wine: Venge 2015 Bone Ash Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Calistoga)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This excellent bottling blends power with finesse, showing fresh red and black cherries, a smoky earthiness and pretty hints of red rose petals and hibiscus on the nose. The flavors are very cohesive and expertly woven on the palate, where bright red fruit is lifted by star anise spice and framed by a taut texture and uplifting acid. Stunning depth.
Wine: Rusack 2014 Solomon Hills Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The winery's first Syrah offering from this esteemed vineyard after years on the waiting list (hence the name), this stunner brings huckleberry, green herb, mountain blueberry, dried flower, orange peel, iron and bacon fat aromas. Its rich, intense and focused smoked meat and flower flavors linger on the finish for a full 45 seconds. Another feather in the cap for this winery and vineyard.
Wine: Two Vintners 2015 The Waiting List Boushey Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: This small-production offering is defined by a nose of nutmeg and clove. It explodes handsomely on the palate in jammy blackberry and dark chocolate, with a plush texture and concentrated, rich fruit that lingers. It balances that richness in bright, well-defined acidity.
Wine: Venge 2013 DLCV Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Williams Selyem
Review: A showcase of great winemaking, this has fruit from both the Sonoma Coast and Russian River Valley appellations. Complex, structured and built with strong textural components, it boasts melded flavors of fresh strawberry, citrus and blueberry, as well as lingering notes of black tea and baking spice.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a jammy wine with a lot of life. It's moderately structured and fruity in blackberry and cherry flavors. Cedar and dried herb tones add complexity to the expansive midpalate, which is sticky in tannin and oak. It will benefit from more time in the bottle; enjoy 2024–2030.
Wine: Black Stallion 2014 Transcendent Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This stainless steel-fermented wine is dry, fresh and delightful. Flavors of apricot and white peach tease the palate and are joined by grapefruit, wet stone and lime zest. The vibrant acidity lingers alongside tones of ginger and oyster shell on the finish.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2017 Dutton Ranch Green Valley Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Green Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Wow, this is a beautiful wine. A blend of 77% Pinot Grigio from the Napa Valley's Chiles Valley and 23% Greco from Russian River Valley, winemaker Dan Petroski melds them both together into a floral and fresh explosion of vivid flavor. Tart apricot and peach meet freshly squeezed lemon as balanced acidity lingers masterfully on the finish.
Wine: Massican 2017 Gemina White (California)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Extremely light yet lovely aromas of hibiscus, pomegranate, strawberry, wet slate and sagebrush show on the nose of this bottling from an iconic vineyard atop the appellation. The palate balances tannic weight with acidic energy, carrying flavors of white pepper, fresh thyme and fresh pomegranate and hibiscus, going down easy but with circumstance.
Wine: Rusack 2015 Mt. Carmel Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This estate-grown block-designate is insanely good, soft and spicy in black and white pepper from first sip. Elongated, chalky tannins support bright, fresh acidity and strong, well-defined flavors of leather pouch, crushed rock and cherry. The texture is supple and complex.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 1910 Block Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A matchstick tone rules the nose of this tremendously powerful white, which evolves to show toasted oak and salty notes. The robust palate unravels in layers of Gravenstein apple, fig and crushed rock, with plenty of length on the nutmeg-laden finish.
Wine: Hertelendy 2015 Ritchie Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dark in color, this comes from a coastal and rugged Annapolis-area site. Dark cherry, blood orange and pomegranate flavors ride along a midpalate of dense, bold and layered concentration, finding life from ample acidity, wild spice and anise on the lengthy finish.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2015 Redwood Ridge Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Muted at first, this reserve wine shows a deft hand. A red currant tone is met by a mild grip of tannins and a soft midpalate that is lightly rich in coconut shavings and mocha. Supple and balanced in richness, it offers classic flavors of cassis and cherry wrapped in supportive oak.
Wine: Groth 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: From a certified-organic vineyard in Rutherford, this is a 100% varietal wine that impresses from start to finish, allowing room for a slight whiff of reduction and tar on the nose. Dark notions of coffee are interwoven between bright layers of cassis and red cherry around structured acidity and oak. Enjoy 2020–2028.
Wine: Heitz 2012 Trailside Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose on this iconic bottling is tightly wound and reminiscent of springtime, with fresh lily, white melon, Meyer lemon pith and faint butter aromas. It's zesty and zippy on the palate with chalky flavors, showing Pink Lady apple flesh in the midpalate and a racy grapefruit acidity that carries into the finish.
Wine: Sea Smoke 2015 Monopole Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Earthy mint, sage and lavender make for a heady, aromatic introduction to this wine, which continues to impress on the palate in its delicate layering of strawberry and fresh focused acidity. Balanced and light in style, it shows the nuanced greatness of the vintage as well.
Wine: The Withers Winery 2016 Peters Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Chiles Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: From organically grown estate fruit, 100% varietal, this is a lovely wine, high-toned in acidity and impressively balanced all around. Elegant, polished tannins support dark brooding blackberry, black currant and coffee with a complex lingering note of black pepper and bittersweet chocolate on the finish.
Wine: Volker Eisele Family Estate 2014 Sievers Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Chiles Valley)

Appellation: Anaba
Review: This is a delightfully earthy, delicate wine, juicy in light waves of red cherry and pomegranate that are accented by notes of dried herb and cinnamon. The palate is expansively plush yet silky.
Wine: Anaba 2015 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Grassini
Review: Full and soft on the nose, this lush bottling from one of the premiere estates in the region offers aromas of black cherry, caramelized blackberry and spice cake. Polished tannins and a vibrant acidity frame the palate, where lively red-fruit flavors are lifted by peppery spices. Though delicious now, this will last for years. Drink 2019–2029.
Wine: Grassini 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Estate-vineyard designated, pressed like a white wine and aged on its lees in stainless steel, this wine is pale pink in color and deliciously textured, with a richly rewarding midpalate and plenty of balanced acidity. Fresh raspberry, strawberry and watermelon laced in mint all play a memorable role.
Wine: Inman Family 2017 Endless Crush OGV Estate Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aged in neutral puncheons, this wine has aromas that pop, recalling white pepper, dried herbs, raspberry compote, strawberries and spice. The flavors are rich and intense but still maintain a sense of lightness and purity. The depth of the fruit is impressive, with wonderful texture and richness that come in waves. A long, sustained finish caps it off.
Wine: Latta 2014 Upland Vineyard Grenache (Snipes Mountain)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: The Rusack family's quest to grow grapes on Catalina Island continues with great success in this bottling, which is light in the glass and shows loads of sagebrush, forest spice, red cherry and grenadine on the inviting nose. The palate is exuberant with energy and deeply layered with flavors of juniper, rosewater, hibiscus and strawberry.
Wine: Rusack 2015 Santa Catalina Island Vineyards Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Rich flavors of dark chocolate and blueberry cobbler give this wine an inviting taste of sunshine-filled Napa Valley fruit. Its tannins and oak are well integrated, with supportive acidity keeping the experience in check and mouthwateringly delicious through the close.
Wine: Venge 2015 Family Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Rich flavors of dark chocolate and blueberry cobbler give this wine an inviting taste of sunshine-filled Napa Valley fruit. Its tannins and oak are well integrated, with supportive acidity keeping the experience in check and mouthwateringly delicious through the close.
Wine: Venge 2015 Family Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a delicious bottling from Winemaker Paul Clifton. It opens with beautiful aromas of crisp pomegranate, red plum, sweet bay leaf and sagebrush, combining fresh fruit with sultry, earthy spice. A flash of ripe fruit kicks off the palate, followed by dried fennel fronds, rhubarb, wild thyme and tobacco, making for a fresh, herbal experience.
Wine: Hahn 2015 SLH Orchestral Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: The famous site delivers its classic grace and power, this producer's rendering an exploration of sanguine black olive and pungent, floral violet. With toffee, coffee and chocolate components on the midpalate, make no mistake this is a rich, concentrated wine, plush in tannin weight and texture.
Wine: Janzen 2015 Beckstoffer To Kalon Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The 50% Grenache and 46% Mourvèdre in this blend were sourced from Snipes Mountain, while the Syrah hails from the Rocks District. It offers pomegranate, kirsch, white pepper, orange peel and exotic spice aromas. The palate is full bodied and dazzlingly pure, with knee-buckling texture and density and a long, fruit-filled finish. A knockout.
Wine: Latta 2014 Latta Latta G-S-M (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: Highly expressive and elegant, this classic wine offers tones of red cherry, cassis, cinnamon and cola. It is a layered, high-toned yet balanced red that is understated in its ripe character.
Wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2014 The Leap Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the heart of the appellation, this vineyard-designate wine starts off with heady violet and black tea aromas. The juicy palate offers a tremendous depth of flavor in tones of citrus, black cherry and strawberry, with a supple, silky texture.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Olivet Lane Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Perennially delicious, this is a thick, structured wine with underlying elegance and finesse. A baked cherry flavor is enveloped in sweet spice, cola and lavender, uplifted by lively acidity. It is a crowd-pleasing wine that offers plenty of complexity.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Westside Road Neighbors Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a deliciously elegant wine with robust Napa Valley fruit. Reduced on the nose, and showing a depth of oak, it offers sage, blueberry and black-currant flavors wrapped in chocolate-covered espresso beans. Tightly concentrated it has tremendous structure and a hint of dust on the finish.
Wine: Cade 2015 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Calera
Review: This delicious bottling from the iconic estate is clean and taut on the nose, with aromas of lemon peel, Pink Lady apple, honeysuckle and a hint of toast. The palate is extremely well rounded and deep, showing fleshy flavors of ripe apple and white peach before savory sea salt and zesty lemon rind cut through the buttered sourdough midpalate.
Wine: Calera 2016 Chardonnay (Mt. Harlan)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: From the Pritchard Hill producer's estate within an estate, this is dusty in currant and sinewy leather, with a lingering note of resin, violet and graphite. Full bodied and concentrated in black cherry and currant, it shows a density that's complex yet beautifully balanced. Enjoy 2024–2030.
Wine: David Arthur 2014 Three Acre Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
Review: This wine is exceptionally concentrated and flavorful, but retains a hint of restraint in the very firm texture. Aromas of charred wood and black pepper waft up from the glass before concentrated, quiet but deep flavors of black olive, blackberry and oolong tea coat the palate. A massive layer of fine-grained tannins creates a velvety texture that helps carry all the opulent flavors through a lingering finish. Best after 2024.
Wine: Enkidu 2015 Diener Ranch Petite Sirah (Red Hills)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: This reserve-level wine offers impressive extraction and concentration within a full-bodied, complex package of tobacco and sage. The fruit is classically mountain-grown in its intensity, black and liqueur-like, with touches of coconut and dark chocolate.
Wine: Ladera 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Cranberry colored, this is an earthy wine, substantial yet balanced, with a mix of dried herb, strawberry, blood orange and lemon-lime flavors. Vibrantly fresh and dry, it delivers a refreshing experience.
Wine: Lynmar 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Passing Time
Review: This wine contains mostly Cabernet Sauvignon from Discovery and Champoux vineyards, with pinches of Klipsun Merlot (8%) and Champoux Cabernet Franc (4%). Its black currant, cassis, blackberry, graphite, scorched earth and herb notes intoxicate. The palate is ripe, textured, layered and generous but still tightly wound, with polished tannins and an extremely long finish. It is a Cabernet Sauvignon prototype—a complete standout that is delicious now but will have a long life in the cellar. Best from 2023–2035.
Wine: Passing Time 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: The Bee is made of 50% of Muscat Canelli, which is blended with 47% Arneis and 3% Cortese. It refreshes and intrigues, offering pure pleasure and a challenge to the palate in its tension of acidity and stony earth. It indeed evokes honeycomb and wildflowers, with a salty brininess that keeps it in the brain long after it's gone.
Wine: Idlewild 2017 The Bee Flora and Fauna White (North Coast)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Blended with 12% Petit Verdot, this comes from spot picking the estate site for older estate vines atop Pritchard Hill. Floral in violet, it's smoothly textured and lightly spiced, with a delightful brambly note of black raspberry. The tannins are expansive and slightly sweet in mint chocolate, complementing the peppery, spicy elements well.
Wine: David Arthur 2014 Old Vine Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% varietal wine draws you into the glass with its apricot, beeswax, and straw aromas. The palate is full bodied and richly textured, showing a lot of viscosity and weight as well as tension to the fruit flavors. It's a standout with gravitas—a red wine lover's white. Savor its hyper-extended finish. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Latta 2014 Lawrence Vineyards Roussanne (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: With a healthy, welcoming intrigue of spice, this estate-grown wine is dusty and leathery in approach and texture, with lovely layers of red licorice and dark cherry. The acidity is interwoven throughout the full-bodied concentration of flavor, with a finishing touch of white pepper.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 Estate Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made entirely from Pinot Noir sourced from throughout the appellation, this is an infinitely quaffable, well-made wine, with tons of structure and grace. Watermelon, strawberry and a kiss of lemon combine effortlessly and with lasting acidity.
Wine: Paper Planes 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Paradise Springs
Review: This blend of the John Sebastiano, Hilliard Bruce and Sanford & Benedict vineyards excels in fruit and earth, showing black cherry, muddy loam and fennel on the nose. Forest floor and moss are front-loaded on the palate, which gains mushroom, juniper and tangy plum skin toward the complex finish.
Wine: Paradise Springs 2015 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is one of the more exciting rosés of the year, and not just because actor Billy Zane used Thomas Fire ash in his label painting. Pale pink in color, the wine shows chalk and light nectarine on the nose before offering strawberry glacé, a hint of bubblegum, kumquat acidity and an extremely chalky texture on the palate. Proceeds go to fire's victims.
Wine: Paradise Springs 2017 Pink Ash Rosé (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Starmont
Review: This is a beautifully made wine that is richly textured and expressive in dried herb, cedar and understated accompaniments of cherry and vanilla. Dry, integrated tannins round out the texture and provide structure.
Wine: Starmont 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Stewart
Review: Plummy strawberry, blueberry and a voluptuous undertaking of baking spice combine effortlessly and with a great depth of flavor in this juicy, lengthy wine, full-bodied but retentive of enough acidity to complement the robust fruit and body.
Wine: Stewart 2015 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Davies
Review: This is a remarkable deal for the quality and the appellation—a winning study in dusty sage, pencil shavings and lean, well-integrated fruit. A small percentage of Malbec is added, the whole Old World in style and nature, with supple texture and lasting earth and cola spice.
Wine: Davies 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of 65% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Merlot, 9% Cabernet Franc 1% Petit Verdot comes from some of the state's oldest plantings. Its vibrant, complex blackberry, cranberry, black currant, green pepper and dried herb aromas lead to a light, tightly wound but elegant palate with exquisite balance and texture. The finish goes on as long as you care to count. Far from a big, bold bruiser, this is a very sophisticated wine. Best 2026–2034.
Wine: DeLille 2014 Harrison Hill Red (Snipes Mountain)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: With 6% Malbec, this mighty, majestic wine offers crushed rock, graphite and sage on the nose, painting an inviting portrait of its mountain provenance. Richly structured and powerfully built, it exudes freshly picked black cherry and blueberry, finishing in a touch of black and white pepper.
Wine: Krupp Brothers 2014 Veraison Stagecoach Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of 63% Cabernet Sauvignon, 29% Malbec and 8% Merlot comes from Loess, Mill Creek Upland and Seven Hills vineyards. Its aromas are still locked up, offering incense, barrel spice, cherry, raspberry, anise and scorched earth notes as it opens. The palate is packed to the brim with black fruit flavors and tightly wound tannins, maintaining its sophistication long into the finish. It needs time to come into its own but has a very long life ahead of it. Best 2026–2033.
Wine: Leonetti Cellar 2015 Reserve Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dark orange in color, this whole-cluster offering is juicy and delicious in fresh flavors of strawberry and blood orange. Tight, vibrant acidity keeps it exciting and focused, while a posh mouthfeel gives it context and complexity.
Wine: Magna Porcum 2017 Sue Volans Whole Cluster Rosé of Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Smooth and fruity, this indulgent wine is a new luxury-level offering from one of Lodi's most adventurous winemakers. It drenches the palate with extraripe blackberry and blueberry fruit, alongside a polished, creamy texture that helps the flavors cling on the finish. It is a deeply colored, full-bodied and moderately tannic wine.
Wine: Michael David 2015 Rapture Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Passing Time
Review: Almost entirely Klipsun Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon, this includes 3% Bacchus Vineyard Cabernet Franc. The aromas are effusive, with red and black raspberry, scorched earth, blackberry bramble, espresso, herb, green pepper and spice notes, revealing more on each swirl. The palate is suave and sophisticated, showing compelling texture and structure. The finish sails. Though delicious now, patience will be rewarded. Best 2025–2032, but it will have plenty of life beyond that.
Wine: Passing Time 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a blend of 71% Cabernet Sauvignon, 14% Syrah, 8% Malbec and 7% Petit Verdot, aged more than two years in 100% new French oak. It's wonderfully layered, with hints of black pepper, leather and gamy meat. Big, bold and lush, it's enjoyable now in its power but will do well in the cellar. Enjoy 2024–2034.
Wine: Black Stallion 2014 Bucephalus Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Coombsville, Napa, California, US
Review: Not many of these magnums were made, the wine within 100% varietal and aged for 44 months in new French oak. Fruity with a floral nose, it's layered and tart in pomegranate, red currant and dried herb, showing big tannin weight and a hearty complexity. It has ages to go in the big bottle, too. Enjoy 2020–2030.
Wine: Robert John 2013 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Appellation: Stony Hill
Review: Woody, expansive, gritty and grippy, this is an exotic, delicately layered wine from the historic producer, so good in its complexity and lightness of being. Bread and salted butter greet lemon zest and stone fruit along with a line of sophisticated acidity and stony mineral intrigue. This wine will do well in the cellar; enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Stony Hill 2015 Chardonnay (Spring Mountain District)

Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
Review: Grown on the producer's Home Ranch, this offers flavors of juicy peach, stone and white flower, with the midpalate bringing tangy tones of Meyer lemon and grapefruit. Balanced through and through, it shows lushness on the finish.
Wine: Trefethen 2017 Family Owned Estate Grown Dry Riesling (Oak Knoll District)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From one of the producer's coolest sourced sites, this sings in aromas of rose petal, earthy stone and tobacco. The palate brings tangy cranberry and raspberry flavors, with lingering tones of orange peel and clove. The tannins are substantial yet tamed.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Terra De Promissio Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is blended with a hearty 14% Petit Verdot and smaller additions of Merlot and Malbec. Together, they form a harmonious whole of soft, supple and densely packed flavor, characterized by red currant, earthy dried herb, plum and crayon that finishes in bold tannin and dark chocolate.
Wine: Chappellet 2015 Signature Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Seductively perfumed, this is a thick, velvety wine with a grip of earthiness that never lets go. Cola, black cherry and a bolt of clove keep it inviting and complicated in the glass, yet ultimately pleasurable, soft and silky with a length of toasted oak on the finish.
Wine: Croix 2015 Thomas Road Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Los Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Earth, mushroom and a touch of reduction are savory complements to moderate structure and balanced ripeness in this pretty, expressive wine. Succulent cherry and strawberry dominate and provide welcome contrast.
Wine: Fallon Place 2016 Herbitage Vineyard Pinot Noir (Los Carneros)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from a southern Italian grape grown in Carneros, this testifies to a happy new home. Vinified as a white wine, this is lightly orange in color and hearty in aromas of earth and flowers. Lively acidity supports a wealth of white peach, grapefruit and hazelnut, lightly ripe and easy to sip with abandon.
Wine: Hudson Vineyards 2017 Estate Grown Aleatico (Carneros)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Made entirely from Cabernet Sauvignon grown in this Yountville-area site, this is red-fruit forward, full bodied and expansive in waves of flavor and complexity. Compressed tannins round out the structure and powerful grip.
Wine: Janzen 2015 Beckstoffer Missouri Hopper Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Quite light in the glass, this bottling by Ryan Beauregard shows loads of cinnamon, forest floor, candied pomegranate, thyme and sage on the nose. There is bountiful energy on the palate, which carries flavors of bay leaf, juniper and candied raspberry, framed by tense tannins.
Wine: Beauregard 2014 Beauregard Ranch Pinot Noir (Ben Lomond Mountain)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot offers dried black cherry, fruit leather, barrel spice, espresso, graphite, cassis, anise and scorched earth aromas. They lead to broad, textured but supple fruit flavors and a fruit-filled finish. Firm, integrated tannins provide support. Best 2023–2028.
Wine: DeLille 2014 Chaleur Estate Red (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Howell Mountain Vineyards
Review: Bright red fruit and acidity complement this wine's overall power and concentration, buoyed by supple tannin and quiet oak. Violet aromas give it additional complexity and elegance, a nice contrast to the black cherry and cassis.
Wine: Howell Mountain Vineyards 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Though a bit older than most current Chardonnays, this bottling from the region's most historic vineyard hardly shows a hint of age. Aromas of lemon curd, lime zest and walnut are both fresh and warm on the nose. The palate is lively with Bosc pear flavors yet also leans rich, with sea salt caramel and a hint of butterscotch riding far into the finish.
Wine: Sanford 2014 Sanford & Benedict Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Piedmontese-inspired owner and winemaker Sam Bilbro, born, raised and based in Sonoma County, picks selectively to make this light, refreshingly complex wine, cofermenting 47% Nebbiolo with 28% Barbera and 25% Dolcetto. It holds its acidity well, balancing it against a backdrop of fruity tangy grapefruit and orange, with a mineral stoniness that's hard to pin down.
Wine: Idlewild 2017 Flora and Fauna Rosé (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Hertelendy
Review: This is a big and billowy red, offering plenty of concentration. But its soul delivers underlying elegance, the tannins polished and lengthy, complementing the dark brooding plum, cocoa powder, marshmallow and coconut that meld together seamlessly.
Wine: Hertelendy 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Left on skins for 35 days and aged in 40% new French oak, this wine is perfumed, with plum, mulberry, green herb, clove, orange peel, scorched earth and exotic spice notes. The flavors are deep and layered, with spice notes speckled throughout. The balance is exquisite and the finish long. A stunning example of the variety.
Wine: Latta 2014 Northridge Vineyard Malbec (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Newton
Review: Dusty leather and an Old World savory and feral nose, are accented by dried herb and pyrazine in this sinewy red. Pencil shavings, cedar and black olive stay on the classic theme, with plush, expansive tannins gripping the palate with finesse.
Wine: Newton 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Mount Veeder)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: This memorable wine opens with a touch of noble reduction and diesel, showing complexity before opening in the glass. Dusty tar and chalky, polished tannin follow alongside dense, concentrated layers of black fruit, coffee and dried herb.
Wine: Risk 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Very chalky and tight on the nose, this bottling from the extremely challenging vineyard on Catalina Island is a powerful success, also showing Meyer lemon sorbet and Asian pear aromas. It's tightly woven on the palate, with crushed white rock and key-lime spritz flavors, reminiscent of Chablis.
Wine: Rusack 2016 Santa Catalina Island Vineyards Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Shadybrook
Review: A soft entry greets the palate of this well-made wine, complex in its earthiness and supple, polished tannins. With breadth and length, it shines in clove, leather and cedar, ending on notes of toasted oak and black cherry.
Wine: Shadybrook 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: A fine varietal wine blended with 20% Petite Sirah, this tastes of chocolate-covered cherry with sprinkles of white pepper. It's truly balanced in its youth, with a lasting grip of tannins that are pierced by fresh acidity.
Wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2014 Audentia Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is linear and fresh, with a youthful intensity of tropical flavor and oak. Fennel, lemon peel, stone fruit and stony minerality are met by high-toned acidity that buzzes beneath the power and richness. This wine unravels slowly and with complexity.
Wine: Three Sticks 2016 Gap's Crown Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Brioche, hazelnut and a touch of apple skin rise on the nose of this lovely, rich and high-toned wine. Tart acidity presents as crushed rock and stone with a balanced sense of concentration and ripeness that makes it deliciously ready for the table.
Wine: Three Sticks 2016 Origin Durell Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Effusive fruit aromas and flavors are well matched by complex wood, smoke and black pepper accents. The berry and cherry components taste quite ripe, and the oaky, spicy and gamy characters doesn't overwhelm the fruit. A generous mouthfeel completes the profile.
Wine: V. Sattui 2015 Amador Ridge Vineyard Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Benovia
Review: Generously rich and layered, this wine is also lovely in aromas of rose petal and lavender, its texture soft and supple. Dark cherry and red licorice give it fruity savory flavor around a full-bodied ripeness that will please a broad array of palates.
Wine: Benovia 2015 Zinfandel (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Winemaker Bret Urness isn't afraid to break with Old World traditions, and this atypical blend of 41% Chardonnay, 41% Roussanne and 18% Grenache Blanc shows why. The complex but seamless nose combines aromas of lemon, plum flesh, mango and a brush of almond. There is a toasty quality to the palate but also crisp lemony acidity, offering full flavors yet a tight texture.
Wine: Levo 2017 E-99 No. 2 White (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: The third release of this celebration of the Sonoma Coast, sourced from Gap's Crown Vineyard in the Petaluma Gap, this imparts lemon curd and apple skin in a robust body of concentrated richness and rounded texture. Tart, fresh and focused acidity balances the wine's larger-than-life tendencies.
Wine: Chateau St. Jean 2015 Le Seul Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Daou
Review: This is a great way to experience the richness of Daou without hurting the bank account too much. Hedonistic aromas of candied black cherry, caramel, vanilla cake and cola lead into a rich and powerful palate that's soft in texture and lively with exotic plum and black currant flavors.
Wine: Daou 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: A substantial 16% Malbec are 8% Petit Verdot are blended into this tribute to the late Jamie Davies, doyenne and cofounder of the estate. Perfumed, thick in pillowy tannin and bright in acidity, it offers a supple texture extended in mocha, black pepper and clove, with strong, lasting flavors of chocolate-covered cherry.
Wine: Davies 2015 JD Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Diamond Mountain District)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% Cabernet Sauvignon brings brooding notes of macerated black cherries, graphite, cedar, cassis, herb and barrel spice. Far from a big bruiser, the palate is all about nuance and sophistication, with impeccable balance, well-integrated tannins and a long finish. Best 2022–2027.
Wine: DeLille 2014 Grand Ciel Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of 68% Sauvignon Blanc and 32% Sémillon pops on the nose, with white grapefruit, guava, toast, fig, pineapple and herb notes. The flavors are rich and fruit-filled yet exquisitely balanced, with a knee-buckling texture and a warm finish. It's a standout.
Wine: DeLille 2016 Chaleur Blanc White (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Turned earth and forest floor provide a savory context for this boldly ripe, rich red. Dark cherry and raspberry flavors are hearty and complex, complemented by an array of gritty mineral and layered texture.
Wine: Hestan 2015 Vincent Christopher Walala Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of 90% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Syrah comes primarily from a block of the vineyard planted in 1988. Its aromas are focused, recalling char, toast, high-toned herbs, roasted coffee and cherries. The palate is rich, dense and structured, with a lovely texture. The oak is quite prominent at present. Give it some time to integrate.
Wine: J. Bookwalter 2015 Chapter 8 Conner-Lee Vineyard Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Raspberry and blackberry aromatics are strong and inviting in this wine, alongside streaks of violet and white pepper. Dried herb and a mix of Asian and baking spice combine for a welcome complexity and length of power in this full-bodied 100% varietal wine.
Wine: Meeker 2015 Hone #2 Shimmer Christensen Family Vineyard Syrah (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Lust is one of the seven deadly sins, and this tiny-production wine from Michael David is a fitting adjunct to the winery's Seven Deadly Zins offering. Spicy, perfumed oak aromas and equally spicy oak flavors accompany deep tones of black cherry and dark chocolate. The wine has a thick coating of tannins that helps support all the richness and elevated body.
Wine: Michael David 2015 Lust Zinfandel (Lodi)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Elegant, almost delicate, this complex and inviting wine from a Sangiovese specialist is medium bodied, well balanced and offers mostly subtle flavors that weave nicely through a supple and lightly firm texture. It has dried cherry and cranberry aromas, tangy fruit flavors and fine-grained tannins.
Wine: Noceto 2015 Riserva Barrel Select Sangiovese (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine from the Sierra Foothills is a minor classic, showing the textbook black-cherry and black-currant flavors, accented by hints of mint and cocoa, wrapped in a very firm but velvety texture of fine-grained tannins. Owner Steve Ryan made it from dry-farmed vines and aged it in French oak barrels for 22 months. Best now–2022.
Wine: Oakstone 2015 Reserve Estate de Cascabel Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Fair Play)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From a vineyard that's 1,100 feet above Woodside, this bottling offers rounded red cherry, grenadine, densely packed rose petals and potpourri on the nose. The palate is zesty with red flowers and fruit-punch flavors, floating across the tongue with vibrant acidity and a lighter mouthfeel.
Wine: Sante Arcangeli 2016 McConnell Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Thick, smoky and lightly spiced, this appellation wine shows moderate acidity and full-bodied concentration. Black tea, cardamom and baking spice give complexity to the upfront baked cherry and raspberry flavor, finishing in oaky texture.
Wine: Croix 2015 Narrow Gauge Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Mild spices and rich fruit flavors meld nicely in this full-bodied, plush-textured wine that is just as good as the stellar 2012. Attractive baking spice and cedar aromas precede ripe black cherry and cooked plum flavors. Moderate tannins add some extra structure. It is well-balanced and quite appetizing.
Wine: Darcie Kent Vineyards 2014 Clone 337 Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Mourvèdre makes up just over three-quarters of this wine, with the balance Syrah and Grenache Blanc—all picked on the same day. Aged 16 months in neutral oak, it has aromas draw you into the glass, suggesting black pepper, orange zest and savory herbs. The palate is delicate and nuanced—full of herb, black pepper and smoked meat flavors backed by firm tannins that need a few hours open to unwind. It's a unique, intriguing wine that should shine at the dinner table.
Wine: Devium 2016 French Creek Vineyard Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Deviating from its usual path of single-vineyard designates, this wine blends grapes from the Jentoft Vineyard in Green Valley with the coastal Putnam Vineyard near Annapolis. Relatively thick, oaky and tannic at first, it offers robust black fruit and complex texture, followed by handfuls of baking spice and supple intensity.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2015 Deviate Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Effort
Review: Candied black raspberry, white pepper and bay leaf make for a lively, aromatic entry to this bottling. There is an ample amount of acidity on the palate, but also plenty of fruit and spice, from dark berry to thyme and ginger.
Wine: Effort 2016 Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blended with 20% Syrah and coming from the Upper Mill Creek area, this offers perfumed notes of raspberries, fresh flowers, wild blueberries, white pepper, smoked meat, orange zest and herbs. The flavors are ripe and juicy, with pure fruit notes that carry long into the finish.
Wine: Elephant Seven 2016 Yellow Bird Vineyard Grenache (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: En Garde
Review: Tart tangy red fruit tastes slightly dried and fig-like in this lush plush red that's full bodied and ripe. The volcanic soils of the appellation accent mineral-laden teases of crushed rock and stone.
Wine: En Garde 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Light, floral and fragrant, this is a delicately layered wine that concurrently offers plenty of power and underlying richness of flavor. Strawberry and raspberry present with ease around a core of lovely earth and lingering Asian spice.
Wine: Kokomo 2016 Gopher Hill Block Peters Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is the first offering of this variety from the valley, from a recently planted vineyard by the SeVein project. Aged 44 months in a combination of amphorae and new and neutral French oak, it offers tightly wound aromas of blackberries, tar, dark plums, minerals and spices. Though high in acid, it's full of firmly structured dark fruit flavors. It needs some food alongside it as well as time in bottle to be properly appreciated, but the stuffing is there. Best after 2022.
Wine: Leonetti Cellar 2013 Serra Pedace Vineyard Aglianico (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Mabera
Review: This wine is delicious, dark and deep, from the almost-black color to spicy dark-chocolate aromas, extremely rich blueberry and espresso-bean flavors and a very firm tannic texture. The wine easily absorbs a lot of spicy oak and balances it with layers of fruit and fine-grained tannins. Best after 2025.
Wine: Mabera 2013 Petite Sirah (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Passing Time
Review: This 100% varietal wine blends fruit from Seven Hills and Pepper Bridge vineyards. The aromas draw you into the glass, recalling mocha, black cherries, fresh herbs and high toned spices. The palate is supple, refined and polished, with lightly grainy tannins lending support. It's a very pretty expression of the variety that should have a long life ahead of it.
Wine: Passing Time 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a big, bold, oaky and delicious wine from the first whiff of cedar and mint to the lingering, meaty, spicy finish. In between are layers of black cherry, blackberry and dark chocolate that coat the palate and a mouthfilling body braced by firm tannins.
Wine: Ruby Hill Winery 2014 Jewel Collection Series Estate Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Red plums, rust, turned earth, charred wood and oak-smoked meat aromas show on the nose of this bottling. There is a great bounce of acidity on the sip, where cranberry compote, sumac, orange rind and mulling-spice flavors take hold, finishing on a vanilla kick.
Wine: Sante Arcangeli 2016 Lester Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Crisp aromas of key lime pith, nectarine, lemon blossom and chalk show on the restrained, tightly woven nose of this bottling by Eric Mohseni. The palate offers a texturally tight feel, with supple flavors of grapefruit rind, cherimoya, honeysuckle and Gravenstein apple.
Wine: Zaca Mesa 2014 Estate Vineyard Roussanne (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: This top-tier wine from the Long Island sparkling house shows a wonderfully developed nose of toasted almond, citrus cream and brioche. Soft, small-bead bubbles roll across the palate, carrying a concentrated stream of citrus and salty nut flavors that linger for days on the finish. This méthode Champenoise is a blend of 45% Chardonnay, 40% Pinot Noir and 15% Pinot Meunier and was aged eight years on the lees.
Wine: Sparkling Pointe 2008 Brut Séduction (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Leonetti Cellar
Review: Blended with 12% Petit Verdot and 3% Cabernet Franc, this sophisticated wine shows its pedigree, with cocoa, anise, black tea, mint, black cherry, dried herb, bittersweet chocolate and flower aromas. The fruit seems ever so slightly dried out, with surprisingly restrained flavors, considering the warmth of the vintage, and a tight core of tannin that needs time to unwind. Red and black fruit flavors linger effortlessly on the finish. Best after 2025.
Wine: Leonetti Cellar 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Leonetti Cellar
Review: Hailing from Seven Hills, Loess, Leonetti Old Block and Mill Creek Upland vineyards, this is a standout offering of this variety. Its anise, dark fruit, mocha, spice, flower, earth and green pepper aromas lead to focused fruit flavors, with a firm spine of tannin, bright acidity and finish that carries. The structure augurs well for its longevity. Best 2021–2026.
Wine: Leonetti Cellar 2016 Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
Review: This lovely white has a bright, floral nose and is fresh in flavor. Well-textured, it offers a wealth of delicious peach skin, Meyer lemon and grapefruit pith, the tang and juiciness of the fruit flavors melded together in impressive harmony.
Wine: Materra Cunat Family Vineyards 2017 Cunat Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Oak Knoll District)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This study of richness blends 56% Tannat from the Bella Collina Vineyard with 44% Petite Sirah from Loma Seca to deliver deep and dark aromas of black currant, smoke and coffee-caramel candies. The palate offers joyous purple fruits along with vanilla and caramel, cut by tart plum skins. It is sure to please crowds seeking a mouth-filling wine.
Wine: Pulchella 2015 Awakening Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is invitingly fresh in floral rose and lavender, offering a broad depth of flavor around moderate acidity and plenty of enticing flesh and plush tannin. The layered fruit dips into strawberry, dark cherry and blackberry territory, mouthfilling and pleasurable on the lengthy, Asian-spiced finish.
Wine: Venge 2016 Bacigalupi Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Williams Selyem
Review: Earthy in baked citrus, black tea and clove, this wine offers a supple midpalate and plenty of length. Moderate acidity and balanced ripeness transition to a savory crushed-mineral tone. It's rich within reason, more elegant than robust.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
