Review: Rust and red cherry meet with rhubarb and sage oil on the nose of this bottling from an extremely coastal site north of Santa Cruz. Bountiful acidity cuts through the rhubarb, pomegranate and fig balsamic notes of the vibrant palate.
Wine: Beauregard 2014 Coast Grade Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ben Lomond Mountain)

Appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling is quite dense on the nose with aromas of forest pine, juniper, bay leaf, rusty earth and dried cherry. There is richness to the palate, where a shiitake mushroom and boysenberry meet with similar forest and juniper notes.
Wine: Beauregard 2015 Beauregard Ranch Pinot Noir (Ben Lomond Mountain)

Appellation: Heitz
Review: Made from certified organic grapes, this wine offers a strong uplift of acidity and refreshing layers of tangerine, white peach and Meyer lemon. With just enough grip and body it has complexity amid the freshness.
Wine: Heitz 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Earthy herb and turned earth open this blend of 58% Cabernet Sauvignon, 33% Merlot and 9% Malbec. Offering substantial length and breadth, it's dusty in crushed rock, rose and cedar, with supple, lasting power and a distinct finish of dark cherry.
Wine: Baldacci 2013 Fraternity Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted wood, dense but not overripe black currant and crushed slate show on the nose of this blend of 32% Petit Verdot, 26% Cabernet Sauvignon, 26% Merlot, 13% Cabernet Franc and 3% Malbec. Rounded and rich blackberry meets with dust and fennel pollen on the palate, which is vibrant with acidity.
Wine: Écluse 2015 Ensemble Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: Earthy notes of turned earth lead the way to cassis and cherry coulis amid a background of dusty crushed rock and mineral in this impressive, ranch-specific wine. Bright streaks of acidity lift the grippy tannin. This is built to age, so enjoy 2024-2029.
Wine: Howell Mountain Vineyards 2014 Beatty Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon makes up 47% of this wine, with the balance 45% Merlot and 8% Malbec. Its nuanced cherry, dark coffee, herb, vanilla and spice aromas are followed by palate-coating fruit and barrel flavors that feel seamless. Coffee notes linger on the finish.
Wine: J. Bookwalter 2015 Conflict Conner-Lee Vineyard Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% Cabernet Sauvignon wine hails from the esteemed Dionysus Vineyard. Reserved aromas of fresh herbs, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, cherries, raspberries and plums are followed by plentiful dark fruit and chocolate flavors. It's all about subtlety and nuance, with enough structure to go the distance.
Wine: J. Bookwalter 2015 Volume 5 Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Earthy herb and turned earth open this blend of 58% Cabernet Sauvignon, 33% Merlot and 9% Malbec. Offering substantial length and breadth, it's dusty in crushed rock, rose and cedar, with supple, lasting power and a distinct finish of dark cherry.
Wine: Baldacci 2013 Fraternity Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted wood, dense but not overripe black currant and crushed slate show on the nose of this blend of 32% Petit Verdot, 26% Cabernet Sauvignon, 26% Merlot, 13% Cabernet Franc and 3% Malbec. Rounded and rich blackberry meets with dust and fennel pollen on the palate, which is vibrant with acidity.
Wine: Écluse 2015 Ensemble Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There are hints of thyme, pepper and roast game on the nose of this blend of 25% Tannat, 25% Petit Verdot, 25% Merlot and 25% Cabernet Franc, yet it's mostly framed by crisp blackberry and lavender aromas. The full-bodied palate blends fresh acidity with sage-like seasonings and a roasted-plum flavor, set against thick yet polished tannins.
Wine: Écluse 2015 Insider Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Newton
Review: Freshly turned earth underlies burly grippy tannin and integrated oak in this complex and concentrated appellation wine. Cedar, graphite and currant provide nuance along a tension of acidity and moderate ripeness.
Wine: Newton 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Spring Mountain District)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly wound aromas of red currant, rose petals and carnations show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate is full of hibiscus and other red-flower flavors, with a touch of cinnamon spice and cedar, all wrapped in a soft mouthfeel.
Wine: Tessier Winery 2016 Saveria Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This is a rich warm mouth-coating wine that's packed with ripe, almost late-harvest, berry flavors, and that feels smooth and dense on the tongue. It is inviting, layered, concentrated and full bodied, showing moderate tannins and a long finish.
Wine: V. Sattui 2015 Pilgrim Vineyard Zinfandel (Lodi)

Appellation: Adaptation
Review: Blended with 22% Merlot, this wine is made by Odette's winemaker, part of the PlumpJack group. It's a crowd-pleasing wine, concentrated and structured, yet floral, rich and round, with length and freshness on the finish.
Wine: Adaptation 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is an inventive and stunning bottling from Spanish Springs Vineyard by Bryan Babcock. A beautiful shade of hot pink and extremely cloudy in the glass, this wine shows lush aromas of strawberry cake, vanilla and caramel on the nose. The mouthfeel is creamy but the flavors are tangy with kumquat, and that compelling combo holds until baked goods arise on the finish. It is a really fascinating wine.
Wine: Babcock 2016 Eye of the Beholder En Tirage Rosé of Grenache (San Luis Obispo County)

Appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's an intriguing and somewhat thick forest-spice element throughout this bottling, with juniper, pine and menthol aromas decorating the cooked red-cherry nose. The palate is also rich with herbaceous elements, offering bay leaf, black pepper and Indian spices against rhubarb, beet and stewed plum flavors.
Wine: Beauregard 2015 Coast Grade Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ben Lomond Mountain)

Appellation: Bella Grace
Review: Delicious and dry, this wine layers blackberry, dark chocolate and cherry flavors throughout the aromas, the flavors and the lingering finish. A minty, cedary oak accent adds complexity and a light layer of tannins keeps the mouthfeel lively and appetizing.
Wine: Bella Grace 2014 Primitivo (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Star anise, caramel, black plum and black currant show on the rich nose of this bottling, which is enhanced with 12% Grenache and 12% Monastrell. There is solid acidic energy to the palate, lifting up the cassis and gingerbread flavors that ride polished tannins into the finish.
Wine: Caliza 2014 Sympatico Tempranillo (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: Extracted black and red berries provides this wine with a succulent midpalate of full-bodied fleshy flavor. The clove and dried herb that ride along the lengthy finish complement and add complexity.
Wine: Christophe 2014 Explorer's Series Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Juicy, thick and structured, this tiny production is pretty with a touch of earth and Asian spice. Supple in texture and tannin, it offers a wealth of ripe cherry and raspberry that explodes on the midpalate before finishing in a breadth of toasted oak.
Wine: De Loach 2015 La Bienvenue Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: La Folia Winery
Review: This is a very distinctive, aromatic and enchanting wine that successfully evokes the magic of its Italian relative, Chianti Classico, in the heady mix of black olive, sage, tamarind and new leather aromas followed by tangy, savory, cranberry and tea flavors. The texture is grippy and lightly astringent, while the balance feels perfect.
Wine: La Folia Winery 2014 Sangiovese (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Spicy tight-grained oak dominates in this rich and structured red, that is thick in tannin and buoyant brambly black cherry and blackberry. Its full-bodied concentration is rich and layered, supported by a thread of persistent acidity that refreshens.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 Rocky Knoll Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Named Dobles Lías because it is given extended lees contact to add richness and texture, this wine impresses in its heady tones of honey and brioche. Tropical pineapple and a touch of brine give it a complementary yin-yang spirit that works.
Wine: Marimar Estate 2015 Don Miguel Vineyard Dobles Lías Estate Grown Estate Bottled Unfiltered Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Nearly pitch black in the glass at first glance, this is a meaty, gooey Petite Sirah, offering aromas of caramel, blueberry and fudge. The flavors are also lavish and thick with black currant, roasted meat, black plum, vanilla, caramel and fudge, surrounded by mouthcoating tannins.
Wine: San Simeon 2014 Estate Reserve Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Saracina
Review: Concentration and depth are the hallmarks of this fresh, flavorful, bracing wine made from organic grapes. It matches bright citrus and grassy aromas with deep, layered melon, fig and prosciutto flavors that seem to expand on the palate.
Wine: Saracina 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Williams Selyem
Review: Tangy and delicate, this coastal wine is dominated by vibrant acidity and an Asian spice tone. Teases of orange peel, red cherry and gravelly forest floor flavors emerge on the well-balanced palate.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light, delicate and lovely on the nose, this single-vineyard expression offers fresh and clean aromas of light pear and lemon rind. The palate picks up toast and toasted nut flavors, with rounded pear flesh, honeysuckle and tangy tangerine rinds as the backdrop.
Wine: Windstream 2014 Sarmento Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This big-boned wine aged in American oak is spicy, very ripe and quite full bodied, so it has plenty of impact on the palate. Black pepper, anise and an almost jammy blackberry flavor give it complexity, and a good structure of tannins while acidity give the texture a nice bite.
Wine: Amador Cellars 2015 Estate Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Bright and richly expansive, this wine is floral and gritty, a beautiful exploration of rose petal, forest floor and strawberry-rhubarb. Lightly spiced, it has a full-bodied figure of ripeness within polished tannin and structured acidity.
Wine: Baldacci 2014 Elizabeth Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Groth
Review: Blended with 20% Merlot, this is a finely made wine that pleases in its granular texture and bright acidity. Sinewy in feel, it has fleshy aspects of red cherry and cassis that are complemented by a cradling of vanilla oak.
Wine: Groth 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a blend of 33% Ribolla, 27% Arneis, 22% Friulano and 18% Albariño, all grown on the producer's vast Carneros ranch. Nutty and floral, it tastes and smells of white flowers, peach, melon and apricot, refreshing in its delightful lightness and lemony finish.
Wine: Hudson Vineyards 2017 White Study Estate Grown White (Carneros)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The heart of this wine comes from a block of this vineyard planted in 1989. The aromas recall peaches, lees, pumpkin spice, candy corn, chamomile tea and toast. There's a sense of seriousness to the palate, with rich fruit flavors and a compelling texture.
Wine: J. Bookwalter 2016 Double Plot Conner-Lee Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Winemaker Mike Januik has shown a knack for crafting top quality Chardonnay over the years, and this is yet another example. Its appealing poached pear, peach and cream aromas lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors with a toasty, lemony finish. It shows wonderful tension.
Wine: Januik 2016 Cold Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Loads of cut pear, yellow apple rinds, dried lime skins and wet cement show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate rides a racy line of acidity and chalky texture to deliver flavors of red apple and Anjou pear.
Wine: Joyce 2017 Cedar Lane Albariño (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A darker shade of reddish pink, this 70% Grenache and 30% Pinot Noir rosé is full of red-plum and raspberry aromas, with an orange-rind twist and warm baking-spice notes as well. It's very full yet tense and balanced on the palate, with flavors of raspberry gum and citrus peels.
Wine: Lumen 2017 Starry Rosé (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This vivid lively wine made from a one-acre vineyard is hot pink in color, bright and fruity in aroma and saturated with peach and grapefruit flavors that light up the taste buds. It has great acidity, medium body and a good sense of concentration while staying fresh on the palate and finish.
Wine: Miro 2017 Chevalier Vineyard Grenache Rosé (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine pits a mountain of tannin against a torrent of opulent extra-ripe blackberry and dark-chocolate flavors and comes out balanced. The saturated flavors soften the effect of a very firm texture for a grand and delicious taste experience. It has smoky, rubber-boot aromas, lots of dark fruit and subtle oak spices.
Wine: Oakstone 2015 Reserve Estate Field Blend Petite Sirah (Fair Play)

Appellation: Passing Time
Review: Though labeled simply as a red wine, this is almost all Cabernet Sauvignon, with just a pinch of 8% Merlot to round it out. The aromas are effusive, suggesting black cherry, black licorice, incense, graphite and spice. The palate is polished and reserved, showing lovely balance and light, grippy tannins.
Wine: Passing Time 2015 Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Rusack
Review: Roasted red-cherry, coffee and star anise aromas converge for a very exuberant nose on this countywide blend by Steve Gerbac. The palate is fresh and vibrant with red-cherry and raspberry flavors and strong acidity that carries the relatively lightweight wine across the tongue with ease.
Wine: Rusack 2014 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Subtle in stone fruit aromas and a waxy apple tease, this vineyard-specific white is bright, fresh and layered with texture. Light in ripeness, it'll do well as an aperitif or companion to the table and a wide variety of fare.
Wine: St. Francis 2017 Wild Oak Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Sourced from vineyards on Red Mountain, this has black currant, black cherry, espresso, pencil lead and barrel spice aromas that are locked up on first pour. Its dark fruit flavors are smooth and supple, with firm tannins providing support. Coffee notes linger on the finish.
Wine: Swiftwater Cellars 2015 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Terra Valentine
Review: Soft, supple and dusty, this 100% varietal wine is subtle in plum, cedar and graphite, showing a nice complexity on the midpalate of textured full-bodied ripeness. The tannins are present and polished.
Wine: Terra Valentine 2015 Merlot (Spring Mountain District)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Subtle in stone fruit aromas and a waxy apple tease, this vineyard-specific white is bright, fresh and layered with texture. Light in ripeness, it'll do well as an aperitif or companion to the table and a wide variety of fare.
Wine: St. Francis 2017 Wild Oak Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Sourced from vineyards on Red Mountain, this has black currant, black cherry, espresso, pencil lead and barrel spice aromas that are locked up on first pour. Its dark fruit flavors are smooth and supple, with firm tannins providing support. Coffee notes linger on the finish.
Wine: Swiftwater Cellars 2015 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Terra Valentine
Review: Soft, supple and dusty, this 100% varietal wine is subtle in plum, cedar and graphite, showing a nice complexity on the midpalate of textured full-bodied ripeness. The tannins are present and polished.
Wine: Terra Valentine 2015 Merlot (Spring Mountain District)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Freshly snapped bubblegum shows on the nose of this bottling, which also offers pillowy aromas of strawberry and rose petal. Fresh zippy acidity and a taut texture frame the sip, where the bubblegum flavors are cut by lemon juice and crushed chalk.
Wine: Baileyana 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very light in the glass, this bottling of a white Rhône grape that's new to the region is quite aromatic, offering lemon spray, chilled pear and yuzu aromas. There is laser-sharp focus and racy acid on the palate, offering flavors of cider apple, mandarin zest and crisp Asian pear.
Wine: Barton 2017 Tiny Dancer Glenrose Vineyard Picpoul (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Salted white peach, apple jelly, gardenia and brioche with lemon preserves show on the nose of this small-batch bottling from Sonoma County. Tangy lemon rinds, warm toast and candied melon flavors show on the palate, where the finish is quite lengthy.
Wine: Cattleya 2016 Pratt Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lime peels, rainy cement, flint and cut grass show on the nose of this bottling from the new owners of Thompson Vineyard, which is still a tad young and inward-looking, but sure to blossom in the months to come. It's very zesty on the palate, with long-lasting flavors of lime, pear and crushed gravel.
Wine: Dovecote 2017 Thompson Vineyard Grenache Blanc (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: This zero-dosage méthode Champenoise bottling is warm and inviting on the nose, marked by brioche, lemon custard and pie crust notes. Its smooth perlage boasts ripe citrus and blanched almond flavors, with a tangy saline tone that lingers long on the finish. It was aged 70 months on the lees before disgorgement in February 2017.
Wine: Hermann J. Wiemer 2013 Blanc de Blanc Estate Grown & Grown (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Succulent in fleshy black fruit and lifted acidity, this is a smooth, plush and robust wine. It's a hugely concentrated expression of the grape that's impressive in its power. Black pepper, cigar and dark chocolate linger on the finish.
Wine: Louis M. Martini 2014 Lot No. 1 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This varietal usually shows up in Port-style wines, but here it makes a wonderful dry table wine that's packed with deep berry flavors and has a very polished texture. Moderate tannins and good acidity give a bit of grip on the palate but it's velvety all the way through the finish.
Wine: Wise Villa 2015 Estate Touriga Nacional (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Abeja
Review: This wine's toast, pumpkin spice and peach aromas are followed by lithe, textured stone fruit flavors. It hits a lot of high marks and shows beautiful balance.
Wine: Abeja 2016 Chardonnay (Washington)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% varietal wine was partially fermented in concrete before being aged in all new French oak. It offers cassis, plum, anise, thyme, woodspice and black currant aromas, along with a light medicinal note. Its dark fruit flavors are rich and plush, showing surprisingly soft tannins considering the variety and region.
Wine: Betz Family 2015 Heart of the Hill Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is aged for 26 months in 80% new French oak. It works to support and structure a wealth of robust, ripe fruit, offering a perfumed nose of cherry and vanilla. The flavors follow, soft and dusty in tannin, finishing with a bright swathe of cassis.
Wine: Black Stallion 2014 Barrel Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Morgan
Review: Light aromas of lemon and lime meet with green lily, nectarine and slate on the dynamic nose of this bottling. The palate is fresh, vibrant and grippy in texture, showing lime pith, crushed gravel and a slightly more ripe element of Asian pear.
Wine: Morgan 2017 Grenache Blanc (Monterey)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Boysenberry, black-plum skin and wet soil aromas show on this bottling from the region's pioneering vineyard. Acid powers the palate, where tangy boysenberry, taut red plum and earthy spices intermingle.
Wine: Paradise Springs 2015 Sanford & Benedict Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: An aroma just like blackberry jam provides an eye-opening start to this rich, lightly sweet and full-bodied wine. The color is extra dark for a Zin and the fruit flavors are extra concentrated. Moderate tannins add a little bite to the texture and keep the wine in balance despite huge fruit flavors and a perception of sweetness.
Wine: Pech Merle 2016 Reserve Lot 9 Zinfandel (North Coast)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 52% Syrah, 31% Grenache, 11% Counoise and 6% Mourvèdre is a complete success. Fresh aromas of carnations, purple flowers, crushed cranberries, plump berries and dried sage lead into a taut palate of red plums, red cherries and potpourri spice.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2016 Patelin de Tablas Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Two Vintners
Review: This new offering from the winery combines fruit from Olsen and Boushey vineyards. Light in color, it offers restrained but nuanced plum, fresh herb, orange peel, smoked meat, white pepper and raspberry aromas. There's a pleasing sense of purity to the juicy fruit flavors, making it a very pretty interpretation of the variety. Give it plenty of time to open up.
Wine: Two Vintners 2016 Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: High-toned and brimming in acidity, this is a fresh tart expression of raspberry and vanilla, fleshy and expansive on the palate in texture and mineral undertones of rock and stone. It is made in tiny quantities and well worth seeking out.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2015 Sweetwater Springs Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's black raspberry, crushed rock, blackberry, smoke and plum aromas are brooding. Its rich but focused cranberry and cherry flavors linger on the finish.
Wine: DeLille 2014 Grand Ciel Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is 38% Mourvèdre, 38% Grenache, 21% Syrah and 3% Cinsaut. Its reserved blackberry, cherry cordial, herb and spice aromas lead to full-bodied red and black fruit flavors. Give it some time to open up.
Wine: DeLille 2015 Métier Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Mineral-driven, earthy and floral, this gorgeous white is elusive in fruit, youthfully demure and full of vigorous acidity. Lightly ripe peach and mango come into play midpalate, with a squeeze of lemon emphasizing the wine's vibrancy on the finish.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2017 Dutton Ranch Shop Block Pinot Blanc (Green Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a foot-trod, whole-cluster wine fermented like a white, that is copper orange and pink in color. The grapes come from the producer's Fox Den Vineyard and another Dutton Ranch site. Earthy cantaloupe, cherry and cranberry figure into the mix, as does orange peel and watermelon, the acidity tight and tautly stretched across the vibrant texture.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Heath Vineyards
Review: Salt and pepper spice show on the nose of this bottling by a Texas-based winery, leading into aromas of mulberry, black plum and star anise. Darker black-plum flavors meet with pepper and allspice on the palate, which is rich in style.
Wine: Heath Vineyards 2014 Pinot Noir (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a dense, juicy wine, with up-front richness to its bouquet of red cherry and strawberry. The acidity is lasting and refreshing, with silky tannins that add texture and grace.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Arrendell Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: St. Helena, Napa, California, US
Review: Dried herb, sage and lavender make for a potent bouquet of inviting complexity and intrigue, followed by a tease of anise. Juicy, thick and rich on the palate, the wine has a grip and power that never lets go, showing its youth and 100% barrel fermentation. It will be hard to wait on this one, but cellaring will reward. Best 2024–2034.
Wine: Alpha Omega 2014 Beckstoffer Dr. Crane Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is ethereal and intoxicating on the nose, offering a bouquet of wild rose and lavender that's hard to resist. Dense, concentrated strawberry and pomegranate flavors give it a tart freshness on the palate that contrasts well against its innate power. There's plenty of structure here for further aging.
Wine: Benovia 2015 La Pommeraie Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a stellar combining of 52% Zinfandel, 45% Syrah and 3% Grenache, all estate-grown and dancing in acidity. Incredibly floral, bright and jammy, it evokes violet and berry pie, with rounded tannins that don't get in the way of the juicy midpalate. This wine is fresh with plenty of power.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 1023 Red (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: Succulent, generous in fruit and expansive on the palate, this exudes vibrant, polished layers of baked plum, blueberry and tobacco, a showcase for the famous site in the heart of the appellation. Big and bold, it doesn't hold back in power or richness yet succeeds in finding balance.
Wine: Alpha Omega 2014 Beckstoffer Georges III Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: Sumptuous, structured and exuberantly brimming in tangy red fruit, this wine is also intriguing in dried herb and chalky, polished tannin. It offers a touch of heat around the integrated oak and powerful complex balance between the savory and succulent.
Wine: Alpha Omega 2014 Thomas Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the oldest block of a dry-farmed, hillside site, this bold, beautiful red is a celebratory expression of crushed rock, dusty soil and floral teases of rose and lavender. Hearty, thick and rich in its youth, it offers a wealth of blue fruit, leather and brown sugar. The oak is integrated and the tannins are grippy yet beginning to show polish.
Wine: Devil Proof 2015 Farrow Ranch Malbec (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This stellar vintage of Côte Sud enwraps its bold red fruit in delicious barrel toast and spices. The acids remain unobtrusive yet provide impeccable balance, and the tannins are ripe and polished, redolent of black olive and breakfast tea. The wine develops more nuances as it breathes, finishing with a lovely streak of root beer.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2015 Côte Sud Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lovely aromas of dark strawberry, framboise and star anise make for a very fresh and inviting nose on this bottling. The palate surrounds energetic and tangy pomegranate flavors, which are lifted by thyme and forest moss. Delicious, complex and herbal all at once.
Wine: Talley 2015 Stone Corral Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: The Setting
Review: A 100% varietal wine sourced from the SJ Ranch, this offers intense tastes of sweet tobacco, coconut shavings and mocha, the layered flavors built around thick, extracted tannins and pillowy soft oak. The power and richness are complemented by a tension of acidity that brightens the full-bodied palate.
Wine: The Setting 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine is vivid and concentrated but not overly ripe, so it has an attractive tension between almost-tart red-cherry and sour-cherry flavors and richer savory mushroom and forest-floor notes. It's possibly the most nervy wine yet from the Charles Vineyard. Good acidity and moderate tannins add welcome grip on the palate, while the finish lingers nicely.
Wine: The Withers Winery 2015 Charles Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a lovely, well-made white, bursting in tones of vanilla and biscuits on the nose. It is lush and layered on the light-bodied frame, the oak integrated and subtle, with flavors of green apple and mango.
Wine: Trefethen 2016 Family Owned Estate Grown Chardonnay (Oak Knoll District)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling is led by a beautiful, dynamic nose of wild thyme, chaparral spice, mulberry, raspberry syrup and black-plum skins. The palate is rich and layered as well, with pomegranate reduction, roasted fig, purple flowers and more hints of wild herbs.
Wine: Chamisal Vineyards 2015 Morrito Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve is an excellent representation of the 2015 vintage. Firm, supple and loaded with brambly purple fruit, it carries a pleasing touch of fruit sweetness. It rolls gracefully into a tight finish, with layers of herb, earth, blueberry, black cherry and brown spice notes.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2015 Evenstad Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Entirely stainless-steel fermented and oak aged—the oak neutral—this is a formidably memorable wine, fulsome and balanced in anise and juicy Gravenstein apple and peach. On the palate it's lush and creamy, with supportive acidity maintaining welcome, lasting freshness.
Wine: Hanzell 2015 Day Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Syrah doesn't get much more cool-climate than this, starting with piquant aromas of white and green peppercorns, crushed thyme, bay leaf and tart boysenberry fruit. The intense pepper dominates the palate, though a clean line of black-plum skin runs through the sip.
Wine: Holus Bolus 2016 Presqu'ile Vineyard Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This estate-grown beauty out of the producer's Freestone property is stunning in stemmy, minty earth, a touch of smoke and powerful background tannin and oak. Made in an impressively lean, coastal style that's both exotic and fresh, its fruit leans savory and succulent in cranberry and rhubarb.
Wine: Joseph Phelps 2015 Pastorale Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Consider this bottling the antidote to the richness of Paso Robles. Extremely fresh aromas of framboise, rosewater and white pepper align for a beautifully inviting nose. There is brilliant acidity at the tip of the palate, evolving into elegant tones of rose, red plum, pomegranate and exotic Middle Eastern spice.
Wine: Thacher 2015 Glenrose Vineyard Cinsault (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made to be fresh, fruity and enjoyed frequently, this wine is oily in lemon and apricot, with a refreshing, spritzy acidity that's both bright and complex. The vineyard is one of very few in the state to grow the variety and this producer has made it its mission to honor both the site and the grape. She does.
Wine: Zeitgeist 2017 Fanucchi Wood Road Vineyard Trousseau Gris (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: 21 Grams
Review: This blend of 71% Cabernet Sauvignon, 23% Merlot and 6% Malbec comes off of Cold Creek, Windrow and Stone Tree vineyards. Aged in just 35% new oak, it's locked-up on first pour; yet nuanced earth, cassis, graphite, dried herb and spice notes emerge as it opens. The palate is flavorful but refined, with compelling balance and bright acidity despite the warm vintage. A stunner with a long life ahead, it will be best from 2024–2032 but should last well beyond that. One of the wines of the vintage.
Wine: 21 Grams 2013 Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Atlas Peak, Napa, California, US
Review: Structured, full-bodied and robustly ripe, this mountain wine is 100% barrel-fermented and given nearly two months in oak. Sticky tannins and a sweetness from the oak combine well to provide a velvety lush contrast to the wild blackberry, currant and fleshy mouthfeel of pepper spice and leather.
Wine: Alpha Omega 2014 Stagecoach Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Atlas Peak)

Appellation: Axr
Review: Tart in red and black currant, this wine offers explosive acidity and fleshy polished tannins, the core densely structured and full-bodied. Given nearly two years in French oak, 75% of it new, it is accented in woody, herbal layers of dust and earth. Enjoy 2024–2030.
Wine: Axr 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a gorgeous wine made in minuscule amounts, fermented in both stainless steel and one-third new French oak before aging in neutral French oak. The subtle touches give it a chance to speak softly in lemony quince, with a steely nose of jasmine. Fleshy and full bodied without being heavy, it has a succulence of apple skin on the midpalate.
Wine: Hanzell 2015 Ambassador's 1953 Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Stainless-steel fermented and aged in neutral French oak, this well-made wine offers crisp acidity and supportive oak, with highlights of fennel, green apple and wet stone. Its grainy texture is layered and complex while also being deliciously drinkable now.
Wine: Hanzell 2016 Sebella Chardonnay (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a finely made wine, with tones of herbs, smoked black cherry and blackberry. Thick, velvety smooth and concentrated, it finds its balance in high-toned, underlying acidity and sparks of cardamom and black tea.
Wine: Ladera 2015 Pillow Road Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lively aromas of smashed black currants, caramelized berries, lilacs and açai make for a very inviting and pretty nose on this bottling. The palate is vivid with smoke, blueberry paste, violets, lavender and a savory charred component, finishing with a kiss of vanilla.
Wine: Larner 2013 Reserve Syrah (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Aperture
Review: From winemaker Jesse Katz, this Cabernet Sauvignon-dominant wine includes 4% Malbec. Textured, yet pleasantly soft, it offers an elegance of integrated, billowy tannin and oak. The warmth of the palate is embraced in flavors of mocha and spicy clove, with hints of cedar, graphite and dried herb.
Wine: Aperture 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This refreshing wine is a blend of 62% Syrah and 38% Grenache. It quenches in notes of strawberry, peach and a hint of gaminess. Velvety smooth and dangerously easy to enjoy, it's light and brightly layered in acidity.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2017 Estate Rosé (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This cuvée, sourced from Maresh vineyard old vines, was formerly called Audrey. This vintage, the vineyard gets its due. The old vines contribute both texture and mouthfeel, elevating the overall experience. A lush mix of raspberry, cherry and blackberries flavors unfolds on the palate. Underbrush and mushroom scents and accents emerge as it winds gracefully into the finish.
Wine: Scott Paul 2015 Maresh Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine has a wild side, bringing out the savory smoky singed-rosemary and cooked-cherry elements of the varietal, with great balance aided by firm acidity and tannins. With its spicy aromas and layered concentrated flavors, this should improve with some age. Best after 2021.
Wine: The Withers Winery 2016 Claire's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This memorable white offers flavors of mango, pear and crème brûlée, with a seductive richness to the feel of the palate. The oak is integrated—it shows power and grace within a balanced body and touch of brine.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Olivet Lane Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A rich and spicy take on the grape, this bottling combines dried red plums with juniper, forest moss, spice cake and a fascinating mushroom-laced umami kick on the nose. The palate is taut with raspberry flavors and well integrated exotic Middle Eastern spices. The acidity is lively and the mouthfeel is soft yet grippy on the finish.
Wine: Chamisal Vineyards 2015 Califa Pinot Noir (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is bright in acidity, with a wealth of freshness in tones of Meyer lemon and lime. Quenching on the midpalate, it develops more and more complexity in the glass, where a stony texture meets crisp green apple and fennel.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2015 Rued Vineyard Chardonnay (Green Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the producer's own backyard site, head-trained and planted a century ago, this wine is from the lowest yielding of all their sites. Earthy forest, leather saddle, fennel and a whiff of meatiness highlight a dense brightly layered wine, offering structure that is lifted in red-berry flavor with a spicy tobacco finish.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Hartford Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Marin County, North Coast, California, US
Review: Bold dark-fruit aromas and mouthfilling flavors make this full-bodied wine taste generous and concentrated. A deep core of black plum and black cherry fills the palate and lingers nicely on the finish. It is both ripe and savory but doesn't go over the top, maintaining good balance and a fresh dry aspect.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Marin County Pinot Noir (Marin County)

Appellation: Sonoma Mountain, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Thick and concentrated in baked blueberry, cherry and strawberry, this wine has substantial tannin and weight to it, a powerful backbone that's balanced by bubbling, nuanced acidity and mineral earth tones that linger gingerly on the finish.
Wine: Talisman 2014 Red Dog Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Mountain)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Golden Delicious apple is the star of the show in this beautifully oaked, aromatic and lushly textured white. Caramel and nutmeg rise on the nose, leading the way to fleshy full-bodied concentration and richness, tamed by bright bursts of quince and Meyer lemon.
Wine: Venge 2016 Maldonado Vineyard Dijon Clones Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling from a vineyard at the cool northern edge of the appellation starts with a wildly intriguing nose of dark elderberry, bay leaf, roasted boar and dark violets. The palate throws tons of bay leaf, peppercorn and thyme before settling into boysenberry and game. It could be mistaken for a cool-climate Syrah.
Wine: Landmark 2015 Escolle Road Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A new wine from the producer, this combines 85% Syrah with 15% Viognier, and it is a whirlwind of intriguing flavor. Blackberry, waxy plum, dried herb, cedar, clove and black pepper highlight a rounded dense beginning that evolves to show lengthy tannin structure and complexity. Still, the wine's just fun.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 Elie O Syrah-Viognier (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This lush, compelling wine deftly mixes barrel spice notes with blackberry fruit. The tannins are polished and the flavors dusted with dark chocolate. The finish is long and nicely textured, adding dried herb suggestions to the mix. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2015 Two Barns Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Planted more than 100 years ago by her family, this head-trained vineyard is still looked after by Dina. The wine's tart focused acidity zeroes in on candied-cherry and strawberry flavors. Sumptuous and brightly rich, it has undeniable structure and a lasting mineral element of oyster shell and brine.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Dina's Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Named for the way part of the vineyard is planted, the vines trained on a high wire, this is a dense earthy red. (The site is also field planted to Carignane.) Juicy with plenty of acidity on the midpalate, it oozes blackberry, black cherry and white and black pepper, with a lasting hit of texture and freshness.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Highwire Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Abundantly flavorful and full bodied, this wine has lots of dark berry and black-cherry aromas, a big rich mouthfeel and deep layered fruit flavors sprinkled with spices from cinnamon to bay leaf to black pepper. It tastes extra ripe and has the moderate tannins and good acidity to support that ripeness.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Muldune Trail Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is a distinctive and detailed wine that starts with floral and spicy aromas, follows with generous fruit flavors and intriguing accents of tea, rhubarb and wet stone. It's ripe but not overly so, and that little bit of restraint gives it an appealing structured mouthfeel and fine sense of balance.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Velvet Sisters Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Holus Bolus
Review: Loads of chaparral spice, peppercorns and dried herbs dominate the nose of this appellation blend from one of California's cool-climate Syrah stars, but there is also a dark-fruit background of blackberry soda. Buoyant acidity carries the palate through chopped dill, juniper and more peppercorn flavors.
Wine: Holus Bolus 2016 Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Explosive in succulent layers of fruit, this apple and pear-driven beauty is lightly spiced and well-integrated, with an impressive depth and length that gives it a warmth and welcoming character.
Wine: Kokomo 2016 Peters Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: High-toned acidity and spice combine with great intrigue in this beautifully quaffable wine, marked by complex texture and bright layers of orange and grapefruit.
Wine: MacRostie 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sol Rouge
Review: Extremely concentrated fruit flavors and full body make this wine impressive and memorable. It has spicy, floral, slightly smoky aromas, and deep dark black-cherry and blackberry flavors that are unusually intense and delicious. The mouthfeel is moderately tannic and helps support all that fruit.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2014 Syrah (Red Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Loads of green peppercorns, juniper, dried violets and charcoal show on the nose of this extremely cool-climate Syrah. That pepper spice powers the palate, where thyme, forest moss and firm tannins frame background boysenberry flavors.
Wine: Waxwing 2016 Dierberg Vineyard Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This blend of Mourvèdre, Grenache and Petite Sirah is big and brawny, with aromas of roast beef, black pepper and wood smoke. The palate is concentrated and layered in flavors of blackberry, coffee bean and blueberry, framed by fine-grained, gripping tannins. Made by the Bekeris family, who emigrated from Lithuania. Best after 2021.
Wine: Mabera 2013 Amadeus Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Rich blue fruit is the star of the show in this 100% varietal wine, from grapes grown on this hillside site. Enticing in crushed rock and dusty earth, the fruit is contrasted by tones of leather and black pepper. A powerful tannic structure underlies it all.
Wine: Aperture 2015 Del Rio Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Rockpile, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a new dry-farmed site, this is fleshy and expansive in complex waves of flavor and texture. Mocha, coconut flakes and blueberry combine around a rich and rounded body that boasts power and grip.
Wine: Devil Proof 2015 Rockpile Ridge Malbec (Rockpile)

Appellation: Eighty Four
Review: This project from Doug Shafer and Elias Fernandez continues to impress, showing the beauty of this variety in California when in the right hands. The nose offers an undeniable wealth of violet and lavender while the palate exudes smoked cherry, juicy blueberry and an underbelly of garrigue.
Wine: Eighty Four 2014 Malbec (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the producer's estate-grown site near the coast in Freestone, this shows soft, structured waves of citrus and wild strawberry met with hints of wood and pine. Bolstered by quenching acidity at its core, this is light in feel and delicately crafted.
Wine: Joseph Phelps 2015 Quarter Moon Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light in the glass, this bottling is redolent with carnations, hibiscus and pomegranate on the nose, which is sprinkled with oregano, marjoram and black-pepper spice. It's lighter bodied on the sip, which is full of energy and layered with texture, showing cranberry and minty flavors.
Wine: Ken Brown 2014 Rancho La Vina Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Estate grown, this combines 98% Syrah and 2% Grenache into a fist of perfumed violet, lavender and garrigue—the nose both feral and pretty. Black pepper, tar and up-front tannin give it an intensity that persists on the full-bodied palate, accented in meaty complexity.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 Hail Mary Syrah-Grenache (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Ram's Gate
Review: Ethereally earthy and forested, this appellation wine is succulent and supple in fleshy blackberry, huckleberry and a freshness of cardamom spice. The full-bodied density exudes fruitiness supported in rounded tannin.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Roberts & Rogers
Review: Earthy in an inviting tapestry of spice, this wine is textured and full bodied, with lingering sentiments of clove and cinnamon. The fruit shines bright and tart in red currant and cassis. It offers well-developed flavors that work well with a complement of oak.
Wine: Roberts & Rogers 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a screaming deal for a wine of this quality: a light, delicate and earthy expression of the grape that's stemmy and spicy. Forest floor, bark and dark brooding fruit meet a tangle of tight-woven acidity dipped in orange zest.
Wine: RouteStock 2016 Route 116 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This appealing, fragrant wine displays the textural complexity for which the AVA is noted. It's a thoroughly delicious bottle with a subtle mix of barrel spice and black fruit flavors. Threads of cola, brown spice and mocha weave through the long finish.
Wine: Scott Paul 2015 Ribbon Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Amador Cellars
Review: This is a big fascinating wine that adds complex smoky earthy tobacco aromas to rich mouthfilling flavors of blackberry and blueberry. Full body, moderate tannins and good acidity give it grip on the palate and deep funky earthy flavors linger on the finish.
Wine: Amador Cellars 2015 Syrah (Amador County)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a youthful, tightly woven wine, with a floral nose of cherry blossom. A wealth of bright cranberry and raspberry melds over a grainy texture, supportive acidity and integrated oak.
Wine: Benovia 2015 Martaella Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The winery calls this the most Chablis-like of their many Chardonnays due to its tight, high-acid style and firm spine. Apple, grapefruit, lime and stone flavors are in focus, with Graham cracker highlights and a hint of straw. It was gently aged in 50% new French oak.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2015 Etoile Vineyard Chardonnay (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very dense in the glass, this rich complex wine shows dark blackberry, black currant and even flashes of blueberry on the nose, with spice cake and concentrated jasmine as well. The tannins are thick but polished on the sip, where elegant purple-flower flavors meet with vanilla cake, chocolate, blueberry muffin and a strong acid blast on the finish.
Wine: Écluse 2013 Lock Vineyard Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Silky smooth, soft and concentrated, this hails from 100-year-old vines in the heart of the appellation. The wine is luscious in strawberry and black-cherry flavors. Expansive and boldly ripe, it has a core of richness that never overwhelms, finding companionship in a wisp of black and white pepper.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Fanucchi Wood Road Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Baked red cherry, roasted plum, rose petals, carnation and extremely dark spice show on the nose of this bold bottling from the historic vineyard. It's elegantly presented on the palate, where flavors of red currant and framboise mix with baking spice, prominent floral touches and a penetrating acidity.
Wine: Ken Brown 2015 Sanford & Benedict Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a coastal site overlooking the Pacific Ocean near Annapolis, this is cool-climate yet brawny in its grasp of cherry cola, black pepper and black licorice, that is wild and densely packed with power. Wild blackberry and blueberry come along for the ride, adding to the succulence of the midpalate, a nice contrast to the underlying gaminess and tobacco.
Wine: Hartford Court 2013 Outer Limits Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Cola, blueberry and red fruits meet with sweet tobacco and peppercorn-crusted beef on the nose of this foot-stomped bottling. Though young, it's very accessible now, with smashed berries, tar and savory flavors of black, white and green peppercorn riding a strong acidity.
Wine: Holus Bolus 2016 Franc De Pied Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep aromas of caramelized black plum, elegant lilacs, brown sugar and roasted beef show on the nose of this blend of 50% Syrah, 30% Mourvèdre and 20% Grenache. The palate blends rich boysenberry with beef char, smoke and savory herbs, wrapped in a brilliant acidity that drives long into the finish.
Wine: Kukkula 2014 Sisu Red (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Here's a wine that puts Counoise in the driver's seat to great effect. Bolstered by 36% Mourvèdre and 19% Grenache, the wine starts with candied cherry, tangy cranberry, red flowers, white pepper and potpourri on the nose. Exotic spices, familiar herbs and bright red fruit shine on the lively palate.
Wine: Kukkula 2015 Aatto Red (Adelaida District)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This blend of 43% Mourvèdre, 16% Syrah, 14% Grenache, 14% Carignane and 13% Cabernet Sauvignon is a great look at what this cult producer is doing, but for much less price than other bottlings. Pure tangy fruit aromas of mulberry and condensed flower petals cut through the rustic earthy and gamy elements on the nose. Vibrant acidity explodes on the palate, which is full of red-currant, cranberry, parsley, sage and lavender flavors.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Homestead Red (California)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aged in second-fill French puncheons, this wine pops with green and black olive, charcuterie, stem, wet rock and potpourri aromas. The palate explodes with fruit and savory flavors that persist into a mineral-laden finish. A knockout.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2015 Tall Tales Stoney Vine Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Savory aromas of black pepper, roasted lamb and burnt bacon decorate the boysenberry-syrup and dried maple-sugar notes of this bottling's extremely compelling nose. Brown sugar-glazed pork flavors meet with more pepper, soy and au jus on the palate, which will grow more complex and delicious with time. Drink 2020–2030.
Wine: Margerum 2015 Uber Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: A floral and flinty aroma leads to rich black-cherry and mushroom flavors in this medium- to full-bodied wine from one of California's earliest Pinot Noir specialists. It emphasizes complexity more than pure fruit and gets extra credit for a savory, mineral thread and supportive tannins.
Wine: Saintsbury 2016 Donnelly Creek Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly packed blackberry, wood-smoke and black-pepper aromas are remarkably vivid in this full-bodied, rich and creamy-textured wine. It's big in structure, attractively oaky, and filled with ripe, exotic but classic meaty spicy gamy flavors.
Wine: Vasco Urbano 2015 Henry Hayes Ranch Syrah (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has a depth of flavor and length that's rewarding within a richly balanced, focused and tightly textured ring of acidity. There's an imprint of lemon oil that's slightly viscous and completely compelling on the palate.
Wine: Von Holt 2015 Heintz Family Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Waters
Review: Most of the fruit for this wine comes from Old Stones Vineyard in The Rocks District, the rest from top sites Forgotten Hills and Olsen. The aromas pop, with smoked meat, green and black olive, mountain blueberry, gun smoke, fresh herb, orange peel, flower and wet stone notes. The palate is soft, smooth and sultry yet balanced with vibrancy and freshness. With its extraordinarily long blue fruit- and charcuterie-laced finish, it's an outrageous value. Best before 2024.
Wine: Waters 2014 Syrah (Washington)

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Juicy black cherry, crushed rock and dried herb combine with ease in this site-specific wine blended with 11% Cabernet Franc. Grainy oak and powerful concentration on the palate make it hard to forget. Enjoy 2020–2025.
Wine: Aperture 2015 Oliver Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Strong aromas of flint and crushed chalk meet with hints of hazelnut and preserved lemons on the nose of this extremely coastal bottling. There is a tremendous tightness to the palate, where a grippy texture presents racy flavors of lemon, grapefruit rind, nectarine and sea salt on the finish.
Wine: Beauregard 2016 Bald Mountain Vineyard Chardonnay (Ben Lomond Mountain)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This sensational 2016 release is packed with juicy blackberry fruit dappled with hints of bitter herbs. With excellent definition and length, the multi-faceted flavors unravel into layers of highlights—orange peel, cinnamon, espresso and more. The tannins are ripe, and the overall balance calls for putting a few bottles away for further aging. Drink now–2030.
Wine: Big Table Farm 2016 Pelos Sandberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This multi-clonal selection is lushly endowed with a bright mix of red fruit, recalling cranberry, pomegranate, raspberry and cherry. It's annotated with orange peel highlights and orange blossom scents. The detail and subtlety are impressive.
Wine: Le Cadeau 2016 Diversité Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This newcomer to the appellation is boldly styled and hearty in blue fruit and baked cherry, the experience on the palate warming and complete. Concentrated and powerfully built, it shows a wealth of cola spice and vanilla on the lengthy finish.
Wine: Croix 2015 Old Manzana Slope Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made from Pommard clone vines planted in 1973 and 1984, this subtle and yet commanding wine fills the palate with lush strawberry jam flavors. It's smooth and textural, and time in barrel has imbued it with just the right touch of mocha.
Wine: Durant 2015 Bishop Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Fort Ross-Seaview, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a site neighboring Hirsch and Martinelli, this beautifully structured wine is abundantly earthy, savory and spicy in forest floor and cardamom. The blustery spice is contrasted nicely against a wall of crisp, fresh acidity and a finish of black tea.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2015 McDougall Vineyard Pinot Noir (Fort Ross-Seaview)

Appellation: Hartford Court
Review: This wine is an impressive barrel selection of several vineyards across the appellation. It opens with a nose of charcuterie and brined olive, with a palate that is textured and rich in flavors of tarte Tatin and baked mango.
Wine: Hartford Court 2016 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made in homage to Côtes du Rhône, combining 94% Syrah and 6% Viognier, this opens in lavender, violet and garrigue, inviting and smooth. The velvety texture continues, with a spicy savory edginess of white pepper, blackberry and cured meat.
Wine: Keller 2014 Rotie Syrah-Viognier (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very savory and dense on the nose, this bottling by Adam Lee shows smoky roast beef and smoked-pork-shank aromas as well as concentrated black currant and dried purple flowers. The palate is fresh, lively, tense and dense all at once, and needs a bit more time for the black-plum flavors to unfurl and acidity to mellow. Drink 2020–2035.
Wine: Novy 2015 Sierra Mar Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Powerful and earthy, this rich and concentrated wine is full bodied, broad in texture and has envelope-pushing spice and leather aromas backed by well-concentrated wild-berry and plum-compote flavors of significant depth. It's seductive and lavish in character.
Wine: Ruby Hill Winery 2015 Jewel Collection Series Estate Reserve Malbec (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark cherry, sweet sage, rust and moist earth aromas show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard just miles from the coast behind Cambria. Dried cherry and pomegranate show on the sip, but that earthy kick carries through, with more sage, juniper and bay leaf. The finish is lively and mouthwatering.
Wine: Stolo 2015 Hillside Reserve Pinot Noir (San Luis Obispo County)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: This Right Bank-inspired blend allows Merlot to take the lead at 60%, combined nicely with 25% Cabernet Sauvignon and 15% Cabernet Franc. Sanguine, its richness muted and well-integrated, the flavors lean into black currant, clove, leather and black licorice, with a softness to the texture.
Wine: Textbook 2014 Page Turner Red (Oakville)

Appellation: El Dorado County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This is a seriously delicious wine that's packed tightly with fruit, floral and spice flavors and has a firm but velvety texture that makes it a pleasure to sip. It has a deep dark ruby color, expressive aromas, generous black-cherry and dark chocolate flavors and a lingering finish. Best after 2022.
Wine: Vinum Cellars 2015 The Scrapper Cabernet Franc (El Dorado County)

Appellation: Waters
Review: The aromas in this 100% varietal Cabernet Sauvignon from Cold Creek and Stone Tree vineyards rise out of the glass, suggesting scorched earth, dried herb, graphite, flint, cassis and cherry. It has bright but balanced acidity to support its fruit flavors, with green pepper and cherry notes that linger on the finish. It's flat-out delicious and exceptionally balanced. Put it on the dinner table and watch it shine.
Wine: Waters 2013 Cabernet Sauvignon (Washington)

Appellation: Shokrian Vineyard
Review: This bottling comes from what was once Verna's Vineyard, whose new owner employed Drake Whitcraft for this bottling. Quite dark for a Pinot Noir, it shows very concentrated blackberry sorbet, strong mint, cola and vanilla bean aromas on the nose. The palate is lush and thick with boysenberry paste, clove, star anise and vanilla dust flavors.
Wine: Shokrian Vineyard 2015 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Tart, focused and bright in acidity, this unoaked wine doesn't hold back in richness, allowing the fruit to speak freely for itself in lemon, Mandarin orange and melon. Asian pear and peach play supporting roles as lingering aromas of jasmine weigh in.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Unoaked Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Alta Mesa, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This is a compelling take on a sometimes simply fruity and lively varietal from risk-taking winemaker Kevin Luther. It's medium bodied, well balanced and has a complexity in the aromas and flavors that is fascinating to taste. It blends tasty cherry and raspberry notes with accents of tamarind, black tea and clove.
Wine: Wise Villa 2015 Estate Barbera (Alta Mesa)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: A relatively light color leads to spicy aromas, a firm gripping texture and very tasty, complex but restrained flavors including red cherry, cardamom and beef tartare. The wine has great balance due to firm tannins and good acidity, and tastes incredibly fresh and appetizing.
Wine: Amador Cellars 2014 Reserve Grenache Noir (Amador County)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Fresh aromas of framboise, hibiscus and rose petals make for a very lively and floral nose on this bottling. The palate is also alive and vibrant with flavors of red-currant sorbet, yet mint and tarragon hold that fruity aspect at bay enough to add intrigue.
Wine: Anaba 2015 Soberanes Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Franc from Boushey and Champoux vineyards is bouyantly aromatic, with dark raspberry, leafy herb, cocoa powder and incense notes. On the palate, it's flavorful yet light-footed and exquisitely balanced. Thoroughly captivating.
Wine: Avennia 2015 Valery Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Big Table Farm
Review: Though this multi-vineyard is blend priced below the winery's vineyard designates, it was given the same exacting care. A substantial wine, it's lush with blackberry, black cherry, lemon peel and orange blossom scents and flavors. Barrel aging has added clove and other spice notes. A stylish effort that outperforms its price.
Wine: Big Table Farm 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Black Stallion
Review: With a woody nose of toasted oak and dried herb, this impressive wine is structured and bright, with fresh cassis and red cherry. Balanced and well integrated, it shows depth of flavor and complexity.
Wine: Black Stallion 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Fermented in neutral French oak, this is a big, spicy and polished rosé. Bright strawberry and cherry fruit is in abundance, dotted with cinnamon spice. It's a full-flavored, full-bodied tour de force, giving rare muscle to a category mostly devoted to light, simple summer sippers.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe and rich aromas of black plum are cut by savory, gamy and peppery qualities on the nose of this complex Syrah. The cohesive palate is quite delicious, showing roasted plums, pepper-crusted beef and touches of oregano, marjoram and rosemary. Acid keeps it lively.
Wine: Cass 2014 Backbone Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: This has a pretty floral nose, a delicate aspect that is in contrast with the thick integrated tannin and depth of baked cherry tart, caramel and oak. Black pepper and dried herb season the full-bodied density well.
Wine: Chaix 2014 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Great concentration, full body and an almost thick texture make a big statement in this no-holds-barred wine that was barrel-fermented in old barrels that don't add oaky flavors. It smells like honey, cream and vanilla, tastes nutty and buttery and coats the palate with a richness that continues to linger even after the last sip.
Wine: Cobden Wini 2016 Dalton Vineyard Marsanne-Roussanne (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Creamy and lush, with warmth of baked pear and fig, this wine fully embraces a ripe fleshy style and does it justice. Supportive, integrated oak adds to the full-bodied voluptuousness as jolts of acidity settle things down and make the wine complex in underlying freshness.
Wine: Croix 2015 Narrow Gauge Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blended with 15% Mourvèdre, this hails from Stoney Vine, Stone Tree, Olsen and Red Heaven Vineyards. Its generous raspberry, black pepper, herb and orange peel aromas are fresh and pure. The palate is rich and ripe, with a smoked meat-filled finish that carries into the distance.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2014 Stained Tooth Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a light, floral red, aromatic in rose petal and white pepper, that evolves to show a wealth of balanced red fruit, from rhubarb to strawberry. A hint of cola is contrasted nicely against a plushness of cola and sweet tannin.
Wine: FEL 2015 Hirsch Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: An aggressive smoky earthy tobacco aroma precedes rich berry and chocolate flavors that drench the palate in this full-bodied, concentrated and almost feral wine. It's an adventure to drink and far from boring.
Wine: Holly's Hill 2015 Patriarche Red (El Dorado)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is a fruity wine that overflows with cherry, plum and raspberry aromas and beautifully ripe pure flavors along with some rhubarb and herbal accents that add complexity and interest. It's full bodied, and has a silky-smooth texture.
Wine: Jackson Estate 2015 Outland Ridge Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Tognetti
Review: Nobly reduced on the nose, this is a savory, leathery red, tart in cherry and cassis. Full bodied, it imparts elegant seasonings of cedar, dried herb and woody tannin that grip and structure.
Wine: Tognetti 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve-level offering is subtle and complex in tones of fig, blackberry, black cherry, leather, espresso and oregano that come together beautifully. There's no need to wait, but it should continue to drink well through 2025.
Wine: 2Hawk 2015 Darow Series Tempranillo (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Technically dry yet with enough residual sweetness to round its sharp edges, this is a juicy and delightful wine. Fresh, tangy citrus, peach and melon flavors are all in play—ripe and beautifully melded. The acidity is clean and refreshing, with no chalkiness.
Wine: Chehalem 2016 Corral Creek Vineyards Riesling (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aromas of cherry kirsch and framboise meet with star anise, allspice and a welcoming French toast element on the nose of this bottling from a new producer based in Monterey. The palate is very fresh and spicy, with ginger snaps, tart pomegranate and cranberry flavors, riding an acidity that simmers low and long.
Wine: Comanche 2015 Chareva Vineyard Pinot Noir (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Drouhin Oregon Roserock
Review: Domaine Drouhin Oregon's new Eola-Amity wine continues to impress. Supple, seductive and rippled with kiwi, apple, citrus and melon flavors, it's nicely ripe and well melded. The barrel influence is modest, which perfectly suits fruit this good.
Wine: Drouhin Oregon Roserock 2016 Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rich black fruit meets with a touch of roasted lamb and rosemary on the classic nose of this Syrah, which was planted in 1989 as a memorial for Fess Parker's late son-in-law. The gamy qualities are much stronger on the sip, with charred lamb and more savory herbs, yet the backdrop is all boysenberry.
Wine: Fess Parker 2015 Rodney's Vineyard Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Among Holloran's lineup of excellent Rieslings, this is top tier. In this outstanding vintage, it shows exceptional focus and concentration, with heady aromas and dense peach, apricot and papaya flavors. Though quite young, it's supple, rich and ready for immediate enjoyment yet could certainly age for a decade or longer.
Wine: Holloran 2015 Le Pavillon Vineyard Riesling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light in the glass, there is freshness and tension to the nose of this blend of 52% Grenache, 25% Carignane and 23% Syrah, with aromas of mulberry, red plum and hibiscus but also cinnamon, sumac and rose petal. Its light weight sails across the palate, mixing pomegranate, sage and cracked pepper flavors.
Wine: Kitá 2015 Spe'y Camp 4 Vineyard Red (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Blackberry, thyme, anise, maple and a prominent hickory smoke show on the nose of this blend. That smoke extends throughout the firmly structured palate, giving savory depth to flavors of boysenberry paste, pound cake and vanilla. Slick acidity carries it all deep into the finish.
Wine: Opolo 2015 Maestro Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Paradise Springs
Review: From one of the country's first bicoastal wineries, the Virginia-cum-California is off to a strong start with this wine from John Sebastiano and La Rinconada vineyards. Aromas of lemon curd, sweet cream and lime pith are soft yet attention-grabbing. The palate is clean, crisp and tightly woven with tangy citrus flavors and great textural grip.
Wine: Paradise Springs 2015 Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Perfusion
Review: This wine comes from a small vineyard in Wildcat Canyon, which is located in the hills of the East Bay. Aromas of mulberry, purple flowers, new leather, curry and cardamom lead into a palate of roasted tomato jam and chai spice.
Wine: Perfusion 2014 Pinot Noir (San Francisco Bay)

Appellation: Peter Franus
Review: This impressive wine, grown at 3,000 feet, offers deep dark-fruit flavors and hints of dark chocolate carried on a lush rich texture. It's full bodied, very ripe and concentrated, featuring blackberry and boysenberry flavors that flood the palate and linger on the finish.
Wine: Peter Franus 2014 Red (Red Hills)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Bottled in 2017, this dessert wine is made entirely from Chardonnay and dazzles in lithe layers of apple, pear and melon. With a medium-bodied feel, it shows density around underlying balance and structure.
Wine: Prager 2013 Aria White Port (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the wilds of the appellation and field blended with nearly 16% Petite Sirah and smaller amounts of Carignane and Alicante Bouschet, this wine is rich in red brambly dusty fruit. Demure on the palate at first, it is soft and structured, with a strong taste of strawberry and white pepper on the finish.
Wine: Ravenswood 2015 Teldeschi Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine has a dark color, fragrant floral and blueberry aromas and a mouth-coating richness that carries jammy blackberry and boysenberry flavors. It is full bodied, moderately tannic and lingers nicely on the finish.
Wine: Tanner 2015 Estate Grown Grande Petit Verdot (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: The Withers Winery
Review: Subtle and complex rather than simply fruity, this medium-bodied wine brings aromas of sunbaked earth, cedar and leather along with flavors like sour cherry, beef broth and anise that are compelling to taste. The texture is firm, moderately tannic and provides just enough tension so that the flavors seem to release slowly onto the taste buds.
Wine: The Withers Winery 2015 Grenache (El Dorado)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Moderate fruit flavors, light spices and a firm texture make this medium-bodied wine appetizing and food-friendly. Made from 86% Mourvèdre grapes plus Grenache and Syrah, it's a tenor rather than a baritone and gives a brilliant performance.
Wine: The Withers Winery 2015 Ruben Mourvèdre (El Dorado)

Appellation: Washington, Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: This blend of 60% Cabernet Franc from The Rocks and 40% Merlot from Canoe Ridge Vineyard enchants with its complex medley of fresh ground herb, sliced green pepper, moist earth, mineral and cherry aromas. There's dazzling texture and purity to its graceful fruit and savory flavors that carry deep into the finish. Delicious stuff.
Wine: Waters 2014 Capella Red (Washington)

Appellation: Washington, Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: This wine is half Merlot, with the balance Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Petit Verdot and Malbec. Well-delineated notes of dried herb, raspberry, black cherry, dried flower, graphite and anise mark the nose. The palate bursts with fresh fruit and earth flavors that are at once textured, pure, polished and light on their feet. A long, fruit-filled finish caps it off. It's a gorgeous, nuanced wine that way over-delivers for the price.
Wine: Waters 2015 Interlude Red (Washington)

Appellation: Windchaser
Review: Tempting toast and fresh bread aromas lead to layers of lemon, butter, crisp apple and baking-spice flavors in this nicely complex, compact and well-balanced wine from a three-year-old urban winery in Berkeley. It is medium bodied, feels lively but smooth on the palate and has aged-on-the-lees complexity and richness.
Wine: Windchaser 2016 Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Not long out of the barrel, this bright young wine is loaded with tasty raspberry fruit. Those flavors are both deep and lively, amped up with plenty of acidity and rounded with a lick of chocolate from oak-aging. Though already quite tasty and showing a lot of youthful energy, the overall structure suggests it will reward cellaring. Tuck a few bottles away and drink now–2030.
Wine: Aubichon Cellars 2016 Riverside Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Mountain, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This well-made wine is crisp and structured, layered in Meyer lemon, mandarin orange and a steely core of effusive acidity. Light bodied, it shows depth and texture enough to match a meal and find companionship at the table.
Wine: Benziger 2017 Estate Paradiso de Maria Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma Mountain)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a beautifully blended 63% Petite Sirah, 32% Zinfandel and 5% Syrah from one estate block. Earthy, it offers soft, supple layers of blueberry, blackberry and cocoa powder, the tannins present, supportive and dusty. The finish explores the garrigue and black pepper side of the Rhône grapes.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 Obsidian Block Red (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: St. Helena, Napa, California, US
