Review: With a strong tone of oak and tar on the nose, this vineyard-designate wine offers well-integrated power and intensity. Fresh red currant greets the palate within a framework of concentrated depth and extraction, with a lasting finish.
Wine: Nickel & Nickel 2015 Hayne Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The name of this cuvée is Chinese for rich and beautiful, honoring the mother of one of the winery's owners. It's a rich white version of Pinot Noir that moves from a sharply defined crisp apple and citrus fruit into a softer, broader midpalate. It carries hints of cherry pit and a light suggestion of chocolate.
Wine: Patton Valley 2016 Fu-Mei Pinot Noir Blanc Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Grenache makes up the majority of this blend at 65%, with 15% Syrah and 20% Mourvèdre. Together they offer earthy barnyard, compost and fresh strawberry puree, the body thick and dense in tightly packed tannin. This is delicious and complex.
Wine: Quivira 2015 Wine Creek Ranch G-S-M (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Roots, stems and dried leaves make for an earthy entry into this estate appellation wine. Wraparound tannins and oak emphasize a gritty, grainy texture marked by robust cherry ripeness and secondary characteristics of black tea and rose.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This outstanding single vineyard selection pulls out all the stops. Though still young and somewhat stiff, it already shows superior balance and complexity, capturing the tensile strengths of the vintage. Its ripe and polished layers of berry- and cherry-inflected fruit—the result of 30% whole cluster fermentation—are accented with streaks of mocha and caramel from aging 12 months in 30% new French oak. Give it a little more bottle age and drink 2020–2030.
Wine: Broadley 2015 Shea Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This broad, rich and mouth-coating wine starts with effusive spicy oak aromas like wood smoke, cardamom and cedar before spilling very ripe, almost jammy, boysenberry flavors on the palate. It's unabashedly oaky, but has so many ripe generous fruit flavors that they balance each other out.
Wine: Dante Robere 2015 Estate Reserve Syrah (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Elegant and spicy floral notes of concentrated rose petal, hibiscus, sage and juniper play against a sugar-plum aroma on the nose of this bottling. Thyme and bay leaf lace the ripe plum-pudding and baked berry flavors of the palate, which is lifted by a crushed purple-flower element.
Wine: Derby 2014 Derby Vineyard Grenache (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made from ripe Pommard clone fruit, this explodes with rich cherry, sweet cola, molasses and wet stone flavors, with a touch of leather. Of all the winery's 2015 Pinot Noirs, this is one to open soon—within the next couple of years.
Wine: Durant 2015 Olivia Grace Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Sourced from one of the state's top Chardonnay sites, this wine was aged longer in barrel (16 months vs. 10), with a greater percentage of new oak (50% vs 35%) than the winery's Columbia Valley bottling. Its toast, cardamom, peach and clarified butter aromas are followed by full-bodied, creamy stone fruit flavors with plentiful spice accents. It's a delicious expression of the variety from a warm vintage.
Wine: Forgeron 2015 Anvil French Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Chalone, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The oak is still showing prominently throughout this young bottling, but it has all the bones to make for a compelling sip for the next decade or so. Aromas of black raspberry sorbet and smoke lead into a palate of snappy red fruit, white pepper, star anise and clove. Be patient and this will smooth out nicely. Drink 2020–2030.
Wine: Fulcrum 2016 Brosseau Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chalone)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Blending five of the producer's vineyard-designates, all dry-farmed and old-vine, this is a high-acid red with hearty spice and components of dried herb, cedar and oak. Supple and rich, it's distinctively savory and tart on the midpalate and finish, finishing in a blur of pepper.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Old Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Hanzell
Review: There's a note of barrel influence on the nose, a heartiness of oak that weaves within the greater whole as the wine develops. Smooth, rounded richness, a mix of baked apple and hazelnut, provide a textured balance of flavor within lovely highlights of lemongrass and ginger.
Wine: Hanzell 2015 Chardonnay (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 50% Grenache and 50% Syrah expertly employs the best of both grapes, blending beastly brawn with floral beauty. Aromas of composting rose petals, forest underbrush, rustic berries and gamy animal hide lead into a savory, complex palate of salted plums, lamb hide and marjoram.
Wine: Kukkula 2014 Pas De Deux Red (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Part of the winery's reserve tier, this was barrel-fermented, offering a totally different set of flavors from the stainless steel-fermented Viognier. It is lush on the palate, with concentrated apple, grapefruit and papaya flavors and a buttery, toasty finish.
Wine: 2Hawk 2016 Darow Series Viognier (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling from four vineyards, with 12% Mourvèdre, shows loads of crushed carnation, rose petal, cranberry and raspberry on the nose. There is a compelling freshness to the palate, with potpourri and lavender flavors meshing into a background of pomegranate and rosewater.
Wine: Bonny Doon 2017 Clos de Gilroy Grenache (Monterey County)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded aromas of Meyer lemon and white peach are quite plush, and there are hints of butter and oak also slipping into the nose of this bottling. There is great zip to the sip, where rich flavors of pan-fried apples are cut by strong acidity.
Wine: Fess Parker 2016 Sierra Madre Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: As the name suggests, this wine comes off a rocky part of the estate vineyard, creating a sturdy platform for its rich array of blueberry and brambly cherry fruit. There's a whiff of chicken stock also, and it's still tight with youthful tension. Give it plenty of aeration or an extra year or two in bottle before popping the cork.
Wine: Le Cadeau 2016 Rocheux Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Herbal in brushy sage, with thick determined tannins, this is a complex worldly wine, leathery and full of black and white pepper. Soy, meat and tobacco also figure in, speaking loudly back to the spine of acidity.
Wine: Limerick Lane 2016 Headpruned Block Syrah (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This big bold Bordeaux-inspired blend combines 85% Cabernet Sauvignon with 10% Petit Verdot and 5% Cabernet Franc. It offers a layering of dusty sage and crushed rock around tight-grained tannin that presents as soft and structured on the palate. The integrated fruit is a welcome mix of cassis and red currant.
Wine: Merryvale 2014 Profile Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Flavorful and rich in texture, this generous and full-bodied wine presents a rather light, toasty aroma. Ripe, concentrated fruit and oak flavors are carried on a plush texture that coats the palate with vanilla, baking spice and ripe pear that linger on the finish.
Wine: Poseidon 2016 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Spicy floral Hungarian oak aromas and rich, detailed and concentrated fruit and spice-rack flavors give great appeal to this full-bodied and well-balanced wine. It has a plush layered texture, a great foundation of black cherry and complex tea, plus interwoven notes of cinnamon and forest floor.
Wine: Poseidon 2016 Estate Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The Alloro vineyard is among the finest in the Chehalem Mountain AVA. Sweet blue fruit is on full display here, delivering a broadside of blueberry and blue plum flavors. It's smooth, supple and perfectly balanced, its 30% new oak well integrated and adding just a light touch of toast.
Wine: Rex Hill 2015 Alloro Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied, steely and austere wine has a pale orange-gold color, citrus and green-apple aromas and crisp, dry flavors like grapefruit. It has light almond and earth accents and is driven by good acidity for a refreshing mouthfeel. Extra brut means truly dry, and this wine shows how appealing the style can be.
Wine: Schramsberg 2009 Extra Brut Sparkling (North Coast)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Scott Paul's Azana is precise and distinctive, delivering a focused fusion of strawberry, blueberry and spicy cherry flavors. There's a pleasing touch of lightly earthy funk as well, and the overall balance keeps it interesting and on point through the finish.
Wine: Scott Paul 2015 Azana Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The famous vineyard is showing well here. Winemaker Ian Burch has a fine ability to provide a distinct focus for each of the winery's single vineyard selections. This bottling is refined, with an intriguing mix of flavors, from grapefruit and Bing cherry, to chicken broth and milk chocolate. As odd as it sounds, it all knits together quite well.
Wine: Scott Paul 2015 Nysa Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Central Coast, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Fresh red currants, rose petals, tarragon and thyme meet with vanilla and caramel on the very pleasing nose of this blend of 70% Grenache, 16% Mourvèdre and 14% Syrah. Rosewater shows on the palate along with fresh cherry and strawberry flavors, wrapped in light tannins and judicious acidity. It goes down easy.
Wine: Sculpterra 2015 Mega Focus Red (Central Coast)

Appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
Review: An enticing aroma of toasted oak meets spicy ripe peach and pear flavors in this full-bodied luxuriously creamy wine. It has vanilla, nutmeg and ginger notes and a mouth-coating texture that is also well supported by acidity. Oaky, yes; delicious and balanced, also yes.
Wine: Shannon 2016 Reserve Chardonnay (Red Hills)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a dynamic and lovely white wine that checks all the boxes. Aromas of melon and Meyer lemon meet with honeysuckle and wet cement on the nose. The palate is framed by a grippy tension, yet shows welcoming flavors of nectarine and pear. A powerful streak of lime acidity slices through it all.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2017 Estate Grown & Bottled Vermentino (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Subtle aromas of white peach flesh, crushed limestone and nectarine blossom decorate the nose of this estate bottling from a pioneering family. The palate is loaded with flint, smoke and a plaster of Paris element in the background, all giving depth to the nectarine cream, key lime spritz and hint of chive flavors.
Wine: Beauregard 2016 Beauregard Ranch Chardonnay (Ben Lomond Mountain)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a new offering from the producer, sourced from a cool windy site in the Petaluma Gap. A whiff of violet rides atop dense concentrated blackberry and dried herb. The wine offers a brushy dusty character and long polished tannins, showing cool-climate balance and elegance.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2016 West Block Syrah (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: A light floral note in the aroma joins up with layered and ripe fruit flavors that are handsomely accented by cedar, cocoa and balsam, for a complex and lasting impression on the palate. Full body and firm tannins provide good structure to balance the rich flavors in this Zinfandel-based, traditional Northern California blend.
Wine: Brutocao 2014 Coro Mendocino Red (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Reduced with a strong grasp of oak, this wine has powerful concentration and body, a mix of dried herb and cedar that tangles with dark chocolate, brown sugar and blackberry cobbler richness.
Wine: Duckhorn 2014 Monitor Ledge Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Durant's Dove is a fine-boned wine, with crushed rose and red plum aromas. On the palate, expect cherry pastry-like flavors that persist into a rich, full and nicely textured finish.
Wine: Durant 2015 Dove Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From head-trained vines planted more than a century ago, then aged in French oak, this is a bold, plum-driven expression of cherry and berry pie seasoned in cinnamon that's structured and exuberantly full bodied. It offers a bright streak of acidity that keeps it succulent in the glass.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Jolene's Vineyard Old Vine Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: Thick, elongated tannins rule the day in this mountain-grown wine, textured and grippy with a balance of bright acidity. The fruit is brambly in blackberry with dustings of dried herb, cola and clove that accent it well.
Wine: Howell Mountain Vineyards 2015 Old Vine Zinfandel (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A plump candied-blackberry aroma and a touch of wet slate make for a very inviting nose to this bottling, which is bolstered by 9% Petit Verdot, 5% Malbec and 2% Cabernet Franc. It tightens up on the palate thanks to firm tannins, and delivers flavors of black cherry, milk chocolate and toast. Acidity rises into the finish.
Wine: Niner 2015 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Made entirely from Petite Sirah, this is given three years in neutral barrels and was bottled in 2016. Thick, syrupy, soft and sublime, it imparts a heady decadence of blackberry, cedar and tobacco.
Wine: Prager 2013 Royal Escort Paladini Vineyard Port (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A blend of the historic Sierra Madre and Bien Nacido vineyards, this reserve wine shows toasted hazelnut, seared lemon rind, salted apricot and a touch of sour cream on the tangy yet smoky nose. A sharp sandalwood flavors comes through on the sip, along with poached apple, buttered toast and sea salt. It needs a touch more time to come together.
Wine: Rusack 2016 Reserve Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
Review: This Grenache-based wine has very ripe satisfying black-fruit flavors at its core and plenty of good acidity and firm tannins to balance them out. Blackberry, balsam, beef jus and a light touch of black pepper emerge as it opens in the glass.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2014 Gypsy Rouge Red (Red Hills)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: “Retro” may be winemaker Rich Cushman's reference to this wine's sweet style, since it clocks in at 24 g/L of residual sugar. It's a pungent take on the grape, with a piney aroma and massively concentrated fruit. Peach, apricot and papaya flavorscome into play, with balanced acidity. The finish is deep, pure and long.
Wine: Viento 2016 Retro Old Vines Riesling (Columbia Gorge (OR))

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Sweet herb aromas of oregano and tarragon mesh with exotic mulberry, plum and Luxardo cherry on the nose of this blend of 32% Syrah, 16% Grenache, 14% Petit Verdot, 12% Cabernet Franc, 12% Alicante Bouschet, 7% Cabernet Sauvignon and 7% Petite Sirah. That herbal intensity carries into the palate, where minty flavors decorate the background of plum fruit.
Wine: Villa San Juliette 2014 Chorum Reserve Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Diamond Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: Feral aromas of leather and countryside make for a complex backdrop from which to enjoy this well-integrated wine's succulent black fruit, dried herb and clove. Full bodied, it's structured to age, dense from the vintage and appellation, yet softly layered in polished tannin.
Wine: Wallis Family Estate 2015 Seraphim Cabernet Sauvignon (Diamond Mountain District)

Appellation: Ben Lomond Mountain, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This experimental lot was made in a concrete egg, and it's a fascinating wine. Strong aromas of honeysuckle, lemongrass, chalk and lemon curd show on the nose. The palate is zippy with acidity, offering flavors of lime, wet river stones and a hint of flint. The finish is quite sour.
Wine: Beauregard 2016 Oeuf en Beton Bald Mountain Vineyard Chardonnay (Ben Lomond Mountain)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Opening with lovely mulberry and spiced plum scents, this wine this invites further exploration with tangy acidity. That brightness elevates the fruit, bringing out crushed rose petal, citrus peel and cherry bon bon highlights.
Wine: Broadley 2016 Open Claim Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Deep purple in hue, this wine's dark and spicy aromas lead to rich and ripe black fruit flavors. Its intense blackberry-inflected fruit drives straight through the palate, adding coffee, toast and chocolate touches along the way.
Wine: Broadley 2016 Zenith Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's near-equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec saw just a touch (15%) of new oak. The aromas draw you into the glass, evoking plums, cloves, dried herbs and spices. Its ripe, full, soft fruit flavors coat the palate, extending into a warm finish. It exudes a lovely sense of purity.
Wine: Brook & Bull 2016 The Few and Far Between Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's fresh, ripe pear flavor is accented by touches of tart orange and lemon peel. Though technically dry, it has enough residual sugar to gently round off its youthful edges and keep the alcohol rather low.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2017 David's Block Estate Grown Pinot Blanc (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This lovely wine is full, firm and bursting with lightly spicy strawberry fruit. Its concentrated midpalate brings a light dusting of cinnamon flavor that carries into the clean, fresh finish that trails off gracefully.
Wine: David Hill 2017 Estate Pinot Noir Rosé (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This lovely and seductive wine from a top producer delivers a supple, smooth and silky mix of orange peel, strawberry compote and chocolate bonbon flavors. At its relatively modest price, you can't hope for a better value for iconic Dundee Hills Pinot Noir.
Wine: Domaine Drouhin Oregon 2016 Dundee Hills Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This Pommard clone bottling showed significant variation during tasting, the first example exhibiting leathery aromas and some bitter tack room flavors. The second bottle merits this score, with juicy cranberry and raspberry fruit, ample acidity and good length.
Wine: Durant 2015 Ava Roan Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from vines planted a quarter century ago, this stainless steel-aged white offers smooth and balanced fresh pear flavors, with refreshing, wet stone-like minerality. Light hints of garden herbs make it a model Pinot Gris with style, length and the ability to age. Drink now–2025.
Wine: Durant 2016 Southview Pinot Gris (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Etude
Review: The appellation shows well in this wine, sharing full-bodied concentration within a cooler-climate personality of woody graphite, chalky tannin and floral, dried herb. Cassis and currant accentuate the burbling acidity. This will do well in the cellar. Best 2020–2030.
Wine: Etude 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Appellation: Fulcrum
Review: Earthy, meaty, oaky, aromas and rich ripe cherry and strawberry flavors give this full-bodied and plush-textured wine plenty to appreciate. It tastes generous and feels smooth and mouthfilling.
Wine: Fulcrum 2016 Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Holloran
Review: Although this wine was fermented dry, in this forward, ripe year the fruit brings an impression of sweetness. Juicy peach, apricot and papaya flavors commingle, with a fresh acidity that makes it delicious when slightly chilled on a hot day.
Wine: Holloran 2014 Riesling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This full-flavored, fruit-powered wine takes off with ripe blackberry and black cherry notes. Barrel aging has contributed brown spice, cola and chocolate accents, which fill out the finish. It's quite tasty and ready to enjoy now and over the next couple years.
Wine: J. Scott Cellars 2015 Bradshaw Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: J. Scott Cellars
Review: From one of a handful of Oregon wineries working with Sauvignon Blanc, this wine focuses on the natural, herbaceous pungency of the grape. The palate is ripe in pineapple, apple and melon flavors, giving an appealing, round feel. Touches of hibiscus and honey trail on the finish.
Wine: J. Scott Cellars 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Oregon)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very light and airy in the glass, this bottling shows exotic red plums, fresh cherries, rust, bay leaf and wild mint on the lively nose. It's also lightly bodied and energetic on the palate, where tart cherry fruit is enhanced by pinches of red Mexican spices.
Wine: Kitá 2015 Hilliard Bruce Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an earthy wine, funky in rose garden and compost, with a demure entry that develops into a more full-bodied sense of thickness and dense tannin over time. There's a nice flourish of strawberry and rhubarb that takes on a compote-like lushness.
Wine: MacRostie 2015 Champlin Creek Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Dunnigan Hills, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Savory aromas of burnt sage and black pepper along with beef, anise and carbon flavors make this an adventurous wine. It's medium bodied, not overly ripe or rich and has a tight mouthfeel due to moderate tannins and lively acidity.
Wine: Matchbook 2014 Estate Bottled Syrah (Dunnigan Hills)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: This wine is warm and welcoming, starting with ripe plum and cherry-compote aromas, then presenting rich cherry-pie flavors that are generous but not sweet and a soothing smooth texture with just a touch of tannin.
Wine: On Point 2016 Christinna's Cuvee Pinot Noir (North Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from vines grafted over to Pinot Gris in 1978, this was wild yeast-fermented in neutral oak and aged another 22 months before bottling. This is fresh on the nose, with lush tones of melon, pineapple, pear and a touch of honey.
Wine: Ponzi 2015 Old Vine Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Ryan Rose
Review: Lovely earth, mushroom and leather aromas bring softness to this full-bodied wine. It's packed with black fruit, cola, coffee, smoke and baking spice notes, all well integrated, with impressive length and complexity.
Wine: Ryan Rose 2016 Malbec (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Only three barrels of this distinctive wine were produced. It's aromatically complex, with hints of pear and mushroom, the fruit flavors firmly rooted in citrus and peach, with a touch of mint as well. The texture is impressive, and helps to extend the finish.
Wine: Scott Paul 2015 La Paulée Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This new winery is showing lots of promise early on, and this bottling may be the best yet, with elegant aromas of blackberry jam, charred beef, smoke and dense purple flowers. It's lively and fresh on the palate in tones of elderberry and lilac, bolstered by stiff tannins and a chalky backbone. Bittersweet chocolate shows on the finish.
Wine: Verde 2015 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a layered, full-bodied red, thick in baked bread, cherry and vanilla flavors. It has underlying elegance, with balanced acidity and polish tannins that keep it fresh and succulent.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Fanucchi-Wood Road Vineyard Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Great fruit flavors and an especially smooth and creamy texture make this full-bodied wine hard to resist. It smells delicious like black cherries and tastes rich, almost jammy, with blackberry-pie notes. Moderate tannins add some good structure for all that fruit.
Wine: Wise Villa 2015 Estate Petit Verdot (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Shokrian Vineyard
Review: Babak Shokrian is the new owner of what was once the Melvilles' Verna's Vineyard, and he hired Morgan Clendenen to make this Syrah. It's rich with stewed black currants and black plum, with hints of licorice and cinnamon on the nose. The well-structured palate shows blackened blackberry and just a glimpse of bacon and maple.
Wine: Shokrian Vineyard 2015 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: The winery's best white, this decadently rich wine is packed with ripe honeysuckle, Meyer lemon, orange, tangerine, peach and apricot flavors. It's a totally delicious fruit bomb to be enjoyed now–2022.
Wine: 2Hawk 2016 Viognier (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Young, sharp and tightly wound, this pushes a complex mix of lime, grapefruit and crisp apple fruit forward. There are subtle notes of Bergamot orange and cardamom, with a light toasty touch from having aged in 21% new oak. Delicious already, it should age nicely for up to a decade.
Wine: Adelsheim 2015 Staking Claim Chardonnay (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Copper orange in color, this is a meaty, complex quencher, with a metallic edge of steely wet stone. Citrus and peach give it a restrained fruitiness that never becomes heavy or anything but refreshing.
Wine: Anaba 2017 Rosé of Grenache (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz-Monterey County, California Other, California, US
Review: This blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon (from Santa Cruz County) and 47% Syrah and 3% Viognier (from Monterey County) is still tightly wound on the nose, with crystalline purple-fruit and lilac aromas. The palate is elegant, energetic and clean, with firm tannins framing the purple-fruit flavors, with a touch of oak and chocolate on the finish.
Wine: Big Basin 2014 Odeon Red (Santa Cruz-Monterey County)

Appellation: Spring Mountain District, Napa, California, US
Review: From a high-elevation site where the vines enjoy volcanic calcareous soils, this lightly ripe wine is high toned in pomegranate, rhubarb and orange peel, textured with a sense of crushed rock, and easy to love. It is Gamay-like in its delicate brightness and retention of acidity.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2015 La Perla Vineyard Pinot Noir (Spring Mountain District)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This estate-grown, aromatic wine opens with a pretty mix of peach, honeysuckle and pink grapefruit notes. It's tart, racy and complex, with a hint of honey that carries from the aroma into the dry, lingering finish.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2017 Estate Riesling (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black pepper and blueberry meet with tarragon, sweet mint and beef char on the nose of this bottling. The palate offers a range of minty herbal qualities, but is dominated by a black-plum-sauce richness. The structure is solid but soft enough to enjoy now.
Wine: Carlisle 2016 Sierra Mar Vineyard Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black pepper and blueberry meet with tarragon, sweet mint and beef char on the nose of this bottling. The palate offers a range of minty herbal qualities, but is dominated by a black-plum-sauce richness. The structure is solid but soft enough to enjoy now.
Wine: Carlisle 2016 Sierra Mar Vineyard Syrah (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Marin County, North Coast, California, US
Review: This classy wine starts with cinnamon stick aromas that lead to a warm cherry pie flavor. It gains grip and complexity on the palate and finish, with moderate tannins and fresh acidity alongside a nip of sour cherry for good balance.
Wine: De Loach 2015 Vineyard Designate Marin Pinot Noir (Marin County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This entry level Pinot Noir is a fine introduction to the winery's portfolio of single vineyard selections. Tight and still tart, it mixes wild berry fruit with well-managed herb and bark accents. Though the tannins need more time to soften, the overall balance and depth suggest medium term aging potential. Drink 2020–2025.
Wine: Domaine Serene 2015 Yamhill Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Fairsing
Review: The winery is making a considerable effort to downsize the alcohol in its Chardonnays, with positive results. This Dijon clone blend was fermented in one quarter new French oak barrels. A portion underwent malolactic fermentation, yielding a well-balanced wine with a steely core of pear and apple fruit. There's a pleasing touch of buttered toast from the malo, and everything stays in perfect proportion through the finish.
Wine: Fairsing 2016 Chardonnay (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Monte Volpe
Review: It's a treat to welcome a new producer of Vermentino in California. This wine balances vivid herb and ripe apple flavors with vibrant acidity for a mouthfilling but still refreshing character. Touches of lime and lemon perk up the palate while an almost sweet apple-tart note kicks in on the finish.
Wine: Monte Volpe 2017 Vermentino (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Sonoma County-Napa County, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Lavender and licorice combine effortlessly on the nose and entry of this wine, which deserves its reserve billing. Juicy cherry, currant, cedar and dried herb are the highlights, woven around a dense core of generous tannin, richness and density. Enjoy 2024–2034.
Wine: Pride Mountain 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County-Napa County)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is such a winning combination, a blend of 47% Grenache, 25% Mourvèdre, 15% Petite Sirah, 8% Counoise and 5% Syrah, all from the estate. Fuzzy apricot and peach present first within a dark pinkish-red color. Strawberry follows, the whole brightened by plenty of buzzy acidity.
Wine: Quivira 2017 Wine Creek Ranch Rosé (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Sculpterra
Review: Concentrated aromas of red-plum jelly and berry syrup are lifted by fresh-plucked thyme and purple flowers on the nose of this bottling, which includes 12% Petite Sirah. The wine leans toward a heavier-bodied style on the palate, where intense blackberry flavors meet with forest herbs and a lively acidity, proving quite complex.
Wine: Sculpterra 2016 Primitivo (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This long-standing vineyard designate is robust on the nose in forest earthiness and spicy cardamom, and pleasantly expansive on the palate in lasting concentration and jammy cherry and strawberry flavors.
Wine: Siduri 2016 Parsons' Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Goosepen Block is a site that was planted to Pommard clone in 1998. The wine is compact, with black cherry and leather notes and firm tannins. Aged in 38% new French oak, it's wreathed in smoke and espresso accents, with a touch of dark chocolate.
Wine: Sokol Blosser 2015 Goosepen Block Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This offers concentrated black fruit along with the tannins and stem flavors that result from extended maceration. It was aged 17 months in 44% new French oak, which lends smoke and espresso notes to the extended finish.
Wine: Sokol Blosser 2015 Orchard Block Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Sola
Review: Ripe and bold in flavor, this polished, focused wine is full bodied and firmly tannic. It has effusive blackberry aromas and wonderfully dry, concentrated flavors.
Wine: Sola 2014 Syrah (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is another boundary-breaking bottling by Larry Tercero, who foot stomped this whole cluster blend of 40% Cinsault, 40% Grenache and 20% Carignan, aged it solely in stainless steel and then released it young with advice to chill before drinking. It's light in color and loaded with aromas of carnation, rose petal, red plum, cola and wet stone. The palate's rounded bright red fruit is fun and easy to glug.
Wine: Tercero 2017 Aberration Red (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Named after proprietor Bill Price's son, this bottling offers lean yet focused black raspberry and crushed purple flowers on the nose, as well as a slightly sour funky streak. The palate is framed by tangy dense boysenberry with a hint of pine tar. Patience will allow the flavors to better coalesce. Drink 2020–2030.
Wine: Three Sticks 2016 The James Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This estate-grown, 100% varietal wine is well made and full bodied in its thick, billowy yet tannic structure. Baked blueberry and leather provide a dense, savory core marked by lasting cedar and black pepper impressions.
Wine: Trinchero 2015 BRV Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: High-toned citrus is wrapped in youthful oak in this integrated, textured wine that's medium in weight and ripeness. A dustiness of crushed rock and nutmeg ride along the underside of the palate, lending nuance and savory balance to the fruit before a bolt of acidity hits the fresh, focused finish.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Heintz Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark candied black-cherry and baked licorice aromas make for a rich entry to this bottling by Michael Larner. A smooth yet structured texture delivers ripe flavors of cracked pepper and boysenberry sorbet.
Wine: Larner 2014 Elemental Red (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Maison Roy
Review: This golden hued wine from two vineyard sources—Terry Family and Iron Filbert—was fermented in neutral barrels and tastes of bright apple fruit. Orange peel and saltine cracker highlights emerge as it persists into a tight, focused finish. Give it another couple years of bottle age, and it should drink very well through the next decade.
Wine: Maison Roy 2016 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This excellent reserve celebrating the winery's 45th anniversary is a multi-vineyard blend that includes grapes from the top cuvées. It's high toned and scented with whiskey barrel aromas and hints of fresh bread, caramel and almond paste. Although there's plenty going on, the fruit plays a supporting role to all the barrel flavors. Drink now and into the early 2020s.
Wine: Ponzi 2015 Anniversary Reserve Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine was sourced from lots from all four of the winery's single vineyard designations. Close in quality to those bottles yet priced well below, it's thick and aromatic in tones of plum, cherry, mushroom and tangerine. Enjoy now through 2025.
Wine: Scott Paul 2015 La Paulée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This excellent reserve celebrating the winery's 45th anniversary is a multi-vineyard blend that includes grapes from the top cuvées. It's high toned and scented with whiskey barrel aromas and hints of fresh bread, caramel and almond paste. Although there's plenty going on, the fruit plays a supporting role to all the barrel flavors. Drink now and into the early 2020s.
Wine: Ponzi 2015 Anniversary Reserve Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine was sourced from lots from all four of the winery's single vineyard designations. Close in quality to those bottles yet priced well below, it's thick and aromatic in tones of plum, cherry, mushroom and tangerine. Enjoy now through 2025.
Wine: Scott Paul 2015 La Paulée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Tangy cherry fruit anchors this wine, which is highlighted with scents and flavors of stems and tea leaves. There's a light hint of tanned leather, and the palate-pleasing texture keeps the mix of flavors lifted and compelling. A touch of toast emerges on the finish.
Wine: Sokol Blosser 2015 Big Tree Block Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light on its feet, this cool-climate Syrah shows just-pressed elderberry and boysenberry on the nose, with hints of cedar, herbs and game. The palate is restrained, likely a reflection of the young vines, with clean and easy flavors of berry, thyme and white pepper.
Wine: Spear 2016 Estate Grown Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Full bodied but well balanced, dry and somewhat restrained in fruit flavors, this wine brings on the complex earthy meaty untamed aromas and flavors of the grape variety as well as blackberry and blueberry that build on the finish. It's a good way to put more adventure in your diet.
Wine: Spicy Vines 2015 Dragon's Kiss Syrah (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Soft aromas of nectarine, raspberry granita and cotton candy come across as extremely fresh, crisp and clean on this rosé of Mourvèdre from Camp 4 Vineyard. There is a great zesty quality to the palate, which is full of life and taut with flavors of red pear, Pink Lady apple and grapefruit zest.
Wine: Tercero 2017 Rosé of Mourvèdre (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Brooks
Review: Though not labeled as such, this was made entirely from Crannell vineyard fruit and fermented in stainless steel. It's a lively mix of pear, apricot, starfruit and lemon curd notes, with crisp and juicy minerality. In short, it's lip-smackingly delicious, with impeccable freshness.
Wine: Brooks 2017 Pinot Blanc (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted blackberry and black-plum aromas meet with milk chocolate and baking spice on the nose of this bottling, which sees 21% new oak. The flavors are broad and rich with violets, black currants and blueberries, framed by strong tannins and a persistent deep acidity.
Wine: Derby 2014 Derby Vineyard Malbec (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from estate-grown Pinot Noir, Chardonnay and Pinot Gris, this wine is focused in acidity, with dry, fresh components of lemon and green apple. Complex in mineral overtones, it offers a taste of oyster shell and wet stone.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2013 Brut Sparkling (Carneros)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of 58% Syrah, 26% Mourvèdre and 16% Grenache hails from Boushey and Heart of the Hill vineyards. Subdued out of the gate, it offers raspberry, white pepper, herb, cherry pit and marionberry aromas as it opens. The flavors are graceful, pretty and balanced.
Wine: Forgeron 2014 Façon Rouge G-S-M (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Joleté
Review: Rich black fruit flavors anchor this excellent wine, which accents its brambly character with complex hints of olive, bark and citrus. It's solid, substantial and a fine value, finishing with a touch of alcoholic heat.
Wine: Joleté 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Leather, tobacco and smoky char define the opening of this full-bodied, rich wine, blended with 15% Merlot, 3% Petit Verdot, 3% Malbec and 2% Cabernet Franc. Woody and structured, its fruit leans dark and plummy, ending on a touch of dark chocolate.
Wine: Joseph Phelps 2015 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% varietal wine brings graphite, cherry, cassis, vanilla and spice aromas. The palate shows depth and concentration, with rich yet restrained flavors backed by velvety tannins. Give it time to open up.
Wine: Forgeron 2014 Anvil Minnick Hills Vineyard Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Forgeron
Review: This is a true pan-Washington Chardonnay, made from grapes from Yakima Valley, Columbia Gorge, Walla Walla Valley and Wahluke Slope. Its clarified butter, lemon curd, white peach and spice aromas lead to a full-bodied, creamy palate, with plentiful lemony accents. It's richer in style than recent vintages, but the warm year no doubt contributed to that.
Wine: Forgeron 2015 Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Coming from old vines, this bottling is typically one of the more compelling non-Chardonnays from Santa Barbara County. This vintage shows light lemon, chalk, white peach and Asian pear on the nose. The palate is grippy as ever, with lemon-lime acidity and a green-pear flavor.
Wine: Foxen 2016 Ernesto Wickenden Vineyard Old Vines Chenin Blanc (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Kokomo
Review: This wine is generously rich in red and blue berry, a density of fruit that is nicely contrasted against waves of peppery spice and leather. The oak is present yet polished alongside lengthy tannins and a lasting earthiness of sweet compost.
Wine: Kokomo 2016 Malbec (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From vineyards planted in shallow soils on steep slopes, this bottling offers plump cherries, sumac and rust on the nose, which combines fruit and soil compellingly. Tart pomegranate and hibiscus come through on the palate, which is taut, fresh and grippy, with a sharp mace spice kick.
Wine: La Honda Winery 2016 Sequence Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: A vast improvement from the previous vintage, this standout wine is a sophisticated expression of a grape that's staking a valid claim to being Southern Oregon's signature red. Black fruit, tanned leather and strong tobacco and clove suggestions combine. The flavors are wrapped in a supple, polished package and show exceptional balance and length.
Wine: 2Hawk 2015 Tempranillo (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: 2Hawk does exceptionally well with its Viogniers. This one is bright and spicy, its flavors jumping agilely from citrus to apple to pineapple to mango. This is well balanced and lingering.
Wine: 2Hawk 2017 Viognier (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This rosé bridges the gap between sunshine-driven fruits and the more mineral character of a classic pink wine, starting with a nose that blends ripe melon, strawberry and bubblegum aromas with wet river stones. The palate is crisp, bright and very stony, yet there is a peach element as well. Sure to please many palates.
Wine: Andrew Murray 2017 Espérance Curtis Vineyard Rosé (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Bennett Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Bright, dusty leather and raspberry cola highlight this lovely vineyard-designate, which shows cool-climate aromatics and retention of acidity. In balance, it's both fruity and weighty, with varietal highlights of pepper and garrigue.
Wine: Baldassari Family Wines 2015 Nolan Vineyard Syrah (Bennett Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Light aromas of carnation and snappy black raspberry meet with the elegant touch of bay leaf on the nose of this cool-climate Merlot. Its grapes grow on a southwest-facing orientation, which is the only reason they get ripe at all. The palate's red-currant and cherry tones are overcome by herbal touches of bay, juniper and mint, wrapped in zesty acidity.
Wine: Beauregard 2014 Zayante Vineyard Merlot (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the winery's coastal estate property, this is inviting in candied strawberry Jolly Rancher and peach. With lovely acidity and freshness, it offers enough body and mid-tier weight to be a nice companion at the table as well as stand up on its own.
Wine: Benziger 2017 De Coelo Rosé of Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Three cheers for this much-improved release from the Russell-Grooters estate vineyard. Refined and complex, it deftly mixes cherry and citrus flavors. Blood orange flesh and rind notes come through, leading to a midpalate stiff with tannins and a finishing whiff of chocolate.
Wine: Carlton Cellars 2014 Estate Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Floral aromas and plenty of black-fruit flavors nicely fill out the full body of this ripe and opulently textured wine. The color is black almost to the rim, the aromas are spiced with vanilla and cocoa, and the flavors are so ripe with dried berries and cherries as to taste slightly sweet on the finish.
Wine: Charles B. Mitchell 2015 Reserve Tempranillo (Fair Play)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Effusively fruity, this delightful rosé mixes lemon oil, tangerine, red berry and cherry hints in a detailed, forward and delicious style. It's a wine that simply insists you refill your glass, then magically disappears.
Wine: Chehalem 2017 Three Vineyard Rosé of Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine aged in Hungarian oak barrels is rich and concentrated, well-balanced and feels velvety smooth. It has black-cherry and raspberry flavors shaded by considerable smoky spicy oak notes that open up on the palate.
Wine: Dante Robere 2015 Estate Syrah (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made from estate-grown grapes, 51% Pinot Noir and 49% Chardonnay, this dry delicious wine sings in high-acid lemon zest and pulp. It's layered, focused, fresh, tart and simply delicious.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2013 Ultra Brut Sparkling (Carneros)

Appellation: Etude
Review: Sweet compost, tobacco and big, ripe tannins provide a robust entry into this wine. The palate opens with waves of boysenberry that hold tight through a spicy, peppery finish.
Wine: Etude 2013 Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The east-facing block that comprises this wine brings delicate flavors and a hint of compost. Mixed citrus highlights and tart cherry fruit fill out the midpalate, and after a bit of breathing, the wine stretches out through a tasty finish threaded with dark chocolate notes.
Wine: Le Cadeau 2016 Côte Est Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine wraps subtle fruity and floral flavors in a rich mouthfilling texture that feels sweet even though it's a dry wine. It has layers of light honeysuckle, vanilla and apricot that persist from the aroma through a lingering finish.
Wine: Naggiar 2017 Estate Grown Root 49 Viognier (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A 100% stainless-steel white, this is quenching and substantial in weight, with a grainy texture that shows complexity and layering of flavor. The fruit is a pleasing mix of Meyer lemon and kiwi.
Wine: Pech Merle 2017 Valhall Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: An earthy mineral aroma leads to baking-spice flavors, mild cherry and subtle plum fruit in this very smooth-textured and medium- to full-bodied wine. For having been aged in all-new Hungarian oak barrels it's not at all overpowering with oakiness.
Wine: Poseidon 2015 Primo's Hill Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: There's an element of compressed wood to the oak in this wine, which rises on the nose with force, alongside a robust ripeness of berry pie. Soft and supple, it mellows in the glass to unveil elegant layers of strawberry and orange zest.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 Gap's Crown Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 40% Cabernet Franc, 39% Malbec and 21% Cabernet Sauvignon needs a little time to unwind, but is quite compelling when given that space. Aromas of oregano, dried berries, leather and earth lead into a palate of dark red fruits, juniper and pine wood. Potpourri spice and more voluptuous purple-flower and fruit flavors emerge with time.
Wine: Thacher 2013 Original Copy Red (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine sources from several of the producer's coastal sites, from Gap's Crown to Durell Vineyard. It's herbal and smoky, velvety thick and soft, with an underlying persistence of cardamom, clove, orange and dark cherry. The full-bodied concentration supports polished tannins and a density of fruit.
Wine: Three Sticks 2016 PFV Estate Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This limited, estate-grown reserve is the last of Van Duzer's 2014 Pinot Noirs to be released. It seamlessly layers berry, leaf, cola and caramel components, which lead to an extended, well-balanced finish framed by firm, ripe tannins.
Wine: Van Duzer 2014 Alchemy Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's less of this wine available than in past years, but the quality remains high. Its nuanced aromas include cocoa dust, caramel and red fruit. Berry and cherry flavors come into focus as it opens, and it seems likely to benefit from more bottle age.
Wine: Adelsheim 2014 Elizabeth's Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Anaba
Review: This appellation wine is made from multiple single-vineyard sites. It's light and floral, with a fresh, focused embrace of grapefruit, Meyer lemon and Gravenstein apple. Hints of fennel and orange mark the finish.
Wine: Anaba 2015 Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling of an Alban clone was fermented 56% whole cluster, and makes for a more mineral-driven Grenache, with aromas of dried red currants, sarsaparilla, leather and pencil shavings. It's very dry on the palate with red plum, rosewater, candied jasmine and a hint of spearmint, but the firm tannins need much more time to smooth out.
Wine: Big Basin 2014 Grizzly Grenache (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Bravium
Review: This wine boasts a lush palate of apple, pear and Meyer lemon. It is grainy in texture and supported by oak, yet there's a steely thread of acidity to help balance the richness.
Wine: Bravium 2016 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Bryn Mawr Vineyards
Review: This exciting wine points the way for this Italian variety in the Eola-Amity Hills. Rich, plush blackberry and plum fruit flavors, along with juicy acidity, create a bombshell of a wine that is near irresistible. There's a peppery bite to the finish, and it should continue to drink well for another five or six years at least.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2016 Dolcetto (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve cuvée was fermented with native yeasts and aged 18 months in one third new oak. It's fruit-centric, with blackberry and black cherry flavors and barrel notes of mocha and cacao. The mouthfeel is smooth, with polished tannins that carry an herbal note gracefully into the finish.
Wine: Cramoisi 2015 Reserve Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Fleshy and bright in citrus and green apple, this wine is driven by its streak of supportive acidity, a succulence that helps moderate the toasted oak, nuttiness and full-strength body.
Wine: Croix 2015 Starling Morelli Roost Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Nearly half of this blend of 35% Viognier, 20% Marsanne, 18% Roussanne, 18% Picpoul Blanc and 9% Grenache Blanc is aged in acacia, with the other half in stainless steel and 8% in amphora. That combo delivers broad toasty aromas that are light and buttery yet convey guava jam and honeydew syrup touches. The palate is rounded with pear, peach and Rainier cherry flavors, enveloped in a racy lemony veil.
Wine: Derby 2014 Derby Vineyard Fifteen 10 White (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Knudsen
Review: Knudsen's Pinot Noirs are consistently elegant, pretty wines. This one delivers light plum flavors with allspice highlights. It has appealing softness and extends into a lovely finish marked by a twist of orange peel.
Wine: Knudsen 2015 Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The California producer ventures into Oregon with this excellent single vineyard offering. It's both elegant and full-flavored, with fleshy black fruit and citrus peel highlights. Barrel aging seems to have contributed coffee and dark chocolate accents, making it feel supple and polished, with an underpinning of clean earth.
Wine: Manross 2015 Hawk's View Vineyard Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Strong peppercorn, bay leaf, grilled berries and a touch of tar show on the nose of this blend of 69% Grenache and 31% Syrah. It's fairly thick on the palate with roasted plum, soy and lilac flavors, but quite complex and attention-grabbing.
Wine: Órale 2013 Buena Onda Grenache-Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve-level Pinot Noir is aromatic and inviting, with crushed rose and sandalwood scents. Red fruit abounds, recalling cranberry, raspberry and cherry. It's too young and forward now to offer the complexities that further age will bring. Drink now through the late 2020s.
Wine: Patton Valley 2015 Lorna-Marie Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Robert John
Review: This blends in tiny amounts of Petit Verdot, Malbec and Cabernet Franc, the whole an expansive big-boned expression of structured cassis and currant. Graphite, dust and dried herb provide savory seasoning and additional complexity.
Wine: Robert John 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Appellation: Schug
Review: With an exotic nose of gardenia and jasmine, this is an inviting light-bodied white that is bright in sizzling acidity, with a strong taste of peach and melon.
Wine: Schug 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Starmont
Review: This wine offers a balanced celebration of plum, dark cherry and cola spice that's velvety and textured. With moderate acidity keeping it fresh in the glass, it offers depth and length, as well as a slight tease of orange peel.
Wine: Starmont 2015 Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Clean and well-rounded on the nose, this bottling shows ripe pear, tight banana, white flowers and a toasty warmth. There's a hint of mango tropicality on the sip, but the bright citrusy edge of lime juice and flashes of toast and wood provide balance.
Wine: Stasis 2016 Murmur Vineyard Viognier (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Stolo
Review: This fresh and zesty bottling smells of springtime, with lily and light sweetgrass aromas as well as riper flashes of peach, pear and apple flesh. There's zip and grip to the sip, with candied grapefruit rind and passion-fruit flavors.
Wine: Stolo 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (San Luis Obispo County)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The 55% Grenache component of this blend takes the lead on the nose, where crushed rose, bright cherry, framboise and jasmine aromas align. The 25% Syrah, 13% Mourvèdre and 7% Counoise make their slighter presence a bit more known on the complex palate, where candied strawberry, cherry and pomegranate flavors dominate.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2016 Cotes de Tablas Red (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Arroyo Grande Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Earthy aromas of turned loam mix with Bing cherry on the nose of this bottling, which is likely to grow more complex and intriguing with age. It's light and fresh on the sip, showing red currant, vanilla and a light touch of spice.
Wine: Talley 2015 East Rincon Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is made from one-third each Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot, all grown from the producer's estate vineyards in remote Chiles Valley. It's beautifully floral and soft, with a mix of candied plum, coffee and dried herb. Dusty, balanced and juicy, it is a lovely representation of elegance and quiet power.
Wine: Volker Eisele Family Estate 2014 Terzetto Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: V. Sattui
Review: Spicy in honeyed oak, this full-bodied wine is bright in acidity and strong flavors of lime and lemon verbena. Balanced and integrated despite its complete embrace of ripeness, it allows for a brightness of acidity beneath grainy texture and grip.
Wine: V. Sattui 2016 Chardonnay (Los Carneros)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From a promising new Bordeaux varietal estate project in Gilroy, this blend of 46% Cabernet Franc, 31% Petit Verdot and 23% Cabernet Sauvignon starts with traditional aromas of oak, leather, black cherry, fig paste, tobacco leaf and cigar box. The tannins are a bit firm and grippy but well polished, carrying cocoa, dried herb and black-cherry flavors.
Wine: Verde 2015 Sophie's Estate Red (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a brawny blend of a majority Cabernet Sauvignon with smaller amounts of Petite Sirah, Zinfandel, Syrah, Cabernet Franc and Grenache. Tar, leather and cola ooze from a moderately structured, full-bodied core that's fleshy and rich, seasoned in currant and cedar.
Wine: VGS 2016 Potelle Two Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: From 34-year-old vines, this has an appealing texture that fluctuates between creaminess and stoniness. The fruit ripened into peach-and-banana territory—a ripeness curbed by seven months on the lees.
Wine: Viento 2015 Old Vines Dry Riesling (Columbia Gorge (OR))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The grapes for this wine were picked at low brix, intended from the start for rosé. This results in an elegant, low alcohol expression that's dry but not sour, light but not thin. Its wild strawberry, cocoa and ground coffee flavors are appealing, complex and picnic-ready.
Wine: Walnut City WineWorks 2017 Pinot Noir Rosé (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Writer's Block
Review: Very concentrated and layered, this deeply colored and full-bodied wine has a powerful mouthfeel and firm tannins underlying the saturated cherry, earth and game nuances that come out with each sip.
Wine: Writer's Block 2015 Syrah (Lake County)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an approachable, lovable expression of peach and apricot with a floral nose that invites one in to explore. Fresh citrus-driven acidity drives the brightness of the wine, making it both thirst-quenching and fun.
Wine: Bruliam 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Yellow-gold in color and buttery in the mouth, this tasty, toasty wine maintains a firm spine of acidity through the finish. Bread dough and croissant suggestions linger in the aftertaste.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2016 Estate Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Carlton Cellars
Review: Sourced from an acre of the estate planted in 2009, this well-made wine tastes perfectly ripe. Flavors of white peach, radish and jicama meld with ample acidity on the palate. Overall, this is well balanced and lingering.
Wine: Carlton Cellars 2016 Pinot Blanc (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Carlton Cellars
Review: This new vintage is a great stride for Willamette Valley Sauvignon Blanc. It conjures up the intense grassiness of a Loire Valley wine, with crisply defined, tart apple fruit and fresh green herb notes that bring chervil to mind. It softens a bit on the finish, suggesting that at least some partial malolactic fermentation took place.
Wine: Carlton Cellars 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This gets more than two years in mostly new American oak, as well as a sprinkling of Alicante Bouschet. Pepper, meat and violet rise from the nose, complementing the fleshy fruity blueberry that is to come. Full bodied, the wine is velvety soft and supple in texture and balanced in weight.
Wine: Carol Shelton 2014 Florence Vineyard Petite Sirah (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This marks the last vintage prior to the sale of the winery and the change of winemakers. Stainless steel fermented and aged and immaculately fresh in style, it offers precise citrus flesh, juice and rind flavors. Lemon, lime, grapefruit and orange notes combine in a zesty package built for those who love high-acid flavors.
Wine: Chehalem 2017 INOX Unoaked Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lightly honeyed aromas as well as honeydew meet with crushed chalk and hot sand on the nose of this bottling. The palate shows strong and fresh lemon flavors alongside a touch of cantaloupe, but remains expertly restrained throughout.
Wine: Cooper-Garrod 2016 Randall Grahm Clone Viognier (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Duckhorn
Review: From both the east and west sides of the appellation, this is an intensely fruity wine, soft in cassis and plum, that offers a sizable presence of polished tannin. The oak takes on a dustiness of black pepper and dark chocolate that lingers in spicy clove.
Wine: Duckhorn 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's name refers to the floods that brought seismic change to the Willamette Valley millennia ago. It's as soft and smooth as a slice of blackberry pie, with cut tobacco highlights. In flavor, it's closer to old vine Lodi field blends than to typical Oregon Pinot Noir. Yet, it's quite delicious and ready to drink.
Wine: Elouan 2016 Missoulan Wash Reserve Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Holloran
Review: Despite the relatively low alcohol, this wine drinks absolutely dry, showing plenty of grip and length. The cool vintage flavors recall grapefruit and green apple, with a twist of lemon. A lovely sipping wine.
Wine: Holloran 2013 Riesling (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is one of a series of single clone offerings from Kason. Much improved from the previous vintage, it offers blackberry and black cherry fruit that's ripe yet restrained in alcohol. It has pleasing sandalwood and toasted coconut highlights, and the tannins are soft and well integrated.
Wine: Kason 2015 Dijon 777 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Earthy in mushroom and pine, this Petaluma Gap-made wine is generous in tannin, with a substantial underlying weight that supports cherry and blueberry flavors. The earthiness takes on a stemmy quality that is wild and complex.
Wine: Keller 2015 El Coro Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Sourced from the Mirabelle and Jewell Ranch vineyards, the grapes Musque clone, this is a delightfully delicious and impressively made white. Floral, herbal and steely, it shows a wealth of crisp green apple and melon flavor with just a touch of neutral oak influence.
Wine: MacRostie 2017 Clockwise Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dunnigan Hills, Central Valley, California, US
Review: A toasty, oaky, spicy aroma precedes equally oaky flavors that are nevertheless backed by ripe, juicy pear and ginger notes. These tones expand on the palate and linger on the finish. It's full bodied and broad in texture.
Wine: Matchbook 2016 The Arsonist Chardonnay (Dunnigan Hills)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: More than just fruity, this intense and concentrated wine is deep and dark in color, smells like wood smoke and black pepper and tastes like blackberries, anise and dark chocolate. It is full-bodied and firmly tannic in texture to pair well with the richest roast or steak.
Wine: Obscurity 2015 Estate Geoff & Katy Vineyard Malbec (Fair Play)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon takes the lead in this blend, balanced with 20% Merlot, 5% Malbec and Petit Verdot. Sourced from top vineyards and aged in just 32% new French oak, it delivers appealing blackberry, dried herb, cocoa, graphite and cherry aromas and well-constructed fruit flavors that dip considerably in the middle. It is nicely structured and comes back together on the finish.
Wine: Pamplin 2014 JRG Red (Columbia Valley (OR))

Appellation: Paradise Springs
Review: Very light and clean on the nose, this bottling, which is overseen by proprietor Kirk Wiles and winemaker Doug Margerum, shows citrus blossoms and apple flesh on the nose. There is lots of zippy structure to the palate, which zings deep into the finish with green-apple flavors.
Wine: Paradise Springs 2015 Sauvignon Blanc (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This crisp bracing wine has a pale-salmon color, vivid cherry and plum aromas and very good balance. Good acidity and almost the heft of red wine give it more personality than many rosés.
Wine: Pech Merle 2017 Rivino Vineyard Vin Rosé of Syrah (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Prager
Review: Bottled in 2015, this is made from 61% Petite Sirah, 36% Tinta Roriz and 3% Cabernet Sauvignon, then aged for two years in neutral oak. It has older characteristics of leather and sandalwood, as well as a savory backbone that's brightened by a rich, viscous contrast of black cherry and blackberry.
Wine: Prager 2012 Port (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A strong aromatic element of eucalyptus and bay leaf permeate on the nose of this wine, which settles into a full-figured, lush and textured commingling of coffee, dark chocolate and berry pie, the finish brightened by a tease of acidity.
Wine: Ravenswood 2015 Old Hill Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Mike Landt has added Sauvignon Blanc to his stable of cool climate wines, making it in a superripe, almost candied style. This is nothing like a Loire Valley version but is nonetheless well structured. Leesy and creamy, it has a lightly buttery finish. Taken on its own, it's remarkably tasty and rather unique.
Wine: River's Edge 2016 Vintage Farm Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Rutherford Ranch
Review: This white is beautifully lush and delicious—a light bright explosion of fresh peach and grapefruit dipped in Tahitian vanilla.
Wine: Rutherford Ranch 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sass
Review: Sourced from southern Oregon, this shows amped-up fruit and gentle acidity, resulting in very tasty, almost-tropical flavors. Barrel fermented using indigenous yeasts and aged in a mix of stainless steel and neutral wood, it delivers lush melon and banana flavors, with a creamy yet lively mouthfeel.
Wine: Sass 2015 Pinot Blanc (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve was aged 18 months in 50% new French oak, lending some butterfat to the mouthfeel and highlights of licorice and chocolate to the finish. The fruit centers on black raspberry, and the extended barrel aging has left some rough tannins that may require another year or two in bottle to smooth out.
Wine: Scenic Valley Farms 2015 Zielinski Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sol Rouge
Review: Generous cherry aromas and gentle cherry flavors make this medium-bodied wine easy to appreciate. It has a supple texture due to mild acidity and light tannins and a sense of lightness that is almost delicate.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2014 Cinsault (Red Hills)

Appellation: Stags' Leap Winery
Review: This wine is thick and rich in cocoa powder, cassis and cedar, plus a slight note of blueberry in the background. Polished tannins give it structured elegance and a medium-bodied sense of ripeness that's welcome at the dinner table.
Wine: Stags' Leap Winery 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Aubichon Cellars
Review: This blend from three vineyards comes on thick and sappy, with chunky black fruit flavors. Earth, forest floor and dark chocolate details emerge as it fills the palate. It glides smoothly into a rich finish marked by a vein of cola.
Wine: Aubichon Cellars 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Bluebird Hill
Review: This wine's inviting buttered popcorn scents suggest an old school style of Chardonnay, yet it delivers the precision and focus of Willamette Valley fruit. It was fermented in one quarter new French oak barrels, and half underwent malolactic fermentation. It's a generous wine that should be drunk over the next couple of years.
Wine: Bluebird Hill 2016 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve is modest in concentration, but the clean red fruit is nicely balanced by light spice and supportive acidity. It's precise and nicely textured throughout.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2015 Reserve Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Capo Creek
Review: Buttery oak and a whiff of sulfur blow off to reveal a light-bodied, ripe core of honey, apple and quince. A dried herb note gingerly lingers on the finish.
Wine: Capo Creek 2015 Grenache Blanc (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve bottling is all about power. Its black cherry fruit comes with a suggestion of banana cream pie, and 18 months aging in French oak has given it a big, toasty frame. A hint of alcoholic burn emerges on the finish.
Wine: Carlton Cellars 2014 Roads End Reserve Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose on this bottling from a vineyard located 1,100 feet in the mountains is very concentrated with roasted cherry, mulberry and hibiscus extract aromas, even showing hints of maple sugar. The palate is quite interesting, offering thick plum juice as well as sandalwood and crème brûlée flavors.
Wine: Comartin 2016 R-Bar-R Ranch Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Cramoisi
Review: Texture, detail and length are the highlights of this exceptional vintage. They're all present here, anchored by blackberry and black cherry fruit that's ripe to a fine lustre. It's accented with cinnamon and black pepper notes from aging 12 months in 30% new oak. Firm, polished tannins finish it nicely.
Wine: Cramoisi 2015 Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Reduced on the nose, with a distinction of barrel and tar, this vineyard and clone-designate shows a richness of baked cherry and blueberry, as well as a lush earthiness. Integrated, the tannins are soft and easy on the palate.
Wine: Davis Bynum 2015 Jane's Vineyard Pommard Clone Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: From the site made famous for Merlot, this estate wine shows the other side of the coin, more structured in tight tannins and a wealth of powerful concentration. Leather, baked plum and cocoa powder dominate the further components of blackberry and blueberry compote.
Wine: Duckhorn 2014 Three Palms Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Etude
Review: This 100% varietal wine is pillowy in texture and tannin, with structure to spare. Herbal and grippy, it exudes plenty of rich black fruit, leather, cedar and clove.
Wine: Etude 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This coastal wine is juicy in black fruit, black tea and a pronouncement of oak, while the body is big-boned, savory and thick in up-front tannin. There's an underlying earthiness that's hard to resist and likably integrated with the highlights of strawberry and rhubarb.
Wine: Hanzell 2016 Sebella Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: La Folia Winery
Review: This remarkable wine is rather rich and creamy in texture, has mild herb and mineral aromas and a green-apple flavor that slowly opens and deepens on the palate. It's medium bodied, well-balanced and has good acidity without being overtly crisp.
Wine: La Folia Winery 2016 Vermentino (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: High-toned in fleshy peach and apricot with a nod of Good & Plenty licorice, this big-boned, structured and lushly crafted wine stands out with its complement of rich concentrated fruitiness and toasty oak.
Wine: Lucie 2016 Dutton Hill Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Marcella's
Review: Featuring a label painted by renowned Central Coast artist Chris Potter, this is a blend of 53% Viognier, 34% Grenache Blanc and 13% Roussane. Aromas of melon, yellow peach, lemon rind and chalky minerality lead into a palate loaded with ripe stone-fruit flavors that are balanced by citrusy acidity.
Wine: Marcella's 2016 White (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Aged and fermented in stainless steel and in the barrel, this white is richly concentrated in baked flavors of quince and pear. Up-front in its intensity, it opens to reveal floral aromas and bright acidity midpalate and through a lengthy, lightly spiced finish.
Wine: Medlock Ames 2016 Lower Slope Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Merryvale
Review: Pretty in jasmine on the nose, this wine offers juicy stone fruit within a rounded, likable framework of balanced richness and lingering acidity.
Wine: Merryvale 2016 Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The aromatic background of this wine is full of blackberry, black plum and black-currant paste, but the foreground shows dill, spearmint and tarragon on the nose, with a hint of chocolate richness. The palate is dry, showing dark red fruit, leather and earth, with a tight tannic weave that will last for years.
Wine: Opolo 2014 Fusion Cabernet Sauvignon-Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Brimming with tasty black cherry fruit, this affordable and supremely enjoyable bottle should be tasted immediately. Cola and mocha touches percolate through the finish. Best now through the early 2020s.
Wine: Redhawk 2016 Estate Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: St. Helena, Napa, California, US
Review: Somewhat reduced and tightly wound, this is a robustly ripe wine. The full-bodied palate offers soft layers of dense baked-fruit flavors, a dusty texture and considerable oak.
Wine: Roberts & Rogers 2014 Louer Family Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This pink blend of 49% Mourvèdre, 39% Grenache and 12% Counoise makes for a deep, almost rusty shade of pink, and delivers an intense nose of kirsch, clove and iron. The palate is full flavored with cherry and red-plum skins, making for a strong lively rosé.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2017 Dianthus Rosé (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Talley
Review: Pretty aromas of pomegranate, red-rose petals, carnations and hibiscus make for a fresh and juicy entry to this appellation blend. The relatively lighter-bodied palate is richer than expected, with deep pomegranate and hibiscus flavors.
Wine: Talley 2015 Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This Petaluma Gap-grown wine is stemmy in earthiness and a strong bite of tannin, its core juicy in red cherry and boysenberry, with a savory edge of forest and Asian spice.
Wine: Tamber Bey 2016 Sun Chase Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Los Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Pungent in nutty oak, this wine is hearty and reduced, with a steeliness on the palate. Mango, pineapple and brioche figure into the richness, while the midpalate tacks on a lemony brightness with moderate complexity.
Wine: Tognetti 2015 Aloise Francisco Vineyards Chardonnay (Los Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This block-designated wine features 30-year-old Pommard clone fruit. It's a tasty mix of berry, plum, blood orange and lemon peel flavors, with a touch of bitter grapefruit. Well structured and buoyed by ample acidity, it falls on the darker, earthier side of Oregon Pinot Noir.
Wine: Van Duzer 2015 Homestead Block Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Walnut City WineWorks
