Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A yellowish hue of pink in the glass, this blend of 64% Grenache, 29% Mourvèdre, 5% Syrah and 2% Counoise shows very light and pleasant aromas of crisp melon. It's crisp and zesty on the palate with flavors of lemon juice, ripe nectarine and wet river stone.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2017 Patelin de Tablas Rosé (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Earthy in compost and forest, this is a fleshy rounded red with thick dense layers of tannin and baked cherry that finishes in spicy vanilla oak.
Wine: Taken Wine Co. 2015 Complicated Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: The Winery SF
Review: This rich and slightly earthy wine has an aroma of dried figs and ripe black plums plus a slight funky note that blows off. That's followed by juicy and friendly cherry and berry flavors and a smooth sleek texture. It's medium bodied, not overtly oaky and light on tannin.
Wine: The Winery SF 2013 Merlot (North Coast)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This pale-colored wine offers pure cherry candy and raspberry aromas. The flavors are light, tart and elegant. It doesn't quite stand up on its own but should fit in well at the dinner table.
Wine: Viola 2015 Dugger Creek Vineyard Sangiovese (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's confusing name may lead consumers to think it's a sparkling wine rather than a white wine made from Pinot Noir grapes. Round and juicy, it's loaded with grapefruit, orange peel and light peach flavors. Fermented entirely in stainless steel, it's a good alternative to Chardonnay.
Wine: Vista Hills 2017 Fool's Gold Blanc de Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a great price for a single vineyard Chardonnay, and is sure to be a crowd-pleaser, thanks to the familiar buttered toast and singed oak aromas, which are cut but a lemon-curd-pastry element. The palate falls in line with traditional California style, but done well and balanced, with oak, vanilla and marshmallow flavors.
Wine: Wente 2016 Riva Ranch Chardonnay (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Cedary, floral aromas and powerful fruit and oak-spice flavors make this very full-bodied wine really fun to taste. It's unusual in the level of interesting complexity it offers.
Wine: Amador Cellars 2014 Farmhouse Red (Amador County)

Appellation: Bella Grace
Review: Herbal, grassy, peppery aromas and flavors give a big personality to this tangy, assertive but light-bodied wine. It has crisp acidity and taut balance.
Wine: Bella Grace 2017 Vermentino (Amador County)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is an attractive well-made dry wine that smells fruity and spicy, tastes moderately ripe and has a firm texture that will help it pair well with rich food. It's well balanced and medium bodied.
Wine: Bliss 2015 Blissful Red (Mendocino)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Bright and spicy, this seems to have a bit of residual sugar, evidenced by brown sugar and cherry pie highlights. The flavors are upfront and compact, and the wine should drink well into the early 2020s.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2016 Estate Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Pink-orange in color, this is fresh and lightly fruity, balanced in a lasting combination of strawberry and peach flavors, the acidity in check.
Wine: C R Graybehl 2017 Rosé of Grenache (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a unique blend of 44% Sangiovese, 20% Barbera and 13% Primitivo, with pinches of Syrah, Nebbiolo and Malbec. The aromas are light, recalling sour cherry, licorice and spice. The flavors are tart, bringing a blast of acidity and firm tannins. Put it on the dinner table to see it at its best.
Wine: Cana's Feast 2013 Bricco Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly wound and bright lemon-peel aromas meet with honeysuckle, wet stone, nectarine flesh and a hint of charred wood on this blend of Grenache Blanc, Roussanne, Marsanne and Viognier. There's a flash of sweetness on the palate which then tightens onto tangy lime and grapefruit peels with a touch of peachy warmth.
Wine: Carol Shelton 2016 Coquille Blanc White (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Blackberry jam, bacon, maple, wet slate and vanilla all show on the nose of this bottling from Cripple Creek Vineyard in the El Pomar District. The tannic structure is a tad firm on the sip still, but carries smoky flavors of roasted pork, rich dark fruit and a pinch of baking spice. The acidity is piercing and will mellow with time.
Wine: Counter Punch 2015 Engage Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Del Rio
Review: Supple and fruity, this fresh and lively white wine bring scents and flavors of peach and pear. The balanced acidity adds a note of fresh cut orange slices.
Wine: Del Rio 2016 Pinot Gris (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Pale copper in color, this dry, spicy wine has tart grapefruit and watermelon flavors and the lively, tangy crispness that suits a hot summer day. It finishes with a touch of pepper.
Wine: Del Rio 2017 Grenache Rosé (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's pretty strawberry and spicy/tart cherry fruit shines, with medium concentration and length. Its light tannins and supportive acids are in fine balance, making it a nice alternative to more elegant Pinot Noir-based Oregon rosés.
Wine: Eliana 2017 Rosé of Merlot (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Distinctly European in style, this steely take on the quintessential Oregon white wine is a no-frills, fruit-driven effort. It will please those who prefer their white wines oak-free and low alcohol, with its clean, pure expression of apple and pear fruit.
Wine: Girardet 2016 Estate Grown Pinot Gris (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Highland Valley
Review: Fresh crushed berries mix with jasmine, vanilla and caramel on the ripe nose of this bottling. The palate is also thick and somewhat sweet, with sugar plums and vanilla extract, but makes for a promising bottling for this Southern California region.
Wine: Highland Valley 2015 Syrah (San Diego County)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: This is a fairly light, leafy, fruity style of Cabernet Franc. The tannins have been tamed, revealing a lively mix of candied raspberry and citrus highlights. It's front-loaded with fruit and should be enjoyed now–2020.
Wine: 2Hawk 2015 Cabernet Franc (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: Ripeness is not an issue for this rich, unctuous wine. It's soft and butter-smooth in the mouth, loaded with peachy fruit. All but a fraction was barrel fermented and put through malolactic. Enjoy it while it retains its youthful freshness.
Wine: 2Hawk 2016 Chardonnay (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: This sharp, steely, grassy bottling pays respect to the innate herbaceousness of the grape. Gooseberry, lemon and grapefruit flavors spotlight the sharp acidity. It was principally fermented in stainless steel, with a small amount in neutral barrels.
Wine: 2Hawk 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% varietal wine saw just a kiss of new French oak (20%). Its leafy green herb, blackberry, anise, orange zest and cherry aromas are followed by stylish fruit and fresh herb flavors that linger on the finish. It's very well made, albeit quite green.
Wine: Adamant Cellars 2014 Winemaker's Select Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Adelsheim
Review: This widely-available Pinot Noir is the first release of the vintage from Adelsheim and provides a good standard for those to follow. Still tight, it's lightly herbal, with clean raspberry fruit and a hint of cinnamon from aging 10 months in one quarter new oak.
Wine: Adelsheim 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Amador Cellars
Review: Good concentration and a lively texture highlight this full-bodied and refreshing wine. It has mineral, melon and citrus aromas, and crisp fruit flavors sprinkled with fresh herbs like mint and thyme.
Wine: Amador Cellars 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Amador County)

Appellation: Bacon
Review: Wet gravel, black-raspberry, black-plum-jelly and a hint of roasted-meat aromas arise in this blend of 35% Syrah, 25% Grenache, 20% Mourvèdre, 10% Merlot and Petite Sirah 10%. There are riper currant flavors at first and then come more earthy and damp rock flavors, all lifted by cola spice.
Wine: Bacon 2016 Red (Central Coast)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This is a fresh breezy light-bodied wine that's a delight to drink. An enticing aroma of apple blossoms and white peach leads to lots of fruity flavors and a texture that's both smooth and crisp at the same time.
Wine: Bella Grace 2017 3 Graces Blanc White (Amador County)

Appellation: Bella Grace
Review: Rich white-cherry and apple flavors are matched by very crisp, tangy elements in this medium-bodied and well-balanced wine. It has a good full mouthfeel without sacrificing the refreshing character of the acidity.
Wine: Bella Grace 2017 Grenache Blanc (Amador County)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is light and delicate in texture, with a fragrance of pungent earth and dark underbelly of the forest. Cardamom, black tea and cranberry combine around a fresh, nearly carbonic body.
Wine: Blagden 2012 Sangiacomo Roberts Road Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very light in the glass, this bottling of a rarely found but increasingly popular grape shows white melon, Granny Smith apple flesh, pink limes and rainy cement aromas on the nose. Dried lime peels and rocky granite-like flavors show on the sip.
Wine: Bonny Doon 2017 Beeswax Vineyard Picpoul (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve wine—only a few bucks more than the regular 2015 Pinot Noir—was made from 60% Pommard and 40% Wadenswil, aged in 40% new oak. It's dramatically toasty, with roasted black cherry and cola flavots. Tasty, though rough-hewn, it will be best now–2020.
Wine: Bradley 2015 Estate Reserve Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Daou
Review: This is a very ripe take on the grape, with vivacious and full aromas of yellow pear, white peach and lemon blossom. Broad flavors of apple and red pear are clean and very expressive, bordering on tropical.
Wine: Daou 2016 Chardonnay (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Savory aromas of fig balsamic sauce, dill, toasted oak and pressed purple flowers show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. The palate is dense and dark with a firm tannic structure and approachable acidity, showing dark-chocolate and black-cherry flavors.
Wine: Derby 2014 Laura's Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A small bottling from a Paso Robles-based producer, this is a brawny, tannic style of wine, up-front in its ripeness and richness, with lush layers of sweet tannin, forest floor and cherry cola.
Wine: Lusso Della Terra 2015 Reserve Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Merryvale
Review: Smoky char and dried sage mark the entry of this wine, aged for nearly two years in French oak, half of it new. Tart and tangy in red currant and cassis, it finishes awash in spicy clove and leather, full bodied and polished in tannin.
Wine: Merryvale 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Muirwood
Review: Oaky in style, this bottling shows black cherry, vanilla and caramel on the nose, becoming inviting if a tad single-noted. Baked gingerbread and cherry compote arise on the palate, which is a bit chunky in texture but makes for an enjoyable wine.
Wine: Muirwood 2016 Pinot Noir (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: San Bernabe, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a smoky bottling, with wafts of hickory and oak overcoming the lemon blossoms, yet remaining quite inviting. The palate starts floral, with honeysuckle and orange blossom flavors, then moves toward lemon curd and sandalwood on the finish.
Wine: Noble Vines 2016 446 Chardonnay (San Bernabe)

Appellation: San Bernabe, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling shows candied honeysuckle and pear extract on the nose. It's simple, fresh and easy-to-like on the palate, full of yellow apples, red pears and a decent acidity.
Wine: Noble Vines 2017 152 Pinot Grigio (San Bernabe)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blended with 25% Malbec, this delivers exotic spice, dark fruit and black licorice aromas. Its black fruit flavors are speckled with plentiful barrel accents, seeming slightly dried out.
Wine: Obelisco Estate 2014 Estate Grown BDX Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's bittersweet chocolate, currant and baking spice aromas are followed by medium-bodied fruit flavors, with cocoa notes on the finish. Though sophisticated, it seems dominated by oak.
Wine: Obelisco Estate 2014 Estate Grown BDX Merlot (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Obelisco Estate
Review: This wine's barrel aromas are up-front, with vanilla, anise, cocoa and baking spice notes obscuring its dark fruit and varietal character. It's medium bodied and enjoyable, with a smooth finish.
Wine: Obelisco Estate 2014 Malbec (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This dry Portuguese-style blend of 50% Touriga Nacional, 25% Tinto Cão and 25% Souzão offers aromas of lilacs, Concord grapes and cooked black plums on the nose. The palate starts with a strong tannic grip but then releases into plum jelly and sweet-seeming black fruits.
Wine: Per Caso 2013 Iberian Red (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Picayune
Review: Given time in both stainless steel and neutral oak, this is a steely floral expression of the grape—dry and balanced in green-apple and melon flavors with a freshly focused finish of lasting acidity.
Wine: Picayune 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa County-Sonoma County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This latest vintage is purple-black in color and loaded with sweet black cherry fruit, broad streaks of cola, and supple tannins. It stops short on the finish, though another year or two in bottle may correct that to some degree.
Wine: Rex Hill 2015 Sims Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Ruby Cellars
Review: Quite light in the glass, this bottling shows fresh mulberry, red plum, cherry, cinnamon and dried tarragon on the nose, with a bit of dust. The palate offers great herbal qualities that mesh with berry syrup and vanilla on the finish.
Wine: Ruby Cellars 2013 Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A new offering, this is made to evoke Provence—a light, bright and likable wine that's beguiling in strawberry, cherry and peach. The acidity emphasizes the tartness of lemon peel.
Wine: Sonoma-Cutrer 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Steele
Review: Hints of mint and cedar make the aroma of this full-bodied wine tempting, and the flavors deliver lots of plump berries and light, spicy accents. It's well-balanced and easy to appreciate.
Wine: Steele 2015 Merlot (Lake County)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Blended with 10% Merlot, this offers high-toned cherry, cassis and a simple tannin structure, creating an elegant take on the variety that's polished and built for enjoying with a meal.
Wine: Textbook 2014 Mise en Place Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aromas of pound cake, apple galette and plumeria are bound together in a tight steely frame on the nose of this bottling. There's a bright and sharp grapefruit edge to the palate but also a pastry-like warmth, but it's the high-acid that takes center stage, arising on the front of the sip and carrying deep into the finish.
Wine: Thacher 2016 Hastings Ranch Vineyard Viognier (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark plum, cherry, chocolate cake, star anise and leather show on the nose of this blend of 71% Merlot, 18% Cabernet Sauvignon and 11% Petite Sirah. There is a strong structure that grabs hold of the palate and won't let go, showing that the tannins need a bit more time to resolve. That will allow the piquant flavors of dark red fruit and licorice to emerge.
Wine: Tooth and Nail 2015 The Fiend Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: V. Sattui
Review: This is a lightly sweet version of the famously aromatic varietal, and it delivers fragrant pine needle, peach and diesel aromas followed by rich peach and melon flavors. The texture is smooth and soft.
Wine: V. Sattui 2015 Riesling (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: This 100% varietal wine is explosively fruity. Its tart red plum and black cherry fruit bursts from the glass. High alcohol gives the finish a slight, liquorous burn. But if it's fruit flavor you want, it's here in spades.
Wine: 2Hawk 2016 Grenache (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: This young, peppery wine has compact purple fruit, moderate acidity and a spicy kick. Aged in 18% new French oak, it's still pulling itself together. Drink from 2020.
Wine: 2Hawk 2016 Malbec (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, 20% each Malbec, Merlot and Petit Verdot and 10% Cabernet Franc. Its strong dill, green herb, cherry and orange zest aromas lead to tart herb and fruit flavors. It might be too green for some tastes.
Wine: Adamant Cellars 2013 Nalin Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% varietal wine was aged in 20% new French oak. Its raspberry, green herb and spice aromas lead to ripe fruit flavors that coat the palate. It's lovely and exquisitely made but seems a bit green for the variety.
Wine: Adamant Cellars 2013 Winemaker's Select Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This pretty pale peach-colored wine opens with strawberry, watermelon and honeydew melon aromas. Its dry, kiwi-like flavors finish with a kiss of sweetness. It brings a lot of appeal.
Wine: Airfield Estates 2017 Sangiovese Rosé (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Bluebird Hill
Review: Tight and stiffly tannic, this wine is still knitting itself together. At the moment, the herbal components and tannins outshine its lighter red fruit. It finishes with a pleasing burst of caramel from 10 months in 10% new French oak.
Wine: Bluebird Hill 2015 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A play on the famous line from the film Sideways, this bottling attempts to resurrect Merlot's image, starting with rich fresh aromas of blackberry sorbet, tangy black-plum skins and crushed gravel. It's a very young wine throughout, as the lighter bodied palate offers candied black-raspberry and plum flavors. Good with a chill.
Wine: Bonny Doon 2016 I Am Not Drinking Any $%&*# Merlot (Monterey County)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: A subtle savory earthy leathery aspect adds intrigue to this medium-bodied and rather soft-textured wine. The fruit component is light raspberry.
Wine: Cavaletti 2016 The 109 Mile Grenache (California)

Appellation: Fair Play, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Spicy and well-integrated oak shapes nicely the taste of this full-bodied, concentrated and well-structured wine. Cedar and baking spices highlight the scent, while black cherry, mint and dark chocolate dominate the flavors. The wine feels firmly tannic and is in no hurry to be drunk.
Wine: Charles B. Mitchell 2015 Estate Grand Reserve Red (Fair Play)

Appellation: Templeton Gap District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From Briarwood Vineyard, this bottling shows boysenberry and black-currant sorbet on the nose with a strong licorice spice. The palate combines grilled berries with spice-cake flavors, proving rather ripe but still quite delicious.
Wine: Cloak & Dagger 2015 The Conspirator's Reserve Syrah (Templeton Gap District)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Sourced from Elephant Mountain Vineyard, this offers café au lait, char, woodspice and cherry aromas and sleekly styled fruit flavors backed by bright acidity. The variety's characteristic burly tannins are well in check.
Wine: Cloudlift Cellars 2015 Stratus Petit Verdot (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Santa Clara Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Cherry, dried herbs and baked earth show on the nose of this bottling from a new producer based in Monterey County. It's a clean, down-the-middle expression of the grape, with dark red cherry, cocoa spice and herb flavors framed by medium tannins and acidity.
Wine: Comanche 2013 Zajak Vineyard Merlot (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly woven, somewhat sour aromas of apple and sweetgrass meet with wet gravel on the nose of this bottling. Clean lime flesh and more wet stone show on the palate.
Wine: Comartin 2017 Zabala Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Warm, earthy and smoky aromas show on the nose of this blend of two vineyards, which also offers caramelized cherry touches. It's relatively light on the palate, with dried-cherry and cherry-pit flavors along with dark spice and a vanilla glaze on the finish.
Wine: Cooper-Garrod 2015 Two Vineyards Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: From a single (though unspecified) vineyard, this wine is a friendly, flavorful burst of sweet berry fruit. The label doesn't do justice to what's in the bottle, which includes a dash of sweet baking spice, also. This isn't a wine to cellar; it's a wine to drink up while it's young and carefree.
Wine: Drum Roll 2015 Pinot Renoir Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Floral with a pretty nose of jasmine and apple blossom, this hearty full-bodied white has an underlying freshness of acidity that evolves into a thicker midpalate of ripe pineapple and mango. Its finish flourishes in nutmeg and ginger.
Wine: Dry Creek Vineyard 2016 DVC Estate Block 10 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Etude
Review: This wine opens with modesty on the nose before unleashing powerful intensity on the palate. Plum, dark cherry and cassis are dusted in oak and cedar, presenting a full-bodied richness that never lets go.
Wine: Etude 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's a high-toned sharpness to this wine's aroma that brightens up its fruit flavors. Raspberry and cherry highlights hit the palate then seem to fade just as quickly.
Wine: High Pass 2016 Union School Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: The Oregon designation suggests this includes both southern Oregon fruit and grapes from the Eola-Amity Hills. It's an affordable look at an emerging specialty for the state, with olive, bacon fat and dried rosemary notes accenting light, red berry-like fruit. Tannins firm up the finish.
Wine: Holloran 2015 Stafford Hill Tempranillo (Oregon)

Appellation: Jason-Stephens
Review: Black pepper, dried and fresh marjoram and dried strawberry aromas show on the herbaceaous nose of this bottling, which is varietally correct. The palate shows an herbal backbone full of peppercorns and oregano, giving depth to the snappy black-raspberry flavors.
Wine: Jason-Stephens 2014 Cabernet Franc (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is fleshy in peach, melon and anise, with a bright yet velvety texture that's lush and lasting in moderate acidity.
Wine: Keller 2015 La Cruz Vineyard Pinot Gris (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Kriselle
Review: This sports toasty aromas that enwrap its supple strawberry and cherry fruit. Those firm fruit flavors persist on the palate, encased in plenty of barrel toast. It's a substantial, chewy, tannic wine with generous alcohol and richness.
Wine: Kriselle 2015 Malbec (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Waxy peach skin and white flowers invite one into this light-bodied springtime wine, which is thick and viscous on the palate. From a longtime grower of the grape, this has moderate acidity and a juiciness that will work well with a variety of food.
Wine: Mahoney 2016 Estate Vermentino (Carneros)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a cleanly made wine but done in such a powerfully classic Chardonnay style that it will please some but dissuade others. Golden in the glass, it shows aromas of ripe Gravenstein apples, lemon syrup, buttered toast and plumeria on the big nose. The palate is loaded with toasted oak, vanilla, caramel, hazelnut and marshmallow flavors, yet has zesty acidity.
Wine: Muirwood 2016 Zanetta Reserve Chardonnay (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Wood smoke and char notes in the aroma of this dark-colored and full-bodied wine are especially vivid while very ripe saturated blackberry flavors and hints of vanilla coat the palate. It's bold and oaky and not at all apologetic.
Wine: Nottingham Cellars 2014 Supremacy Red (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Rusack
Review: Tightly wound and yet very grassy on the nose, this is a Kiwi-style take on the grape, with aromas of wet cement and apple flesh. The palate is tangy with lime and more grass, yet there is ripeness of pome fruit in the midpalate.
Wine: Rusack 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This late-release reserve was aged 40 months in 20% new oak. Its fruit flavors are quite ripe, owing to the very warm vintage, yet they seem to be aging out, pushing dry barrel notes forward. Drink this now, as it's ready to go.
Wine: Sass 2012 Vieux Amis Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Warm aromas of brioche, toasted apple, cinnamon and baking spice show on the nose of this bottling. It's clean, crisp and rounded on the palate, tasting a bit like a riper Chardonnay with butter and stone fruit, but quite inviting.
Wine: Strange Family Vineyards 2014 Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Talbott
Review: Hazelnut and lemon-butter aromas make for a familiar and classic style on the nose of this bottling, yet there is a vibrant citrus twist and touch of herbs that add complexity. The palate is full of lime zest along with a touch of lanolin flavors.
Wine: Talbott 2016 Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This light-bodied wine is wound up tightly by tannins and good acidity, while the fruit and spice flavors seem restrained. Purposely made in a lean style, it will make a good pairing with rich proteins but may need more time in the bottle to unwind. Best after 2020.
Wine: The Withers Winery 2015 Mr. Burgess Syrah (El Dorado)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is stemmy, smoky and robust in earth, its richness nuanced in a simple grasp of red cherry. Light and ethereal in nature, it has delicacy and a restrained sense of ripeness.
Wine: Von Holt 2015 Hummingbird Hill Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Walnut City WineWorks
Review: This pleasantly fruity wine pushes a gentle mix of strawberry and black cherry fruit flavors forward. It's a blend from five vineyards, softened by aging 10 months in French oak (presumably neutral). Drink now–2022.
Wine: Walnut City WineWorks 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Fruit concentration and a firm texture make this wine seriously good. It has oak spice and dark-fruit aromas, rich blackberry and black-cherry flavors, full body and a good layer of gripping tannins.
Wine: Weibel Family 2013 Patriot Red (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Alta Mesa, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Flavorful and exuberant, this wine is very fruity in aroma and flavor. It layers ripe cherry and blackberry with milk chocolate notes, feels broad and rich on the palate and keeps emphasizing fresh black fruit all the way through the finish.
Wine: Wise Villa 2015 Estate Malbec (Alta Mesa)

Appellation: Writer's Block
Review: This wine is medium bodied, full flavored and well structured. Ripe cherries and black plums fill the aroma, dark cherries and subtle spice and smoke come out on the palate as a firm layer of tannin grips the sides of the mouth, ready to handle rich proteins.
Wine: Writer's Block 2015 Grenache (Lake County)

Appellation: 2Hawk
Review: This new release falls just a little flat, with a bit of a hole in the middle. Its light fruit flavors suggest citrus, apples and bananas, finishing with a hint of toast from brief aging in 15% new French oak.
Wine: 2Hawk 2017 Chardonnay (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's graphite, herb, orange peel and cherry aromas are followed by light plum flavors backed by soft tannins. It trails off on the finish.
Wine: Adamant Cellars 2013 Winemaker's Select Tempranillo (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Light-bodied for a red wine and a little rustic in flavor, this wine has engaging earth, leather and cedar aromas, good fruit flavors and a roasted, chocolaty aspect that develops on the palate and lingers on the finish. It's moderately tannic and robust in texture.
Wine: Andis 2015 Hawk Creek Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Castillo de Feliciana
Review: Blended with 12% Syrah, this has initially light aromas that open up to reveal cocoa powder, woodspice, dried herb, red berry and mineral notes. Its sweet cherry flavors are ripe and front-loaded, with a core of tannin in the middle. Cranberry flavors linger on the finish.
Wine: Castillo de Feliciana 2014 Garnacha (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from a few vineyards from the AVA, this offers aromas of green wood, cherry and tobacco. Its plum and cherry flavors are pleasant accents to a core of intense tannins.
Wine: Castillo de Feliciana 2014 Reserve Tempranillo (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's plum, clove, herb, freshly hewn wood and barrel spice aromas are followed by plump yet elegant, smooth fruit flavors. The oak steals the show.
Wine: Castillo de Feliciana 2015 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Clos La Chance
Review: Light aromas of dried grass, apples and a hint of nectarine show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is extremely light, with lime and grassy tones, although a bit watery.
Wine: Clos La Chance 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Central Coast)

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a single vineyard that is not specified, this is an intensely fruity floral wine, with a generous body and sizable tannin and oak. The structure is robustly built and the finish is dusty on the palate.
Wine: Gagnon Cellars 2015 Single Vineyard Petite Sirah (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: J. Wilkes
Review: Plump raspberries meet with wet soil, clay and dried herbs on the nose of this bottling. The flavors are pleasant if simple, with wood spice, more dried herbs and tart berries.
Wine: J. Wilkes 2014 Zinfandel (Paso Robles Highlands District)

Appellation: J. Wilkes
Review: Plump raspberries meet with wet soil, clay and dried herbs on the nose of this bottling. The flavors are pleasant if simple, with wood spice, more dried herbs and tart berries.
Wine: J. Wilkes 2014 Zinfandel (Paso Robles Highlands District)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Virtually a carbon copy of the 2014, this fruit-driven wine leans heavily on blackberry jam scents and flavors. If there was any exposure to new wood, it's not indicated and remains invisible.
Wine: Joyful Noise 2015 Lazy River Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Tangy on the nose, this is a thick and richly layered vineyard-designate brashly layered in blueberry, black cherry and cola. The oak is supportive and youthful.
Wine: Kenwood 2015 Santa Nella Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Redwood Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: All fruit all the time could be the motto of this deeply colored, berry-scented and jammy tasting wine. Ripe blackberry aromas and flavors make it appealing and it has just a touch of tannins to help fill out the mouthfeel.
Wine: Kokomo 2016 Cuvée Red (Redwood Valley)

Appellation: Murphy-Goode
Review: This wine is oaky first and fruity second, showing smoky spicy aromas and equally spicy, lightly charred flavors. Medium body and moderate tannins give it heft on the palate and there's just enough blackberry flavor underneath to counterbalance the oakiness.
Wine: Murphy-Goode 2014 Merlot (California)

Appellation: Picayune
Review: This wine has a persistent earthiness and tart tangy acidity that balance against each other well. A fine value for the quality, its light-bodied ripeness showcases cranberry and rhubarb as well as a touch of smoke.
Wine: Picayune 2015 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a generously full-bodied and layered wine, richly tannic and leathery in texture, with lasting flavors of vanilla cola and blackberry pie.
Wine: Rodney Strong 2014 Reserve Malbec (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Clean white peach, buttercup, sweet cream and ripe red-pear aromas show on the nose of this clonal selection. It lands on the palate with a tense texture and a dominating oak smoke flavor, with vanilla, caramelized lemons and Pink Lady apples making for a slightly sweet impression.
Wine: Scott 2016 Dijon Clone Chardonnay (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Tooth and Nail
Review: Just-crushed raspberries, chopped sage and baked earth show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is easy and a bit simple, delivering flavors of hibiscus, pomegranate and a pinch of black sage.
Wine: Tooth and Nail 2015 Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Anise, cherry, green herb, orange peel and spice aromas carry the nose. These tones carry to the full, fleshy fruit flavors on the palate.
Wine: Adamant Cellars 2014 Winemaker's Select Merlot (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Bradley
Review: Sourced from a Wadenswil block planted in 1983, this is a step up from recent vintages. Its big, chunky fruit informs old school, rustic winemaking. Deep blackberry flavors and chocolate highlights from aging in 25% new wood, come in an easy-drinking package. There's nothing flashy here—just a big glass of ripe fruit and barrel flavors.
Wine: Bradley 2015 Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Bradley
Review: The light sweetness from 12 g/L of residual sugar offsets this wine's searing acidity. Its tart and sweet components clash rather than meld, recalling sour plum, satsuma orange and Gatorade.
Wine: Bradley 2016 Riesling (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Bridlewood
Review: Rustic aromas of cherry, strawberry, baked earth, dried herbs and charred wood show on the nose of this bottling. Snappy berry flavors and more herbs arise on the palate, which is a little soft in structure.
Wine: Bridlewood 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Light blueberry and cherry flavors combine gracefully here, though in the mouth, it seems slightly dilute. There are balanced acids, a touch of toast and a finishing streak of mocha.
Wine: Cubanisimo Vineyards 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This label holds back its reserves far longer than virtually anyone else in Oregon. This bottling, produced by Eola Hills winery, was sourced from the Bella Vista vineyard in Ashland. It drinks like an aged, inexpensive Bordeaux, with earthy, dried fruit flavors of fig and berry, with a touch of citrus. The 2010, also available now, is even drier.
Wine: Eliana 2011 Reserve Red (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Gagnon Cellars
Review: A blend of 50% Petite Sirah, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon and 20% Zinfandel, aged nearly two years in French oak, this wine is round and generous in tannin, with baked, raisiny plum and packed blueberry flavors. The finish is simple and succinct.
Wine: Gagnon Cellars 2015 Red (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Girardet
Review: This current release spent 30 months in one quarter new French oak and still tastes a bit raw. With its cherry-like fruit and moderate acidity, it's a wine to drink over the next couple of years, while the fruit remains prominent.
Wine: Girardet 2012 Cabernet Sauvignon (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: San Diego County, South Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly wound aromas of lemon blossom, chalk and the slightest show of a guava tropicality arise on the nose of this atypical blend of 72% Viognier and 28% Pinot Gris. It's a tad vinous on the sip, with candied melon and wet stone flavors.
Wine: Hungry Hawk 2017 Mélange Blanc White (San Diego County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This light colored wine brings tire rubber, potpourri, raspberry and spice aromas. The palate is soft in feel—full of red fruit flavors that seem a bit hot.
Wine: Maryhill 2015 Proprietor's Reserve Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Floral, fruity aromas lead to tones of cherry and peach on the palate. The wine has generous mouthfilling bubbles, good acidity and a hint of sweetness that promotes a smooth texture.
Wine: Oro Bello 2017 Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (California)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Steely, high in acidity and persistently floral, this well-made white is deceptively robust and ripe, with a tartness to the fruit.
Wine: Quivira 2016 Wine Creek Ranch Roussanne-Viognier (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A darker shade of pink, this bottling shows aromas of raspberry extract and grapefruit rind. The palate is tangy with tangerine-rind flavor.
Wine: Saint K 2017 Around the Way Rosé (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose on this bottling from a vineyard 2,600 feet high in the mountains is a little reserved, with rust, dried cranberries and turned rocky soil. There is decent acidity on the palate, but the flavors of dried sour cherry and rose petals are reticent.
Wine: Sarah's Vineyard 2016 Muns Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Sequoia Grove
Review: Floral and confectionery on the nose, this wine has a steely sensibility that suggest light oak and high acidity, with a strong flavor profile of freshly squeezed citrus.
Wine: Sequoia Grove 2016 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Blended with 20% Merlot, this wine has an earthy funk built around brawny thick layers of blueberry and blackberry that finish soft in black pepper.
Wine: Spann Vineyards 2014 Five Barrels Malbec (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Toccata
Review: Quite clear in the glass, this bottling from the Goodchild Vineyard shows soft peach, tangerine and a slightly vinous aroma on the nose. The palate offers citrus and tangy apple skins.
Wine: Toccata 2017 Pinot Grigio (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Uptick Vineyards
Review: This medium-bodied white is dry and slightly metallic in texture, with highlights of apricot, lemongrass and dried herb.
Wine: Uptick Vineyards 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: V. Sattui
Review: Toasted vanilla and lemony pear provide a focused palate of one-dimensional flavor in this fleshy, grainy wine that's robustly ripe and rich.
Wine: V. Sattui 2016 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Still showing some CO2, this is tart to the point of sour. Its lemon and pear fruit flavors are clean and crisp, with appealing mineral tones.
Wine: Vista Hills 2017 Treehouse Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Windchaser
Review: Savory, earthy aromas set the stage for flavors that are lean, meaty and tea-like, while the texture is smooth and just lightly tannic. Interesting that the color is quite light and brownish, but that's not too unusual for a Grenache, and goes along with the maverick nature of this envelope-pushing wine.
Wine: Windchaser 2015 Grenache Noir (El Dorado County)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine has an unusually deep gold color, lots of butter and butterscotch aromas, medium body and attractive peach and pear flavors. It looks pretty mature and tastes pretty good.
Wine: Wise Villa 2015 Sur Lies Estate Chardonnay (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's fresh and dried herb, black pepper, orange peel and spice aromas lead to somewhat linear-seeming fruit flavors. It shows none of the hallmarks of either the variety or the appellation.
Wine: Adamant Cellars 2014 Artisan Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Malbec and Merlot. The aromas are quite subdued, recalling dried orange peel, dark raspberry, plum, cranberry and spice. The fruit flavors are pleasing and finish tart.
Wine: Basalt 2014 Rim Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's light aromas suggest woodspice and cherry. The palate mixes fruit and barrel flavors, showing pleasing texture and a tart finish. There's a barbeque note that seems out of place.
Wine: Basalt 2014 Winemaker's Barrel Select Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's unusual rubber tube, stem, herb, sarsaparilla, strawberry and spice aromas lead to full-feeling red fruit flavors speckled with spice. It's backed by grainy tannins and comes off as slightly green, but there's still enjoyment to be had.
Wine: Battle Creek 2016 Undconditional Pinot Noir (Oregon)

Appellation: La Honda Winery
Review: Reduced black-plum and dark berry aromas make for a somewhat simple, slightly shy nose on this bottling. There is density to the palate, with chalky tannins presenting flavors of slightly sour black plum. Still very young and tight, it may emerge with more complexity over time.
Wine: La Honda Winery 2016 Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This pale salmon-colored wine offers orange and herb aromas. The flavors are a bit heavy but finish tart.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2017 Tahija Sangiovese Candy Mountain Vineyard Rosé (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted cherries, dried herbs and a hint of prune show on the nose of this blend of Merlot, Syrah, Zinfandel and Petite Sirah. There's a raisin touch to the palate along with leather, and it's a very ripe and dried-out expression overall.
Wine: Lorenzi Estate 2013 Rated R Red (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This wine is light bodied, subtle in flavor and very dry. Flavors like fennel bulb, white cherry and white pepper accompany a soft texture and neutral finish. The 2016 vintage had more depth of flavor, and since this was just bottled it may improve with time.
Wine: Markus Wine Co 2017 Insieme Joey Torrontés (Lodi)

Appellation: Muirwood
Review: Crushed chalk, crisp honeysuckle and a gunmetal aroma show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is more rich, with full flavors of marzipan and lemon curd, very much in the classic California Chardonnay vein.
Wine: Muirwood 2016 Chardonnay (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Though cellared and bottled by a company in Santa Rosa, California, the actual winemaking for this label is performed in Oregon. It's as forward and appealing as cherry cobbler, with sweet fruit that lingers a bit before quickly fading away. Don't look for depth, just an easy-drinking, lighthearted red fit for a summer picnic.
Wine: Oregon Trails 2016 OTWC Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: River Road
Review: This is a reasonably ripe and well-balanced wine that smells like red and black cherries, and adds accents of black tea on the palate. A smooth texture and mild tannins complete the attractive picture.
Wine: River Road 2016 Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine smells quite fruity and buttery, and tastes lush and ripe. It has plenty of vanilla, butterscotch, ripe pear and cream notes along with a texture so broad that it's almost sweet on the tongue.
Wine: Shannon Ridge 2016 High Elevation Collection Chardonnay (Lake County)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Blended with 25% Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a thick dense expression of two tannic grapes, offering undefined red-berry flavor around sizable oak. Secondary characteristics are marked by dried herb and leather.
Wine: Spann Vineyards 2014 5 Barrels Petit Verdot (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Napa-Mendocino-Sonoma, North Coast, California, US
Review: This is a relatively light wine that has ripe strawberry aromas and fresh grapey flavors on a smooth texture and medium body. It's not too complicated or complex but simply delivers appealing fruit character.
Wine: The Federalist 2015 Honest Red (Napa-Mendocino-Sonoma)

Appellation: Viviani
Review: Peach and ripe apples make for a very broad, slightly vinous nose on this bottling by a successful restaurant group in Chicago. Ripe Pink Lady apple and orange blossom flavors are framed by a decent acidity on the palate.
Wine: Viviani 2016 Chardonnay (Central Coast)

Appellation: Castle Rock
Review: A good dose of ripe black cherry and sweet spices make this medium-bodied wine easy to enjoy. The texture is smooth—almost soft—and nicely mouthfilling.
Wine: Castle Rock 2016 Pinot Noir (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Cathedral Ridge
Review: This rustic 50-50 blend has leathery aromas that mute the fruit yet on the palate, the sweet, ripe blackberry flavors come through.
Wine: Cathedral Ridge 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon-Merlot (Columbia Valley (OR))

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Girardet's Bush Vine series explores the winery's recent plantings of Spanish and Italian varieties. It's difficult to coax definitive varietal character from young vine Barbera; this one is not quite there yet but offers straightforward, pleasant fruit, strawberry and cherry flavors and moderate acidity.
Wine: Girardet 2015 Bush Vine Barbera (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: At almost five years old, this shows mature flavors that suggest it should be consumed shortly. The fruit is soft and rounded, and the barrel influence pushes strong vanilla bean notes forward. Tasting a bit like a slice of apple pie, it gives the impression it has rounded the hilltop and is beginning to fade.
Wine: Holloran 2013 Le Pavillon Vineyard Chardonnay (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: J. Wilkes
Review: The aromas on this bottling are quite shy, with hints of cedar, dark cherry and loamy soils. There is a dominant cherry-flavored pipe-tobacco taste on the palate, with light acid and tannins.
Wine: J. Wilkes 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles Highlands District)

Appellation: Kason
Review: This wine's flavor stays close to the Chardonnay standard of apple flesh and skin, with a hint of vanilla wafer. It is light and drinking nicely but lacks complexity. Enjoy now–2020.
Wine: Kason 2015 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's aroma seems shut down even after aggressive aeration. On the palate, it delivers direct but rather generic red wine flavors, with herbal notes and stiff tannins. It finishes with a hint of alcoholic heat.
Wine: Holloran 2014 La Chenaie Tempranillo (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Hungry Hawk
Review: Light aromas of Gala apple rinds and a hint of lime blossom make for a subtle and easy entry to this bottling. The palate shows green apple peels, lime skins, wet river stone and a hint of sweetgrass.
Wine: Hungry Hawk 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (San Diego County)

Appellation: Jason-Stephens
Review: Leather and cedar aromas wrap around blackberry, licorice, spice cake and turned earth on the nose of this bottling. Those earthy flavors show on the palate as well, alongside tangy black plum and decent tannins.
Wine: Jason-Stephens 2014 Meritage (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Muted in floral aromatics, this simple, approachable and rounded wine is thick in tropical flavor and baked apple, with a wild tease of fennel within its medium-bodied concentration.
Wine: B.R. Cohn 2016 Silver Label Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's appealing fresh plum, cherry, pencil lead, wood spice and dried herb aromas are followed by generous fruit and barrel flavors that bring a lightly grainy feel. It's an intriguing example of this variety.
Wine: Castillo de Feliciana 2015 Estate Tempranillo (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blended with small amounts of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Petit Verdot, this offers high-toned spice, raspberry, matchstick, cherry and dried herb aromas. Its light, elegant fruit flavors make it a pretty expression of the variety.
Wine: Cloudlift Cellars 2015 Ascent Cabernet Franc (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's aroma seems shut down even after aggressive aeration. On the palate, it delivers direct but rather generic red wine flavors, with herbal notes and stiff tannins. It finishes with a hint of alcoholic heat.
Wine: Holloran 2014 La Chenaie Tempranillo (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Hungry Hawk
Review: Light aromas of Gala apple rinds and a hint of lime blossom make for a subtle and easy entry to this bottling. The palate shows green apple peels, lime skins, wet river stone and a hint of sweetgrass.
Wine: Hungry Hawk 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (San Diego County)

Appellation: Jason-Stephens
Review: Leather and cedar aromas wrap around blackberry, licorice, spice cake and turned earth on the nose of this bottling. Those earthy flavors show on the palate as well, alongside tangy black plum and decent tannins.
Wine: Jason-Stephens 2014 Meritage (Santa Clara Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles Geneseo District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The nose is a bit weak on this blend of 31% Sangiovese, 24% Barbera, 24% Petit Verdot and 21% Cabernet Sauvignon, showing subtle hints of candied red fruit and cinnamon. Red fruit and herbs show on the sip, which is clean but also quite subtle.
Wine: Niner 2015 Super Paso Reserve Red (Paso Robles Geneseo District)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an austere wine with a waxy element to its texture, highlighted in fennel and grass. Fresh and high in acidity, it's flinty on the finish.
Wine: People's Wine Revolution 2015 Salem Ranch Viognier (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Blended with nearly 19% Petite Sirah, this is a thick and dense wine, fruity and meaty in equal measure, with a jammy richness to its full grasp of blackberry character.
Wine: Ravenswood 2015 Barricia Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's a strong herbal expression throughout this wine, starting on the nose with oregano and peppercorns that mesh with dried plum fruit. The palate shows tart and dark fruit, with more herbs and even a hint of bell pepper, leveled a bit by smoke.
Wine: Sculpterra 2015 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A bit lighter in the glass, this blend of 65% Grenache and 35% Mourvèdre rides a candied rose-petal aroma as well as a slightly sour tang on the nose. There's also a mix of candied and tangy cherry on the palate, alongside hints of fruit punch, leather and dewy herbs.
Wine: Seven Oxen 2015 Cassidy Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made from purchased grapes, this is the most leathery of the winery's 2015 Pinot Noirs. Those muted aromas lead to a tart and tannic wine marked by bitter earthiness. It's a more traditional, herbal style of Oregon winemaking, and the leather aromas will appeal to some but not to others.
Wine: Sokol Blosser 2015 Thistle Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: The Smuggler's Son
Review: This full-bodied wine is based on Zinfandel and tastes ripe and smooth, fills the mouth with blackberry and cherry flavors and has enough richness to fill out its lightly tannic frame.
Wine: The Smuggler's Son 2015 Red (California)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Like a liquid fruit salad, this medium-bodied wine spills over with pear, apple, peach and pineapple flavors on a rather soft texture. There is no obvious oak component, however a light vanilla accent adds interest.
Wine: Tortoise Creek 2016 Jam's Blend Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Clarksburg, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This wine is very flavorful and unapologetically oaky, from the smoky aromas to the almost-sweet maple and brown-sugar flavors that blend with a jammy fruit character. It is quite deep in color, saturated in flavor but not overly full bodied.
Wine: Tortoise Creek 2016 The Revivalist Merlot (Clarksburg)

Appellation: Upper Five
Review: This softly fruity wine delivers a mix of red berry and light spice flavors. Hints of tobacco, cola and citrus peel come through, though the acids leave a chalky aftertaste.
Wine: Upper Five 2015 Syrah (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Van Duzer
Review: Quite tannic from the start, this has stem flavors interwoven with light, wild berry fruit. What it lacks in charm, it makes up for with muscle. Aerate aggressively and pair with a rich beef stew.
Wine: Van Duzer 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Principally Sangiovese, this red blend includes 17% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Syrah. It spent 28 months in 20% new French oak, contributing strong tobacco and vanilla aromas. There's a lightly leafy note, with moderately flavorful strawberry and cherry fruit. Drink now–2020.
Wine: Viento 2014 Vento Red (Columbia Gorge (OR))

Appellation: Black Stallion
Review: Lightly colored and textured, this wine nonetheless offers plenty of concentrated power and depth of flavor. It makes a strong statement of baked cherry, earthy mint and toasted oak that lingers in cola spice.
Wine: Black Stallion 2016 Pinot Noir (Los Carneros)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A significant increase in production has not done this wine any favors, since this vintage shows both bottle variation and thin fruit. The second bottle tasted showed best, with cranberry fruit, lemon notes and grainy tannins.
Wine: Bryn Mawr Vineyards 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Liberty Lake
Review: Aged for 30 months in Russian oak, this has reserved aromas suggesting dried and fresh herbs, woodspice, cherries and flowers. The palate is big and brawny, with firm tannins and a green note that persists throughout. It should do well at the dinner table.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2013 Petit Verdot (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Luna
Review: This is a lemony oaky white, rich in baked apple and tropical notes. Full bodied and concentrated in powerful ripeness, it finishes clean and big.
Wine: Luna 2016 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 40% Cabernet Franc, topped off with 10% Petit Verdot and 5% Merlot. Aged in a mixture of American and French oak, it delivers green aromas, suggesting savory herbs, cherry, vanilla, coconut, dill and spice. The sweet barrel flavors tussle a bit with the fruit on the palate, not seeming entirely harmonious at present.
Wine: Dumas Station 2015 Cow Catcher Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Mourvèdre makes up 63% of this wine, with the rest 32% Syrah and 5% Grenache. It's quite reduced out of the gate yet shows a ripe mixture of blackberry, raspberry, black pepper and spice flavors.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2015 Wallywood Stone Tree Vineyard Red (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Almost as clear as water in the glass, this is a very fresh and clean bottling, yet extremely tropical in style. Aromas of guava, ripe papaya and plumeria extract lead into a palate that tightens up at first before unleashing the coconut oil, guava juice and white-flower flavors. Very crisp, yet it is flowery and ripe.
Wine: Folktale 2017 Le Mistral Single Vineyard Grenache Blanc (Monterey County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's forward black cherry candy flavors lead to some less appealing stiff tannins. There's a chalky mouthfeel as it finishes. It's a fair value for the price, and more bottle age may soften it a bit.
Wine: High Pass 2016 High Pass Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This follow-up to the winery's excellent 2016 rosé puts more emphasis on bitter herbal flavors as a counterpoint to sweet red fruit. There's detectable residual sugar, and the balance between bitter and sweet components is a little jarring, at least for the moment. Further bottle age may help pull things together.
Wine: High Pass 2017 Pinot Noir Rosé (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Leather and pine needle scents compete with blackberry fruit in this wine. The mouthfeel is soft and rounded, and the fruit is annotated with dried rosemary highlights. That leathery note continues through the finish.
Wine: Kason 2015 Old Vine Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Keeler
Review: This opens with strawberry and cherry candy scents and flavors. It's front-loaded and fruity, the flavors fresh but fading quickly. Though it spent 14 months in 40% new French oak, the barrel influence is muted.
Wine: Keeler 2015 Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Merryvale
Review: Minty bay leaf and rose petal greet the nose in this ripe, robust and jammy wine that's moderate in acidity and structure with a wealth of baked cherry and strawberry on offer.
Wine: Merryvale 2014 Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Blended with 25% Malbec, this wine leads with dominant barrel notes, its vanilla, incense, anise, wood and baking spice aromas accenting fruit leather scents. The palate is lighter styled, with dried-out fruit flavors. A meat- and medicine cabinet-laced finish caps it off.
Wine: Obelisco Estate 2014 Les Gosses Vineyard Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Nearly red in color, this wine is robust on the nose in earthy brambly berry that becomes pie-like in richness and girth. The generosity of fruit is laced in lemon zest.
Wine: Pedroncelli 2017 Signature Selection Dry Rosé of Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This includes 25% mixed blacks, all old-vine—a study in compost earthiness and baked blueberry. Full bodied and quite ripe, it has a smokiness to the oak that contrasts against the fruit and dust.
Wine: Ravenswood 2015 Belloni Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Schug
Review: A dense juicy core of tannin and oak rides beneath dark cherry, cassis and cinnamon in this relatively light-bodied wine, softened by the addition of 8% Cabernet Franc, 7% Malbec, 6% Merlot and 3% Petit Verdot.
Wine: Schug 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Nearly equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec make up the core of this blend, along with 23% Syrah and 10% Petit Verdot. Simple in structure and approach, it's approachable rich and round, with a sweet tannin profile and dark cherry flavors.
Wine: Spann Vineyards 2014 MoJo Red (Sonoma County)

Appellation: The Withers Winery
Review: This wine is lean in structure and flavor, starting with a light-garnet color, then followed by aromas like tea and mahogany and flavors like tart cherry. It has a snappy tangy quality due to good acidity and moderate tannins, so it's a good palate cleanser.
Wine: The Withers Winery 2016 Gamay Noir (El Dorado)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Briny and oaky, this wine offers a sweetness of vanilla, peach and pineapple, with a bite of apple pie at its end.
Wine: Benziger 2016 West Rows Sangiacomo Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Charles B. Mitchell
Review: Peppery, beefy aromas and rich deep berry flavors highlight this full-bodied and firm-textured wine. It is bold and mouthfilling, with a touch of ripeness on the finish.
Wine: Charles B. Mitchell 2014 Tempranillo (Amador County)

Appellation: Del Rio
Review: A step up in quality from the previous vintage, this delivers sweet berry and milk chocolate flavors from first whiff. It's appealing but stops short on the midpalate, finishing with hints of Graham cracker and mocha.
Wine: Del Rio 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Del Rio
Review: There's little ripe fruit here, as the wine is dominated by tea leaf, earth, granite and pepper flavors. That said, it's a style that wouldn't be out of place among inexpensive Burgundies, best enjoyed with a hearty stew.
Wine: Del Rio 2015 Pinot Noir (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Fleur
Review: This well-balanced wine is medium to full bodied, has modest fruit and spice aromas and a clean, straightforward fruit flavor.
Wine: Fleur 2016 Chardonnay (North Coast)

Appellation: Fleur
Review: This well-balanced wine is medium to full bodied, has modest fruit and spice aromas and a clean, straightforward fruit flavor.
Wine: Fleur 2016 Chardonnay (North Coast)

Appellation: La Crema
Review: This wine presents as oaky upfront before making room for layered flavors of melon, baked apple and peach, the grapes sourced from a multitude of locations within the appellation. Round and approachable, it offers great value.
Wine: La Crema 2016 Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine has a smoky aroma, good blackberry and black-plum flavors and a smooth non-tannic mouthfeel. It's showing a lot of heavily-toasted oak that comes off as char and black pepper.
Wine: Replica 2015 Just Right Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine has an earthy, lightly herbal aroma, with plum and red cherry flavors as well as a little textural grip. The slightly rustic, earthy notes add character.
Wine: Castle Rock 2016 California Cuvée Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Fleur
Review: Roses, lavender and dried herb wrap around the nose of this wine, a light-bodied expression that's enjoyable and approachable. The structure is moderate, as is the acidity, with a straightforward approach to the texture.
Wine: Fleur 2015 Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This wine has an aroma just like blackberry jam followed by opulent jammy mapley flavors and a sense of sweetness that lingers on the finish. It's full bodied and very lush in texture.
Wine: Gnarly Head 2016 1924 Double Black Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Imagery
Review: Very fruity and mostly soft on the palate, this medium-bodied wine is an easy sipper for casual occasions. It has well-concentrated blackberry and raspberry flavors and a lightly tannic mouthfeel.
Wine: Imagery 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Jack's House
Review: This is a straightforward, well-balanced and medium-bodied wine that will please a lot of people and offend no one. It has fresh juicy berry flavors, and mild tannins and acidity that add just enough texture.
Wine: Jack's House 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Liberty Lake
Review: This varietal wine was aged for 32 months in new American oak. Its vanilla, coconut and cherry aromas lead to a mixture of fruit and sweet barrel flavors, and the latter win out on the finish. The tannins are strong and cinching, and the oak seems too far out front.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: It's difficult to imagine a darker inkier color than this full-bodied wine has. The aromas and flavors are not as deep and concentrated as the color suggests. Mild blackberry and blueberry flavors dominate and the texture is moderately tannic.
Wine: Mount Peak 2015 Gravity Red (California)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Though prinicipally Pinot Noir and Gamay, this simple, quaffing blend includes 5% Chardonnay and a splash of Pinot Gris. It's light and fruity, with citrus and strawberry notes and a hint of cherry candy, making it a go-to pour when something heavier suits neither your mood nor your food.
Wine: Patton Valley 2017 PTG Red (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Robert Mondavi
Review: This is a burly ripe red, with small amounts of Merlot, Petit Verdot and Cabernet Franc blended within. Dried herb meets substantial concentrations of baked plum and possessive tannin.
Wine: Robert Mondavi 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Orange blossom, key lime syrup and a botanical quinine kick show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is sweet but not treacly, with sweet apple and a touch of citrus rind. It lacks a textural complexity and acidity.
Wine: Wilson Creek 2017 Cassidy Vineyard Muscat (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This has a carbonic, stemmy energy to its overall earthiness. It also offers an exploration of forest floor, spicy dried herb and baked raspberry.
Wine: Blagden 2013 Sangiacomo Roberts Road Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Mad Housewife
Review: This wine is buttery in aroma and flavor and has a generous mouthfilling texture. Being medium bodied and rather low in acidity helps the feeling of richness but keeps the balance a touch too soft.
Wine: Mad Housewife 2015 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Matchbook
Review: Stiffly structured, this wine holds tight to its blackberry and black-cherry flavors with very firm tannins that leave a drying sensation. It has a good core of ripe black cherry and black pepper but will need to pair with a fat juicy piece of meat to tame its astringency.
Wine: Matchbook 2014 Tempranillo (Dunnigan Hills)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a full-bore, heavily oaked, big and tannic wine from the charred cedar aroma to the cinnamon and black-cherry flavors that are held tightly by strong dry tannins. It will need an especially indulgent fatty dish to pair with.
Wine: Nottingham Cellars 2016 Ralphi's Red (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Somehow this reserve, which presumably received extra care and attention in the winery, falls short. It's quickly drying out, the fruit close to disappearing. Drink up.
Wine: Redhawk 2016 Vintner's Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sol Rouge
Review: Very ripe and roasted in character, this full-bodied wine smells smoky, tastes meaty and brings some heat to the midpalate and finish. It is big and a bit rough around the edges.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2014 Grenache (Red Hills)

Appellation: True Myth
Review: Caramelized aromas of oak, vanilla and concentrated cherry show on the nose of this bottling with butterflies on the label. The palate is a bit sweeter and simpler than in vintages past, with oak, caramel, vanilla dust and red-cherry flavors.
Wine: True Myth 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's mushroom, mint, cranberry and spice aromas seem a bit muddled, and the flavors suggest more of the same. It finishes tart.
Wine: van Loben Sels 2016 Conner Lee Vineyard Pinot Noir (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: St. Helena, Napa, California, US
Review: Musty, earthy and taut on the palate, this white is intensely verbose in lemon peel and melon, with a steely character that makes it seem lean.
Wine: Gibbs 2017 Centa Vineyard Estate Sauvignon Blanc (St. Helena)

Appellation: I Mille
Review: Dark and inky in color, this 100% varietal wine is thick, dense and simple in approach, with mountain-size tannins. Leather saddle, earth and blackberry dipped in chocolate make up the flavor profile.
Wine: I Mille 2014 Petite Sirah (Rockpile)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from Conner Lee (42%), Dionysus (33%), Bacchus (21%) and Stillwater Creek vineyards. Its medicine cabinet, dried cherry, pencil lead and woodspice aromas lead to fruit leather flavors. It seems dried out.
Wine: Arbor Crest 2015 Four Vineyards Merlot (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's green herb, black cherry, cedar box and woodspice aromas lead to dry fruit flavors with a tart, medicinal finish. It seems slightly dried out.
Wine: Arbor Crest 2016 Five Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Leese-Fitch
Review: This is a good middle-of-the-road wine with sufficient fruit flavors and fairly crisp acidity that will make it quite food-friendly. It's light to medium in body, and has light lemon and herb flavors.
Wine: Leese-Fitch 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (California)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is half Syrah and half Cabernet Sauvignon, aged 30 months in new American and Slovakian oak. It delivers copper penny, wet herb and baking spice aromas, seeming unready to reveal its charms. The palate shows a mixture of fruit and barrel notes that continue through the finish.
Wine: Liberty Lake 2013 Heritage Reserve Red (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This pale-colored blend of 57% Cinsault and 43% Counoise offers light aromas of raspberry, plum and spice. The flavors are elegant but finish tart.
Wine: Maryhill 2014 Indira Elephant Mountain Vineyards Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Fresh and light, this is a delicate wine, light pink in color, showing subtle raspberry aromas, subdued cherry flavors and good acidity that keeps it lively on the palate.
Wine: McKahn 2017 Rosé of Grenache (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a gritty, grippy wine, tannic and showing a touch of herbal underbelly, with a strong sense of sweet compost and mushroomy earth.
Wine: Medlock Ames 2015 Secret Ingredient Malbec (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Monterey, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe pear and wet river rocks show on the clean nose of this bottling, which invites with the fruit and then intrigues with the minerality. It's a bit ripe on the palate, with poached pear flavors.
Wine: Noble Vines 2017 242 Sauvignon Blanc (Monterey)

Appellation: Ruby Cellars
Review: Aromas of underripe elderberry, black currant, sweet smoke and chocolate cake make for an intriguing (if unfamiliar) nose on this bottling from a new producer in Atascadero. Ripe flavors of prune ice cream, figs and raisins show on the sip, which shows decent acid and texture.
Wine: Ruby Cellars 2014 Merlot (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve lacks the depth and ripeness needed to carry its dark, toasty barrel flavors. The wood dominates, and as a result, the fruit flavors thin out quickly.
Wine: Territorial 2015 T Reserve Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: A heavy use of oak pervades this full-bodied wine from the aroma through the finish. It starts with an aroma of freshly cut boards, moves to tight astringent oak and cherry flavors on the palate, and finishes with a lingering ginger and nutmeg spice effect.
Wine: The Endless Summer 2015 Montefort Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cabernet Sauvignon makes up three-quarters of this wine, with the balance Merlot and Cabernet Franc. Its mocha, green herb, blackberry, medicine cabinet and anise aromas lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors that have a lightly creamy feel. It seems evolved for its age.
Wine: van Loben Sels 2015 Bona Dea Stillwater Creek Vineyard Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Bennett Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dark in color and showing sediment, this white is austere on the nose—a combination of steely and floral, with subtle flavors of green apple and potato.
Wine: Domenica Amato 2016 Vivio Vineyard Roussanne (Bennett Valley)

Appellation: Mad Housewife
Review: Vivid cherry and strawberry flavors give a cheery personality to this generous wine. It smells bright and fruity, and tastes more ripe, showing light spicy accents and a good focus on fruit.
Wine: Mad Housewife 2016 Merlot (California)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine is surprisingly soft with a very smooth texture carrying ripe black-plum and milk-chocolate flavors. The acidity and tannins are way in the background and the seemingly sweet flavors take center stage.
Wine: Naggiar 2016 Root 49 Estate The Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Urban Legend
Review: This wine has an earthy, walnutty aroma, sparse fruit flavors improved by a white-pepper and mineral streak, and a very crisp, dry mouthfeel.
Wine: Urban Legend 2016 Vermentino (Lodi)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Honeydew and rainwater make for a nicely restrained nose on this bottling. It's a bit soft and broad on the sip, with mango, guava and more tropical flavors. The texture is a little flat.
Wine: Wilson Creek 2016 Harmony Vineyard Roussanne (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's game, baking spice and Band Aid aromas are followed by cherry and medicine cabinet flavors. It doesn't all come together.
Wine: Arbor Crest 2015 Conner Lee Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Plungerhead
Review: This medium-bodied wine is pleasant and fruity, showing ripe apple and peach flavors over soft acidity.
Wine: Plungerhead 2016 Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This older vintage white has a salty briny nose and a disjointed sensibility of tart lemon on the palate, becoming somewhat heavy on the palate amidst its ultimate leanness.
Wine: Blagden 2012 Sangiacomo Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Softly sweet and very fruity, this light-pink wine is simple and clean. It should appeal especially to new wine drinkers.
Wine: Naggiar 2017 Estate Rosé (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Take Me With You
Review: Very fruity, lightly sweet and quite mouth coating, this rich wine has jammy aromas and flavors centering around blackberries.
Wine: Take Me With You 2016 Red (California)

Appellation: Windchaser
Review: This is a straightforward medium-bodied red wine that has decent balance, moderate tannins and mostly herbaceous, peppery flavors.
Wine: Windchaser 2016 Red (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Woodbridge by Robert Mondavi
Review: Spice and herb flavors dominate this light-bodied, crisp and dry wine. White-pepper, fennel bulb and lemon flavors make an interesting mix and the mouthfeel is respectably tangy.
Wine: Woodbridge by Robert Mondavi 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (California)

Appellation: Mabera
Review: This light-bodied wine strives for concentration and ripeness, but retains the typical bright acidity of Barbera. It smells like black cherries, tastes like not-quite-ripe blackberries and has a tangy, moderately tannic texture.
Wine: Mabera 2015 Barbera (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This wine has a flinty, earthy aroma, ripe fruit flavors and low tannins. It's smooth on the palate and has a hint of good acidity to keep it lively.
Wine: Nine North Wine Company 2016 Chasing Lions Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: A lavender color and cherry-like aromas lead to very dry flavors of not-quite-ripe plums and a sensation of mild tannins in this light-bodied wine.
Wine: Oro Bello 2017 Rose Gold Rosé (California)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine has a slightly cloudy appearance and an auburn edge, a sharp mouthfeel and hints of raspberry vinegar along with cherries, black pepper and smoke. Try it for a complete change of pace.
Wine: Donkey & Goat 2016 The Bear Red (El Dorado)

Appellation: Eliana
Review: Sourced from the Thistlecroft vineyard, this was produced and bottled by Eola Hills winery. It's an oaky, blocky wine, with potent vanilla syrup scents and flavors that marginalize the fruit and disguise any varietal typicity.
Wine: Eliana 2015 Tempranillo (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
