Review: A very dense, almost-black color and concentrated blueberry and chocolate aromas make this wine an attention-getter. It has a touch of sweetness to soften moderate tannins, and offers plenty of grapey jammy fruit flavors.
Wine: Gnarly Head 2016 Authentic Black Red (Lodi)

Appellation: Prototype
Review: Strong flavors of black tea and Bing cherries give a big personality to this medium-bodied wine. It tastes extremely fruity, like cherries and blackberries, has light tannins and a rather soft mouthfeel.
Wine: Prototype 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This wine leads with a profusion of sweet oaky spices in the aroma followed by even more oaky smoky syrupy flavors and a lightly sweet balance. It is full bodied and has lots of flavor impact.
Wine: Replica 2016 Pickpocket Red (California)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Aged in concrete and hailing from three different vineyards, this is an extremely ripe and unctuous bottling, starting with aromas of banana Jolly Rancher with a hint of grapefruit juice. The palate is extremely tropical, blending papaya, guava and banana flavors as well as a dominating coconut-oil element.
Wine: Pulchella 2017 Drifter Viognier (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Rich & Spicy
Review: Very fruity, even jammy in aroma and flavor, this medium-bodied wine is easy to sip. It's low in tannins and acidity, making a very soft texture.
Wine: Rich & Spicy 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Juicy fruits of red currant and boysenberry meet with tar and musty herbs on the nose of this bottling. The palate is very pyrazine-laden, showing lots of dill and bell-pepper flavors against the red fruits.
Wine: Roblar 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Simple Machine
Review: This is the current release, though well past its vintage. It seems flat on first sip but recoups itself with a lingering finish that reflects well-aged Viognier. Drink up.
Wine: Simple Machine 2013 Viognier (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This low-alcohol wine is pink with a hint of peach color and has mostly ripe and slightly sweet fruit flavors like peaches and pears. The texture is smooth and rather thick for a rosé.
Wine: Mad Housewife 2016 Sweet Pink Rosé (California)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This blend of Grenache and Syrah tastes like raspberry purée, with a broad streak of vanilla. The tannins are drying out, and the whole wine is over the top, like a hyper-realistic painting.
Wine: Simple Machine 2014 The Vector Grenache-Syrah (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This is a commercial-style red blend that smells chocolaty and tastes almost like maple syrup. It has noticeable sweetness and a soft mouth-coating texture.
Wine: Apothic 2016 Crush Smooth Red (California)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine has straightforward herb and apple aromas joined by an earthy streak in the flavor. It's rather light in terms of concentration.
Wine: Murphy-Goode 2016 The Fumé Sauvignon Blanc (North Coast)

Appellation: Highland Valley
Review: Sweet in plum, vanilla and brown sugar, this wine is raisiny, soft and somewhat unstructured.
Wine: Highland Valley 2015 Petite Syrah (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: A chocolaty sweetness pervades this medium-bodied, smooth-textured and oaky wine. It adds grape jam to the chocolate flavors and has a soft mouthfeel.
Wine: Apothic 2016 Winemaker's Red (California)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied pop-style wine has jammy aromas and very ripe, lightly sweet fruit flavors that leave a candied taste on the tongue.
Wine: Melodramatic 2016 Darkness Red (California)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a very tight and tannic wine for a varietal that's often considered the lighter relative of Cabernet Sauvignon. It is bone dry, has red and black-cherry flavors, full body and dramatic palate-gripping tannins that leave an astringent aftertaste.
Wine: Nottingham Cellars 2014 Casa De Vinas Micro-Lot Reserve Cabernet Franc (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This is a decent-quality wine with medium body, rather earthy cherry flavors and a reasonably smooth texture.
Wine: Wise Villa 2016 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Willow Creek, North Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling smells a bit more like Chardonnay than Sauvignon Blanc, with lemon rinds and a hint of butter, but a lime and dried apple touch that is varietally familiar. Poached apples show on the palate.
Wine: Heath Vineyards 2014 Captivating Sauvignon Blanc (Willow Creek)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: Dramatic with oakiness, this full-bodied and tannic wine smells smoky and tastes heavy with black-pepper, maple and toasted-bread flavors that dominate the fruit flavors.
Wine: Steele 2014 Stymie Founder's Reserve Limited Production Syrah (Lake County)

Appellation: Mirassou
Review: This wine has an unusually deep color, assertive aromas like wood smoke and cloves and very concentrated, spicy, charred flavors that don't seem to come from the grapes but probably from oak products used during aging.
Wine: Mirassou 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Simple Life
Review: Very ripe fruit flavors and a hint of sweetness give this medium-bodied wine a resemblance to pear nectar. The texture is soft and mouth-coating and the acidity is low.
Wine: Simple Life 2016 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Vanilla, baking spice, game, dried cherry, Band Aid and medicine cabinet aromas are at the fore in this wine. Light fruit and medicinal flavors follow. It doesn't come together.
Wine: Arbor Crest 2015 Farrington Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Mirassou
Review: This medium-bodied wine smells and tastes overtly oaky, as notes of maple syrup, brown sugar and cinnamon blanket the mild fruit flavors underneath.
Wine: Mirassou 2016 Merlot (California)

Appellation: Melodramatic
Review: Very mapley and sweet in flavor, this wine is medium bodied and packed with ripe jammy fruit flavors and heavy accents of brown sugar.
Wine: Melodramatic 2016 Red (California)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This wine has earthy sunbaked aromas and rather lean flavors of fennel and black pepper. It's medium bodied, dry and moderately tannic.
Wine: Campos Family Vineyards 2015 Estate Cabernet Franc (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's aroma can only be described as sweaty, with unappealing dankness. Its cranberry-like fruit is thin, peppered with dried-out tannins.
Wine: Cathedral Ridge 2014 Moody Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (OR))

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: An extreme aroma of rose and hibiscus blossoms leads to sweet, strongly floral flavors and a grape-jelly note on the finish. It's not for anyone expecting a traditional dry wine taste.
Wine: Mad Housewife 2016 Sweet Red (California)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This aggressive and tart wine pushes the limits. It has raspberry and raspberry-vinegar aromas, vivid acidity on the palate and sharp cherry flavors.
Wine: Donkey & Goat 2014 Fenaughty Vineyard Syrah (El Dorado)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This wine is barely reviewable, with totally dried out, leathery flavors.
Wine: Cathedral Ridge 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (OR))

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is bewilderingly savory in tones of clove and sage, but then turns juicy and balanced from flavors of strawberry and blackberry. Grainy in complex texture and tannin, it offers a powerful full-bodied richness and wild quality that's undeniably memorable.
Wine: Three Sticks 2015 Walala Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is grown in old coastal soils and sand, driven greatly by the ground underneath it and its surrounding Laguna Ridge environment. It has density and energy in equal measure, a balance of weighty apple and pear mixed in toasted oak and freshness.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Vine Hill Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a separate block near Durell Vineyard, this wine is completely overtaken by heady floral and mineral notions of beauty and intrigue. High toned and surprisingly delicate, it's buoyant and fresh in crisp green apple and fleshy citrus flavors, with medium-bodied weight and lovely texture.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Stone Flat Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a ridge-top, western-facing site greatly influenced by the Pacific Ocean, this is exotic and distinct in character, with tones of white pepper, tart cherry, rhubarb and strawberry. Gorgeously layered, delicate and structured, it has length and richness to the tannin profile, as well as a notion of peat that adds to the dramatic complexity of the wine.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Seascape Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is such a beautiful wine, incorporating blocks from the nearby Allen Vineyard, also farmed by the Rochiolis. Reduced nicely on the nose, it's lemony with a great core of juicy acidity around grainy, gravelly texture and minerality. With an exotic edge, it finishes elegantly in lemon peel and orange blossom.
Wine: Ramey 2015 Rochioli Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A tightly textured white, this is earthy and spicy in Gravenstein apple, blood orange and hazelnut—the nuttiness taking on a toasted quality that adds warmth and flavor. Bright, refreshing and well-rounded, it has concentrated richness that finds its balance in juicy acidity.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This sources from blocks planted in 1991 and 1997, older selections that show grace and power in the wine. Exotic in lemongrass, ginger and Asian pear, the vineyard-designate doesn't hold back on supportive Meyer lemon-crisp acidity, enough to balance out the richer concentrated fruit aspects and classic oak. This is delicious.
Wine: Ramey 2015 Hyde Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Savory in aromas of black licorice, sage and rose, this is a tremendously impressive, deliciously crafted wine that is delicately layered in cranberry and rhubarb flavors. The complex texture is grainy yet polished, with a succulence that makes it irresistible from start to finish.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2015 Rochioli-Allen Vineyards Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a block growing at high elevation on the extremes of the coast north of Fort Ross, this wine is bright up-front with youthful tannins, its center juicy and densely packed in mocha, coffee and cocoa powder. Soft and structured, the dark cherry and blueberry fruit is dusted in dried herb and lavender.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Far Coast Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine is extremely deep, complex and concentrated in flavor while maintaining wonderful finesse in texture. It starts with fragrant aromas of freshly baked bread and cinnamon. Those are followed by a creamy mouthfeel, pinpoint bubbles and subtle peach, white cherry and apricot flavors that are both delicate and focused at the same time, leading to a long finish. It is so tempting now but best after 2020.
Wine: Roederer Estate 2009 L'Ermitage Brut Sparkling (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From Bien Nacido Vineyard's Z and X blocks, with 3% Viognier, this is a lovely and rich Syrah with lavish aromas of black currant, caramel, teriyaki and German chocolate cake. The palate is similarly thick and chewy, but with elegance and balance, showing black cherry, blueberry, white pepper and crushed rocks, leveled by a steadily rising acidity.
Wine: Clos Solène 2015 Cuvée Jean Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a site awash in Goldridge soils, the vines still on AXR rootstock, this white offers a wealth of high-toned aromatics, a rich robust nose that's unexpectedly bright, focused and fresh. The body takes on more richness and density, with highlights of caramel, brioche, fennel and salty pear.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Trenton Roadhouse Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Reduced on the nose in welcoming, complex ways, this white is intensely spiced and earthy, evolving into a light balanced take on caramel apple, pear and shavings of lemon zest. From a cool windy site in the Sebastopol Hills section of the larger appellation, the lemon takes on a candied note that boosts the acidity to fresh high-toned heights.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Jennifer's Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A clonal exception to the majority of this producer's white wines, the grapes for this wine are grown at 1,800-feet elevation from Mt. Eden and old Wente clones, technically within the new Moon Mountain appellation. It starts rich and robust in juicy salty concentration before allowing in a streak of bright floral acidity that gives it freshness and life. White flower and salty stone persist on the palate.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Kistler Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is comprised of fruit from two coastal sites, but it does not hold back on flavor or complexity. A juicy entry of spicy red and blue fruit is surrounded by moderate structure and an imprint of rose petal. Lasting in intensity and acidity, it's dotted in citrus and polished tannins.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Land's Edge Vineyards Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a wine of great concentration and density that's also savory and earthy. Hearty, heady violet-floral aromatics make for a grand entry into explosively succulent wild strawberry flavor and supple texture. The tannins are robust and rounded and there's a delicate layering of white and black pepper that dominates on the finish. Enjoy best 2020–2030.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Laguna Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Compost earthiness underlies a juicy, expansive and richly layered palate of fruit and spice that lingers expertly on the finish. Polished tannins support crisp strawberry and red cherry flavors that are adorned with cardamom and orange zest.
Wine: Three Sticks 2015 Gap's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a Martinelli family-farmed site, a mark of excellence and history that's hard to beat. Floral and textured, it is marked by bright focused acidity around a core of textured baked-apple flavor and hazelnut crème brûlée. It tastes complete and complex, with undeniable richness and concentration.
Wine: Ramey 2015 Woolsey Road Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Just a dash of Petit Verdot is added to this wine, with the Cabernet Sauvigon coming from the Martin Stelling Vineyard that stands regally behind the winery. This starts off with soft aromas of cassis and red cherry, which appear on the palate that's built by sizable tannins and texture. The richness is defined in dark chocolate, with just enough acidity to keep the mouthfeel succulent and lush.
Wine: Far Niente 2015 Estate Bottled Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a standout wine, earthy in juicy red fruit, spicy clove and citrus peel. It is well integrated and robustly built, with a backbone of acidity that provides lasting structure and a finishing touch of elegance.
Wine: Joseph Phelps 2015 Freestone Vineyards Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: From one of the older blocks of the famous vineyard, once looked after by this winemaker, this wine is beautifully golden in color with a reduced, salty nose of caramelized pretzel. Robustly built, it shows fleshy, lush layers of honey and tropical richness.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Hudson Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is gorgeously floral, with a pretty nose, inviting in its formidable blend of savory spicy tartness and intrigue. The fruit leans into elegant flavors of strawberry and orange peel—a backdrop of rose petal and lavender in the background. A grainy, textured finish sears into the brain's memory with a pleasing length and breadth.
Wine: Hanzell 2014 Ambassador's 1953 Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Warm baking spices ride along a contour of juicy spiced plum, cherry and strawberry in this medium-bodied youthful wine. Expansive on the palate, it offers underlying structure and a boldness of polished tannin and integrated oak. Still, it will do well in the cellar: enjoy best 2025–2030.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Cuvée Natalie Silver Belt Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine opens in muted aromatics that slowly blossom into a shaker of oystershell and saline, a salty and bold character of slate and stone that gives it texture and complexity. Green apple, quince and white flower mingle on the expansive ethereal palate within a medium-bodied balanced context of concentration.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Hyde Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a juicy, expansive and textured wine, incredibly delicious in ripe raspberry and strawberry flavors. It has sanguine undertones, with clove, cardamom and black tea that stand out against polished tannins.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2015 Hallberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This gorgeous white has a density and weight to it that never becomes heavy, instead remaining complex and steely in character. Wet stone, apricot and key lime intermingle effortlessly around a core of balanced richness and supportive acidity, the oak well-integrated and nuanced.
Wine: Kistler 2015 Durell Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sonoma Mountain, Sonoma, California, US
Review: With an underlying richness, this medium-bodied white never forgets about its throughput of acidity, allowing for an undeniable crispness on the palate. Floral on the nose in apple and orange blossom, it shows a stony character that speaks to mineral components like oystershell and rock.
Wine: Kistler 2015 McCrea Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Mountain)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's extreme, maybe even obscene, amounts of cracked black pepper on the savory nose of this cool-climate expression, which comes from the same 12 rows each vintage. There are also scents of roasted beef, asphalt and a pinch of lavender. The pepper character coats the palate too, diced by lively acidity. This is, perhaps, the most pitch-perfect show of Côte-Rôtie in California to date.
Wine: Samsara 2014 Turner Vineyard Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Made entirely from estate-grown Chardonnay, this blanc de blancs is heady and intense with ample mousse and body. Green-apple Jolly Rancher flavor meets steely acidity that takes on a tone of wet stone and a focused structure, with a lasting impression of pineapple upside-down cake and crème brûlée.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2011 Le Rêve Sparkling (Carneros)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep and dark in color with savory aromas galore, this bottling, which includes 3% Grenache and 2% Viognier, shows dense beef-crust aromas along with violet paste, black-currant jam and fudge. Chalky tannins and smooth acidity frame a seamlessly integrated palate, where both caramelized and fresh boysenberries are dusted with lavender.
Wine: Clos Solène 2015 Hommage A Nos Pairs Reserve Syrah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a site farmed by the Dutton family, this wine is beautifully aromatic in brioche and honey apple, with light toasted oak playing a supporting part. An underlying richness presents as expansive and fleshy on the robust palate, with high-toned offerings of peach and Gravenstein apple.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Three Jacks Vineyard Chardonnay (Green Valley)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a tiny-production wine that packs an impressive punch. Currant, cassis and cedar open on the nose and palate, allowing for a soft, approachable beginning that takes on additional complexity as the wine develops. A grippiness dominates on the finish, suggesting it would benefit from time in the cellar. Enjoy 2024–2030.
Wine: Trujillo 2014 Gary Morisoli Vineyard Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Thick, extracted and smoothly integrated, this combines 76% Cabernet Sauvignon, 12% Cabernet Franc and 12% Petit Verdot. The elements are a complementary contradiction of earthy sage, rock and sanguine meat alongside a richer chapter of mocha and toffee. Together, they are formidable and would stand up well to cellaring; enjoy best 2025–2030.
Wine: B Cellars 2015 Blend 26 Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is slightly reductive on the nose, and tannic in its youth, with a strong floral component that brightens the proceedings. From a foggy hillside site overlooking Forestville, it sings in forest pine, tart tangy blood-orange acidity and sprinkles of Asian spice and soy.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Fog Dance Vineyard Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine speaks to cool-climate sensibilities, fleshy and fruity with a vibrancy and intensity. Sage, thyme and forest floor fill the nose before unleashing full-bodied succulent flavors of strawberry and raspberry that take on a kirsch-like complexity.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Hailey's Block Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
Review: A deep and dark color signals the concentrated flavors to come in this very ripe, opulent and ultimately gentle wine. Cinnamon, clove and cedar notes waft up from the glass, with rich blueberry, blackberry and espresso flavors that coat the palate. Grown at 2,640 feet in a vineyard strewn with sharp, black obsidian rocks, the wine is packed with minute threads of tannin that add good grip to the texture without being at all drying. Best after 2023.
Wine: Obsidian Ridge 2015 Half Mile 2640' Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Hills)

Appellation: Three Sticks
Review: Juicy with explosive acidity, this is made from vineyards across the appellation and is a fine showcase of its decadent grace and beauty. Delectable, it has a fleshy midpalate with lasting notions of cardamom, forest spice and wild pomegranate, with a depth of structure and balanced weight.
Wine: Three Sticks 2016 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From Winemaker Kirk Venge, this estate wine is sourced from the heart of the appellation. Char, blueberry and layered swathes of dusty chocolate give it richness around a full-bodied palate that's tempered by bright, lingering acidity.
Wine: Croix 2015 Wood Estate Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has a tannic intensity to it and a depth of rich red fruit. Rose and lavender aromatics season a seductively velvety texture of leather, nutmeg and Asian spice, the spiciness warming and muscular within a full-bodied boldly ripe core.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Jennifer's Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Velvety and luxurious on the nose, this is named for the producers' son and is from a vineyard near the coastal town of Occidental. Dark cherry and chocolate travel along a smooth spicy thoroughfare of integrated oak and tannin, the body bold and full bodied. Forest pine and orange peel add complex nuances of aroma and flavor.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 MacLean's Block Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Year after year, this wine from a spectacularly cool-climate site impresses and intrigues. A crisp green-apple note is followed by high-toned acidity etched in Meyer lemon and wild lime flavors. The fresh, fruity core is well balanced and melds with a grip of oak on the finish, adding ample body and weight.
Wine: Joseph Phelps 2016 Freestone Vineyards Estate Grown Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: The block sourced by this producer was planted in 1972 with Old Wente clone. The combination of site and winemaker is stunningly successful. The grainy, textured wine is nutty and boldly laced in crème brûlée richness. Integrated vanilla oak gives it additional density as supportive acidity freshens flavors of peach, olive and apple.
Wine: Ramey 2015 Ritchie Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Somewhat lighter in color, this wine has expressive aromas, with notes of cigar box, green and black olive, fresh parsley, funk, grilled asparagus, wet stone, ember, black pepper, prosciutto and fresh herb, leaning hard into the savory. The palate shimmers with intensity, packed with sleek but rich, incredibly flavorful flower, earth and smoked-meat notes that persist on the ultralong olive and smoked-meat filled finish. It's a stunner.
Wine: Sleight of Hand 2015 Psychedelic Stoney Vine Vineyard Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Strange Family Vineyards
Review: Very tightly wound on the nose, this bottling is fresh and without many frills, allowing the bright lemon rind, chilled nectarine and crushed chalk aromas to stand clean and pure. There are flashes of honeysuckle and cherimoya on the palate, but it too is very taut and sharp, with crushed sea shells and the slightest hint of oak arising on the finish.
Wine: Strange Family Vineyards 2015 Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Arroyo Grande Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very delicate at first, this single-vineyard expression opens slowly but steadily into sagebrush, elderflower, jasmine, hibiscus and framboise on the nose. On the palate, bright flavors are seamlessly integrated and enveloped in a light but taut texture, proving ethereal and delicious all at once.
Wine: Talley 2015 Rosemary's Vineyard Estate Bottled Pinot Noir (Arroyo Grande Valley)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: From a site on the eastern edges of the appellation, this wine offers robust aromas of pencil shavings, cedar and dried herb. Black peppercorn, vanilla and black currant flavors make for a savory and fruity palate that is supported by a grip of tannins. Enjoy 2025–2030.
Wine: Nickel & Nickel 2015 C.C. Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark in the glass, this bottling from an extremely coastal vineyard shows black plum, intense cola, baked earth and hints of bay leaf and white pepper on the nose. Framed by bright acidity and a tight structure, the palate is savory with salt and pepper, salted plum and hibiscus flavors. It is a thought-provoking wine.
Wine: Pescadero Creek 2014 Pascale Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Ramey
Review: This is one heck of a deal for a wine of this quality and substance. Sourced from four ranches farmed by the Dutton family, as well as the producer's estate and two Rochioli sites, it shows the beauty of blending from such incredible places—a study in exotic lemony quince and soft supple structure. The lasting finish is textured and complex.
Wine: Ramey 2015 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Extremely ripe, rich and seductive, this wine has immense fruit flavors, handsome oak accents and a gorgeous sense of concentration and creaminess on the palate. It layers accents of vanilla, nutmeg and maple between waves of deep blackberry and blueberry, with a long, lingering finish.
Wine: Three 2015 Evangelho Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Williams Selyem
Review: Bright, vivid aromas of purple and red flowers, fennel pollen, dried cranberry and crushed slate drop into a palate that's zippy in acidity. Flavors of dark hibiscus, elderberry jam, thyme and more fennel fly across the palate.
Wine: Williams Selyem 2016 Pinot Noir (Central Coast)

Appellation: Barden
Review: Very tightly focused on the nose, this bottling by Doug Margerum, shows Meyer lemon pith, crushed seashells, lime skin and a hint of honeysuckle on the nose. It's extremely zippy and racy on the palate, with a taut texture that conveys flavors of kumquat, lemon-lime and butter-brushed Asian pears.
Wine: Barden 2016 Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly wound, bright and fresh aromas of lychee, light caramel and white peach make for a delicious entry to this bottling by Winemaker Fintan du Fresne. A chalky texture on the palate delivers complex and intertwined flavors of almond, Meyer lemon and pear.
Wine: Chamisal Vineyards 2015 Califa Estate Grown Chardonnay (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: With a heady entry of rose petal, this sparkling blend is rich, creamy and lush in bold flavors of cherry, strawberry and Creamsicle. Integrated and lushly complex, it offers well-defined acidity and freshness amidst a crisp layered body of delicious flavor.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2012 Le Rêve Rosé Sparkling (Carneros)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: High toned in a rose petal aroma, the palate of this wine is bright in acidity yet medium in build and complex. The concentration of the vintage is on full display in velvety layers of raspberry and strawberry coated in nutmeg and Asian spice.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2015 Dutton Ranch Emerald Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This white is bold and brawny in up-front apple and mango flavors and broadly structured and expansive on the palate in fleshy lush waves. An exotic back note of vanilla butterscotch beckons amid a tight tart finish that freshens as it lingers.
Wine: Keller 2015 La Cruz Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Bright fruit flavors and lavish oak tones burst from the glass. They're followed by mouthcoating flavors of black cherry, clove and cranberry. For all that richness, it also has good structure due to firm tannins and lively acidity that give it balance. Enjoy now–2022.
Wine: Goldeneye 2015 Gowan Creek Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: From estate-grown grapes, mostly Pinot Noir, with 37% Chardonnay, this wine has a lovely orange-copper color and intense aromatics of peach and apple. Dry and complex, it offers structure and beauty in equal measure, with defined acidity and lasting freshness.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2014 Brut Rosé Sparkling (Carneros)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a site high above Green Valley, typically above the fog and in view of the ocean, this is a spicy, forested and savory wine, textured like nobody's business. Rhubarb, cranberry and wild strawberry attempt to intrude, and do quietly, but it's the cardamom and white pepper that persist most emphatically.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 Ulises Valdez Silver Eagle Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Bella Union
Review: Fermented in stainless steel, then aged 16 months in French oak (60% new), this wine is brightly aromatic in tones of cherry, cassis and spicy clove. Supple and integrated on the palate, it has depth at its core, with an intense ripe berry flavor.
Wine: Bella Union 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Made by Philippe Melka, this wine sources fruit from across the valley, adding in 7% Petit Verdot. Structured, chalky tannins settle into a soft, billowy entry of cassis, clove and quiet oak. Dried herb and additional baking spices touch up the lengthy finish.
Wine: Lail 2015 Blueprint Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Bennett Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This block is home to a mysterious clone of Sauvignon Blanc that appears to be the only one of its kind in the region and thought to hail originally from Northern Italy. The resulting wine is citrus-driven on the nose and on the palate—a pure expression that shows complexity and rich layers of flavor, with an intensity of lemongrass.
Wine: Grey Stack 2017 Rosemary's Block Dry Stack Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Bennett Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a substantial complex white, reduced nobly on the nose, with an exotic hint of oak spice and matchstick. Bright focused acidity lifts a grainy texture of mineral-laden stoniness, as high-toned aspects of tangerine and grapefruit underline the freshness that lingers with length.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Fog Dance Vineyard Chardonnay (Green Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a perennially impressive wine, floral in a heady perfume of white roses. Fresh and fleshy, the expansive palate offers concentrated flavors of kiwi and pineapple. The wine was largely fermented in oak, then aged just over a year in French oak (75% new). It holds the oak well, ending bright in juicy acidity.
Wine: Shafer 2016 Red Shoulder Ranch Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a relatively warm site, this wine is rich and tropical, with a lovely texture. Sourced from multiple vineyards along the Laguna Ridge and from older plantings, it has high-toned aspects of tangerine and stone with a warmth of Gravenstein apple and pear. The medium structure supports integrated oak and body.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Four Hearts Vineyards Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This earthy wine is not loud on the nose in fruit tones, yet brings notes of mushroom, chalky, soot and compost to the fore. It's tannic and dense on the palate, with a forest-floor character alongside notes of savory Asian spice and ripe red fruit.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Sevens Bench Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is made from grapes grown within a small block of the larger Durell Vineyard, on a slope that's rocky in soil and helps impart minerality and an undeniable note of flinty stone to the wine. Flowers, earth and dried herb persist, with a hint of ginger as the robust palate takes on fleshy white-peach and citrus flavors and a lasting impression of oak.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Stone Côte Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: B Cellars
Review: Robustly aromatic in earth and a happy explosion of wild strawberry, with a hit of tangerine tanginess, this wine is well-made and integrated. The tannins are textured and add complexity without getting in the way, and serve as an overall balance to the ripeness and fruit.
Wine: B Cellars 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: This wine is sourced from a 24-acre vineyard on the northwestern part of Seneca Lake. While exuding ultraripeness in its plush stone fruit, pineapple and white blossom tones on the nose, there's still great deal of balance and finesse. The palate is broad and expansive in flavors of soft yellow apple, juicy apricot and white plum, with a fresh line of acidity maintaining focus. White tea tannins offer some grip and astringency on the midpalate, extending into the long, lingering finish.
Wine: Hermann J. Wiemer 2016 Magdalena Vineyard Estate Bottled and Grown Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This barrel-fermented white is made from three stellar vineyard sites: Crocker, Farella and Rewa, the latter two in Coombsville. Philippe Melka makes the wine. Smooth, soft and floral, it has citrus-driven acidity that keeps it fresh in the glass against a backdrop of stunning complexity and lush texture.
Wine: Lail 2016 Blueprint Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a serious, sculpted wine with expressive floral, cedar and violet aromas, deep and concentrated cassis and black-cherry flavors and a firm tannic but velvety texture. It has complexity and fruit in spades and will be even better with time. Best after 2023.
Wine: Nottingham Cellars 2014 Smith Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: The second vintage of this estate wine from the producer's property, this opens luxuriously in butterscotch and Gravenstein apple, an inviting combination buoyed by a grainy layered texture. The concentrated flavors are balanced well by a juicy core of fresh acidity.
Wine: Ramey 2015 Estate Westside Farms Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: A compelling, concentrated fruit essence lifts this full-bodied wine to a high level of quality and satisfaction. It has a vivid blackberry and blueberry aroma, lush and layered fruit flavors and light spicy oak accents that don't get in the way of the amazing berry character.
Wine: Renwood 2015 Riker Vineyard Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This has distinctive, exotic fruit nuances that begin in the aroma and continue on the palate and through the lingering finish. It seems to blend blueberry, mint and blackberry notes into a rich texture with moderate tannins that make it nicely mouthfilling. Cofermenting with 13% Petite Sirah and 7% Barbera certainly enhanced the structure as well as the flavors.
Wine: Terra d'Oro 2016 SHR Field Blend Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A dash of spicy oak livens this big, ripe and fruity wine from the aromas through the flavors and on through the finish. Notes of toast, nutmeg and cedar blend seamlessly with raspberry and ripe plum, while firm tannins and full body give it a good sense of weight and structure.
Wine: Three 2015 Bigelow Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Petite Sirah benefits from aging in a portion of new oak barrels, and this one is a great example. It has wonderful spicy cinnamon and cedar aromas, massive ripe blackberry flavors and baking-spice accents from the oak. The color is black with a dark red rim, and the mouthfeel is broad and nicely astringent due to a high level of fine-grained tannnins. It's very full-bodied, too.
Wine: Trinitas 2015 Old Vine Petite Sirah (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Big and juicy, this bold red offers tar and a touch of reduction on the nose. The palate shows tobacco, black cherry and polished, sizable tannins that add weight and density to the midpalate before unfurling a soft, spicy finish of clove and black pepper.
Wine: Nellcôte 2014 500 Chevaux Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very tightly wound and chalky with crushed seashell aromas on the nose, this bottling shows additional aromas of yuzu, Asian pear and cherimoya. There's a great sizzle of acidity and a grippy texture to the palate, where a vibrant frame meets with California sunshine, offering flavors of mandarin and pear flesh.
Wine: Spear 2016 Gnesa Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Chalk Hill, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This blends 58% Sauvignon Blanc and 42% Sémillon, from estate-grown grapes at a high-elevation site in the appellation. It is barrel-fermented and aged in neutral French oak. Floral and pretty on the nose, it is stony and steely on the palate, with integrated acidity and nuanced oak. Lushly crafted, it's deliciously complex.
Wine: Calluna 2017 Estate Blanc Sauvignon Blanc-Sémillon (Chalk Hill)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Guillaume Fabre's blend of 50% Syrah, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon and 20% Grenache needs a bit of time to unwind, but once it does, it's another ode to balanced richness. Aromas of blackberry and wet slate lead into an elegant palate that's thick, soft and full of grippy tannins. Flavors of elderberry and violet lead into a polished vanilla finish. Drink 2019–2030.
Wine: Clos Solène 2015 Fluer de Solene Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From a vineyard just 12 miles inland from the ocean, this bottling shows toasted brioche, preserved lemon, sweet sandalwood and a touch of caramel on the nose. It hits the palate with a riper peachy sweetness, but then tightens into searing, laser-focused acidity rounded by hints of lemon and Gravenstein apple.
Wine: Fess Parker 2016 Ashley's Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Nuances of cinnamon, cedar and wood smoke fill the aroma of this full-bodied velvet-textured wine and lead to ample ripe black-cherry and raspberry flavors. It has a nicely oaky profile that's easily matched by the power of the fruit component, and supported by moderate tannins that add some grip to the texture.
Wine: Goldeneye 2015 Split Rail Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: All Les Collines Vineyard from blocks 36 and 46 with 100% whole cluster, the aromas stop you in your tracks, with notes of freshly chopped parsley, cured meat, potpourri, olive, violet and crushed rock. The palate is full of light tart herb and smoked-meat flavors backed by hefty tannins that need a good bit of time to resolve. It brings a sense of freshness and vibrancy, needing significant time in the cellar to be fully appreciated. Best from 2026–2031.
Wine: Gramercy 2015 John Lewis Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is a bold wine that pushes the envelope in terms of ripeness and power. Hints of butter and caramel in the aroma lead to broad, ripe, almost roasted fruit flavors and a rather viscous texture that clings to the sides of the mouth and helps extend the finish for 30 seconds. Best after 2022.
Wine: Goldeneye 2015 The Narrows Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Hartford Court
Review: The fruit for this wine is sourced from the estate as well as sites across the appellation. Juicy waves of cherry and cardamom ride a full-bodied, concentrated framework of exotic flavors, bright acidity and velvety texture.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: With a crisp entry of green apple and wet stone, this impressive, small-production offering is effusive in floral highlights of jasmine and orange blossom. Buoyantly fresh in the glass, it has substantial body weight and texture that finishes in a cohesive whole.
Wine: Delgado 2015 Rodgers Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This winery's young estate vineyard is proving itself to be a special spot. This is a blend of 56% Cabernet Sauvignon, 30% Merlot, 7% Cabernet Franc and 7% Malbec. The brooding aromas of dark cherry, cassis, fresh and dried herb, incense, luxurious oak spices (50% new French), mineral, pencil lead, flower and scorched earth lead to a flavorful but exceptionally well-balanced palate that shows sophistication. The tannins are highly structured but also bring a sense of polish. It has the stuffing to go the distance but needs significant time to settle in. Best from 2028–2034.
Wine: L'Ecole No. 41 2015 Estate Grown Ferguson Vineyard Red (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a classic field blend of 80% Zinfandel and 20% mixed blacks. High-toned flavors of raspberry and cherry dominate the palate, which has a smoothly textured core of dusty clove and leather that accents the fruit well.
Wine: Armida 2015 Tina's Block Maple Vineyards Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rather wondrous aromas of pear peels, nectarine flesh, gardenias and crushed chalk become almost like a wearable perfume on this blend of 36% Chardonnay, 32% Pinot Blanc and 32% Pinot Gris. The palate is tightly woven and strongly acidic, offering flavors of Anjou pear, lime juice and more chalk.
Wine: Barden 2016 Fonte White (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Bradley Brown opted for 70% whole cluster on this forest-spiced bottling, and the result is a nose full of green peppercorns, tangy green plum, fennel and tapenade. That olive element is also strong on the sip, where green sage, thyme, marjoram, juniper and tangy underripe plum flavors keep the palate entertained.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Lester Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Heavy and rich aromas of black currant and blackberry jam paint a thick picture of depth and ripeness on the nose of this blend of 38% Mourvèdre, 33% Grenache and 29% Syrah. Aromatic purple flowers and lavish dark-fruit tones ride a silky texture on the palate, yet it is still a very young wine. Drink 2019–2029.
Wine: Caliza 2014 Azimuth Red (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: San Francisco Bay, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep, dark and brooding with earth, slate, pepper, mulberry jam, maduro cigar, iodine and sandalwood scents on the nose, this aged bottling from a one-acre block above Palo Alto is fascinatingly unique. The palate is loaded with flavors of soil, menthol, plum jam and tobacco leaf, featuring tannins that have been polished by patience.
Wine: Clos de la Tech 2005 Domaine du Docteur Rodgers Pinot Noir (San Francisco Bay)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The aromatic and flavor profiles of this series of aged-to-release wines, grown on a dramatic slope atop the Santa Cruz Mountains, are unlike any others. Scents of moist earth and turned loam meet with dried mint, chocolate, soy and black cherry reduction on the nose. The palate adds juniper, mulch, pepper and plum to the mix, framed by a firm tannic structure and yet soft mouthfeel.
Wine: Clos de la Tech 2005 Domaine Valeta Sunny Slope Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Niner
Review: There's a compelling tang of preserved lemon to the nose of this bottling by Molly Bohlman, along with hints of sandalwood, hazelnut and toast. There is impressive grip and laser-like acidity to the palate yet it retains a creamy mouthfeel, showing flavors of toasted oak, pear and chalk.
Wine: Niner 2016 Chardonnay (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Monterey, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Samuel Smith, who also works for Morgan Winery, is a young winemaker to watch, and he got his hands on fruit from an epic vineyard for this wine. Aromas of framboise, wild thyme, tea and cigar box lead into a lively palate full of pomegranate and nutmeg spice. The texture, taut yet mouthfilling, is even more fascinating.
Wine: Samuel Louis Smith 2016 Albatross Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Monterey)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Hearty, energetic aromas of boysenberry, cranberry and hibiscus meet with rhubarb, fennel and forest floor on the nose of this bottling—the first vintage for an ambitious new property with initial winemaking overseen by Greg Brewer. Well-integrated flavors of boysenberry, elderberry, anise and Earl Grey tea complete the picture.
Wine: Spear 2016 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine explodes with aromas of cinnamon stick and oak. The entry is thick and dense on impact, with powerful, polished tannins. Dark cherry, raspberry and dusty clove combine with ease around a palate of structure and grace.
Wine: Trefethen 2015 Family Owned Estate Grown Merlot (Oak Knoll District)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a thick concentrated mountain wine, jammy in rich fruit best described as dark cherry, mocha and vanilla. The voluptuousness holds its own against a steep cliff of rocky mineral notes and supportive acidity. The wine is well-served by small additions of Cabernet Franc, which add floral violet aromas, as well as Merlot, Petit Verdot and Malbec.
Wine: Trujillo 2014 Henry Brothers Vineyard Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Dark, inky and earthy, this is a powerfully dense and rich expression of the variety, that is varietal in its mix of fruit, spice and herb. Black-cherry and mocha flavors dance around spicy toasted oak and polished, billowy tannin. Enjoy best 2022–2025.
Wine: Venge 2015 Estate Merlot (Oakville)

Appellation: Ackerman Family Vineyards
Review: A 100% varietal wine, this is soft and subdued, with a woody tinge on the nose of eucalyptus and bay leaf. Expansive and juicy, it offers succulent black fruit, tobacco and tangy toasted oak, finishing balanced in medium-bodied weight and grace.
Wine: Ackerman Family Vineyards 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Coombsville)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is made like a white wine using 52% Pinot Noir and 48% Chardonnay grapes, intended as a bright, white summer wine that's highly drinkable and served chilled. It is indeed quaffable, white in color with a citrus-led nose of crisp, focused and fresh flavor, marked especially by green apple and a hint of cherry. Light in ripeness, it's a perfect picnic wine.
Wine: Brick & Mortar 2017 Vin Clair White (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a lengthy and structured wine, made from four estate-farmed vineyards in the appellation. Tangy in cherry and strawberry, it is exotically earthy, with highlights of black tea, cinnamon and wild mushroom.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2015 Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: On the winery's third reserve designated Cabernet, aromas of freshly tilled soil, dried herb, red and black cherry, graphite and crushed rock are followed by reserved fruit flavors with a fresh cranberry finish. Lip-smacking tightly wound tannins provide support. The structure is impressive. It needs time to show its stuff. Best after 2026, but it should have 20 years of excellent drinking in it.
Wine: Gramercy 2014 Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: A mixture of Olsen and Alder Ridge vineyards, this lighter-colored wine is brooding on first pour, with aromas of fresh parsley, crushed flower, dried herb, mineral, orange peel, smoked meat and raspberry emerging over time. The palate shows a fresh light styling, with a meaty peppery finish. It's a very pretty expression of the variety, with an impressive sense of balance and sophistication.
Wine: Gramercy 2015 L'Idiot du Village Mourvèdre (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: A blend of fruit from Forgotten Hills and Les Collines using 85% whole cluster, the aromas leap up, with notes of fresh parsley, plum, heaping amounts of fresh and dried herb, violet and cured meat showing a lot of nuance. The smoked-meat and red-fruit flavors are reserved in style, bringing a strong sense of tannic structure that needs time to fully settle in. Best after 2022.
Wine: Gramercy 2015 The Deuce Syrah (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: An attractive perfume of violet, tobacco and cedar leads to rich, pure fruit flavors that are carefully accented by subtle oaky notes of cinnamon and nutmeg. The wine has good depth and complexity along with an appropriately firm and gripping texture due to moderate tannins. Expect this to improve with time. It will be best after 2023.
Wine: Las Positas 2014 Estate Bottled Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Bold and dry, this full-bodied wine is especially concentrated in flavor. It has a nearly black color with a purple rim, powerful blackberry aromas shaded by light smoke and black pepper, and flavors that go deep on the palate and last a long time on the finish.
Wine: Las Positas 2014 Obscurus Estate Red (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Effusive in peach flavor and aroma, this is a lovely wine, sizzling in crisp, focused acidity and additional flavors of orange, strawberry and grapefruit. Light in body, it finishes on a flourish of Meyer lemon zest.
Wine: Rodney Strong 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sol Rouge
Review: Very deep and dark in color, this wine has intense blackberry aromas, rich blackberry and dark chocolate flavors and very firm tannins that give a lot of grip on the palate. The flavors are wound up tight and still need time to open and diversify. Best after 2023.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2014 Petite Sirah (Lake County)

Appellation: Sol Rouge
Review: Extreme ripeness, good concentration and a firm texture help this full-bodied wine rise well above the pack. It smells and tastes like a blend of raspberry and blackberry syrups, but is refreshingly dry and nicely supported by moderate tannins.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2014 Zinfandel (Red Hills)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Plump aromas of daffodil, toasted sourdough, hot sand and roasted nuts are cut by lemon rind on the nose of this estate bottling. The palate is laser-focused and grippy, with flavors of preserved lemon, sea salt, tart apple and a light butterscotch touch on the finish.
Wine: Spear 2016 Estate Grown Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A very pale pink in color, this blend of 60% Grenache, 26% Mourvèdre, 9% Syrah and 5% Cinsaut shows squeezed lime, watermelon, pomelo pith and a limestone quarry-like aroma on the nose. There is tremendous grip and subtle citrus flavors on the palate, which is all about brightness, freshness and texture.
Wine: Clos Solène 2017 La Rosé (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Coming from one of the state's top vineyards, this wine is a blend of Merlot (52%) and Cabernet Sauvignon. The aromas pop, with achingly pure notes of raspberry, assorted dried herb, pie cherry, blueberry and spice. The palate shows finesse and grace, with silky fruit flavors and velvety tannins, with savory notes on a finish that won't quit. It's a flat-out gorgeous, exquisitely understated interpretation of this vineyard.
Wine: Kevin White 2015 DuBrul Vineyard Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very firm and tight on the nose, this bottling from a vineyard that's new to this label shows yellow-grapefruit rind, freshly squeezed lime, sea spray and a hint of hazelnut on the nose. Crushed seashell flavors frame the texturally compelling palate, where white cherry, tangerine, Bartlett pear and Asian pear flavors converge.
Wine: Landmark 2015 Hillard Bruce Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Mint, cedar and cigar-box aromas precede fresh concentrated flavors of black cherry and blackberry in this full bodied and nicely tannic wine. It has a gripping texture that will work well with big proteins, and eases that structure with generous fruit and spice notes on the palate.
Wine: Las Positas 2014 Reserve Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep black-plum sauce, cocoa powder, black pepper, dark loam and vanilla show on the nose of this bottling from an unfamiliar vineyard by Adam Lee. The flavors are deep and dark but full of energy, with white pepper and plum jelly riding a relatively lighter frame.
Wine: Siduri 2017 Lemoravo Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Le Casque
Review: Spicy, almost sweet, oak aromas and flavors meld nicely with the intense black-fruit flavors and firm, mouth-clinging tannins of this inky-looking full-bodied wine. It has cinnamon, clove, black-pepper and blackberry aromas and deep concentrated blueberry and dark chocolate flavors that should only improve with time. Best after 2023.
Wine: Le Casque 2015 Petite Sirah (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is 100% varietal. The fruit for this wine hails from Obelisco, Klipsun and Olsen vineyards. Almost completely closed up on first pour, it opens to reveal aromas of the blackest of cherry, crème de cassis, graphite, fresh herb and luxurious barrel spicing (88% new French). The flavors are rich and ripe but still reserved, showing a very appealing sense of balance, with the tannins combed to a fine sheen. An impressively long finish caps it off. It should have a long life ahead of it.
Wine: Mark Ryan 2015 Lonely Heart Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Medium bodied and very generous in flavor, this is a big but well-balanced and well-crafted wine that's suitable for a special occasion. It exudes vanilla, cream and toasted baguette aromas and follows with rich pear, hazelnut and fig flavors and a good lingering finish.
Wine: Meyer Family Cellars 2016 Donnelly Creek Vineyard Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A gorgeous and perfumed French oak aroma joins seamlessly with ripe and lush black-cherry and blueberry flavors in this full-bodied muscular wine. The texture is mouthfilling due to an abundance of fine-grained tannins that give the wine wonderful grip on the palate. Best after 2023.
Wine: Nottingham Cellars 2015 JHC Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This robust wine hails from a 40-acre site at 1,100-feet in elevation. It speaks to mountainous cedar, dried herb, sage and dusty clove components, the body is full bodied and well-integrated in oak and tannin, with a finishing touch of tobacco.
Wine: PreVail 2013 Back Forty Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is a gutsy wine with great structure and concentrated flavors from the family that founded Rosenblum winery and know Zinfandel very well. It has attractive aromas of ripe blackberries and blueberries, generous fruit flavors and light spicy oak accents that add complexity. Firm tannins and good acidity give it some grip on the palate and will help it pair well with a juicy steak or chop.
Wine: Rock Wall 2016 Mariah Vineyard Zinfandel (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This sans soufre, or without sulfur, bottling captures all that's ripe, juicy and fresh about Syrah, eschewing the heady darkness for a change. Joyous aromas of grape punch and boysenberry juice meet with a touch of twigs on the nose, diving into a vibrant, energetic palate of the same. Get it cold and chill out.
Wine: Stolpman 2017 Syrah So Hot Syrah (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Barden
Review: Concentrated aromas of black cherry meet with wondrous amounts of clove, star anise, chaparral and sharper mulling spices on the nose of this bottling. The palate starts with a powerful peppercorn spice before diving into slightly sour pomegranate, lifted with bits of thyme and anise on the finish. Patience will reward on this wine.
Wine: Barden 2016 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There is great depth of color and viscosity on this bottling from the eastern hills of the Salinas Valley, which shows blackberry, blueberry, pepper and thyme on the nose. The palate is still very intense, tightly wound and young, but patience reveals roasted plum and lilac flavors, all riding a soft texture and slow simmering acidity.
Wine: Big Basin 2014 Coastview Vineyards Terraces Syrah (Monterey County)

Appellation: Fort Ross-Seaview, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Tangy and high in acidity, this red-fruit-rich wine offers weight and expansiveness on the palate, around a core of full-bodied tannins. The concentration and density of the vintage shows, suggesting a decant or cellaring.
Wine: Blue Farm 2015 King Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Fort Ross-Seaview)

Appellation: Boeger
Review: Beautifully sculpted and well balanced, this full-bodied and firmly textured Bordeaux-style blend fills the mouth with big flavors and thick velvety tannins. It has excellent concentration, tasty black cherry, cranberry and bay leaf flavors and a light touch of oak spice that blends well with the layers of fruit.
Wine: Boeger 2015 Meritage (El Dorado)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Broad aromas of tangerine rind, tangerine blossom, wet dough and soft yellow melon make for a very pleasant start to this single-vineyard expression. The palate is framed by a powerfully stony grip, which provides a serious backbone to the approachable rounded flavors of ripe melon and creamy peach.
Wine: Comartin 2016 R-Bar-R Ranch Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a hugely structured, boldly layered wine, with strong flavors of quince, fig and caramel. The toasty oak is layered within the fruit and adds welcome spiciness and lingering texture.
Wine: D.R. Stephens 2016 Star Vineyard Chardonnay (Rutherford)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Buttered toast, oak, caramel, vanilla, white peach and crème brûlée indicate a very classic Californian style of Chardonnay on this bottling, but the winery is well versed in honing those elements into a wine that acid-lovers will still enjoy. The palate is zippy with acid that cuts through flavors of lemon oil, sandalwood and poached pears.
Wine: Fess Parker 2016 Parker West Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Generous oak spices light up the aromas and flavors of this full-bodied and gentle-textured wine. Notes of cinnamon, vanilla and nutmeg join soft ripe black-plum, spiced cherry and black-tea flavors for a complex palate impression.
Wine: Goldeneye 2015 Confluence Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Hefty aromas of blackberry and mulberry are spiced by menthol and fennel pollen, and given complexity by a prosciutto-like savory quality on the nose of this bottling. The palate combines pomegranate, dried plum and purple-flower flavors.
Wine: Hitching Post 2015 Highliner Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Intriguing, deep and dark on the nose, this bottling offers aromas of root beer, black-cherry sauce and vanilla. Framed by upright yet polished tannins on the palate, fresh flavors of blackberry and blueberry are lifted by vanilla spice. This is an easy-to-like, yet heavy-duty, wine.
Wine: J. Lohr 2015 Tower Road Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is three-quarters Grenache, balanced by Syrah (15%), Mourvèdre (5%) and Carignan. Lighter in color with a reddish tinge, dried and fresh herb, raspberry, plum, dried orange-peel, smoked-meat and mineral aromas are at the fore, bringing a delightful sense of purity. The palate is all about delicacy of the red-fruit flavors, showing a reserved styling. An extended juicy finish caps it off.
Wine: Gramercy 2015 The Third Man Grenache (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Sublime in mint and forest floor tones, this is a seductively robust wine that's rich and rewarding on the palate but never loses its sense of balance and place. Spicy and fresh, it is carried by soft, velvety tannins and lingers on a black licorice note.
Wine: Iron Horse 2015 Home Block Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: To find such a delicious, lively and fresh Pinot Noir at this price is always a revelation. Aromas of candied strawberry, red plums, rose petals and a pinch of herbs lead into a more herbally driven palate, full of oregano and fennel. But the bright pomegranate and red-cherry hedonism prevails, finishing with a touch of French toast.
Wine: Joyce 2016 Submarine Canyon Pinot Noir (Monterey County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Appealing aromas of bay leaf, cherry, herb, bittersweet chocolate, incense and spice are followed by an action-packed palate, loaded with sweet, polished, elegant fruit flavors. Well-integrated tannins provide support. All about sophistication and delicacy, it shows a remarkable amount of freshness and focus considering the warmth of the vintage. Anise and currant notes linger on the finish. Best after 2026 with a very long life in front of it.
Wine: Betz Family 2015 Père de Famille Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is the pioneering winery's annual take on the fatter California style of Chardonnay, starting with a fat nose of buttery baked apples, seared white peach, pillowy meringue and pear-laced pastry crust. Cinnamon-laced apple pie and buttered toast show on the palate, but there's an underlying citrus freshness that keeps it lively.
Wine: Chamisal Vineyards 2015 Chamise Chardonnay (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Candied red cherries, dried lilacs, salt and pepper show on the nose of this solid bottling from the longtime Zinfandel producer. The palate is a pleasing mix of flavors, from Concord grape and vanilla dust to purple flowers and baking spice.
Wine: Opolo 2016 Summit Creek Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a site farmed by the great vineyard visionary Ulises Valdez, El Diablo lives up to its name, with a grainy texture of muscular strength and power. It settles to reveal unexpected layers of dried herb, forest floor and strawberry-rhubarb, the mix well within a full-bodied frame of ripeness.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 El Diablo Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Rowen
Review: From a Cooley Ranch site situated at 2,000 feet in elevation in the far north of the county, this is an unusual blend of 57% Cabernet Sauvignon, 22% Malbec, 16% Syrah, 4% Viognier and 1% Petit Verdot. Together, they hum along seamlessly, a thick juicy expression of black cherry and berry integrated in oak, with accents of dried herb, vanilla and clove that's cloaked within a smooth texture.
Wine: Rowen 2014 Red (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is a well-rounded approachable bottling, starting with a nose of baked cherry, clove, cardamom and crushed slate. The palate offers a touch of thyme and fennel spice before the solid energy and firm structure let the plum flavors take hold.
Wine: Samsara 2014 Las Hermanas Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Spicy and full bodied, this wine comes from a vineyard planted in 1881. It is full of ripe fruit flavors, with dashes of black pepper and wood smoke that give it extra dimension. Firm tannins and good acidity keep it well balanced, while blackberry and violet flavors coat the tongue.
Wine: Terra d'Oro 2016 Deaver Vineyard Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Contra Costa County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Opulent fruit flavors take center stage in this full-bodied, smooth-textured wine. It practically oozes blackberry and boysenberry in the aroma and also delivers lush, rich berry tones on the palate. The mouthfeel is broad, and the finish lingers.
Wine: Three 2015 Live Oak Zinfandel (Contra Costa County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is 55% Grenache, 32% Mourvèdre and 13% Syrah, coming from Upland, Heart of the Hill and Oldfield respectively. Somewhat lighter in color, the aromas start out brooding with notes of raspberry, high-toned dried herb, mineral, pomegranate and cherry emerging over time. Ripe in style reflecting the warm vintage it comes from, the palate is packed full of red- and blue-fruit flavors that have a seamless feel with generous spice and herb accents throughout. It shows a lovely sense of purity on the fruit-filled finish.
Wine: Avennia 2015 Justine Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Chamisal Vineyards
Review: Fresh and bright aromas of wild lime, chilled melon, Meyer lemon rind and a bit of toast make for a very inviting nose. With this bottling, the Edna Valley-based winery is branching out to other regions. The palate is tightly woven with zippy, sharp acidity, showing flavors of pomelo and Asian pear.
Wine: Chamisal Vineyards 2016 Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Templeton Gap District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Stunning amounts of cracked green peppercorns and bay leaves decorate the tart red fruit on the zesty nose of this bottling. The refreshingly crisp palate also shows tart but not sour red fruit, lifted by Mediterranean spice and lovely light herbs. It is a red to pair with almost any seafood.
Wine: Halcyon 2015 Velo Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Templeton Gap District)

Appellation: Halcyon
Review: A brilliant Loire-esque play on the grape, this wine starts with cherry, dark cranberry, crushed peppercorns, wet stone and a hint of juniper on the nose. The palate is tremendously fresh and glugable, with a peppery spice decorating the deep yet tart red fruit. Airy yet with tannic grip, it has an aromatic finish.
Wine: Halcyon 2016 Cabernet Franc (California)

Appellation: Hanzell
Review: Pungent layers of earthiness, a mix of black tea, compost, clove and forest pine, are at the forefront of this structured, densely packed red. The fruit in this wine shows a lean tart slice of wild strawberry and cranberry. The body is structured and elegant, with plenty of complexity for aging. Enjoy 2020–2024.
Wine: Hanzell 2014 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Intensely concentrated in milky white blossoms and ripe stone fruit, this well-balanced Riesling hits all the marks. There's breadth to the ripe fruit flavors, with plenty of acidity for balance. A delicate, soft grip of astringency holds everything firmly in place, leading into a powdered mineral finish.
Wine: Hermann J. Wiemer 2016 HJW Vineyard Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Sour cherry, turned earth, eucalyptus oil and a touch of game show on the nose of this bottling from Gray Hartley and Frank Ostini. There's a menthol touch to the palate, where roasted boar and dark berry flavors make for an intriguing combination.
Wine: Hitching Post 2015 St. Rita's Earth Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tight-grained oak aromas meet with lemon rind, lime blossom and a touch of smoke on the nose of this bottling. The savory palate is reminiscent of smoked chicken in a lemony herb sauce, dusted with sea salt and framed with a solid structure and acidic verve.
Wine: J. Lohr 2016 Arroyo Vista Chardonnay (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Nottingham Cellars
Review: Complex aromas and rich full fruit and spice flavors drive this full-bodied mouthfilling wine. The aroma gives cedar and nutmeg, the flavors evoke black cherry, clove and blackberry, while the texture is moderately tannic yet still plush and soothing. Best after 2023.
Wine: Nottingham Cellars 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Red Hills, Lake County, California, US
Review: This smells and tastes like a classic California Cabernet. It's full of spicy oak aromas and big, ripe fruit flavors supported by firm tannins for a rich, mouthcoating effect and a lingering finish. Grown in a high-elevation vineyard and aged in all Hungarian oak barrels, it will be best after 2023.
Wine: Obsidian Ridge 2015 Estate Grown Obsidian Ridge Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Hills)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Smoky, charcoal aromas lead to rich, concentrated flavors of blueberry and dark chocolate in this full-bodied, well-structured wine. It has an intensity of black-fruit flavors and a density of fine-grained tannins that is rare for the variety and bodes well for improvement over time. Best after 2023.
Wine: Renwood 2015 Premier Old Vine Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: A wonderful, deep blackberry-jam aroma and equally expressive fruit flavors on the palate give this wine a lot of enjoyment. This feels full and firm, with tones of blackberry, boysenberry, baking spice and dash of oaky complexity from 35% new barrels.
Wine: Wild Thing 2015 Old Vine Zinfandel (Mendocino)

Appellation: Zinfandelic
Review: This big but plush wine is deep in color, rich in blackberry aromas and saturated with ripe jammy flavors that spread across the palate and cling to the sides of the mouth. It is full bodied, very concentrated and has a ripeness that leaves a fruity sensation on the finish.
Wine: Zinfandelic 2016 Zinfandel (Mendocino)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From Mill Station and Shop Block—two exceptional properties farmed by the Duttons—this wine opens awash in anise and wildflowers, with bright, steely acidity. Lemon, orange and green apple flavors define the palate, tempered by an underlying lushness of fruit.
Wine: Anaba 2015 Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Campos Family Vineyards
Review: This is a live wire of a wine from a new family winery. It has arresting aromas of white pepper and lemon zest, and vivid and focused citrus and mineral flavors that are well supported by good acidity.
Wine: Campos Family Vineyards 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Lodi)

Appellation: Chalk Hill, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Smoked meat rides along a richly interwoven body of dark fruit and cardamom in this exotic expansive wine that's made in a burly style. The oak presents as lightly charred and dipped in rose petal.
Wine: Chalk Hill 2016 Mt Eden Clone Pinot Noir (Chalk Hill)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Though just 40% of the blend with the rest Merlot, the Cabernet Franc drives the sensory experience on this bottling, starting with the tart cranberry, thyme and green peppercorn on the fresh, zesty nose. The palate offers more peppercorn along with bay leaf and forest moss, set against a red-plum backdrop.
Wine: CrossHatch 2014 Depth Merlot-Cabernet Franc (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Seneca Lake, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: An earthy, blossomy nose of gardenia and wet slate mixes with fruitier elements of peach and papaya. These primary characters carry to the palate where nuanced notes of waxy lemon offer focus to the broad, riper fruit. A fuzzy peach skin texture extends through the finish.
Wine: Hermann J. Wiemer 2016 Estate Bottled and Grown Reserve Dry Riesling (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Hitching Post
Review: Nice plump red cherries, baking spice, thyme and sagebrush show on the nose of this appellation blend. It's tightly wound on the palate at first, and then the joyous red-fruit tones emerge, with hints of chaparral spice.
Wine: Hitching Post 2015 Pinot Noir (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Baked apple, lime pith, butter-poached pear and almonds show on the nose of this ripe bottling. There is a tightly wound texture to the palate, carrying flavors of apple and nectarine, with a citrus-driven grapefruit pith finish.
Wine: J. Lohr 2016 October Night Chardonnay (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark berries meet with fudge and thyme on the somewhat restrained nose of this blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 39% Syrah and 1% Viognier. Fat boysenberry and blackberry flavors are lifted by mace and dried herbs, framed by a penetrating acidity that drives into the finish.
Wine: Jalopy 2014 Grateful Red (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a light, delicate white, with aromas of honeysuckle and Meyer lemon zest. High in acidity, it invites green apple and pear flavors on the palate, bolstered by seasonings of lemongrass and ginger. It'll please a crowd or excel at starting off a meal.
Wine: Jax 2016 Y3 Chardonnay (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Abundant dark-fruit flavors and a smooth mouth-coating texture make a good combo in this deep-colored, full-bodied but not overly tannic wine. Light touches of cinnamon and vanilla add extra interest, and linger on the finish.
Wine: La Folia Winery 2013 The Madness Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
