Review: Very ripe and fruity in flavor, this medium-bodied wine is soft in texture, full of peach and pear notes and a bit sweet on the finish.
Wine: Chateau St. Jean 2016 Crisp Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Indiana Uplands, Indiana, US
Review: This deep-gold colored sparkler displays aromas of ripe yellow peach, tangerine, lemon tart and orange blossoms. The palate is thick and the bubbles feel weighed down, showing flavors of buttery oak and vanilla over peach, cashew and graham cracker flavors. The medium-length finish features fresh apricot and peach clafoutis.
Wine: Creekbend 2013 Sparkling Vidal Blanc (Indiana Uplands)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Lighter in color and shy on the nose, this bottling eventually allows aromas of red-plum balsamic sauce and herbs to arise. The palate shows loads of fennel pollen, dust and earth, with a touch of red fruit. It's varietally confusing.
Wine: Europa Village 2015 C'est La Vie Syrah (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The anise, cranberry, cherry and spice aromas seem a bit dried out. The cranberry and raspberry flavors are soft and light, with medicinal flavors on the finish.
Wine: Kestrel 2013 Super Yakima Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Lone Birch
Review: The aromas offer notes of canned peach, apple and spice that are followed by off-dry fruit flavors. It's a straightforward easy drinker.
Wine: Lone Birch 2016 Pinot Gris (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: New York, New York Other, New York, US
Review: Spring flowers, cranberry and a hint of anise gently waft from the glass. The palate is light in feel and mildly citric, ending on a soft red berry tone.
Wine: Raphael 2017 Rosé of Pinot Noir (New York)

Appellation: Rosemont
Review: This wine is heavily perfumed in tones of white peach, lychee, white grape and rose essence. On the palate the flavors translate as soapy and the body is quite full on this dry expression of the varietal. The finish is long yet disconnected.
Wine: Rosemont 2017 Traminette (Virginia)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This blends Zinfandel, Syrah, Sangiovese, Merlot, Petite Sirah and Cabernet Sauvignon in a kitchen-sink offering of overripe baked flavors and aromas. Sweet cherry and vanilla highlight thick extracted layers that end simply.
Wine: Ty Caton 2014 Entycement Red (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Bedell
Review: Shy notes of citrus peel and grass carry the nose and palate. This is straightforward, light-bodied and crisp, making it an easy wine to enjoy by itself.
Wine: Bedell 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: A simple, straightforward nose of apple and citrus carries to the light- to medium-bodied palate. It's enjoyable in its transparency and a perfect crowd pleaser.
Wine: Benmarl 2016 Stainless Steel Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Bellangelo
Review: Racy red plum and blackberry tones meet leafy tobacco on the nose and palate. This is plush in feel, with soft tannins and racing acidity that cuts the flavors short.
Wine: Bellangelo 2014 Merlot (Seneca Lake)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of brown sugar, strawberry, mint and wood spice lead to red-fruit flavors on the lighter side of medium bodied, with a grip of tannins and bitter notes on the finish. It's an unusual offering of this variety.
Wine: Maryhill 2014 Painted Hills Vineyard Tempranillo (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of baking spice, dark cherry, green pepper and spice lead to smoky mesquite flavors. It finishes lemony tart.
Wine: Merry Cellars 2014 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Mourvèdre (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Seven Peaks
Review: Savory, veggie aromas and flavors give this medium-bodied wine a lean aspect while rather soft acidity and tannins make it smooth to sip.
Wine: Seven Peaks 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Quiet aromas of citrus and blossoms are simple on the nose. The light-bodied palate shows a bit more character in its soft orange and melon flavors, while a mild vein of acidity offers some levity.
Wine: Swedish Hill 2016 Blue Waters Dry Riesling (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: The Cleaver
Review: A deep color and bright aromas of raspberry and blackberry precede wood-smoke and charred-oak flavors that give this medium-bodied wine an edgy character.
Wine: The Cleaver 2015 Red (California)

Appellation: Buttonwood Grove
Review: Charred oak and bubblegum spice aromas carry to the medium-bodied palate, with saucy cranberry bringing up the rear. This is transparent in its oaky character, but overall an easygoing sip.
Wine: Buttonwood Grove 2016 Pinot Noir (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Chateau Lafayette Reneau
Review: Mild dark berry aromas meld with wood spice and milk chocolate on the nose. Medium in weight and soft in feel, the palate is carried by a low intensity of black berry and cocoa.
Wine: Chateau Lafayette Reneau 2014 Cabernet Franc (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Hahn
Review: This widely available bottling is very fruity on the nose with boysenberry aromas alongside hints of clay and mud. Dark spice and pungent red fruit show on the sip alongside those earthy tones.
Wine: Hahn 2016 Merlot (Central Coast)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is an unusual blend of Merlot, Syrah, Cabernet Sauvignon, Petit Verdot, Mourvèdre and Sangiovese. The aromas bring notes of cranberry, raspberry, medicine cabinet and herb. The cranberry flavors are soft and reserved, with ground cranberry notes on the finish.
Wine: Kestrel 2013 Winemakers Select Series Tribute Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Lighter in color, aromas of baking spice, anise, cherry lollipop, game and medicine cabinet lead to lighter-styled fruit flavors. It all seems a bit dried out.
Wine: Kestrel 2014 Falcon Series Cabernet Sauvignon (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: New Mexico, New Mexico, US
Review: There is an initial impression of barnyard aromas on the nose of this blend of 40% Aglianico, 40% Cabernet Sauvignon and 20% Dolcetto. Brandied cherry, raspberry, and cedar are coaxed from the glass after aggressive swirling. The palate opens up with flavors of black cherry, plum and raspberry hovering over bitter oak and black pepper. Intense tannic grip shrivels the mouthfeel, leading to a relief of acidity swooping in on the finish and lingering black plum and oak flavors.
Wine: La Chiripada 2013 Winemaker's Select Red (New Mexico)

Appellation: Avalon
Review: This medium-bodied wine is fruity, jammy and easy to sip, offering butter and candied-fruit aromas, gentle fruit flavors, a soft texture and low acidity and tannin content.
Wine: Avalon 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Buttonwood Grove
Review: Charred oak and a red-berry aroma make for a straightforward start to this wine. There's mild weight to the palate which boasts juicy red-fruit flavors under a sheen of vanilla and coconut. Light tannins and bright acidity attempt to bring balance.
Wine: Buttonwood Grove 2016 Cabernet Franc (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Cherry syrup, strawberry and balsamic make for an interesting, if atypical, nose. The palate boasts plenty of strawberry and berry flavors, yet mild acidity leaves it feeling flat.
Wine: Chateau Lafayette Reneau 2017 Pinot Noir Rosé (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is an extremely overripe and concentrated take on Pinot Noir that's uncommon for the region. Aromas of concentrated boysenberry and reduced cherry juice are quite syrupy. The dark heavy palate offers black-plum-jam flavors that are nearing prunes.
Wine: Davine Cellars 2014 Muns Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Electric pink, the aromas deliver notes of cherry and mint. It drinks off dry, leaning sweeter with cranberry and cherry flavors throughout. It needs a bit more acidity to stand it up.
Wine: Maryhill 2017 Rosé of Sangiovese (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Very smooth and somewhat sweet, this full-bodied wine smells and tastes like chocolate-covered cherries, and works well for dessert.
Wine: Naggiar 2015 Don Giovanni Estate Grown Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This is a firmly structured and full-bodied wine with a gripping mouthfeel and noticeable tannins but moderate fruit and spice flavors. It has formed harmless tartrate crystals in the bottle.
Wine: Suveg 2014 Incorrigible Cabernet Sauvignon (Lodi)

Appellation: New York, New York Other, New York, US
Review: With the fruit sourced from Sheldrake Point Winery in the Finger Lakes, this pale peach-colored rosé offers an interesting nose of potpourri, pollen and crushed raspberry. The light-bodied palate initially has a soft, silky feel, yet tart red fruit takes over, carrying to a citric, astringent finish.
Wine: Anthony Nappa 2017 White Pinot Noir (New York)

Appellation: Arizona, Arizona, US
Review: Stewed black cherry and plum aromas are muddled with licorice and menthol on the nose. The palate feels flat and lacking in acidity, offering flavors of baked cherries, raspberries, syrupy strawberries and artificial vanilla. There is fleeting grip of tannin leading into the candied raspberry finish.
Wine: Aridus 2014 Tank 28 Red (Arizona)

Appellation: Cannonball
Review: Light on the nose and crisp on the palate, this is a simple, enjoyable white wine, smooth and easygoing with highlights of apple and melon.
Wine: Cannonball 2016 Chardonnay (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Virginia's Eastern Shore, Virginia, US
Review: A heavy margarine scent overpowers faint pineapple and lemon aromas in this wine. These notes carry to the palate, along with oaky vanilla and spice. Flabby in mouthfeel, the finish is long but lacking in lift.
Wine: Chatham 2016 Church Creek Oak Chardonnay (Virginia's Eastern Shore)

Appellation: Creekside Cellars
Review: With some time in the glass, this closed wine offers aromas of black currant, anise and cedar. The palate is equally shy at first, with flavors of nutmeg and cedar, yet with time reveals intense vanilla, plum and raspberry flavors. The tannins start sandy but continue to build on the palate, nearly overwhelming the plum and black pepper flavors on the medium-length finish.
Wine: Creekside Cellars 2015 Cabernet Franc (Grand Valley)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Mild aromas of citrus rind and crushed stone start off this brisk unoaked Chardonnay. Light in profile, with melon and lemon flavors, this is a crisp, refreshing wine.
Wine: Heron Hill 2016 Unoaked Chardonnay (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The aromas are light, with notes of baking spice, red currant, herb and tire rubber that seem a little unsettled. The plum flavors are light and fall a bit flat.
Wine: Kestrel 2014 Falcon Series Merlot (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Cofermented with 7% Viognier, fresh flower, dried orange peel, black licorice, fruit leather and spice aromas are followed by restrained fruit flavors that pull up on the finish.
Wine: Kestrel 2014 Winemakers Select Series Co-ferment Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Merry Cellars
Review: Most of the fruit for this wine comes from Seven Hills Vineyard (85%), with the rest from Stillwater Creek. Barrel-forward aromas of cocoa, vanilla, baking spice and black licorice are out in front of dark cherry. The palate brings a cranberry-tart flavor, with slightly astringent tannins and a smoky finish.
Wine: Merry Cellars 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Generous and fruity with a reasonably firm texture, this medium-bodied wine has spicy oaky aromas and spiced-fruit flavors as well as a slightly sweet finish.
Wine: Oak Grove 2016 Family Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: North Fork of Long Island, Long Island, New York, US
Review: Aromas of sharp red berries and cinnamon are lightly concentrated on the nose. A crisp, lithe body is supported by soft strawberry flavors that transition to an ultratart raspberry note on the finish.
Wine: Paumanok 2017 Dry Rosé (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Prophecy
Review: Very ripe and jammy tasting, this wine floods the palate with cherry and berry flavors and a hint of sweetness that makes the texture soft.
Wine: Prophecy 2016 Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Trio
Review: A blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc, this wine is softly textured but somewhat harsh on the palate. A simple entry of ripe dark cherry is supported by light oak and a diluted finish.
Wine: Trio 2012 Red (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Windchaser
Review: This is a straightforward red wine with a firm texture and monolithic fruit flavors. It is medium bodied, lightly tannic and has a touch of herbs to accent subdued black cherry.
Wine: Windchaser 2015 Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Virginia, Virginia, US
Review: Deep in color, the nose of this rosé reads a bit medicinal. Hints of pomegranate and berries come through on the palate in this bold sipper.
Wine: Veramar 2016 JB Winemaker Series Rosé (Virginia)

Appellation: Outer Coastal Plain, New Jersey, US
Review: Pale rose gold in the glass, this mineral-driven rosé offers aromas of petrichor and fresh herbs. Grapefruit and cantaloupe join in on the palate, fading into a chalky textured finish full of lime pith.
Wine: William Heritage 2016 Grenache Rosé (Outer Coastal Plain)

Appellation: Chime
Review: Cedar and cinnamon aromas lead to moderate plum flavors and a smooth texture in this medium-bodied wine. It has very little tannin and feels soft on the palate.
Wine: Chime 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Avalon
Review: This wine is overtly buttery, oaky and even smoky, showing all those traits in the aroma and also in the flavors. It has full body, a fat, mouth-clinging texture and a spicy wood-smoke and black-pepper finish.
Wine: Avalon 2016 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Fjord
Review: Gooseberry and citrus aromas meld with tomato-leaf aromas in this light-bodied Sauvignon Blanc. The palate and brisk in feel, with an astringent lemon-rind finish.
Wine: Fjord 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (North Fork of Long Island)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: This white Rhône-style blend has a bright gold color, a bit of haziness and some harmless tartrate crystals, so it's easy to guess there was little intervention by the winemaker. It has vivid fig and almond aromas and a honey-like flavor along with a rich texture and a late-harvest character.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2015 Gypsy Blanc White (Lake County)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: Very fruity jammy aromas are followed by fruity and herbal flavors and some sweetness on the tongue. The wine is medium bodied and fairly rich in mouthfeel, with very little tannin or acidity.
Wine: Bota Box 2016 Nighthawk Black Red (California)

Appellation: Rooster Hill
Review: Sharp gooseberry, lemongrass and canned white-bean aromas carry to a light-bodied palate of puckering green tones and flower water. This is delicate in feel, with crisp acidity.
Wine: Rooster Hill 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: The Winery SF
Review: This is a full-bodied, mature and oaky wine that has sediment in the neck of the bottle and aromas like sunbaked earth followed by red-cherry flavors and a firm tannic texture. It's a rustic powerful wine from a small producer.
Wine: The Winery SF 2013 Cabernet Sauvignon (North Coast)

Appellation: Bridgman
Review: Aromas of canned corn and spice lead to medium-bodied but light-seeming fruit flavors with metallic accents and a sweet finish. It doesn't all work.
Wine: Bridgman 2016 Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Indiana Uplands, Indiana, US
Review: This lush rosé features flavors and aromas of watermelon, white grape juice and fresh citrus that linger through a charmingly sweet finish. Balancing acidity keeps it firmly out of cloying territory, perfect for a delicious summer spritzer.
Wine: Creekbend 2016 Catawba Rosé (Indiana Uplands)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aromas of baking spice, vanilla, fruit leather and medicine cabinet lead to tart cherry and spice flavors, with the concentration a bit dilute. The variety seems hard to find.
Wine: Kestrel 2014 Falcon Series Estate Sangiovese (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Bota Box
Review: This wine is light-bodied and very straightforward in flavor, showing modest apple and citrus aromas and equally light flavors. It feels soft on the palate and carries a hint of sweetness.
Wine: Bota Box 2016 Pinot Grigio (California)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Ripe melon and citrus tones are blousy and a bit overblown. The palate shows a decent concentration of citrus flavors, but ultimately overripe fruit tones win out.
Wine: Damiani 2016 Little Lotus Flower Sauvignon Blanc (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: A light but noticeable smoky, ashy element affects the aromas and flavors of this medium-bodied, dark-fruited wine, and a dry, slightly astringent texture accompanies them.
Wine: Bonny Doon 2014 A Proper Claret Red (California)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Ripe, almost jammy in aroma, this wine offers a mix of berry and melon flavors. The palate is low in intensity and soft in feel.
Wine: Glenora 2017 Dry Pinot Noir Rosé (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Vellichor
Review: Closed on the nose, this hugely ripe wine is marked by compressed wood, dried herb and big broad tannins. A leathery texture comes off as somewhat hot and harsh, with the heat returning on the finish.
Wine: Vellichor 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Chalk Hill)

Appellation: 786 Wines
Review: This medium-bodied wine is fruity and relatively soft for the varietal, and has a whiff of raspberry and wet earth in the aroma followed by plum and raspberry flavors.
Wine: 786 Wines 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Coombsville, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine is intensely reduced on the nose, with a strong sense of oak and severe acidity that begins to taste of green olive before becoming seemingly sweet.
Wine: AuburnJames 2016 1001 Reserve Chardonnay (Coombsville)

Appellation: Bota Box
Review: This wine has obvious oaky smoky aromas, and flavors heavily influenced by oak too. It has a sweet fruit character underneath the black-pepper, charred wood and vanilla notes that come from oak.
Wine: Bota Box 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: California Republic
Review: This is a soft, light-bodied and lightly sweet wine with modest berry and cedar flavors and very little tannin.
Wine: California Republic 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (California)

Appellation: Indiana Uplands, Indiana, US
Review: Simple blue-fruit aromas define this rosé, with additional cherry and strawberry flavors. The palate is a bit thin and feels watered down, with a short finish.
Wine: Creekbend 2016 Estate Bottled Chambourcin Rosé (Indiana Uplands)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: This is simple and straightforward in its tart cherry and strawberry tones. The palate feels a bit flabby and the fruit flavors are lacking in clarity.
Wine: Fulkerson 2017 Syrah Rosé (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine presents as slightly sweet and unstructured, muddled in pungent earth and leather.
Wine: Kirkland Signature 2015 Old Vine Zinfandel (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Dunnigan Hills, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This medium-bodied wine is low on fruitiness and soft in terms of mouthfeel. It has mild melon flavors and little noticeable acidity.
Wine: Matchbook 2017 Tinto Rey Estate Bottled Rosé (Dunnigan Hills)

Appellation: Fulkerson
Review: Odd aromas of savory cannellini beans and plastic ride over a mild lemongrass note in this wine. The palate is light in feel and mild in concentration, with a sweet floral note on the close.
Wine: Fulkerson 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Finger Lakes, Finger Lakes, New York, US
Review: Creamy strawberry and balsamic make for an odd combination in this wine. It's light in concentration and low on acid, making it feel flat and simple.
Wine: Fulkerson 2017 Pinot Noir Rosé (Finger Lakes)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This wine has a dusty sunbaked aroma, full body and very mature fruit and spice flavors. Prune, sun-dried tomato and balsamic flavors come through.
Wine: Longevity 2011 Phil-osophy Vintner Select Red (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This lightly sweet and light-bodied wine made from Zinfandel grapes has a vivid pink color, muted aromas and candy-like flavors. It's simple and soft in character.
Wine: American House Wine 2016 Rosé of Zinfandel (California)

Appellation: Lake Michigan Shore, Michigan, US
Review: Extremely floral aromas of potpourri are joined by bruised strawberry and overripe raspberry on the nose. The palate offers an underripe strawberry flavors leading into a sour and bruised fruit finish.
Wine: Dablon 2016 Pinot Noir Rosé (Lake Michigan Shore)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: Unusually full bodied for a rosé, this wine feels rather fat and mouth-coating, and has earthy, almost sweet flavors.
Wine: Mt. Konocti Winery 2016 Petite Rosé (Lake County)

Appellation: New Mexico, New Mexico, US
Review: High-toned black-berry and cherry aromas are sharp against licorice and cedar on the nose. Intense, gravely tannins assault the palate, with subtle flavors of leather, spice and raw wood struggling to make an appearance. The flavors evaporate on the finish, leaving a mouthcoating of chewy tannins.
Wine: La Chiripada 2013 Artist Series I Cabernet Sauvignon (New Mexico)

Appellation: Arizona, Arizona, US
Review: Muted aromas of cherry NyQuil and hard candies are tempered by whispers of sweet baking spice on the nose. Thick and flat, with papery tannins, the palate shows overripe strawberry and cherry dragged down by a bitter medicinal undercurrent. The finish is clipped, with a final swipe of cough syrup.
Wine: Aridus 2015 Limited Production Malbec (Arizona)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This 100% Pommard clone wine from a 1990 planting is immensely deep, dark and textural, with complex aromas that instantly draw one in. Its compact berry, plum jam and baking spice scents come with underlying mineral and earth notes. It hits the palate with a powerfully woven matrix of lush flavors: blueberry, plum, cherry, chocolate, butterscotch and toasted coconut. It's thick, supple and lingering—an ethereal and extraordinary wine.
Wine: Patricia Green Cellars 2016 Estate Vineyard Bonshaw Block Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Aurum, Latin for gold, is the first release of this high-level, small-production wine—a blend of 83% Cabernet Sauvignon, 9% Petit Verdot, 7% Cabernet Franc and 1% Merlot. Spicy clove, black pepper and cigar box highlight a grippy, structured and expansive palate of blackberry and cherry. It's eager for more time in the cellar; enjoy 2025–2035.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2015 Aurum Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: It's hard to imagine a wine with more personality and complexity than this absolutely intriguing mountain-grown Pinot. It continues to surprise and delight in layers of exotic mint, violet, ripe cherry and berry tones that carry through to the vibrant finish. Superb balance comes from firm tannins and ample acidity, with vivid fruit and savory flavors on top of a medium body. Best after 2022.
Wine: Drew 2015 Estate Field Selections Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Even in the midst of the current Oregon Chardonnay renaissance, this bottle stands above and beyond. Concentrated and bursting with lemon drop tang, it's a vibrant, reflective, complex and utterly captivating wine. The estate's focus is on single-vineyard expressions of various Willamette Valley AVAs.
Wine: Lavinea 2015 Lazy River Vineyard Chardonnay (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Sleek, vivid and sophisticated, this wine wows with fresh, concentrated tones. There's a sense of taut balance between acidity and ripeness, with a laser focus of raspberry, cherry and strawberry flavors that extend the finish for minutes. This great wine from a celebrated vineyard is an excellent choice for the cellar, best enjoyed after 2023.
Wine: FEL 2015 Savoy Vineyard Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The back story of this wine could fill a novel; most notable is the fact that Oregon pioneer Dick Erath's Clone 95 is originally from Clos Vougeot cuttings. Here, it's featured with exceptional gravitas, from the opening cherry, fruit leather and compote aromas to the generous assortment of black fruit and sweet spice on the palate. Coffee liqueur notes, a whiff of smoke and a lingering finish make this very special. Drink now–2035.
Wine: Prince Hill 2015 Clone 95 Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This maintains a fine balance between its sugar (145 g/L) and driving acidity. Its lemon drop, black tea, brown sugar, candied citrus and caramel flavors are bright and brilliant. The complexity and sheer deliciousness make it irresistible.
Wine: Armonéa 2014 Wine Country Farm Estate Late Harvest Riesling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This multi-dimensional wine shows off beautiful complexity in the aromas and flavors and creates a very distinctive personality. Black tea, rhubarb and oak spices waft up from the glass and black cherry, clove and bay leaf swirl through the flavors. It's not too full bodied, has a great sense of balance, and good length on the finish. Best after 2022.
Wine: Drew 2015 Morning Dew Ranch Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Domaine Divio
Review: With the third vintage of this wine, Winemaker Bruno Corneaux cements his place among the top rung of Chardonnay producers in Oregon. Using a hands-off approach tied to traditional Burgundian techniques, he has attained complex apple butter, flinty stone, caramel, brioche and roasted chestnut flavors. The cascading details throughout the long finish make drinking this a riveting experience.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2016 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine is practically enchanting with its myriad aromas, lively texture and layers of intricate fruit, spice and woodsy flavors. It offers tones of tart red cherry, rhubarb and cranberry, with enough body and richness to nicely balance those lean characteristics.
Wine: Drew 2015 The Fog-Eater Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine opens with a tropical lushness on the nose before settling onto a tangy palate of citrus and star fruit. It shows balance and grace, with tones of stone and brine.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2015 Olivet Lane Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A focused nose of plump red fruit and baking spice start off this special selection Cabernet, which includes 10% Merlot and 6% Petit Verdot. The palate is zesty in notes of thyme, oregano, blackberry, tobacco and cedar. Over time, it expands broadly and deliciously on the palate. Drink 2020–2034.
Wine: Gainey 2014 Patrick's Vineyard Selection Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine strikes supple fruit tones against broad minerality. Meyer lemon and tangerine flavors are complemented by salty stone and butter. Bright acidity carries the palate as a lovely note of orange blossom persists.
Wine: Gary Farrell 2015 Rochioli-Allen Vineyards Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Exposed to the coast, this crisp white is racy with flavors of salty pretzel and apple skin. It offers impressive weight and viscosity interwoven with juicy acidity, allowing it to stay fresh and focused in the glass. Freshly squeezed lemon shows on the nose and palate, with a touch of brine and supportive oak.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Seascape Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: With less than 6% Petit Verdot, this epic wine is made from the producer's best barrels and is seductive in wild vanilla, red currant and plum. Expansive and succulent on the palate, the oak is well-integrated and supportive, imparting complex notes of cigar box and clove on the lengthy, spicy finish. Enjoy best 2025–2035.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2015 Signature Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Denner
Review: Mellow yet packed with action on the nose, this bottling offers aromas of rose petals, jasmine tea, caramelized black fruit and loam. The mouthfeel is quite full and grippy with tannins, offering big fruity flavors of strawberry, grenadine, lavender and violet. Stunning acidity and a chalky texture carry deep into the finish.
Wine: Denner 2015 Grenache (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tart cranberry and raspberry aromas integrate with wild thyme and baked earth aromas on the nose of this bottling from a biodynamic vineyard that's northwest of the already coastal Sta. Rita Hills. The palate is complex and ever-evolving, with invitingly polished tannins delivering a sense of mulberries and wild berries buried in wet dirt with crushed pine needle and juniper on top.
Wine: Dragonette 2015 Duvarita Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The old vines indicated on this wine's label are 100% Pommard clone planted in 1976. Its compelling aroma gracefully combines flower, fruit, earth and barrel scents. Drinking more like a mature, well-aged wine than a fresh newcomer, it's a bottle for those with with twitchy cork-pulling fingers. Despite generous (50%) new oak, it remains subtly detailed, with beautifully integrated components.
Wine: Dion 2015 Old Vines Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a deft practitioner of the variety, this delivers bold balanced flavors of Meyer lemon, apricot and pear but remains most memorable for its salty gritty undertone of texture and minerality. Bright and supple, it's a delicious wine.
Wine: Dutton-Goldfield 2016 Dutton Ranch Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Firm structure, excellent balance and a profusion of fruit and spice flavors make this wine hard to resist. Moderate tannins give great support to the concentrated black cherry and rhubarb flavors while a sense of richness stops short of excess. Best after 2022.
Wine: FEL 2015 Donnelly Creek Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: A light delicate wine, this features earthy mint, clove and cinnamon stick aromas and flavors within a focused, elegant package of expansive berry and citrus fruit. The acidity is persistent and refreshing, allowing for aspects of brine and flint to shine wildly through.
Wine: Kutch 2016 Bohan Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Aged for 22 months in French oak, this is a substantial red that is soft in polished tannins. The aromas and flavors carry rich layers of dried herb, cedar, cassis and sweet tobacco.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2015 Estate Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Caliza
Review: Concentrated black cherry, coffee cake, roasted beef and violet syrup combine for a very rich, inviting and yet remarkably savory nose on this bottling. It's soft and viscous at first on the sip, with plush flavors of kirsch, vanilla and milk chocolate, then tightens around firm tannins and buoyant acidity. This is a suave attention grabber.
Wine: Caliza 2014 Syrah (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Denner
Review: Nearly opaque in the glass, this bottling shows intense black-currant-syrup aromas along with rocky earth, turned loam, crushed lilacs and black pepper. The mouthfeel is creamy and rich with a mouth-coating texture, combining violet, black plum and, on the finish, tobacco and dried meat flavors.
Wine: Denner 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Muted on the nose at first, this white becomes pretty in white flowers and nutty on the nose, with a character of candied ginger and honey. Preserved lemon flavors add richness to a grittiness of wet stone and quince. Structured and textured, it has ribald ripeness at its core that finds balance in its coastal provenance.
Wine: Hartford Court 2015 Far Coast Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This memorable wine is delightfully heady in fresh aromas of strawberry, raspberry and exotic spices. The palate feels complete, with nice weight and texture. A lift of earth adds intrigue and length to the finish.
Wine: Holdredge 2015 Bucher Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is fruity, fresh and lengthy, with expansive layers of blueberry, strawberry and flowers. From the producer's first estate vineyard, it offers lasting impressions of earth and spice.
Wine: MacRostie 2015 Thale's Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: In honor of the producer's father, who cofounded the winery, this blends 87% Cabernet Franc and 13% Merlot, the two grapes co-fermented. Meaty, it shines in black licorice, toffee, cigar and dusty underbrush, fully in possession of the dominant variety's dried herb and violet notes. Billowy tannins underwrite a powerful concentration and richness finished in mocha. Enjoy best 2025 through 2035.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2015 Gustaf Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This spectacular white opens with a heady mix of baked apple, pineapple and nutmeg—an exotic and concentrated blend of complexity and nuance that begs for additional time. Its gritty texture speaks to a stony mineral element that also compels. Enjoy best 2020 through 2025.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 El Diablo Vineyard Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Underripe raspberries, forest underbrush, moss and Mediterranean herbs combine for a very inviting nose on this bottling. It's fresh and vibrant on the palate, with pure flavors of crushed wild berries, a light menthol character and an engaging structure.
Wine: Samsara 2014 Kessler-Haak Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: A 100% varietal and estate-grown wine from the site made famous in the Paris Tasting, this offers yeasty brioche aromas that lead to crisp expansive flavors of cassis and red currant. The oak is supportive and integrated, adding to the wine's overall earthiness of dried herb and clove, lasting and juicy on the finish.
Wine: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2014 Cask 23 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Falcone
Review: Yet another stellar wine from John and Helen Falcone's modest vineyard in Creston and small family project, this bottling is voluptuous, elegant and layered on the nose with black fruit, purple flowers, sandalwood and hints of soy and cocoa. The palate shows candied red fruit and concentrated black currant, framed by firm yet relenting-as-needed tannins.
Wine: Falcone 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine is light, floral and earthy, blooming in rose petal and feral forest floor. Delicately balanced and focused in acidity, it persists in juicy pomegranate and rhubarb flavors that charm and confound.
Wine: Kutch 2016 Signal Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: The west side of the Salinas Valley takes most of the Pinot Noir glory thanks to the Santa Lucia Highlands, but this bottling shows that the east side, just below Chalone, is also a great place for epic wine. Elegant, supple aromas of tart cherry, red plum and lavender lead into a palate full of pomegranate, raspberry and anise, proving delicious and thirst-quenchingly light.
Wine: Joyce 2016 Gabilan Pinot Noir (Monterey County)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: A wonderfully expressive aroma and mouthfilling flavors bring a lot of excitement to this full-bodied, complex and layered wine from a new producer. From the black tea and wood smoke aromas to the rich black cherry, black plum and clove flavors, it keeps bringing new aspects to the front with each sip. It is big yet beautifully balanced.
Wine: Bailarin 2015 Manchester Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made from own-rooted Pommard clone vines planted in 1979, this offers compelling aromas of tea leaves, citrus oil, bark and other botanicals. Black cherry fruit mixes with dried cherry and cranberry flavors, creating lush complexity all through the palate.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2015 Southeast Block Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From an extreme coastal vineyard just five miles from the sea, this fresh and bright bottling starts with a phenomenally complex nose of candied red cherry, pomegranate and vanilla cut by stemmy impacts of snapped sagebrush, dewy thyme and Kalamata olives. The palate follows suit, with raspberry, eucalyptus oil, juniper berries and more olive tones.
Wine: Peloton 2015 Squire Canyon Vineyard Pinot Noir (San Luis Obispo County)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lovely and plump purple-flower buds of night jasmine and lavender meet with thyme, pink peppercorns and underripe dark berries on the expressive nose of this wine. There is extreme zest to the sip, strong tannic grip and tart boysenberry flavors, with pepper and baking spice on the finish.
Wine: Samuel Louis Smith 2016 Sandstone Terrace Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep, hearty and lavish aromas of nutmeg, boysenberry paste, purple flowers and forest floor show on the nose of this bottling by Matt Dees. It is a thick and masculine expression of Pinot Noir, yet is expertly balanced by bright acidity, polished but firm tannins and an earthy sensibility at its core.
Wine: The Hilt 2015 The Vanguard Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Wild sagebrush, thyme and fennel pollen spice up the tart cherry aromas on the nose of this bottling from 34-year-old vines, which also throws up gingerbread scents as it opens. Framed by solid tannins and well-primed acidity, the palate's tart red fruit is lifted by fennel and wild herbs.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Woodruff Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Regrettably limited in quantity, this outstanding wine offers chewy pink grapefruit notes that dominate the nose, palate and finish. Bitter skin flavors and compelling minerality combine to create a textural, medium-dry wine with superior length and concentration.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Vitae Springs Vineyard Riesling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: A spectacular capturing of an estate-grown site, this substantial age-worthy red is floral and intriguing in flavors of pencil, leather satchel, cedar and dried herb, even a touch of soy burrowing within. A touch of reduction makes it compelling to think about aging. Enjoy best 2024–2034.
Wine: Clos du Val 2014 Three Graces Hirondelle Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: A spectacular capturing of an estate-grown site, this substantial age-worthy red is floral and intriguing in flavors of pencil, leather satchel, cedar and dried herb, even a touch of soy burrowing within. A touch of reduction makes it compelling to think about aging. Enjoy best 2024–2034.
Wine: Clos du Val 2014 Three Graces Hirondelle Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Candied rose petals, pomegranate, hibiscus, ripe red melons and a touch of baking spice show on the nose of this blend of 60% Grenache, 26% Mourvèdre and 14% Syrah. The palate is fresh and lively, with bright red fruit and carnation florality, made more complex and elegant by the dried herbs, pepper, juniper and charred beef finish.
Wine: Clos Solène 2015 Harmonie Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Domaine Divio
Review: This is the ripest of the winery's 2015 Pinots and was given an extra boost (40% rather than 30%) of new oak. Supple and dense, it's packed with deep pomegranate, strawberry and plum flavors, along with orange zest highlights. A toasty, tasty finish brings a licorice note. Drink now and through the 2020s.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2015 Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This concentrated but not overly ripe wine tastes like it's from a cool climate. It has great balance and lots of subtleties to explore. The color is very deep and dark, the aromas recall pencil shavings, earth and roses, and delicious and dry blackberry and dark chocolate emerge on the palate. The vineyard is on a mountainside above Anderson Valley and also produces wonderful Pinot Noir.
Wine: Drew 2015 Valenti Ranch Syrah (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Yountville, Napa, California, US
Review: A 100% varietal wine from the cooler end of the valley, this powerful wine offers tight barrel integration and grippy tannins. Soft, rounded layers of red cherry and cassis add to a lushness of fruit seasoned by savory clove. Enjoy 2025–2035.
Wine: Nickel & Nickel 2015 State Ranch Cabernet Sauvignon (Yountville)

Appellation: Roberts & Rogers
Review: This powerful wine has an inviting bouquet of black cherry and black pepper, dipped in dark chocolate and clove, a well-considered marriage between fruit and spice. Well structured, it has just the right amount of grip, a sure sign of its mountain provenance that adds complexity to the palate.
Wine: Roberts & Rogers 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Samsara
Review: This is an impressive wine, especially for a county blend. Aromas of potpourri, sumac, rose petals, strawberry, tart mulberry and plum make for a very beautiful floral-first nose. Raspberry, cranberry and pomegranate show on the energetic sip, which is framed by a chalky grip and also shows dark turned soil, mint and tarragon elements.
Wine: Samsara 2015 Grenache (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Seductively earthy, this wine is resplendent in Asian spice, citrus and rhubarb. A wealth of red cherry brightens the savory tenacity at its heart, with smooth and delicate layers throughout and a finishing taste of brown sugar.
Wine: Sojourn 2016 Rodgers Creek Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rustic aromas of turned loam, dusty gravel and leather are lifted by carnation, hibiscus and red spice on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. Tight cranberry and raspberry flavors meet with orange peel on the palate, which also includes that earthy streak and floral elements to make a very complete wine.
Wine: Baker & Brain 2014 Le Mistral Vineyard Grenache (Monterey County)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Finished dry and tasting of fresh, mineral-soaked citrus, this is sure to delight fans of phenolic, ageworthy Riesling. Its Meyer lemon and tangerine flavors show outstanding density and purity, with the concentration and length to last for decades. Just a hint of vanilla wafer rounds out the finish. Drink now through 2035 and perhaps beyond.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Meyer Vineyard Riesling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From an organically farmed site managed by go-to viticulturist Phil Coturri, this is a delightfully memorable wine, a mix of blackberry, chocolate and leather that's intensely ripe and robust. Strong in cedar and dried herb accents, it finishes balanced despite its abundance of fruit.
Wine: Carlisle 2015 Rossi Ranch Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Elton's 30-year-old vines weave subtle threads of herb, root and earth around its tight wild strawberry, currant and red licorice flavors. The earthy details run deep, which supports tucking this bottle away for up to a decade.
Wine: Lavinea 2015 Elton Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Just-ripe and robust, this is a relatively big Pinot that tastes rich and feels full bodied, while not overdoing it. Firm tannins and good acidity support complex black tea, black cherry and clove flavors that seem to expand on the palate and linger nicely through he finish. With structure like this it's a good bet to age; best after 2022.
Wine: Drew 2015 Fashauer Vineyards Pinot Noir (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Cohesive aromas of boysenberry, black currant and blackberry meet with thyme and white pepper on the nose of this very dark, intensely scented wine, which also shows a touch of brown sugar. Those dark fruit and peppery spice qualities extend to the sip, where tarragon, tar and beef char flavors also arise.
Wine: Evan's Ranch 2015 Las Brisas Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine offers blackberry and black cherry flavors, with notes of smoke, earth and seashell. Eighteen months aging in 30% new oak barrels adds sandalwood and chocolate scents to the mix.
Wine: Quintet 2015 Lichtenwalter Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Made from the same five rows each year of clone 362, this bottling starts with red-spice aromas of mace and cinnamon and then shows the underlying fresh raspberry and white-pepper tones. The sip starts very peppery, and then offers red currant, carnation, hibiscus and even a flash of red melon.
Wine: Samsara 2014 Larner Vineyard Grenache (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling from the winery's previous owner Chad Melville's family vineyard is strikingly cool climate in expression, starting with loads of rosemary, wild thyme, white pepper, game, charcoal and asphalt—its fruit pushed far to the background. Cracked black pepper and stemmy flavors of green sage and tapenade dominate the palate.
Wine: Samsara 2014 Melville Vineyard Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep tones of blackberry and purple flowers show on the nose of this blend of 46% Cabernet Sauvignon, 19% Merlot, 16% Malbec, 15% Petit Verdot and 4% Cabernet Franc. Bright berry flavors ride a medium-bodied palate and are lifted by dried herbs and a hint of anise. The tannins are chalky on the finish.
Wine: San Simeon 2014 Stormwatch Estate Reserve Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Grippy in tannin, this wine has a substantial weight on the palate that resolves in the glass to highlight flavors of black currant, clove and dried herb. Thick and rich, it has secondary characteristics of tobacco and earthy compost that accentuate its overall savory nature.
Wine: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2014 Fay Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black currant, warm chocolate and sultry spices meet with loamy soil aromas on the nose of this blend of 55% Grenache, 20% Mourvèdre, 10% Syrah, 5% Counoise, 5% Cinsault and 5% Tannat. It's still a very young wine, but the palate offers elderberry, pepper and dried herbs. It's the mouth-coating texture that's most compelling; though very firm now, it will hold this wine for years. Drink 2020–2030.
Wine: Denner 2015 Ditch Digger Red (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a fantastic, high-elevation site, this wine impresses in its broad, muscular power that settles onto notes of black licorice, black cherry and cocoa powder. While not shy in richness or concentration, it remains fresh from supportive acidity.
Wine: Armida 2015 Parmelee-Hill Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling from the estate vineyard, which sits above 1,300 feet, offers roasted blackberry, cassis, caramel and chocolate sauce on the nose. The palate is soft upon entry, with the tannic structure showing itself deeper into the sip, and buoyant acidity presents flavors of fresh dark berry and lively purple flowers.
Wine: Big Basin 2014 Rattlesnake Rock Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Chalk Hill, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This pretty wine is floral and beguiling on the nose. It was blended with 11% Sauvignon Gris and 6% Sauvignon Musqué, with the whole barrel fermented and aged in both French oak and stainless steel drums. Creamy and lush on the palate, the medium body is integrated and complex in highlights of apricot, lime and peach.
Wine: Chalk Hill 2016 Estate Bottled Sauvignon Blanc (Chalk Hill)

Appellation: Domaine Divio
Review: Each of the winery's Pinot Noirs showcases a specific AVA rather than micro-focusing on individual vineyards, blocks or clones. And each is impressive in its own right. Here, the plum and cherry fruit is backed by baking spice and cinnamon toast highlights. Balanced and intense, it finishes with polished tannins and seems closer to peak drinking than the rest of the 2015s.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2015 Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Oak Knoll District, Napa, California, US
Review: Oaky and aromatic in sweet tobacco, this is a juicy, expansive and extracted wine—delicious and big boned, but structured and in balance. Black pepper and dark cherry mingle on the palate, finding complementary sides of an equation. Enjoy best 2024–2034.
Wine: Eleven Eleven 2014 Laki's Vineyard Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Oak Knoll District)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Robust in exotic spicy cardamom and wildflowers, this is from a site the producer considers its most marginal, and it retains a racy on-the-edge character that's hard to pinpoint. Pomegranate, rosemary, sage and clove all appear along a taut tight-grained texture seasoned in irresistible white pepper.
Wine: Kutch 2016 Falstaff Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Kutch
Review: This is made from the producer's several single-vineyard sites, including McDougall, Signal Ridge, Falstaff and Bohan. Concentrated flavors of black cherry and wild vanilla complement an earthy core of dried herb with an undeniable freshness on the midpalate and lengthy finish.
Wine: Kutch 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is one of the more elegant and satisfyingly dark expressions of Pinot Noir in its price range, starting with aromas of sugarplum, hibiscus, dark berries, crushed slate and moist earth. The palate combines rose petals, baked boysenberry and dark cocoa with a strong streak of earthy minerality, all upheld by chalky tannins.
Wine: Lafond 2015 SRH Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Always a top cuvée and good value, this brings tight, sharply defined fruit flavors that run from banana and coconut to peach and papaya, all clustered around a core of blackberry and black cherry. The length and detail are impressive.
Wine: Panther Creek 2015 Lazy River Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From a vineyard 1,700-feet high with 20- to 30-year-old vines, this bottling shows candied raspberry as well as forest undergrowth, olive and dewy thyme on the nose. There's bountiful energy to the sip, which pops with tangy strawberry, oregano, tarragon and pepper spices. A savory smoke quality emerges toward the finish.
Wine: Sante Arcangeli 2016 Split Rail Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Calistoga, Napa, California, US
Review: Billowy, expansive tannins build a foundation of power and structure in this wine, buoyed by bright underlying acidity. Floral and fleshy, it offers substantial flavors of cassis, black cherry and vanilla. It will do well in the cellar; enjoy 2024–2030.
Wine: Summers 2014 Reserve Estate Bottled Cabernet Sauvignon (Calistoga)

Appellation: Atlas Peak, Napa, California, US
Review: From a west-facing block at 1,700-feet in elevation, this youthful, powerful wine is gangly in smoke and oak, with a strong essence of meat. Blueberry cobbler flavors dipped in vanilla are hugely present and ride a concentration of velvety texture.
Wine: Venge 2015 Stagecoach Vineyard Block I-4 Syrah (Atlas Peak)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A beautiful shade of purplish red, this bottling shows cohesive aromas of black plum, strawberry sorbet, vanilla and nutmeg on the nose. The palate is full, rounded and rich in plum jam flavor, but with enough baking spice and a strong crushed rock minerality to add elegance and intrigue.
Wine: Opolo 2016 Mountain Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: A 100% varietal wine, this is spicy and succulent, with expert touches of clove and cinnamon. Roundly rich, it delivers a complexity of long-lasting red plum and cherry flavor accented in dark chocolate and lightly toasted oak.
Wine: Pellet Estate 2015 Pellet Vineyard Merlot (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Light in color and brimming in a white-pepper tone, this is a stemmy and intriguing wine. Fans that prefer a more savory style of Pinot Noir will enjoy this superb offering.
Wine: Red Car 2014 Hagan Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Aged in concrete, this 'wow' of a wine is nuanced in nutty almond, Meyer lemon and crisp grapefruit. Sleek and smooth, it features bright focused acidity that complements the complex savory fruit and hints of lemongrass and ginger.
Wine: Sidebar Cellars 2016 Ritchie Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This powerful wine is a blend of 55% Cabernet Sauvignon, 27% Cabernet Franc, 15% Merlot and 3% Petit Verdot. It's intense yet polished, offering dried herb components around tones of cedar, clove and violet, with background notes of coffee and mocha. The tannins are well integrated and supportive.
Wine: Anderson Conn Valley 2015 Eloge Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a deep, concentrated exploration of the estate vineyard's best lots. Its puréed berry flavors are matched to lush butterscotch, almond paste, oatmeal cookie and milk chocolate notes, all in proportion. It's smooth, sexy and so inviting.
Wine: Anne Amie 2014 Anne Amie Estate Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Charred lamb, peppercorns and wet campfire show on the very cool climate nose of this bottling from a vineyard near Los Alamos. That gamy savory charred touch extends to the palate, where toasted peppercorns, burnt rubber and more lamb-like flavors make for a memorable sip.
Wine: Bellante 2015 Shokrian Vineyard Reserve Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: West Block is the oldest planting at Bethel Heights, dating back to 1977, and as old vine wines often do, this engages with remarkable power and complexity. It's almost Mediterranean in flavor, with sun-dried tomato, black olive, arugula, pepper and green tea notes. Yet, it doesn't lack for fruit; its red and blue fruit core is simply amplified with woodsy, earthy details. Drink now through 2030.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2015 West Block Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Very fruity and also well-balanced, this red-cherry and cranberry scented wine from a small, high-elevation vineyard has medium to full body, lots of freshness in the aromas and flavors and a tangy, lively texture that keeps it feeling refreshing on the palate. It is distinctive and appetizing to sip.
Wine: Drew 2015 Valenti Ranch Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: La Barge
Review: The nose on this estate bottling is thick with blackberry and Concord grape aromas but also fresh, with hints of tarragon and pepper. Texturally smooth, tarry and fuller bodied on the palate, its kirsch flavor is balanced by elements of dried mint and more cracker pepper.
Wine: La Barge 2014 Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Of the winery's many 2015 Pinot Noirs, this is an early standout, with punchy fruit flavors of cranberry and cherry, buoyed by ample natural acidity. The mouthfeel is fresh and spicy, and the finish adds additional chocolate and orange peel highlights.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Crannell Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Stags Leap District, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a robust mineral-laden wine—a true representation of the substantial appellation, so good at offering power and complexity. Quiet layers of toasted coconut and oak are complemented by baked cherry and blackberry along with an unshakable hint of bay leaf. This will do well with more time, so enjoy best 2025–2030.
Wine: Chimney Rock 2015 Estate Grown Cabernet Sauvignon (Stags Leap District)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Supple and sexy, this complex and layered wine pulls together berry, plum and black cherry fruit with subtle hints of mushroom, dried leaves and graphite. Native yeast fermentation adds further textural detail, and the 50% new oak is suitably restrained.
Wine: Dion 2014 115 West Limited Release Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From an ocean view site high above 1,000-feet in elevation, this wine is fresh and fruity, shining in wild strawberry and rose petal, with a thickness to the tannin that belies its overall elegance and spark. Notes of forest floor, blueberry and wild Asian five spice trickle through quietly along a velvety seductive texture of balance.
Wine: Kutch 2016 McDougall Ranch Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Bright black-cherry juice meets rich black-plum sauce and chocolate aromas on the nose of this blend of 37% Cabernet Franc, 29% Petit Verdot, 28% Cabernet Sauvignon and 6% Malbec. It's thick, lavish and chalky in feel, with bright flavors of kirsch and milk chocolate that lead into a hint of fudge on the finish.
Wine: Niner 2014 Fog Catcher Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This new project from Oregon pioneer Dick Erath and his friend and fellow winemaker Laurent Montalieu features the seminal vineyard. What a joy to see these exceptional grapes getting the star treatment they deserve. This stunningly aromatic reserve bottling brings clover and dusty spice notes, with well-layered black cherry, cola, sweet spice and molasses flavors. Even better on the second day, it's a wine to enjoy now through the next decade.
Wine: Prince Hill 2015 Estate Reserve Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: A very distinctive thread of pure fruit flavor winds through this full-bodied wine from the first sip through the lingering finish. It smells like lilac, cloves and blackberry jam and tastes full, rich and ripe, while a layer of fine-grained tannins adds structure. A hint of dark chocolate echoes on the finish.
Wine: Renwood 2015 Story Vineyard Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Plump, rounded and fresh boysenberry aromas meet with pepper, rose petals, coffee bean, tobacco and the slightest hint of game on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. It's bright and zesty on the palate, with dewy thyme and cracked peppercorns that spice up the tart boysenberry backdrop.
Wine: Samsara 2014 Zotovich Vineyard Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Ultima Tulie
Review: This blend of 65% Syrah and 35% Grenache shows crushed violets, candied black currant and a touch of earthy asphalt on the nose. It's very smooth on the palate with well-integrated flavors of black plum and purple flowers that ride soft massaged tannins.
Wine: Ultima Tulie 2014 Red (Central Coast)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This winery's Chardonnays are simply outstanding, from top to bottom. And as the least expensive in the range, this bottling is one to stockpile by the case. Sleek, supple and dense, it matches immaculate stone fruit flavors to bright acidity and pretty barrel toast. Balanced, rich and penetrating, it stands up nicely to wines that cost three times as much.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2015 Estate Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep aromas of mulberry syrup are cut by pine needles and baking spice on the nose of this single-vineyard expression by renowned vintner Bradley Brown from a famed vineyard near Watsonville. Kalamata olives show strong on the palate, alongside berry syrup, green sage, thyme and a stemmy hint of bell pepper.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Alfaro Family Vineyard Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From Alban clone vines on Bradley Brown's 1,300-foot-high estate vineyard and aged in both amphora and oak, this epic bottling shows clean lines of dried lemon skin, lemon curd, pear cream and a hint of pineapple on the nose. The generous and youthful palate is clean and grippy with flavors of honeysuckle, lemon and pear, framed by bright acid. It will last for years.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Homestead Block Roussanne (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Domaine Divio
Review: Along with this wine's complex bramble, berry and red plum flavors come striking cinnamon, pepper and almond paste highlights. Released after one year in 30% new French oak and another in bottle, it does a deep dive into a spicy, lingering finish. At a modest price, it's one of the top Pinots in Oregon.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2015 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Vanilla, baked red cherries, hibiscus and gingerbread show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression by Russell Joyce. The palate is light in structure yet offers all that's needed for enjoyment: cherry, spice and gravelly minerality, buoyant acidity. It is easy and delicious.
Wine: Joyce 2016 Tondre Grapefield Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Plush, lush and fruit-forward on the nose, this Bordeaux-style red blend shows plump black plum, strawberry, cocoa, vanilla and crushed rock aromas. The palate is lush in dark fruit flavors and touches of espresso and cocoa, with strong acidity and firm tannins offering support. Drink 2019–2035.
Wine: Opolo 2015 Rhapsody Reserve Collection Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Yountville, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a tightly wound wine, with a focused, freshly compacted core of vanilla, red cherry, cassis and toasty oak. Bright fruit tones and bright acidity help keep the palate buoyant and alive.
Wine: Piña 2014 Wolff Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Yountville)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This wine from four different vineyards shows concentration and richness, starting with aromas of mulberry paste, turned loam, cardamom and nutmeg. Those spices show on the palate as well, where concentrated hibiscus syrup and condensed rose petals make for a hearty yet uplifting sip.
Wine: Sante Arcangeli 2016 Integrato Barrel Selection Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Toasted hazelnuts and preserved lemons show on the nose of this bottling, which is a tiny bit funky but grows more compelling and clean the longer it sits open. Medium in weight and body on the palate, it's a very savory white wine, with sea salt, lemon peels, nut oil, dried white flower and dried peach flavors. The texture is enveloping.
Wine: Site 2014 Stolpman Vineyard Roussanne (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: Complex, layered and quietly intense, this Tempranillo blend is packed with flavor, and has a generous mouth-coating texture laced with fine-grained tannins. It shows a high degree of concentration, from the smoky, beefy, grilled fruit aromas to deep and dark cherry and black-currant flavors. Best after 2022.
Wine: Six Sigma Ranch 2013 Diamond Mine Cuvée Red (Lake County)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Baked red cherry, dried fennel, wild mint and riverbed aromas show on the nose of this bottling by Santa Barbara County-based Grenache specialist Angela Osborne. Marjoram, oregano and thyme all play on the nose, as do hints of cracked pepper, decorating the supple strawberry core. Strong tannins uphold the finish.
Wine: A Tribute to Grace 2015 Provisor Vineyard Grenache (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This vintage is already in its prime drinking window, and the 16 months aging in 38% new oak has paid off, with lovely sea salt-caramel chocolate notes. Its ripe Bing cherry fruit is dusted with cinnamon and baking spice, bringing further nuances of cola, coffee and Bourbon barrel on the finish.
Wine: Anne Amie 2014 Two Estates Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Stylish and tightly sculpted, this brings zippy raspberry fruit front and center, morphing into chocolatey cherry flavor as it opens. It's sharp and well defined, with a balanced framework of acidity and tannin that carries it into an extended finish. It's deliciously youthful but has the structure to cellar through 2026.
Wine: Armonéa 2014 Russell Grooters Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This is an outstanding, nervy, rather lean wine that is quite appetizing and well balanced. It combines tart cherry and cranberry aromas with rhubarb, black tea and mushroom flavors that are fascinating to taste. Medium body and a smooth texture are bolstered by moderate tannins for a very food-friendly mouthfeel.
Wine: Bailarin 2014 Manchester Ridge Vineyard Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Concentrated, nearly syrupy aromas of blackberry and black currant are lifted by black pepper, Chinese five spice, charred beef and complex mint qualities on the elegant nose of this bottling. A slow-simmering combination of acid and tannins slowly reveal fresh black fruit, charred vanilla and roasted fig flavors. It's still a young wine, so drink 2019–2030.
Wine: Bellante 2015 Jack McGinley Vineyard Reserve Syrah (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This robust, muscular wine is packed with black cherry fruit. New French oak swathes the outstanding fruit in comforting flavors of mocha and butterscotch. It's smooth and seductive, with a kiss of dark chocolate on the finish.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Juniper, pine needle and sandalwood aromas decorate the dark cranberry fruit on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard 2,200-feet above the eastern Salinas Valley. The 55% whole cluster fermentation contributes to the woody side of the grape on the palate, where herbal and forest flavors are sprinkled on the baked raspberry fruit.
Wine: Big Basin 2015 Coastview Vineyard Pinot Noir (Monterey County)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the famous Sonoma Valley site farmed by the same family since 1895, this includes 6% Alicante Bouschet and a touch of Petite Sirah from nearby Rossi Ranch (another of the producer's vineyard designates). Juicy, broad and likably round and soft, it features a grittiness of black cherry and pomegranate.
Wine: Carlisle 2015 Pagani Ranch Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: As in 2014, this reserve bottling uses all estate fruit, 85% whole cluster fermentation and native yeasts. It's concentrated and complex, with black cherry, cola, iron and coffee highlights. The various components are deftly threaded into a textural, compelling package with a decade of life ahead.
Wine: Le Cadeau 2015 Trajet Reserve Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Domaine Divio
Review: This young-drinking wine offers tart cranberry and raspberry flavors that are as concentrated and intense as fruit purée. There are aromatic hints of lavender and compost, as well as a sprinkling of black pepper and overripe tannins.
Wine: Domaine Divio 2015 Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: St. Helena, Napa, California, US
Review: Touches of Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Petit Verdot figure into the mix of this impressive wine, a study in reductive oak and cherry vanilla. Substantial concentration belies an underlying foundation of acidity, that lingers and supports flashes of cinnamon and black cherry.
Wine: Ehlers Estate 2015 1886 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly wound, this bottling from one of the region's dry-farmed vineyards shows lime skin, lemongrass and Meyer lemon pith on the nose. The palate is loaded with fresh, tart flavors of wild lime and sea shells, wrapped in a chalky texture and jam-packed with textural intrigue and depth.
Wine: Foxen 2016 Tinaquaic Vineyard Estate Grown Dry Farmed Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Very light in the glass, this blend of McGinley and Grassini vineyards, much of which spent time in cigar-shaped barrels, shows reserved aromas of wet stone, soft peach blossom, subtle apple and crushed chalk on the nose. The palate is vibrant with crisp clean pure flavors of citrus, cherimoya and poached pear, with a unique touch of green tea and scallions toward the finish.
Wine: Margerum 2016 D Sauvignon Blanc (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Eagle Peak, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Generous dark-fruit flavors join leafy earthy complexities in this very rich and full-bodied wine. It has a soft expansive mouthfeel, moderate tannins and a great sense of concentration on the palate and through the long finish.
Wine: Masút 2016 Estate Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eagle Peak)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Aromas like iron, earth and cherries lead to good rich fruit flavors in this well-balanced and medium-bodied wine. Energized by firm tannins and lively acidity, it matches them with ripe cherry and raspberry flavors and a tantalizing spiciness that lasts through the finish.
Wine: Noceto 2015 Hillside Sangiovese (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: San Luis Obispo County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This is an extremely fresh, vibrant and lovely wine that should be enjoyed in its utter youth. Clean, chalky and stony aromas of crushed oyster shells, wet shaved marble and the lightest hints of nectarine lead into a racy, mouthwatering palate of wet concrete, grapefruit rind and Gravenstein apple flesh.
Wine: Peloton 2016 Spanish Springs Vineyard Pinot Grigio (San Luis Obispo County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This relatively new mid-level Pinot Noir is a mix of estate and purchased grapes aged for almost a year in one third new oak barrels. It's firm, compact and juicy, with red fruit set in an aromatic frame of crushed raspberry, lavender and thyme notes.
Wine: Ponzi 2015 Classico Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: The Eyrie Vineyards
Review: From the winery that introduced Pinot Gris to America comes another gem. Pungent aromas suggesting citrus oil and petrol lead to a complex and detailed palate stacked with grapefruit, lemon and pineapple flavors. Leesy minerality contributes to a long, clean, immaculate finish. It would be hard to find a better or more affordable all-purpose summer white.
Wine: The Eyrie Vineyards 2016 Pinot Gris (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Equal parts Syrah, Mourvèdre and Grenache, this was aged in neutral oak. Its aroma intoxicates with piercingly pure chopped parsley, green olive, dried flower, bacon fat, red plum, white pepper, smoke and moist earth notes. The flavors live up to the hype; they're lithe and light but full of fruit and savory notes, culminating in a bacon fat- and fresh herb-inflected finish. It drinks well now but should only improve with time in the bottle. Best after 2021.
Wine: W.T. Vintners 2015 Boushey Vineyard Rhône Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine is full bodied and immediately enjoyable, with berry and cherry flavors gently wrapped in baking spice. Cocoa, coffee and cinnamon highlights reflect its 10 months aging in one quarter new French oak.
Wine: 51 Weeks 2015 Voetjes Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's not a lot of Gamay Noir in Oregon, but this goes right to the head of the class. Deep blue-purple in hue, it's a mouthful of blueberry jam, with fine tannins and a finishing lick of black tea. Additional black olive and smoked almond details add to the complexity.
Wine: Anne Amie 2015 Twelve Oaks Estate Gamay Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: La Barge
Review: Candied pomegranate and grenadine aromas are lifted by mace and cinnamon on the nose of this bottling from a newer project whose winery sits on the far west end of the appellation. Lighter in body, flavors of red berries, thyme and dried sage ride a fascinating texture into an extended finish.
Wine: La Barge 2015 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The top-tier vineyard planted in 1981 is showcased here in a complex mix of rhubarb, strawberry and raspberry jam flavors, with subtle inflections of stem and dried leaves. Those flavors soak the palate, lingering through a breakfast teea-laced finish.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Temperance Hill Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Some residual sugar accents this wine's lush orange, peach and papaya flavors. Further details emerge as it opens: vanilla wafer, butter cookie, apple pie. It's complex and thoroughly delicious now but will age beautifully for many years.
Wine: Brooks 2016 Orchard Fold Vineyard Riesling (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Cowhorn
Review: This biodynamic producer excels at Viognier, and this vintage is especially succulent, with a juicy and compelling mix of stone fruit, Meyer lemon and tangerine flavors. Impeccably balanced, textured and long, with citrus rind highlights, it spent just four months in 30% new oak. Its flavors remain clean and clear all the way through a delicious finish.
Wine: Cowhorn 2016 Viognier (Applegate Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Thick and dark in the glass, there are compelling aromas of crushed rocks, concentrated black currants and slight purple flowers on the somewhat reserved nose of this blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Petit Verdot and 15% Merlot. The palate combines tobacco, anise and dried herbs with freshly pressed blackberry. The tannins are firm, upright and need some time. Drink 2020–2035.
Wine: Denner 2015 Mother of Exiles Red (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: As with the previous vintage, this wine is showing premature signs of aging, despite its relative youth. The upside is that it requires no further cellaring for immediate enjoyment, unlike many of the 2015s. Its cherry fruit is soft and lush, resting in a spicy sea of ginger, allspice and sweet baking spice notes.
Wine: Dion 2015 Winemaker's Reserve Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's an oily petrol kick to the nose of this Bordeaux-like single vineyard expression, atop a base of apple syrup and grapefruit pith. The oily nature extends to the palate, where wafts of smoke envelop pithy flavors of citrus skin and a compelling texture. It's an unctuous, compelling take on the grape for a region usually focused on freshness.
Wine: Dragonette 2015 Vogelzang Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is superconcentrated, dense and impactful. It's stacked with stone fruit flavors and a buttery bite of brioche. Eighteen months' aging in 30% new French oak has contributed a toasted nut note that dominates the finish.
Wine: Flâneur 2015 X-Novo Vineyard Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
