Review: Tight, bright and refreshing on the nose, this very pale Grenache-based rosé shows strawberry and wet river stones on the nose. There's an immense grip to the sip, with pithy lime rinds framing the tightly wound strawberry flavors that carry far into the finish. Beware the ease with which it vanishes.
Wine: Margerum 2017 Riviera Rosé (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: Fully ripe, robust black fruit brims along a seamless and intense core of spicy tobacco, black pepper and plum highlights in this wine. A dusting of tannins carries a spark of cocoa powder on the finish.
Wine: Piña 2014 Firehouse Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Rutherford)

Appellation: Red Car
Review: Light and earthy, this is made in a restrained style that shows focused, fresh flavors of citrus, cherry and pomegranate. Acid-driven and nuanced on the midpalate in white pepper and cardamom, the finish brings a rush of fruit flavors.
Wine: Red Car 2014 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine has the brambly, wild berry character of Zinfandel in spades. Combine that signature flavor with good balance, medium to full body and a mildly tannic texture, and a well-crafted, distinctive wine is the result. Aged in 40% new French oak, it is not overtly spicy, but finds great flavor balance.
Wine: Renwood 2015 Special Reserve Grandpère Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: About as big and bold as they come, this wine is extraordinary. An extra deep color and unusually saturated flavors meet a full body and a thick but soft layer of tannins that provide good grip on the palate and help to balance the richness and ripeness of the blackberry and blueberry compote flavors.
Wine: Sentivo 2013 Estate Reserve Syrah (El Dorado)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: From one of the state's top Syrah sites, this 50% whole cluster wine draws you in with captivating notes of fresh and dried herb, ground black pepper, iron, crushed flower, green olive, cherry and bacon fat. Its fruit and savory flavors are palate-coating but still sleek, pure and vibrant. A meaty finish caps it off. Give it time to open up, and it's flat out delicious.
Wine: W.T. Vintners 2015 Boushey Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Edging out its companions in 2015, the Natasha Block bottling offers a concentrated mash-up of berry, blood oranges and melon flavors. Though the listed alcohol is relatively high for the region, it doesn't intrude on the terrific fruit, which is in balance and delicious already.
Wine: Youngberg Hill Vineyards 2015 Natasha Block Pinot Noir (McMinnville)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Blackberry syrup, roasted cocoa and a hint of coffee show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard that the Gainey family owns far west of and more coastal than their primary estate. The energetic palate shows solid black-fruit flavors that are both lush and tart, lifted by lavender and framed by fresh acidity and strong tannins.
Wine: Evan's Ranch 2015 Lone Oak Syrah (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Anderson Valley, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Beautifully fruity and focused, this medium-bodied wine is underpinned by good acidity and accented with light butter and almond flavors to go along with the vivid lemon and crisp apple notes. Fine balance and the pure fruit expression make it special.
Wine: FEL 2015 Savoy Vineyard Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dense and richly interwoven, this wine is made in a substantial style, with polished yet hearty tannins that need time to resolve in its youth. Black licorice and cherry meet nicely in the middle to offer well-balanced fruit and spice tones.
Wine: Holdredge 2015 Rolling Thunder Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This pungent, detailed wine offers peppery raspberry and cherry flavors. It has an herbal side that suggests thyme, and the lingering finish adds a streak of Dr. Pepper. Aged a year in one third new oak, it's drinking well and shows the fruit appeal of the vintage.
Wine: King Estate 2014 Antiquum Vineyards Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lemon peels, sea salt, hazelnut and honeysuckle aromas play up the more voluptuous side of Chardonnay, and hint at marshmallow without going so far. The palate is surprisingly zippy with acid and Meyer lemon zest, but also shows richer hints of browned butter and toasted almond toward the finish. It's a crowd-pleaser for many tastes.
Wine: Lafond 2016 SRH Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rose petals, cola, macerated wild cherry and cherry pits meet with gravel and crushed brick minerality on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard just on the east side of Highway 101 south of Orcutt. The palate is fresh and mineral-driven, with turned earth, gravel and strong acid taking center stage over the light-red-fruit flavors.
Wine: A Tribute to Grace 2015 Murmur Vineyard Grenache (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Named for the windy corridor that gives the estate fruit its grip and concentration, this packs its black cherry and cassis flavors with compelling highlights. Pepper, cedar and sandalwood accents linger and penetrate the core of dark fruit. It spent 14 months in 45% new French oak.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2015 Aeolian Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This dessert bottling kicks off with the boozy aromas of port, but also shows lively fresh fruit reminiscent of concentrated blackberry syrup with hints of cola spice. It hits the palate with undeniable sweetness, but then come strong sandalwood and cedar flavors and a rush of vanilla and clove. It is soft while penetrating, like a dagger under silk lace.
Wine: Cottonwood Canyon 2008 Estate Dessert Syrah (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Juicy and bright in brooding dark cherry and strawberry, this wine persists in earthy dried herb and dry toasted tannins. The full-bodied concentration is well-managed and intriguingly complex.
Wine: Etude 2015 Ellenbach Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Like a walk through a chaparral thicket, this bottling shows tons of herbal influence, with dried oregano, thyme and sage sprinkled atop tones of red plum and hibiscus. Those herbs also decorate the palate's cranberry core, which also offers a roasted meat flavor.
Wine: Peachy Canyon 2015 Snow Zinfandel (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Samsara
Review: Savory aromas of roasted pork in a black-plum reduction combine with tar and loads of black pepper on the nose of this county blend. Purple flower and Concord grape flavors are prevalent on the sip, which is ready to drink now but structured to last awhile.
Wine: Samsara 2015 Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Juicy and velvety in texture, this wine shows a wealth of full-bodied oak and tannin up front that settles into lovely characteristics of rose petal, strawberry, rhubarb and forest floor. The finish is lengthy and robust.
Wine: Sojourn 2016 Gap's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Vitesse
Review: This wine is pretty in aromatics of cassis and violet, and soft and approachable on the complex palate. Full bodied, it's able to find a balance between etched flavors of cinnamon, plum and cherry that persist on a lasting grip of integrated tannin.
Wine: Vitesse 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Salty seasonings of wet stone ride along a brawny texture of mineral-laden earthiness and tightly wound layers of green apple in this lovely lush white. Made in small amounts it shows balance and graceful elegance.
Wine: Blue Farm 2015 Laceroni Vineyard Estate Farmed Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Brooks
Review: The most affordable and widely available Riesling in the Brooks lineup, this is an especially appealing cuvée in 2016. It's fragrant and inviting, with orange blossom, lemon zest and grapefruit components. That tangy fruit is layered and textural, with a phenolic snap. It's a blend sourced from a number of unspecified old vine sites.
Wine: Brooks 2016 Riesling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Lush marionberry, boysenberry, blueberry and plum flavors are on display here, with subtle hints of pepper. Aged in 30% new French oak, it finishes with cocoa and vanilla custard notes.
Wine: Lavinea 2015 Lazy River Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Peter Stolpman is up to some wacky stuff on his family estate, with eye-opening and delicious results. Cloudy, cranberry-juice-red in the glass, this starts with rustic, lively aromas of tangy strawberry, plum, fruit punch and crushed spice. Then the zingy palate, which is nearly effervescent, picks up with pomegranate, citrus rind and white pepper. It goes down too easy.
Wine: Combe 2016 Stolpman Vineyards Trousseau (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Floral, savory aromas and good, juicy red and black-cherry flavors are lifted by racy acidity and moderate tannins in this medium-bodied wine. It has a tangy lip-smacking texture, fine balance and reveals more nuances with each sip. Best after 2022.
Wine: Drew 2016 Mid-Elevation Pinot Noir (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a fresh, exotic and beguiling wine, with youthful tannins and nice concentration. The rich, bold flavors are marked by cherry, cola and a touch of smoky char that lead to highlights of clove and forest floor.
Wine: Holdredge 2015 Judgment Tree Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a soft, succulent wine that's focused and full bodied, richly rewarding in perfumed aromas of rose and lavender. Made in tiny amounts, it offers a depth of concentrated blueberry and huckleberry that's entirely delicious.
Wine: Holdredge 2015 The True Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Elegant aromas of black raspberry, blueberry, violets and black pepper show on the nose of this bottling, which comes from grapes located adjacent to the historic Ridge winery. Sandalwood frames the palate, which offers the region's typical herb and spice-rack flavors atop a rounded blackberry core. The tannins are firm now, and need some time to resolve.
Wine: I. Brand & Family 2014 Monte Bello Road Cabernet Sauvignon (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: La Barge
Review: Surprisingly concentrated in style for such a coastal vineyard, this bottling shows boysenberry syrup, black-plum pudding and spice cake on the nose. The palate is intense with dark fruits of blueberry and roasted black plum, with nutmeg and gingerbread flavors as well as firm tannins framing it all.
Wine: La Barge 2014 Grenache (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: The third vintage of this bottling from the producer's cool-climate site shows exotic and subdued undertones of wood, dried herb and white pepper. The palate is substantial yet softly layered.
Wine: Marimar Estate 2014 Don Miguel Vineyard Estate Grown & Bottled Unfiltered Syrah (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Not many California Sangioveses are this good. It's impressive how a core of great fruit flavor fills up this well-balanced and full-bodied wine from the first whiff to the lingering finish. It starts with cinnamon, nutmeg and black-cherry aromas, brings clove and more cherry on the palate and wraps it all in a texture of velvety tannins.
Wine: Naggiar 2015 Estate Grown Sangiovese (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The top-notch vineyard delivers a big, juicy mouthful of ripe strawberry and raspberry fruit in this wine. Its refreshing acidity is a fine counterpoint to the barrel flavors from time spent in 38% new French oak. Still young and ageworthy, it's already showing fine balance and proportion.
Wine: Panther Creek 2015 Carter Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Ballard Canyon, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Roasted black currant, char and a hint of pepper show on the deep, dark, elegant and yet somewhat reserved nose of this bottling. There's a flash of black cherry on the tip of the sip and then comes waves of black pepper and roasted beef. The texture is full and grippy, with tangy acidity and a long peppery finish.
Wine: Potek 2013 Tierra Alta Syrah (Ballard Canyon)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This is a firmly textured, well-balanced wine that offers aromas of black pepper and grilled beef. The palate brings a fresh blackberry flavor, with a gripping mouthfeel framed by good tannins. Made from 100% Zinfandel, it comes off dry and concentrated. Best after 2023.
Wine: Renwood 2015 Jack Rabbit Flat Vineyard Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The vines used here date back to the 1970s, yielding an edgy wine loaded with strong grapefruit, lemon oil and orange peel flavors. Those citrus highlights surround a core of red berry fruit, with ample details and texture. Its subtlety requires a little extra attention, which it will reward in spades.
Wine: Ruby 2015 Estate Blend Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Tightly wound aromas of lemon pith, buttered toast and honeysuckle make for a familiar and pristine entry to this bottling from a single vineyard that sits at 1,700 feet. There's a strong Chablis-like grip to the tip of the sip, leading into crisp Pink Lady apple, Asian pear and, toward the finish, flashes of pineapple and more opulent fruit.
Wine: Sante Arcangeli 2016 Split Rail Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This is a rich, concentrated and ripe wine, but one that doesn't go over the top. It offers enticing aromas of blackberry and dark chocolate, followed by satisfying blueberry and espresso flavors, with a firm texture from a healthy layering of fine-grained tannins.
Wine: Sentivo 2012 Estate Syrah (El Dorado)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: From estate-grown, barrel-fermented grapes, this lovely wine appeals to all the senses. Its sunset hue is striking, as is the fine bead and inviting cherry and cocoa aromas. On the palate, it's an elegant and sophisticated sparkler with tart cherry fruit and bracing minerality.
Wine: Soter 2013 Mineral Springs Vineyard Brut Rosé Sparkling (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Textbook
Review: Dark gold in color, this is an inviting white wine, light and fresh with highlights of peach Melba and honeysuckle. Tahitian vanilla adds a note of balanced richness that rewards the palate with substance and grace.
Wine: Textbook 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: The winery's first Grenache from this esteemed vineyard, this was aged in neutral French oak. It's expressive in aroma, with flower, mountain strawberry, green olive, white pepper and smoked meat notes that become more prominent over time. The palate is full-flavored but still elegant, with fruit and savory notes that lead to a peppery finish.
Wine: W.T. Vintners 2015 Boushey Vineyard Grenache (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: A Tribute to Grace
Review: This is the most affordable and easiest-to-find take on Angela Osborne's uniquely light style of Grenache. Cranberry, hibiscus and crushed gravel show on the nose, while the palate carries her typically lively texture, persistent acidity and fresh flavors of pressed raspberries.
Wine: A Tribute to Grace 2016 Grenache (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine offers expansive aromas of lavender and rose on the nose. Ripe plum, fig and cassis mark the softly textured palate, with a rich finish almost like a late-harvest wine.
Wine: Andis 2015 Indian Creek Vineyard Primitivo (Amador County)

Appellation: Brandborg
Review: This late release is sourced from a single vineyard and shows extraordinary focus. Even at this age it remains tightly wound, with tart raspberry fruit streaked with ground coffee and dark chocolate notes.
Wine: Brandborg 2013 Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is an abundantly earthy wine, full of meat and black and white pepper. Cedar, pencil shavings and big-boned black cherry add to the intrigue, with a hint of black olive and substantial tannin that suggest aging. Enjoy best 2025 through 2028.
Wine: Carlisle 2015 Bedrock Vineyard Zinfandel (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the producer's home vineyard in the heart of the appellation, this is dusty in plum, raspberry, black licorice and tobacco, with a lift of floral aromatics and grippy structure. It includes 12% mixed black and white varieties, from Grand Noir to Malvasia.
Wine: Carlisle 2015 Carlisle Vineyard Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This blend of the winery's four best barrels spent 18 months in half new oak. Although it has the same firm, tannic structure as the entry-level 2014, it's a bit deeper and riper, with cassis, black olive, espresso and dark chocolate notes.
Wine: Carlton Hill 2014 Estate Reserve Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine from a respected vineyard in the Dundee Hills brings pinpoint focus to its just-ripe wild berry flavors. Its astringency is more the result of lemony acids than dusty tannins, and its caramel chocolate highlights the result of aging in 30% new French oak.
Wine: Lavinea 2015 Nysa Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Stewed pomegranates and red currants are lifted by vanilla and baking spice on the nose of this blend that's named after the “heart of the vineyard.” Rounded cherry and mulberry flavors show on the palate, which gains complexity from the licorice and red-flower flavors. This is easy drinking and boasts smooth tannins.
Wine: Le Vigne 2015 Cuore Della Vigna Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Lorimar
Review: This new winery is showing a lot of potential, and this bottling, which includes 5% Petite Sirah, is the strongest showing yet. Aromas of fresh-pressed boysenberry, licorice and baking spice head into a weighty palate loaded with mouth-coating polished tannins. The stewed berry and spice-cake flavors finish clean.
Wine: Lorimar 2014 Syrah (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This young, fresh and delicious wine was neither fined nor filtered and was fermented with native yeasts. Barrel aging (30% new) has resulted in a toastiness that frames its spicy raspberry jam flavors. The texture, balance and finish are spot-on.
Wine: Furioso 2016 La Linea Furioso Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe cherry fruit is cut by touches of rust and turned soil on the inviting nose of this bottling. The mouthfeel is thick and grippy, carrying rounded berry flavors, a hint of baking spice and some dried thyme on the back end.
Wine: Hahn 2016 SLH Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Part of an expanding portfolio from NW Wine Company, this is a creamy, leesy take on Pinot Gris. Its rich fruit flavors bring jicama, white peach and cinnamon-dusted apple to mind, with a soft finish reminiscent of unsalted whipped butter. Overall, this delivers exceptional style and grace.
Wine: Northwest Ridge 2016 8 Barrel Pinot Gris (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This reserve bottling takes some time to open up, but is quite elegant when it arrives. Aromas of muddy earth and dark fruit lead into a dense, lavish palate framed by firm tannins. Red plum and strawberry sorbet flavors rise above the loamy, clay-like elements at the core. Cocoa spice and a soft texture unfold with patience.
Wine: Opolo 2015 Forte Reserve Collection Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Ponzi's Tavola consistently out-performs reserve-level wines from elsewhere. Credit the outstanding vineyard sources, which include Ponzi's Avellana vineyard, and of course the skillful winemaking, which begins with native yeast fermentation. It was aged 11 months in 20% new French oak and has scents and flavors of Bourbon tea, cinnamon spice and black cherry fruit. There's plenty of power and a clean, fresh finish.
Wine: Ponzi 2016 Tavola Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: With a bright, fresh and floral nose, this is a succulent and pleasurable wine, elegant and balanced, the fruit components layered in cherry, raspberry and strawberry.
Wine: River Road 2016 Stephanie's Cuvée Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Still quite young, this offers concentrated raspberry fruit, with tangerine highlights. The acidity is spot-on, emphasizing the bright, ripe fruit, held in check by 10 months' aging in 10% new French oak.
Wine: Ruby 2016 Hendricks Legacy Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Samsara
Review: There's a dark red-fruit element that starts the deep nose of this wine, but then come brighter red cherries, carnation and vanilla spice. Tart red cherries and nutmeg show on the sip, where a grippy texture and just enough acidity make for a solid appellation blend.
Wine: Samsara 2014 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This young wine is tight and tart, with the characteristic McMinnville underpinnings of cement and wet stone. The structure and balance are in fine proportion; it just needs more bottle age to unwind. Decant or cellar another year or two before opening.
Wine: Sol Vie 2015 Hyland Vineyard Pinot Noir (McMinnville)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Stillwater Creek, Upland, Boushey and Destiny Ridge vineyards comprise equal parts of this 100% varietal wine. Light in color, it has pleasing aromas that suggest dried and fresh herb, along with toasty spice, cherry and moist earth. Full, luscious, pure cherry flavors are followed by a lingering finish. It's a winner.
Wine: Structure 2015 Foundation Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yountville, Napa, California, US
Review: Robust in tobacco, cocoa powder and black currant, this is a structured, integrated and ultimately balanced wine, softened by small additions of Merlot and Petit Verdot. It shows structure and grace within a wall of blackberry and vanilla.
Wine: Tamber Bey 2014 Deux Chevaux Cabernet Sauvignon (Yountville)

Appellation: Verve
Review: With a waxy, floral nose, this wine is made in a big style with power and concentration, its fruit profile marked by a wealth of raspberry and dark cherry. Present oak is spiked in persistent spice.
Wine: Verve 2015 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Fermented in a single 600-liter barrel, this reserve-level wine leads with intense, sharp-toned concentration. Its bright apple and peach fruit morphs into softer banana flavors, and a light touch of toast carries into the finish. A bit more bottle age will help; drink 2020–2025.
Wine: Vidon Vineyard 2016 Apollo Chardonnay (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Vie Winery
Review: This wine yields ripe citrus, melon and vanilla aromas, along with waxy minerally notes that add delicious complexity. It's technically light-bodied in terms of alcohol but fills out the palate nicely and lingers on the finish, echoing oak spice and mineral tones.
Wine: Vie Winery 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Lake County)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aged in stainless steel and fermented with native yeasts, this has freshly crushed cranberry, raspberry and lemon peel aromas and pure flavors that undulate across the palate with compelling texture. Fresh raspberry notes persist on the tart finish. It's flat-out delicious and should shine at the dinner table.
Wine: Viola 2016 Barbera d'Alder Alder Ridge Vineyard Barbera (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Blue Victorian Winery
Review: Lively fruit flavors and a little richness in the texture make a good combination for this full-bodied wine that tastes lightly oaky while balanced by a flood of grapefruit and lime. Made with 15% new oak and 8% Verdelho grapes, It is mouth filling and refreshing at the same time, which is a great combination.
Wine: Blue Victorian Winery 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Suisun Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This estate reserve is produced from biodynamic grapes. It's sweet and spicy, with concentrated raspberry fruit, baking spice and hints of toasted coconut. A touch riper than the previous vintage, it's already drinking well.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Rastaban Brooks Estate Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Placer County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Ripe tropical fruit in the aroma, fresh clean flavors and a rich texture buoyed by good acidity make this medium-bodied wine easy to like. Barrel-fermented in mostly neutral oak, it's smooth and fairly broad on the palate, and stays nice and dry and firm on the finish.
Wine: Carol Shelton 2016 Wild Thing Damiano Vineyard Viognier (Placer County)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the famous site along Westside Road, this red is medium bodied and sultry, with a backdrop of Asian baking spice. Tangy pomegranate, orange and rose petal fill out its entry and midpalate with exotic fresh flavor.
Wine: Cast 2015 Bacigalupi Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: From Winemaker Jean-Michel Jussiaume, this sparkling wine is produced entirely from Chardonnay sourced from the Del Rio Vineyard. It offers concentrated lemon, grapefruit and pineapple flavors, with a fine bead and impeccable overall balance.
Wine: Maison Jussiaume 2015 Blanc de Blancs Sparkling (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: MC4
Review: A 100% varietal wine from a one-acre vineyard site, made in small amounts, this impresses in waxy cherry and vanilla flavors dipped in toasted clove. Soft, round and pleasantly approachable, it offers a touch of grip on the finish.
Wine: MC4 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (St. Helena)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a delicious mix of earth, rock, leaf, cherry and chocolate notes, with some pretty orange peel highlights. It reflects the earthy characteristics of the AVA and nicely integrates its one third new French oak.
Wine: Panther Creek 2015 Schindler Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A rich expression of the grape, this single-vineyard bottling shows hearty aromas of black currant and concentrated violets. There is a chalky structure and turned loam minerality to the palate, with Indian spice, pepper and cardamom enhancing the black plum core.
Wine: Peachy Canyon 2015 Bailey Zinfandel (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Elegantly soft and succulent, this wine is polished in tannin and integrated oak, with dark brooding flavors of black cherry and sage. Powerfully concentrated, it impresses from first sip, with a length of black pepper and clove.
Wine: Pellet Estate 2014 Pellet Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This delivers rich, ripe and concentrated fruit flavors of cranberry and raspberry purée. The fruit pushes deep into the finish. It's clean and generous, without obvious oak influence.
Wine: River's Edge 2015 Barrel Select Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Strawberry and raspberry sorbet meet with sweet wood, cherry blossoms, earth and leather on the nose of this reserve bottling. Herbal tones of oregano and marjoram frame the sip, surrounding the framboise and root beer core.
Wine: Seven Oxen 2015 Reserve Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Made predominantly from Wallula vineyard fruit (40%), with equal parts Upland, Destiny Ridge and Hedges, this has generous boysenberry, mountain blueberry, flower and dried herb aromas, along with kisses of spice. Ripe, silky fruit flavors lead to a lingering, olive- and meat-filled finish. A charmer.
Wine: Structure 2015 Foundation Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of fruit from Destiny Ridge, Stillwater Creek, Boushey and Upland vineyards. Fragrant aromas of flower, cherry and green herb lead to a focused, flavorful palate. With the oak influence pleasantly dialed back, it's a superb value.
Wine: Structure 2015 Piloti Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This vintage showcases strong mineral tones and brambly fruit. Its cranberry and raspberry flavors are sharply etched, with the youth and precision to age another decade or more.
Wine: Youngberg Hill Vineyards 2015 Jordan Block Pinot Noir (McMinnville)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine is boisterous and full of energy, featuring juicy bolts of strawberry and citrus seasoned in dried herb and plenty of earthiness. Bright and acid-driven, it's light and made in a style that will rightfully please fans of more restrained wines.
Wine: La Pitchoune 2014 English Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Le Cadeau
Review: This red label cuvée is made exclusively from estate grown fruit. And although its production is higher in 2016, the quality remains consistent. Concentrated black fruit abounds, recalling blackberry, blueberry and black cherry. There's a touch of dark chocolate and café crème, along with fine-grained tannins.
Wine: Le Cadeau 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Le P'tit Paysan
Review: Warm aromas of baked red cherry and caramel grow more complex due to a gravelly minerality and hints of peppercorns on the nose of this bottling by Ian Brand. The palate leads with oregano and pepper, those spices overwhelming the fruit, and the rocky minerality continues, leading into a cocoa-laced finish. It is a lithe and lively style of Cab.
Wine: Le P'tit Paysan 2016 Cabernet Sauvignon (Central Coast)

Appellation: Applegate Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Only one barrel of this wine was produced, and it seems to have taken a leathery direction, owing perhaps to its two years of oak aging. That leathery note permeates the black cherry and cassis fruit, which is concentrated enough to withstand that feature. Still, it's a bit over the top, with coffee liqueur, amaro and cured meat flavors and austere, drying tannins.
Wine: Leah Jørgensen Cellars 2014 Mae's Vineyard Grand Reserve Cabernet Franc (Applegate Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Though bottled in early 2017, this wine appeared to be in a dumb phase when tasted a year later. Nonetheless, the overall complexity was apparent, with whiffs of mushroom, ground coffee and cherry tobacco introducing a mellow blend of black fruit notes. It's layered and complex behind a translucent screen at the moment, as it fades into flavors of dried leaves and crackers.
Wine: Leah Jørgensen Cellars 2015 Clos Rogue Valley Reserve Cabernet Franc (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Though bottled in early 2017, this wine appeared to be in a dumb phase when tasted a year later. Nonetheless, the overall complexity was apparent, with whiffs of mushroom, ground coffee and cherry tobacco introducing a mellow blend of black fruit notes. It's layered and complex behind a translucent screen at the moment, as it fades into flavors of dried leaves and crackers.
Wine: Leah Jørgensen Cellars 2015 Clos Rogue Valley Reserve Cabernet Franc (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: A broad-shouldered, fruit-forward wine with plenty of ripeness, this is blended with a hearty 15% Petite Sirah. Cherry, blackberry, vanilla and peppery cinnamon take turns on the rich, concentrated palate, finishing on an oaky tone.
Wine: Napa Cellars 2015 Classic Zinfandel (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Ryan Rose
Review: Lovely aromas introduce this pleasingly complex young wine. One new and one once-used barrel were used, lending interesting scents and highlights of mushroom, cola and chocolate to its core of black cherry fruit. The tannins are well managed and ripe, with resonating streaks of bacon and vanilla.
Wine: Ryan Rose 2015 Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Pretty on the nose in floral freshness, this wine offers big bold flavors of smoked cherry, stemmy earth and a bite of citrus that keeps it intriguing and bright. Tart complementary flavors of pomegranate and strawberry persist pleasurably on the light-bodied palate.
Wine: Sanglier Cellars 2015 Old Camp Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Senders
Review: Stainless steel-aged, this delightful white shows high-toned floral characteristics of apricot and green apple, with a medium-bodied oomph of creamy lushness on the finish. It'll do well with food or on its own.
Wine: Senders 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Oak Knoll District)

Appellation: Lake County, Lake County, California, US
Review: This big but superbly polished wine shows a great sense of finesse along with abundant fruit and spice flavors. The aromas are at once bright, spicy and like new leather, while the flavors evoke black cherry, black currant and blueberry.
Wine: Six Sigma Ranch 2014 Diamond Mine Cuvée Red (Lake County)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Too many rosés go for power over finesse; this takes the lighter path, to good effect. Made from all organic estate fruit fermented entirely in stainless steel, it's fragrant and spicy at just 12% alcohol. But there's no lack of flavor: fresh strawberry, pink grapefruit and blood orange. A hint of pepper spices up the finish.
Wine: Sokol Blosser 2017 Estate Cuvée Rosé of Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is made from equal parts Upland, Hedges and Destiny Ridge vineyard fruit. The aromas leap out of the glass, suggesting green olives, chopped parsley, fresh flowers and smoked meat, the fruit notes lurking the background. The concentration of fruit and savory flavors is seamless and exquisite, with a lengthy finish.
Wine: Structure 2015 Bauhaus Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Stillwater Creek is considered a Bordeaux variety site, but this wine proves that Syrah can excel there too. Mineral, dried herb, bacon fat, dark plum, barrel spice and red and blue fruit aromas lead to a full-bodied palate that blends fruit and savory notes. It's equal parts intrigue and delivery.
Wine: Structure 2015 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Tablas Creek
Review: Dense aromas of black-plum syrup are fruit-forward and plump but not sweet on the nose of this bottling from the producer who brought this grape to California. A chalky, very full mouthfeel carries flavors of black plum, fennel and pepper.
Wine: Tablas Creek 2015 Tannat (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Tercero
Review: Larry Schaffer isn't afraid to tackle obscure blending grapes and throw them in the bottle alone. This large grape produces a lighter, fresh wine, showing red plum skins, strawberry, rose petals, sumac and pepper on the nose, like an herbally enhanced fruit punch. The palate carries forth with juicy, rounded red melon and bubblegum flavors and buoyant acidity.
Wine: Tercero 2016 Cinsault (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Extremely fruity and relatively light in body, this exuberant wine is easy to quaff. The strawberry and cherry flavors are so ripe and fresh they taste sweet, and the texture is soft and full with very little tannin.
Wine: The Endless Summer 2014 Montfort Vineyards Zinfandel (Lodi)

Appellation: ZD
Review: Big flavors and a broad, mouthfilling texture help this barrel-fermented beauty stand out. Vanilla, custard and melted butter aromas lead to similarly rich flavors on the palate, where the wine feels layered and concentrated.
Wine: ZD 2016 Chardonnay (California)

Appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Made from estate-grown fruit fermented in neutral oak, this is a unique white wine with a pale straw color and remarkable power. Fleshy and loaded with an intriguing mix of apple, pear, chocolate and almond paste flavors, it's a bit like a blend of Viognier and Pinot Gris, with more muscle.
Wine: Brandborg 2016 Fleur de Lis White Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine, from a tiny mountainside vineyard, has an especially deep gold color, bold aromas of orange zest and peaches, and rich but bright fruit flavors shaded by mineral and spice notes. It feels full in body and viscous in texture, giving a lot of palate impact.
Wine: Drew 2015 Valenti Ranch Chardonnay (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This full-bodied wine brings richness and ripe opulent flavors to the fore. Tobacco, cedar and black-plum aromas come before blackberry and dark-chocolate flavors while firm tannins and good acidity wrap around the palate for support.
Wine: Fenestra 2012 Thatcher Bay Vineyard Merlot (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This wine offers a lovely balance of dry, oaky substance on a well-framed, light body. The palate is fresh and fruity, with an exotic core of papaya, lemon and butter that's bolstered by succulent freshness and a lush backbone.
Wine: Grgich Hills 2015 Estate Grown Fumé Blanc Dry Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Hyland
Review: Tasty and toasty, this young wine is drinking quite nicely now. It's spicy and fresh, with pleasing creaminess. Citrus, lime and melon flavors are married to wet rock and a streak of butterscotch. It was aged for 10 months in 40% new oak.
Wine: Hyland 2016 Chardonnay (McMinnville)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded aromas of black cherry, cola and vanilla meet with more intense expressions of violet and white pepper on the nose of this wine, one of the few Petite Sirahs grown in this county. Black-cherry syrup meets with savory tones of toasted beef and black pepper on the palate, which is framed by polished tannins.
Wine: Jaffurs 2016 Thompson Vineyard Petite Sirah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a chunky, spicy, agreeable wine, with a brambly mix of red fruit notes. It's all power on the midpalate, while the oak aging—one year in 30% new barrels—brings toasted hazelnut highlights.
Wine: King Estate 2014 Kennel Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Hugely concentrated and ripely fleshy, this big broad-shouldered wine features rustic and robust flavors of leather, black pepper and clove wrapped in black fig and berry. The tannins are thick but supportive, youthful in their integration.
Wine: Krupp Brothers 2015 Black Bart Syrah (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 44% Grenache Blanc, 38% Roussanne, 11% Viognier and 7% Picpoul is tightly wound on the nose, offering soft aromas of ambrosia melon and a hint of daffodil. The wine is clean and easy on the palate, with delicately ripe flavors of stone fruit, melon and honey dust.
Wine: 13th & Third 2016 Lily White (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Ancient Peaks
Review: Fresh violets and rose petals make for a florally dominated nose, but there's also blackberry sorbet on this bottling. Crisp flavors of violet, blackberry paste and blueberry make for a fulfilling sip.
Wine: Ancient Peaks 2014 Petite Sirah (Santa Margarita Ranch)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This lovely, full-flavored and fruit-driven wine needs no special occasion to enjoy. It's a delicious mélange of strawberry preserve, raspberry purée and black cherry cola notes.
Wine: Andrew Rich 2015 Prelude Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from own-rooted Pommard clone vines planted in 1979, this starts out with a tannic grip and pomegranate and brambly berry flavors. Its underlying, astringent minerality drives the palate forward into a buttery finish. While all Bethel Heights Pinot Noirs are ageworthy, this one will notably benefit from another year or two in bottle.
Wine: Bethel Heights 2015 Flat Block Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This elegant medium-bodied wine has everything in place, from fresh plummy aromas to warm layered flavors to an appetizing and moderately tannic texture. It has excellent balance, with a sense of freshness and depth that is compelling.
Wine: Bonterra 2015 Made with Organic Grapes Merlot (California)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This reserve-level wine is priced at the high end of the winery's substantial lineup of Rieslings and sourced from unspecified old vine sites. It offers a fruity mix of Meyer lemon, apricot and peach that's ripe enough to carry the impression of sweetness yet finishes (and is labeled) dry. Drink now and over the next half decade.
Wine: Brooks 2016 Ara Riesling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Cabana Wines
Review: Leather and barnyard aromas add complexity without taking over this rich, earthy, smooth-textured and full-bodied wine. Complex flavors like tobacco, rhubarb, black pepper and wild blackberry fill the palate and moderate tannins provide some needed grip. It's on the wild side, for adventurous drinkers.
Wine: Cabana Wines 2011 Nebbiolo (Amador County)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Clean lines of Meyer lemon, hazelnut and vanilla are framed by a smoky oak touch on this first ever Chardonnay from this winery. The wood flavors show prominently on the sip, which offers toast with lime preserves and a hint of forest spice.
Wine: Challen 2015 Zotovich Vineyard Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This pioneering vineyard still holds vines planted in 1965 by the original owner, Charles Coury. The Coury clone, along with Wadenswil and Pommard from the same era, combine gracefully in this lush, spicy wine. Its tart berry fruit is balanced by firm acidity and generous barrel flavors of toast and buttered nuts. This is a fine value for a rare old-vine Pinot Noir.
Wine: David Hill 2015 Old Vine Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Atlas Peak, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a hugely tannic, thick and extracted wine that bears further time in the cellar. Within its powerful frame lie layers of leather, tobacco, black currant and dried herb that show richness and power. Enjoy 2024–2034.
Wine: Dowdell 2014 Soda Canyon Cabernet Sauvignon (Atlas Peak)

Appellation: Mendocino Ridge, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: Serious ripeness and juiciness stand out in this deep-colored medium-bodied wine grown at high elevation. It smells earthy and lightly oaky, and tastes very fruity and generous, flooding the palate with jammy blackberry and black cherry flavors.
Wine: Drew 2015 The Ornbaun Syrah (Mendocino Ridge)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from the oldest vines of the estate's La Bohème vineyard, this lush sparkler is made from 100% Pinot Noir. Its pretty strawberry shade matches the scents and flavors. With exceptional concentration and elegance, it seemingly gathers strength through its long, flavorful finish.
Wine: Elk Cove 2015 La Bohème Estate Grown Brut Rosé Sparkling (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Yummy is the word that comes to mind with this wine, its ripe, round, slightly candied fruit flavors on full display. Orange, tangerine, blackberry and sour cherry flavors create a sweet/tart effect that's held in check by just a touch of barrel toast.
Wine: Lavinea 2015 Tualatin Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Lorimar
Review: A promising new project out of Temecula, this bottling, which includes 15% Merlot and 5% Cabernet Sauvignon, offers dense aromas of dried strawberry, red plum, vanilla and baking spice. Cooked cranberry, strawberry and pomegranate flavors show on the sip, which is framed by a chalky texture and lifted by hints of rose and carnation.
Wine: Lorimar 2014 Sangiovese (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's mountain blueberry, huckleberry and flint aromas leap out of the glass. Its blue fruit flavors are rich, saturated and hedonistic. It's unabashed in its appeal.
Wine: Muret-Gaston 2015 Edythe Mae Vineyard Syrah (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Sierra Foothills, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This wine has pleasant floral and spice aromas, a velvety-soft texture full of fine-grained tannins and generous black-plum and dark chocolate flavors that verge on sweet. It's full bodied, mouth-filling and delicious.
Wine: Naggiar 2015 Mistero Estate Grown Red (Sierra Foothills)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: An aroma like ginger cookies and generous fruit and spice flavors make this full-bodied wine hard to resist. Clove, ginger and nutmeg fill the aroma, while black-cherry and black-currant notes coat the palate and linger on the finish. It's a fairly big wine that's delicious and well-balanced.
Wine: Noceto 2015 Dos Oakies Sangiovese (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling is lively on the nose in touches of caramel, red cherry, Chinese five spice and crème brûlée. The palate is fruit forward in a candied cherry note, but cut by ginger spice and framed in a chalky, tannic structure.
Wine: Opolo 2014 Rhapsody Reserve Collection Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's quite a bit less of the De Ponte bottling available this vintage, but it's well worth seeking out. Fresh, tight, clean and concentrated, it's packed with raspberry and cherry fruit. The acids prevail over the tannins, which only furthers the pleasure.
Wine: Panther Creek 2015 De Ponte Vineyard Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Howell Mountain, Napa, California, US
Review: Full bodied and rich, this wine is structured and classically aromatic in cedar, pencil and sage brush. The herbal, earthy elements are well developed and seasoned further in toasted oak, black pepper and clove. Cellar through 2034.
Wine: Piña 2014 Buckeye Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Howell Mountain)

Appellation: Moon Mountain District Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a thick, dense and structured wine sourced from the Bismark Vineyard high atop the appellation. Juicy and soft, it has substantial tannins up front that resolve and mellow in the glass. Black currant, earthy sage and dried herb hint at its mountainous provenance and higher elevation.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2013 Winemaker's Cuvée Cabernet Sauvignon (Moon Mountain District Sonoma County)

Appellation: Seven Oxen
Review: Dense boysenberry, black plum and dried teriyaki meet with savory notes of soy and teriyaki on the nose of this bottling. Roasted black-plum flavors show on the smoky sip, which is enhanced by roasted lamb and complex rosemary notes. The tannins are still stiff and young, but this will drink well until at least 2025.
Wine: Seven Oxen 2015 Tannat (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Fermented in stainless steel and aged on the lees for a month, this leads with compelling aromas of sweet herb, melon, citrus, and tropical fruit. The sleek palate bursts with fruit flavors, framed by lively acidity.
Wine: Sightglass 2017 Artz Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Fermented and aged in stainless steel, this offers apple, pear, straw and lees aromas followed by full-feeling, textured fruit flavors with captivating purity. A warm finish caps it off.
Wine: Sightglass 2017 Conner Lee Vineyard Chardonnay (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: The mother-daughter team behind this wine and the new Petaluma Gap appellation showcases the brawny, boisterous nature of the site, coaxing lush layers of blueberry and black cherry from its thick extracted layers of polished tannin and underlying bolts of acidity.
Wine: Trombetta 2015 Gap's Crown Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Achingly pure plum, red fruit, game, black pepper and fresh green herb aromas are followed by textured, seamless red and black fruit flavors in this wine. The finish is long and redolent of cranberries. It's riper than the norm for this winery, but so was the vintage it comes from.
Wine: W.T. Vintners 2015 Boushey Vineyard Mourvèdre (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Copper-yellow in hue, this is a dry blush wine made from barrel-fermented free run juice. Its boasts papaya, plum and melon flavors in a softly fruity and open framework. Ripe and accessible, it should be consumed over the next two years.
Wine: Anne Amie 2014 Prismé Blanc Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This is made from 82% Merlot, with the balance Cabernet Franc (14%) and Petit Verdot from Southwind, Stone Tree and Dionysus vineyards. Raspberry compote, fresh flower and barrel spice aromas lead to full-bodied, no-holds-barred fruit flavors that coat the palate from end to end, backed by lightly grainy tannins. The style is ripe and rich, but so is the vintage it comes from.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2014 BFM Red (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Plush and textured, with tasty, crushed berry-like fruit, this has hints of stems but finishes with richer notes of chocolate wafer and toasted almonds. It was aged in 30% new French oak.
Wine: Flâneur 2015 X-Novo Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Santa Maria Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Sea salt, preserved lemons, pan-seared apples, plumeria and honeysuckle show on the engaging nose of this bottling from a preferred block in this historic vineyard. The palate plays to the savory side of Chardonnay, offering an oily texture that carries flavors of cashew and marmalade.
Wine: Foxen 2016 Block UU Bien Nacido Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a three-block section of the vineyard, this wine is high-toned in rhubarb and pomegranate. The texture is grainy and complex, layered nicely with a lasting note of plush, velvety black cherry and fresh acidity.
Wine: Iron Horse 2015 North Block Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There is a honeydew rind tightness and a lemon curd opulence to the nose of this bottling from a vineyard planted in 1997, along with chalk and lemongrass aromas. The palate starts with strong grip and then opens with tart lime skin and a hint of butter—very refreshing.
Wine: Joyce 2016 Tondre Grapefield Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Tart cranberry and pomegranate fruit is front and center in this wine, streaked with an herbed butter accent. Barrel aged for a year in 30% new French oak, it's smooth and silky in feel. The tannins are somewhat astringent but should soften in time.
Wine: King Estate 2014 Croft Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine comes from the oldest vines on Red Mountain, planted in 1975. The aromas are appealing, recalling herbs, cassis, dark fruit, dates and exotic spice. The fruit and barrel flavors are concentrated and tightly wound, bringing a structure that augurs well for its longevity.
Wine: Kiona 2014 Old Block Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: As with all this winery's reds, there's substantial extract here, giving deep color, dense flavors, and chewy tannins. Its blueberry and black cherry fruit is accented by earthy mushroom notes. It makes a strong case for growing Malbec in Southern Oregon, where Tempranillo and Cabernet Franc also shine.
Wine: Leah Jørgensen Cellars 2015 Crater View Vineyard Malbec (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Southern Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: No one in Oregon is more dedicated to this grape than Leah Jørgensen, and nowhere does it pay off better than in her entry-level bottling. A baseline of deep, saturated blue fruit carries the taster into a lush mix of coffee, pepper, tobacco and dusty tannins. The depth and concentration put most $25 reds to shame.
Wine: Leah Jørgensen Cellars 2016 Loiregon Cabernet Franc (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: MacRostie
Review: A muted nose of toasted oak and brioche leads to an expansive and fleshy midpalate of apple and peach in this moderately structured, medium-bodied and balanced wine. The finish is lingering and vibrantly bright in acidity.
Wine: MacRostie 2016 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This wine balances ripe fruit flavors with oak spiciness. Aromas of mahogany and cedar start it off, followed by cherry and black currant flavors that are shaded by chocolate and linger on the finish. It boasts an appetizing and moderately tannic texture, with supportive acidity that keeps it fresh and compelling.
Wine: Masthead 2015 Mohr-Fry Ranch Block 433 Sangiovese (Lodi)

Appellation: Pamplin
Review: The fruit for this 100% varietal wine comes from top sites Seven Hills (51%) and Klipsun (46%), with a dash from Scooteney Flats. Its barrel spice, dried herb, cocoa, black currant, pencil lead and dark cherry aromas are locked up at the moment, but the palate is well balanced and full of fruit and crunchy tannins. It needs time to unwind. Best after 2020.
Wine: Pamplin 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This inaugural release from Ben Paplow, assistant winemaker at Gorman Winery, is a blend of 67% Grenache, 10% Syrah, 10% Mourvèdre, 9% Cinsault and 4% Viognier—all cofermented and aged in neutral oak. Its blackberry jam, white pepper, flower and orange rind aromas are followed by smooth, polished fruit and meat flavors. It displays a lot of purity and finesse.
Wine: Paplow 2014 Boushey Vineyard G-S-M (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a blend of 65% Viognier, 28% Chardonnay and smaller amounts of Rousanne and Marsanne. Aromatic in jasmine, it's medium bodied with fresh, vibrant layers of fresh acidity built around strong flavors of apricot and apple.
Wine: Paraduxx 2016 Proprietary White (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles Willow Creek District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Concentrated aromas of red currant, alpine strawberry and carnation show on the nose of this bottling from one of the region's Zinfandel pioneers. The palate follows suit, with a juicy blackberry sorbet flavor and a gravelly minerality that are upheld by firm tannins and solid acidity.
Wine: Peachy Canyon 2015 Clevenger Zinfandel (Paso Robles Willow Creek District)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Medium bodied and well-crafted, from a tremendously well-farmed site, this white is crisp and acid-driven with a lightness of being that surprises. Asian pear and crème brûlée both play a part in intriguing the palate.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 Durell Vineyard Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Rococo
Review: From 40-year-old vines comes this semisweet wine by young winemaker Natalie Darr, full of aromas of honey, honeysuckle, chamomile and fortune cookies on the nose. The sweetness is subtle on the palate, as it surrounds a chalky core and grippy texture.
Wine: Rococo 2016 Chenin Blanc (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From 40-year-old vines in Los Alamos comes this crisp, lovely wine, which shows nectarine, Meyer lemon spray and grapefruit peel aromas on the nose. The palate is crisp and grippy, with light stone-fruit flavors alongside crushed white rocks and a slight citrus tang.
Wine: Rococo 2016 Sur Lie Chenin Blanc (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: North Coast, North Coast, California, US
Review: A combination of spicy, fruity and savory flavors, as well as a suave texture, make this wine quite impressive. Subtle nutmeg and vanilla aromas lead to fresh pear and white peach flavors, with a touch of minerality for a tasty but not extreme personality.
Wine: Scotto Family Cellars 2016 Anthony & Dominic Chardonnay (North Coast)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a nicely put together, complex red, brimming in smooth layers of integrated black fruit, plum, cinnamon and clove. The robust ripeness is well-managed and in check, with a welcome smoky touch to the lengthy finish.
Wine: Sojourn 2015 Proprietary Cuvée Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Estate-grown, this wine is juicy and expansive, with an approachability that makes it instantly pleasing on the palate. Black currant, graphite and dark-chocolate flavors meet brushy dried herb and toasted oak, integrating into a lengthy finish.
Wine: Stag's Leap Wine Cellars 2014 S.L.V. Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This 100% varietal wine hails from Olsen Brothers vineyard in Yakima Valley and Upland vineyard on Snipes Mountain. The aromas leap from the glass, suggesting satsuma orange peel, jasmine, green herb and plum. They lead to plush red and purple fruit flavors, with prominent satsuma peel notes on the finish. It shows delightful purity.
Wine: Structure 2015 Foundation Malbec (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Brawny and full bodied, this earthy wine shows a generosity of forest floor, cardamom and cola, before unveiling integrated layers of bright strawberry and citrus.
Wine: The Calling 2015 Fox Den Vineyard Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This spent 18 months in French oak and another three years in bottle. Yet despite its age, it looks and drinks quite young, perhaps because it is sealed with a glass cap. There's even a whiff of yeast on the nose, and the tart, fresh fruit includes blood orange, cranberry and raspberry notes. It's firmly tannic and may hold its youthful freshness considerably longer.
Wine: Vidon Vineyard 2013 Barrel Select Pinot Noir (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's light strawberry fruit is scented with unusual notes of dried straw. There's a hint of barnyard on the nose, which follows through to the palate. The mix of grain, grass and berry notes keeps it interesting, though it's definitely on the lighter side of Oregon Pinot.
Wine: Armonéa 2014 Summit Vineyard Estate Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Black Stallion
Review: This is a bright fresh white that shows a nice complement of dried herb and lemongrass with juicier, more concentrated flavors of white peach and melon. Elegantly crafted, it has a lushness to the palate that's lengthy and complex.
Wine: Black Stallion 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Firm and tart, this is anchored by black cherry fruit, with strong coffee and cola highlights. Give it a long sniff and you'll detect a slightly funky note. Drink soon.
Wine: Brandborg 2014 Bradley Vineyard Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 57% Touriga Nacional, 29% Sauzao, 9% Tinta Cao and 5% Tinta Roriz. Its vanilla, purple fruit and barrel aromas lead to sweet, balanced fruit flavors that persist into the finish.
Wine: Brian Carter 2014 Opulento Dessert Wine Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Smoke and coffee aromas float above this four-barrel reserve. In the mouth, it's still compact, with tart cherry and black olive flavors and astringent tannins. It spent 18 months in 30% new French oak and seems built for at least a decade of life ahead.
Wine: Carlton Hill 2015 Estate Tournament Reserve Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's light strawberry fruit is scented with unusual notes of dried straw. There's a hint of barnyard on the nose, which follows through to the palate. The mix of grain, grass and berry notes keeps it interesting, though it's definitely on the lighter side of Oregon Pinot.
Wine: Armonéa 2014 Summit Vineyard Estate Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Black Stallion
Review: This is a bright fresh white that shows a nice complement of dried herb and lemongrass with juicier, more concentrated flavors of white peach and melon. Elegantly crafted, it has a lushness to the palate that's lengthy and complex.
Wine: Black Stallion 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Elkton Oregon, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Firm and tart, this is anchored by black cherry fruit, with strong coffee and cola highlights. Give it a long sniff and you'll detect a slightly funky note. Drink soon.
Wine: Brandborg 2014 Bradley Vineyard Pinot Noir (Elkton Oregon)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine is a blend of 57% Touriga Nacional, 29% Sauzao, 9% Tinta Cao and 5% Tinta Roriz. Its vanilla, purple fruit and barrel aromas lead to sweet, balanced fruit flavors that persist into the finish.
Wine: Brian Carter 2014 Opulento Dessert Wine Red (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Smoke and coffee aromas float above this four-barrel reserve. In the mouth, it's still compact, with tart cherry and black olive flavors and astringent tannins. It spent 18 months in 30% new French oak and seems built for at least a decade of life ahead.
Wine: Carlton Hill 2015 Estate Tournament Reserve Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend from Dionysus and Stone Tree vineyards offers ripe blackberry jam, black plum, nougat and barrel spice aromas. They're followed by a full-bodied palate rich with velvety tannins. There's no mistaking the warmth of the vintage, though its hedonistic style brings appeal.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2014 V.R. Special Cabernet Sauvignon (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Mixed with small amounts of Syrah and Petite Sirah, this is aged in both French and American oak, and it shows a richly woven palate of grainy leather, tobacco and cedar. The ripe succulent fruit is jammy in blackberry and dark chocolate.
Wine: Fogline Vineyards 2014 Grist Vineyard Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: High Valley Vineyard
Review: This well-balanced wine from high-elevation Lake County has everything in the right proportions: fresh herb and citrus aromas, lip-smacking, crisp fruit flavors, a generous texture and lingering finish.
Wine: High Valley Vineyard 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (High Valley)

Appellation: Hoopes
Review: Sanguine and crisp in cranberry, currant and violet aromas, this wine is bright, expansive and integrated in oak, with accents of cedar and graphite. The full-bodied ripeness holds its own.
Wine: Hoopes 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Ilaria
Review: From vineyards in St. Helena, Atlas Peak and Howell Mountain, this is a well-made, relatively restrained wine, smoky and earthy up front. Broadly structured, it features fine highlights of black currant and pencil lead and will work nicely at the table.
Wine: Ilaria 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Whole cluster fermentation brings this wine's juicy fruit flavors front and center. Like an especially fine Beaujolais, it pushes ripe berry notes into the spotlight and finishes with drying, tea leaf tannins. It was aged 11 months in one quarter new French oak.
Wine: Iota Cellars 2015 Whole Cluster Pelos Sandberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: An elegant, almost delicate wine, it has floral and cherry-like aromas, delicious cherry and pomegranate flavors and a gentle texture with good acidity and very light tannins.
Wine: Jessie's Grove 2016 Sin So Cinsault (Lodi)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A first for Lange, this 75% Pinot Noir and 25% Chardonnay bubbly is elegant and bone dry, with a pleasant earthy character that suggests loess and chalk. The fruit flavors are dried apple, gooseberry and grapefruit, with first-rate length and finesse.
Wine: Lange 2015 Mia Mousseux Méthode Champenoise Brut Rosé Sparkling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Concentrated black plum and slightly sour blueberry aromas met with dried earth and leather on the nose of this wine. The palate is dense and heavily weighted, with an acidity that slowly rises through the soft tannins, carrying flavors of dark fruit and peppery spice.
Wine: Le Vigne 2015 Di Domenico Tannat (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Cruz Mountains, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A good pét-nat combines funk, foam and fun with tart fruit and a full body, and this succeeds on all fronts. Cloudy in the glass, this shows aromas of watermelon soda, strawberry, cherry Jolly Rancher and yeast. Albeit focused on primary flavors, the palate is tart with raspberry candy and sour bubblegum, offering quite a voluptuous mouthfeel.
Wine: Left Bend 2016 Fiz Nat Rosé of Syrah (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Lyric by Etude
Review: Light on the nose with hints of cranberry, crushed gravel, wet slate and rose petals, this affordable bottling gives a good sense of minerality at a fair price. There's an herbal background to the bright palate, which offers tart pomegranate and hibiscus flavors.
Wine: Lyric by Etude 2016 Pinot Noir (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Maddalena
Review: This wine is clean, crisp and tasty. Aromas of honey, lime peel and rounded mango lead into a palate that's zippy in bright acidity and grippy in structure. Racy mandarin zest, yellow melon and wet stone flavors carry the palate.
Wine: Maddalena 2016 Pinot Grigio (Monterey)

Appellation: Outlot
Review: Stainless-steel fermented, this is a red that's ready to drink, blended with small amounts of Syrah and Pinot Noir. Thick, leathery, structured black fruit stars alongside dried herb and earth before a long, juicy finish.
Wine: Outlot 2014 Cabernet Sauvignon (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Produced from old vines (age unspecified) and fermented using whole clusters, this is an aromatic mélange of strawberry preserves, cranberry sauce and graham crackers. Its solid, chunky midpalate keeps those tart fruit flavors front and center.
Wine: Van Duzer 2014 Tradition Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Vidon Vineyard
Review: Plush and fruity, this sports a tasty mix of apple, pear, apricot and peach flavors, along with a hint of tropical fruit. It's soft and accessible, with a little extra texture due, perhaps, to indigenous yeast fermentation.
Wine: Vidon Vineyard 2016 Chardonnay (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Los Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Cofermented with 3% Viognier, this red is lovely and floral in red cherry and blueberry, the fruit richly concentrated and approachable. Lovely accents of white pepper and dried herb add to a tease of black olive that's entirely rewarding.
Wine: Vie Winery 2013 Las Madres Vineyard Syrah (Los Carneros)

Appellation: Los Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a 100% varietal wine from one clone, made in tiny amounts with indigenous yeast fermentation. Exotic and inviting, it offers robust berry, citrus and leather, with a biting quality of tannin that eases into a concentration of velvety texture.
Wine: Vie Winery 2014 Estrella River Clone Petris Vineyard Syrah (Los Carneros)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Broad aromas of black plum, cherry, sweet cedar and a touch of smoke show on the nose of this blend of 38% Petit Verdot, 36% Malbec and 26% Cabernet Sauvignon. The palate is framed by layered tannins that provide structure but don't get in the way, allowing ripe flavors of boysenberry to mesh with peppery spices and crushed gravel.
Wine: Volatus 2014 Topgun Cuvée Reserve Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (WA), Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: One of the few bottlings of this variety in the state, this brings spicy herb, white peach, citrus rind and white pepper aromas. The flavors are light, sleek and acid-driven, with a drawn-out finish. It provides a lot of appeal and versatility at the table.
Wine: W.T. Vintners 2017 Underwood Mountain Vineyard Grüner Veltliner (Columbia Gorge (WA))

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a 100% varietal wine grown on Mount George at the southern end of the valley. Cave-aged nearly two years in all French oak, it's tightly wound and intensely ripe, a bold, boisterous offering of black cherry, black pepper, clove and lasting oak. Let it open in the glass.
Wine: Alyris 2014 The Audition Take 1 Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Chehalem Mountains, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This 100% Pinot Noir sparkling wine opens with tart fruit flavors of rhubarb, strawberry and sour cherry. It's tight and sharply defined at first but broadens as it opens, finishing with a lick of vanilla.
Wine: Anne Amie 2014 Marilyn Brut Rosé Sparkling (Chehalem Mountains)

Appellation: Rutherford, Napa, California, US
Review: For fans of a bigger voluptuous style, this wine delivers a lush layered combination of honeycomb and crème brûlée. Dark in color, the oak is pronounced and supportive, while the structure is moderate, opting for velvety texture and rich ripe fruit.
Wine: B Cellars 2015 Star Vineyard Chardonnay (Rutherford)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made in a medium-sweet style, this emphasizes strong peach flavors that some might call syrupy. It's nicely ripe, fruit-driven, off dry and should be enjoyed slightly chilled.
Wine: Brooks 2016 Cahiers Riesling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's plum, crushed flower, blackberry jam and wet rock aromas are followed by concentrated purple and black fruit flavors that persist on the fruit-filled finish. A big wine, it pulls no punches.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2014 Rachis Stone Tree Vineyard Syrah (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Fenestra
Review: This wine shows a classic, generous style with the waxy aromas and rich texture typical of the grape variety. Melon, walnut and lemon zest flavors make it interesting to sip, and the mouthfeel is broad and inviting.
Wine: Fenestra 2016 Semillon (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Foris
Review: This pretty, affordable Oregon Pinot Noir brings purple fruit character and plenty of appeal. Soft on entry, it loosens up on the palate to deliver a blast of blueberry jam and French oak flavors (though its oak aging is unspecified), finishing with a chocolate note recalling a Hershey's kiss. This is a good candidate for immediate summertime enjoyment.
Wine: Foris 2015 Pinot Noir (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: McMinnville, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Old vine is an unregulated term, and the bottle gives no indication of what it signifies here. The wine starts out toasty and a little hot, improving as it opens, with black cherry, coffee and toasted walnut flavors. The finish brings a lingering taste of chicken stock.
Wine: Hyland 2016 Old Vine Pinot Noir (McMinnville)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: There's plenty of concentrated, tangy fruit here. The wine bursts with juicy cranberry and raspberry flavors, bolstered by ample acidity. It spent just under a year in barrel, 7% new. Another year in bottle would be a good idea before pulling the cork.
Wine: Iota Cellars 2015 Not One iOTA Pelos Sandberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Sonoma County, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This affordable red succeeds in offering full-bodied dark cherry and black-currant flavors among an expansive palate of integrated oak and structured tannins. The finish is an extended mix of cinnamon, toast and chocolate tones.
Wine: Kendall-Jackson 2014 Grand Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Crisp and juicy aromas of squeezed Meyer lemon, white peach, honeydew rind and rainy sidewalk show on the nose of this single-vineyard bottling. There is great grip to the palate as well as a light texture, but the flavors are generous with more stone fruit and melon, making it rounded and likable for many tastes.
Wine: La Marea 2017 Kristy Vineyard Albariño (Monterey County)

Appellation: El Dorado, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Extra richness and depth lift this wine to a high level of quality and deliciousness. Its ripe blueberry, blackberry and dark-chocolate flavors seem layered and generous, and it fills the palate with fine-grained tannins and a full body.
Wine: Lava Cap 2015 Estate Bottled Merlot (El Dorado)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This wine is dense with rounded and deep blackberry at its core. The palate is framed by strong tannins but also bright acidity, which carry forth energetic well-integrated flavors of bursting berry fruit and dark spice.
Wine: Le Vigne 2015 Di Domenico Sangiovese (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Lemon cream, peach and mango show on the nose of this top-tier bottling from the historic regional producer. The flavors are light and bright, with lemon juice and apple flesh, though the wine feels a bit more reserved in this vintage.
Wine: Morgan 2016 Double L Vineyard Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Muret-Gaston
Review: This wine's black cherry, herb, graphite, woodspice and chili pepper aromas are followed by a palate tightly wound with burly tannins and fresh acidity. It needs some time in the cellar to settle.
Wine: Muret-Gaston 2013 Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: The purity of fruit flavor in this medium-bodied wine is compelling to taste, and shines through in a focused way uncomplicated by noticeable oakiness. The wine is elegant, sleek in texture and redolent of red cherries all the way through a lingering finish.
Wine: Noceto 2014 Riserva Sangiovese (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: From Cat Canyon vineyard and aged in neutral French oak, this bottling is tightly wound on the nose, with restrained aromas of white peach, nectarine, pineapple and lemon rind. There's a touch of almond paste to the sip, then come fresh lemon wedges and buttered nuts in the finish.
Wine: Parker 2015 Los Alamos Valley Chardonnay (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This blend of 70% Pinot Noir and 30% Chardonnay brings big bubbles and bold flavors. Its cherry and berry fruit puts it squarely in a New World style, and it was sourced from some of the estate's oldest vines. A March 2016 disgorgement, it's drinking well at this time, finishing with a touch of dark chocolate.
Wine: Ponzi 2014 Brut Rosé Sparkling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Portola Vineyards
Review: Sandalwood, black cherry, mulberry jam and campfire smoke show on the nose of this wine that's sourced from the Regan and Veranda vineyards. It's already showing a touch of age on the palate, with balsamic notes drizzled across the plump berry, white pepper and marjoram spices.
Wine: Portola Vineyards 2013 Pinot Noir (Santa Cruz Mountains)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This robust and powerfully concentrated wine is thick in tannin yet pretty in rose petal and strong flavors of black cherry, strawberry puree and tangerine. For fans of a bigger style, it delivers.
Wine: Publix 2016 Limited Edition Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Blended with 14% Petite Sirah from a planting that dates back to 1904, this wine is smoky in oak and brightly fresh in black cherry and blackberry fruitiness. Focused on the palate, it's robust yet balanced and enjoyable.
Wine: Puccioni 2015 Old Vine Zinfandel (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This blend of 66% Cabernet Sauvignon (from two different vineyards) and 34% Zinfandel shows reduced strawberry and fig juice on the nose as well as cola, pepper and baked earth aromas.
