It's pleasantly smooth on the palate, offering baked plums, stewed raspberries and woody herbal qualities of thyme and peppercorn.
Wine: The Blending Lab 2015 beCS2wZ Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Vie Winery
Review: For a white wine, this one has almost the feel of a big red. It shows a deep, gold color, lots of body, a gripping texture and flavors that are much more savory and nutty than simply fruity. It should open up and get more interesting with time. Best after 2020.
Wine: Vie Winery 2015 Roussanne (Lake County)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This is made in an especially leesy, mineral-drenched style, which sets it apart from the vast majority of new world Sauvignon Blancs. Its immaculate lime skin, grapefruit, pineapple and fresh herb flavors combine in a most refreshing way.
Wine: Viola 2016 Allegre Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc (Columbia Gorge (OR))

Appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine underwent a vineyard change this vintage; the fruit now comes from 1979 plantings at Upland. The aromas pop, recalling scooped cantaloupe, ripe pear, red apple and freshly sliced star fruit, with intriguing salinity. Simultaneously sleek and textured fruit flavors lead to an acid-driven finish.
Wine: W.T. Vintners 2017 Upland Vineyard Chenin Blanc (Snipes Mountain)

Appellation: Arroyo Seco, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Though light on the nose, there is a distinctive toasted hazelnut aromas on this bottling along with nectarine cream, brioche and citrus rind. The palate is a fuller expression yet without becoming tropical, offering toast with marmalade flavors, a lively acidity and a grippy texture.
Wine: Martin Ranch 2015 Therese Vineyards Viognier (Arroyo Seco)

Appellation: Muret-Gaston
Review: Vibrant black cherry, black raspberry, licorice and barrel spice aromas lead to pitch-black fruit flavors in this wine. Despite the warmth of the fruit profile, it has lovely balance. Best before 2022.
Wine: Muret-Gaston 2013 Syrah (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: Raspberry, earth and leather aromas lead to rich, deep and savory flavors in this full-bodied, firmly tannic and nicely funky wine. It goes beyond the simple fruit and acidity of many Barberas and adds a lot of complexity.
Wine: Noceto 2013 Linsteadt Vineyard Barbera (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Honey, lemon curd, plumeria and white jasmine aromas meet with poached apple on the nose of this bottling. It's subtle on the palate and smoothed out with even flavors of roasted pear, caramelized apple, lemon juice and toast.
Wine: Parker 2015 Camp 4 Vineyard Roussanne (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A dense plummy nose of milk chocolate and cherry compote is quite unctuous for this dark brooding blend of 62% Cabernet Sauvignon and 38% Petite Sirah. It's very soft and welcoming upon entry to the palate, showing slightly tart yet plush plum and fig flavors. The tannins are still sticky at this young age.
Wine: Parrish Family 2014 Silken Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Peter Franus
Review: Blending sizable portions of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot with Cabernet Franc, this approachable mix opens in a succulence of cherry and berry that remain juicy through the fleshy midpalate and finish. The oak is well-integrated and the tannins softened.
Wine: Peter Franus 2014 Red (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Raeburn
Review: This lovely and lingering white impresses from start to finish, showing a wealth of pear and peach flavors within an inviting jasmine aroma. It finishes in swift teases of wild vanilla and subtle oak.
Wine: Raeburn 2016 Chardonnay (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has a feral aspect to it—a mix of wild mushroom and gritty stone, with the grit and grip persistent on the palate. Asian pear, apple and nutmeg highlight a full-bodied concentration nuanced in toasted oak.
Wine: Ram's Gate 2015 Estate Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Seven Oxen
Review: Rusty red cherry, dried anise and a hint of carnation show on the nose of this bottling. A rose petal flavor is strong on the lightly bodied palate, where a firm tannic structure and solid acidity frame soft, welcoming flavors of Concord grape and vanilla on the finish.
Wine: Seven Oxen 2015 Zinfandel (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Seven Peaks
Review: What a wonderful value. Smooth and subtle, this medium-bodied wine layers raspberry and light earthy aromas over a smooth palate of ripe plum, tea leaf and baking spices. Soft tannins blend in nicely with a touch of good acidity for very nice balance.
Wine: Seven Peaks 2016 Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Sojourn
Review: This is an approachable, rounded and likable appellation wine, robustly built and shy in fruit, with soft, smooth layers of clove, red cherry and plum.
Wine: Sojourn 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Warm spices override a wealth of blackberry crumble in this robust wine, substantial in concentration and richness. Toasty smoky oak plays a background part, allowing the wine to remain fruit forward and soft on the palate.
Wine: Sojourn 2015 Home Ranch Cuvée Cabernet Sauvignon (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Sojourn
Review: An appellation wine that impresses with its complexity, this offers earthy tones of bark, cinnamon and wild strawberry within a sultry sleek texture that's spicy and moderately structured.
Wine: Sojourn 2016 Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Earthy compost aromas and notions of forest floor tease the nose of this wine, which shows high-toned spiky acidity underneath strawberry, cranberry and rhubarb flavors. It is full bodied and concentrated in ripeness.
Wine: Sojourn 2016 Sangiacomo Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Sol Rouge
Review: This variety is rare in California, but wouldn't be if they were all as good as this nicely funky, meaty wine. It combines earthy beefy mushroomy flavors with good plummy bass notes on a medium to full body, along with light tannins adding some grip.
Wine: Sol Rouge 2013 Cinsault (Red Hills)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This blend of 55% Syrah, 36% Grenache and 9% Mourvèdre offers unctuous flavors of blueberry and blackberry wrapped in sweet vanilla and full-bodied ripeness.
Wine: V. Sattui 2015 Entanglement G-S-M (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: This is a 100% varietal wine, made in a small-production from Howell Mountain fruit. Dense black cherry and blackberry dominate around supersize tannins that are grippy and strong. It also offers a wealth of dried herb and sage. This wine will do well in the cellar; enjoy best 2023–2030.
Wine: Valance 2013 Estate Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Mendocino County, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: A deep pink color and bold fruit and spice flavors help this wine stand out from the pack. Made from mostly old-vine Carignan, it is full bodied, rounded and rich on the palate, yet has good acidity and a glimmer of tannin to add structure. Winemaker Carol Shelton achieves concentration that helps the flavors hang in there for a lingering finish.
Wine: Wild Thing 2017 Rendezvous Rosé (Mendocino County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This fresh, pretty, fruit-driven wine is loaded with ripe strawberry, raspberry and cherry notes. The lively fruit is underscored by hints of stem and stone, finishing with a dash of barrel toast.
Wine: Youngberg Hill Vineyards 2015 Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a traditional field blend consisting of 80% Zinfandel, 18% Petite Sirah and 2% mixed blacks. It's juicy and seductively soft, a study of blackberry, wild herb, toasted oak and grainy leather. It holds its full-bodied ripeness well.
Wine: Armida 2015 Il Campo Estate Field Red (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: From a site planted in 1934, and blended with 4% Carignan, this is an earthy pungent wine that is concentrated and approachable. Tobacco, dark cherry and dried herb mingle well along a velvety smooth palate of full-bodied ripeness.
Wine: Carlisle 2015 Papera Ranch Zinfandel (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This seems stiff but clearly focused, with strong licorice and coffee flavors over lighter cranberry and pomegranate fruit. It's not a wine bursting with charm, but it does have tannic muscle and power. Light tobacco notes thread through the grainy finish. Cellar and drink during the 2020s.
Wine: Carlton Hill 2014 Estate Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Carpe Diem
Review: This appealing and medium-bodied wine has a light earthy, buttery aroma and plenty of butter, lemon and vanilla flavors underpinned by good, lively acidity that keeps it fresh through the finish.
Wine: Carpe Diem 2015 Chardonnay (Anderson Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from one of Oregon's highest vineyards (2,000 feet), this is of a style different from Syrahs from Southern Oregon or further south. Its tart, sappy Marionberry and loganberry flavors come with a delicate savory note. There's a touch of cedar and coffee and enough acidity to match a wide variety of protein-based entrées.
Wine: Dobbes Family Estate 2013 Fortmiller Vineyard Syrah (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: The winery lists this as a reserve, though there doesn't appear to be any such indication on the label. The flavors are robust, penetrating and succulent, suggesting Meyer lemon, lime and pineapple.
Wine: Dominio IV 2015 Glass House Viognier (Oregon)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This leads with high toned notes of clove, toast and plum. Its full-bodied purple fruit and spice flavors are tightly wound for now, backed by firm tannins. Abundant orange peel and black pepper flavors linger on the finish.
Wine: Gård 2014 Lawrence Vineyards Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dried herbs, dark red strawberry and cherry and dried rose petals show on the nose of this blend of 48% Grenache, 27% Mourvèdre and 25% Syrah. The texture is chalky and the acid is solid, carrying flavors of rounded red fruit and well-integrated herbs.
Wine: 13th & Third 2015 NMR Red (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Napa Valley, Napa, California, US
Review: Soft in texture, this wine features rounded, dry tannins and showy wood, revealing its 24 months in new French oak. Graphite, cedar and red currant give it herbal earthiness and a brightness of tangy fruit.
Wine: Allen Estate Wines 2014 Audacieux Stanford Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Napa Valley)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Floral like a rose garden, this wine appears deeply extracted and dark in color, its style intensely full-bodied. Black cherry, rhubarb, blueberry and dark-chocolate flavors make for a taste experience that's both tart and richly concentrated.
Wine: Armida 2015 Gap's Crown Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This meaty wine offers a payload of black fruit and even darker seams of espresso and charcoal. The barrels used likely had a pretty heavy toast, as the flavors border on burnt. It's rare a Pinot Noir belongs with barbecue; this one does.
Wine: Brandborg 2014 Westbrook Vineyard Pinot Noir (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a tasty, focused young wine from vines just entering maturity. Pleasing highlights of chocolate mint carry from the nose to the finish, adding interest to tightly wound cranberry and raspberry fruit.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Sunset Ridge Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: From a cool site, this is tightly wound, with herbal accents and thin red berry fruit. Despite its relatively high alcohol, it seems restrained and slightly underripe, with tomato leaf scents and flavors.
Wine: Le Cadeau 2015 Côte Est Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Atlas Peak, Napa, California, US
Review: A wine that is still available in limited amounts, this aged red offers classic secondary aromas of leather, tobacco and raisin, with a seasoning of clove. Drink soon—it risks being quickly past its prime.
Wine: Cobblestone 2007 Cobblestone Vineyard Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Atlas Peak)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: From the neighboring vineyard that has done so much for the variety in this appellation, this white is grainy in toasted oak and caramel crème brûlée, rich and made in a full-bodied style. The richness is kept in check by juicy notions of baked tangerine and Meyer lemon.
Wine: Domaine Carneros 2015 Hyde Vineyard Chardonnay (Carneros)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Medium bodied, with a core of black cherry fruit, this is nicely textured and has a streak of cola. The earthy flavors of the AVA are in evidence, leading to a tannic finish. It improves significantly with generous aeration.
Wine: Dominio IV 2014 Willakia Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Dry Creek Vineyard
Review: This wine is predominantly Cabernet Sauvignon, blended with small amounts of Merlot, Petit Verdot, Cabernet Franc and Malbec. Smoky, toasted oak underlies rounded layers of blueberry, black cherry and plum, leaving the palate rich and pleasing.
Wine: Dry Creek Vineyard 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon (Dry Creek Valley)

Appellation: Dusted Valley
Review: This wine blends Walla Walla Valley, Wahluke Slope and Columbia Valley fruit. Its blackberry, black plum jam, herb and spice aromas are followed by ripe, hedonistic black fruit flavors and a spice- and green herb-filled finish. It's an unabashed warm vintage wine that displays both power and charm.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2014 Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Earthy and robustly expansive on the palate, this wine is full of black cherry, oak and bark elements—complementary expressions that work well within a medium-bodied context. A smoky element of forest floor lingers on the finish.
Wine: Etude 2015 Grace Benoist Ranch Estate Grown Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The most widely produced Pinot Noir in the winery's lineup, this is also the most accessible. Dark, aromatic and lightly smoky, it offers rich red, blue and black berry flavors. The tannins are chewy and dark, with coffee and dark chocolate highlights.
Wine: Flâneur 2016 Cuvée Constantin Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Ribbon Ridge, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: From one of the winery's estate vineyards planted in 2003, this offers raspberry and cherry candy flavors backed by mineral highlights. It was fermented with 20% whole clusters and aged for 12 months in 37% new French oak.
Wine: Flâneur 2016 Flanerie Vineyard Pinot Noir (Ribbon Ridge)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Exotic aromas of wildflowers are inviting on the entry of this wine, which is bright in fresh acidity with a backbone of substantial tannin that presents as intense. Pomegranate and strawberry tanginess follow through nicely on the textured palate.
Wine: Fogline Vineyards 2013 Sun Chase Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Green Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: With a slight note of reduction and toasted oak, this wine is ultimately high-toned and high in acidity, with fresh streaks of plum and black cherry. Accents of dried herbs pepper it with additional complexity and earthiness.
Wine: Iron Horse 2015 Deer Gate Pinot Noir (Green Valley)

Appellation: Los Olivos District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This bottling, of which all profits go toward climate research in honor of the winemaker's scientist father, shows candied orange peels, fresh lily blossoms, pear flesh and a touch of cream on the nose. The palate is impressively cohesive and complex, its grippy texture carrying flavors of grapefruit pith, peach and a touch of hazelnut.
Wine: Jalopy 2016 Dr. Sundquist Riesling (Los Olivos District)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Intense, freshly crushed berry aromas and flavors seem to light up this full-bodied, bold and ripe wine. The fruit flavors are focused and pure and the texture is vibrant, giving the wine a lot of life.
Wine: Jessie's Grove 2015 Ancient Vine Carignane (Lodi)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Floral in aromatics—think lemongrass and jasmine—this estate-grown wine is creamy yet light in feel. The palate brings distinct flavors of crisp green apple, apricot, lime and wet stone.
Wine: Marimar Estate 2016 Don Miguel Vineyard Estate Grown & Bottled Chardonnay-Albariño (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Alexander Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This wine has a fruity entry of dark cherry and plum: flavors that are dusted in a lightness of cinnamon spice. Well put together, it's soft and round on the palate with a full-bodied ripeness that minds its manners and plays well with its more elegant intentions.
Wine: Medlock Ames 2015 Heritage Merlot (Alexander Valley)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: A spicy cedary minerally aroma leads to bright raspberry and cranberry flavors in this medium-bodied, complex and appetizing wine. It has good acidity and fine-grained tannins to help the grip, and pleasant light flavors that will be great at the table.
Wine: Noceto 2011 AX1 Sangiovese (Amador County)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sweet toast and concentrated fruit aromas introduce this forward and appealing wine. Suggestions of berries, tree fruits and light tropical highlights combine gracefully. It's ready for immediate enjoyment and will reward any extra attention you give it.
Wine: Panther Creek 2015 Kalita Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Plum jelly, sarsaparilla and cola aromas show on the inviting nose of this bottling. There is great freshness and liveliness to the palate, where white pepper spices up the grenadine flavors.
Wine: Peachy Canyon 2015 Especial Zinfandel (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Oakville, Napa, California, US
Review: Dusty concentration and big oak offer a lasting impression of power and body in this wine, followed by a depth of rich red cherry and cassis, a sprinkling of dried herb lingering on the finish.
Wine: Piña 2014 Ames Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Oakville)

Appellation: Sonoma Coast, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Light in color and made to be acid-driven and fresh, this wine succeeds with a slightly carbonic expression of stemmy earthiness and intrigue. Strawberry-jam aromas are followed by a layering of citrus that persists through an understated finish.
Wine: Red Car 2014 Platt Vineyard Pinot Noir (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Ryan Rose
Review: Lightly ripe, this boasts clean varietal fruit amidst lushly toasty barrel flavors. Aged one year on the lees in half new and half neutral barrels, it's fresh and tasty, with sea salt caramel notes that enliven the finish.
Wine: Ryan Rose 2016 Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Sol Vie
Review: This spicy, round, fruit-powered wine offers a pleasing mix of berry and cherry flavors. The fruit is annotated with citrus rind highlights and has a firm, substantial finish with well-built tannins and a touch of toast.
Wine: Sol Vie 2015 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a smooth, round and likable wine, richly interwoven in baked cherry, cassis and cinnamon bark that's somewhat smoky in a good way on the lengthy finish.
Wine: St. Francis 2014 Lagomarsino Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Three quarters Pinot Noir and one quarter Chardonnay, this young sparkler is tart and tangy with lemon, pink grapefruit, green apple and orange flavors. There's a dash of baking spice and a slightly earthy note in the aroma, but overall it's enjoyable.
Wine: Stoller 2014 LaRue's Brut Rosé Sparkling (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Released each year around Valentine's Day, this carbonic experiment was an immediate hit. Served with a chill and very light in the glass, it shows primary aromas of strawberry, cola and rosewater. The playful palate is zippy with acid and dances across the tongue with flavors of tart red fruit. A great sunny day wine, but buy multiple bottles because they go fast.
Wine: Stolpman 2017 Love You Bunches Carbonic Sangiovese (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Bountiful dark red-fruit aromas meet with cocoa and herbs on the nose of this bottling, which leans toward slightly stewed fruit. The palate is framed by chalky tannins and lively acidity, carrying lavish fruit flavors and making for a very tasty if straightforward sip.
Wine: The Blending Lab 2015 bCS Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Deep and fresh black currant aromas meet with dried fennel on the nose of this bottling by a winery based in Los Angeles. A penetrating acidity kicks off the sip, where solid tannins carry dark fruit and rosemary flower flavors.
Wine: The Blending Lab 2015 PS Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: The Calling
Review: This wine is lovely and expressive in stony mineral, lemon rind, apple, quince and bread. It's medium-bodied, with a pleasant lushness that unfolds on the midpalate.
Wine: The Calling 2016 Chardonnay (Sonoma Coast)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Black-plum sauce, star anise, concentrated rose and strawberry-jam aromas make for a luxurious and inviting, if a bit powerful, nose on this bottling. Strawberry paste, white pepper and a gravelly minerality show on the sip.
Wine: Vie Winery 2013 L'Imaginaire Grenache (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Vigilance
Review: Smooth and flavorful, this wine has plenty of pear and light herb aromas. Light spice, mineral and melon flavors offer a good sense of layering on the palate, all leading to a generous mouthfeel and lingering finish.
Wine: Vigilance 2017 Sauvignon Blanc (Red Hills)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (WA), Washington Other, Washington, US
Review: Vibrant white flower, lychee and candied ginger aromas are followed by bone-dry fruit flavors in this wine. It shows exquisite length and balance, with a flavorful finish.
Wine: Viola 2016 Traminer Aromatico Oak Ridge Vineyard Gewürztraminer (Columbia Gorge (WA))

Appellation: Acrobat
Review: The second vintage of this variety for the popular Acrobat brand, this is a fine value: ripe and fruity, with a pleasing mix of citrus and tree fruit flavors. There's a gentle touch of fruit skin bitterness, balanced acidity and a light, butter-inflected finish.
Wine: Acrobat 2016 Chardonnay (Oregon)

Appellation: Santa Lucia Highlands, Central Coast, California, US
Review: There's a compelling fatness to the nose of this bottling, with broad aromas of nectarine, banana and coconut. That tropicality is present in the palate, with flavors of plumeria and coconut cream, but it's dialed back by a zesty lemon-edged acidity. Both rich and racy, this will appeal to many Chardonnay lovers.
Wine: Boekenoogen 2016 Estate Chardonnay (Santa Lucia Highlands)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is the first sparkling Riesling from Brooks, and it's a stunner. With dry, precise flavors, it's dominated by citrus rind notes and suggestions of rocks. It's penetrating and long, with lemon peel highlights throughout the finish.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Sparkling Riesling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Las Positas
Review: Light in body and very crisp in texture, this wine nevertheless packs a lot of flavor, showing bright lemon and fresh herb aromas, and very focused, tangy lemon and lime components on the palate. It is super refreshing and will be great with seafood among many other pairings.
Wine: Las Positas 2016 Verdelho (Alta Mesa)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Warm aromas of black cherry meet with vanilla and clove on the cohesive, satisfying nose of this reserve bottling. Bright red and candied fruit show on the hedonistic palate, where a pinch of green herbs provide complexity and a refreshing acidity washes into the finish.
Wine: Le Vigne 2014 Di Domenico Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Dark red-cherry, sweet blueberry and ripe watermelon aromas make for a very voluptuous and unique nose on this bottling. The palate is also fruity and zesty with sharp energetic acidity, showing juicy cranberry as well as baking spice on the finish. The acid should mellow soon and make for an even better wine.
Wine: Le Vigne 2015 Di Domenico Malbec (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Oregon, Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This blend of 60% Cabernet Franc and 40% Gamay is loaded with bright and brambly red berry and black cherry fruit. It does not shy away from acidity, shows no new oak and revels in exceptional concentration and a zippy dose of citrus.
Wine: Leah Jørgensen Cellars 2016 Oregon Tour Rain Vin Rouge Red (Oregon)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This Syrah-dominated blend has ripe raspberry jam, blueberry pie, dried herb, anise and blackberry aromas that lead to full-bodied dark fruit flavors. It's full-bore in style, like the vintage it comes from.
Wine: Co Dinn 2015 Red Wine Lonesome Springs Ranch Vineyard G-S-M (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Dragonette
Review: Forest undergrowth, muddy earth, crushed tarragon, dried mint and dark but not sweet plums show on the nose of this appellation blend. The palate shows earthy clay flavors as well as ripe cranberry and rose petals.
Wine: Dragonette 2015 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Dusted Valley
Review: This combines fruit from Southwind, Sconni Block and Stone Tree vineyards. The aromas are light out of the gate, with barrel spice, fresh herb, black cherry, coffee and mineral notes that become more prominent over time. Concentrated fruit flavors are backed by firm, grippy tannins. The structure is impressive.
Wine: Dusted Valley 2015 Cabernet Franc (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Perfumed in rose and violet and velvety smooth, this thick concentrated wine is richly woven in black cherry and black licorice. Its weightiness is youthful yet in check.
Wine: Etude 2015 Deer Camp Vineyard Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Santa Ynez Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Candied blackberry and black currant meet with lilacs on the concentrated gooey nose of this bottling by the pop star Fergie and her father. The thick blackberry note shows on the palate as well, with beef char, a touch of teriyaki and liquefied violets.
Wine: Ferguson Crest 2014 Private Reserve Syrah (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Fox Farm
Review: Co-fermented with 12% Syrah, this tasty wine opens with complex cinnamon, roasted coriander and wood smoke aromas. Mixed berry fruit flavors follow, with added brightness from using 30% whole clusters. The tannins are polished, contributing streaks of tea and tobacco.
Wine: Fox Farm 2015 Grenache (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Dark in color, this is a pretty wine, intensely aromatic in jasmine, anise and fresh flavors of white peach and green apple. Medium bodied, it has some oomph to the palate but is balanced.
Wine: Hawley 2017 Hopkins River Ranch Sauvignon Blanc (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Iron Hub
Review: This is a smooth mouth-filling wine that's easy to love for its deft combination of ripe plum and black cherry along with chocolate and baking-spice undertones. It feels medium bodied, well balanced and has a touch of tannin to help the texture.
Wine: Iron Hub 2014 Barbera (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Jaffurs
Review: The longtime Rhône variety-focused winery is expanding into Burgundian varieties, and this first Chardonnay is a solid start. Aromas of lime, white melon, wet stone and a touch of guava lean toward a richer expression. The palate is rounded with clotted cream, salt and lemon zest flavors, balancing between the buttery Californian and tenser Old World styles.
Wine: Jaffurs 2015 Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: California, California Other, California, US
Review: This is a spicy, oaky, full-bodied wine that's alluring in aroma and rich in flavor. Hints of vanilla, nutmeg and coconut lead to broad, ripe cherry and raspberry flavors on a smooth and lightly tannic texture.
Wine: Kendall-Jackson 2016 Vintner's Reserve Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Red Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: From one of the appellation's most esteemed vineyards, this offers brooding aromas on first pour, including black cherry, tar, flower and high toned herb notes. The palate is restrained in style, with a long finish.
Wine: Muret-Gaston 2014 Klipsun Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Red Mountain)

Appellation: Sta. Rita Hills, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Rounded, yeasty aromas of baking bread, sharp apple skins and the slightest hint of petrol show on the nose of this bubbly by Dave Potter. The bubbles are incredibly sharp and the tangy citrus flavors are refreshingly sour, with a dried apple touch rounding out the midpalate.
Wine: Potek 2014 Blanc de Blanc Chardonnay (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Roth
Review: This soft, round Merlot blends in small amounts of Malbec and Syrah to offer a powerful, full-bodied frame. It's lengthy on the palate in tart red fruit, integrated oak and fresh acidity.
Wine: Roth 2015 Merlot (Sonoma County)

Appellation: Columbia Valley (WA), Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: An equal split between the two varieties, this brings lurking dark roasted coffee, herb, plum, dark fruit and spice aromas. Its blue fruit flavors are tightly wound; they dip in the middle before coming back together, surrounded by luxurious French oak spice notes. The wood seems a bit primary at present, but there are a lot of good things going on.
Wine: Sightglass 2015 Stillwater Creek Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon-Malbec (Columbia Valley (WA))

Appellation: The Calling
Review: Made by Winemaker Dan Goldfield, this wine is well crafted and earthy. It's a soft, gentle expression of just-picked strawberry that's light in approach and delicate on the palate.
Wine: The Calling 2015 Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This is a light and delightful wine with bright and fresh fruit flavors suggesting apple, pear and peach. It's smooth and supple in the mouth, finishing with a touch of caramel.
Wine: Van Duzer 2016 Bieze Vineyard Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Arndt
Review: A very down-the-middle red wine, sure to please most, this bottling starts with dark blackberry, elderflower, char and vanilla aromas. The palate offers dried blueberry and hints of thyme, riding fine-grained tannins and strong acidity into the finish. Still a tad sticky, so it could use more time.
Wine: Arndt 2014 Merlot (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Made in a lighter style emphasizing elegance and precision, this young wine spent 14 months in 50% new oak. At the moment, oak intensity overrides the pretty apple butter-like fruit flavors, but the overall balance suggests it will iron itself out with more time in bottle.
Wine: Björnson 2016 Reserve Chardonnay (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Umpqua Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This wine is rooted in mixed berry fruit flavors, with a strong streak of citrus. Some unspecified barrel aging adds a seam of sea salt caramel to its medium-bodied fruit. It's in a drinking window that should extend to about 2022.
Wine: Brandborg 2014 Love Puppets Pinot Noir (Umpqua Valley)

Appellation: Ferguson Crest
Review: Concentrated berries, cola spice, licorice and gingerbread aromas show on the nose of this bottling. It's thick on the palate with boysenberry, plum, hoisin and gingersnap flavors—a heavier and spice-laden take on the grape.
Wine: Ferguson Crest 2015 Grenache (Santa Ynez Valley)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The first Chardonnay from Furioso, this is balanced and puckery, with zippy citrus, apple and pineapple flavors. Its ample acidity is sure to please fans of juicy whites; it's balanced by a light hint of toast on the finish.
Wine: Furioso 2015 La Linea Furioso Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Hawk Watch Winery
Review: Boysenberry, black pepper, dark spices and a hint of sandalwood show on the nose of this bottling, a good indication that Petite Sirah may thrive in this warmer Southern California climate. Rustic flavors of leather, dust, roasted blackberries and teriyaki are lifted with a pinch of purple flowers.
Wine: Hawk Watch Winery 2014 Petite Sirah (South Coast)

Appellation: Iron Hub
Review: A lot of ripeness and plenty of warm spicy oaky accents make this wine both mouth filling and easy to dive into. There are vanilla, cinnamon and sandalwood scents in the aromas, and fully ripe plum flavors along with light tannins.
Wine: Iron Hub 2014 Sangiovese (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Sonoma Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: Sanguine and herbal, this wine is hugely concentrated in extracted and intense flavors of blackberry, red currant and cedar. It showcases meaty tannins and rich oak.
Wine: Kunde 2015 Estate Merlot (Sonoma Valley)

Appellation: Le P'tit Paysan
Review: Dried herbs, elderberries, peppercorns and a strong streak of gamy meat show on the nose of this bottling, which is less dense and more nuanced in style than many other Petite Sirahs. The gamy element extends to the palate, giving complexity to the black fruits and sticky tannins.
Wine: Le P'tit Paysan 2014 Petite Sirah (Monterey County)

Appellation: Wahluke Slope, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's nuanced aromas include pear, baking spice and apple. Its restrained fruit and barrel flavors display finesse and length. A charmer.
Wine: Muret-Gaston 2016 Weinbau Vineyard Chardonnay (Wahluke Slope)

Appellation: Shenandoah Valley (CA), Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: A beefy brothy aroma leads to rich concentrated fruit flavors in this full-bodied and firm-textured wine. It has good structure, tasty layers of black cherry and red cherry and a mouth-filling presence that's appealing.
Wine: Noceto 2015 Misto Sangiovese (Shenandoah Valley (CA))

Appellation: Second Growth
Review: Despite the uninspired, generic package, this is a credible effort offering good value. Its ripe strawberry fruit is accented by gentle hints of mushroom, cherry cola and graham cracker. All the components are integrated, and the overall balance is spot-on.
Wine: Second Growth 2016 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Agate Ridge
Review: This barrel-fermented wine is fruity, full bodied and loaded with apple, peach and snappy grapefruit flavors. It's well balanced, ripe while keeping its alcohol in check, and framed with well-managed fruit skin flavors.
Wine: Agate Ridge 2015 Viognier (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Though still a little rough around the edges, this appeals with tart and spicy cranberry fruit and generous barrel flavors of chocolate wafer. Drink it over the next couple of years, lightly chilled.
Wine: Apolloni 2015 Estate Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Earth and rock flavors underscore this estate-grown wine's compact cranberry and blue plum fruit. The tannins bring green tea and dried tobacco notes.
Wine: Björnson 2015 Isabel Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Ripe pear and stone fruit aromas meet with smoke, wood and citrus pith on the dynamic nose of this blend of 48% Viognier, 26% Grenache Blanc and 26% Roussanne. It's tightly wound on the palate, with grippy texture and wild lime flavors.
Wine: Caliza 2016 Kissin' Cousins White (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Snipes Mountain, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This blend of Dijon clones 76 and 96 was fermented in 25% new French oak barrels and aged 17 months sur lie. Focused aromas of clarified butter, corn silk, baking spice and lees are followed by straw, stone fruit and citrus flavors that show texture and viscosity. It's equal parts intrigue and delivery, though it might be too creamy for some.
Wine: Co Dinn 2015 Roskamp Vineyard Chardonnay (Snipes Mountain)

Appellation: Carneros, Napa-Sonoma, California, US
Review: Woody, herbal and thick, this full-bodied wine is from a specific block of the winery's estate vineyard and its highest elevation spot. It's deeply concentrated and powerful in oak, a study in pepper and cardamom spice specked in black cherry.
Wine: Cuvaison 2015 Spire Pinot Noir (Carneros)

Appellation: Temecula Valley, South Coast, California, US
Review: Bright red fruit, rose petals, carnation and cinnamon spice show on the nose of this promising bottling from a newer producer in Temecula. Zesty and lighter bodied on the palate with pomegranate and fennel flavors, this would be perfect for washing down pizza or pasta.
Wine: Europa Village 2015 Vienza Montepulciano (Temecula Valley)

Appellation: Falcone
Review: Ripe tones of Pink Lady apple, light pineapple and tropical white flowers make for a soft and supple nose on this bottling. There is brightness to the sip, with lemongrass freshness that cuts through the slightly sweet lime-candy elements.
Wine: Falcone 2016 Chardonnay (Santa Maria Valley)

Appellation: Rogue Valley, Southern Oregon, Oregon, US
Review: This accessible wine is made for near-term enjoyment. It's soft, round, open and medium bodied, with vanilla-inflected mulberry and blackberry fruit. A streak of cola runs through the finish.
Wine: Irvine & Roberts 2015 115 Block Pinot Noir (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Jessie's Grove
Review: This is a silky smooth, full-bodied wine with a light gold color, inviting baking-spice aromas, ripe and concentrated fruit flavors and an especially rich mouthfeel, due partly to a high alcohol level.
Wine: Jessie's Grove 2016 Chardonnay (Lodi)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This well-balanced and straightforward wine has fresh crisp apple and white-peach flavors and a good dry palate with light acidity and light body. Those are just the traits that many people are looking for in a rosé.
Wine: Klinker Brick 2017 Bricks & Roses Estate Rosé (Lodi)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This might bring the current wave of traditional method British sparkling wines to mind, with hints of chalk, lime, gooseberry, apple and grapefruit. It's delicate and dry, blending 44% Chardonnay, 34% Pinot Noir and 22% Piinot Meunier.
Wine: Kramer 2015 Brut Zero Dosage Sparkling (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Walla Walla Valley (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: Appealing aromas of fresh herb, dried thyme, raspberry and cherry are followed by plump, lightly styled fruit flavors. Grainy tannins provide support. Give it some time to open up.
Wine: Laelaps 2015 Seven Hills Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon (Walla Walla Valley (OR))

Appellation: Monterey County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Hints of lime blossoms, toasted nuts and wood smoke show on the nose of this very fairly priced bottling, whose previous vintages have been shown to age magically. Wood-fired pears and apples show on the palate, which will please both those seeking a bit of oak and those who enjoy a racier style of Chardonnay.
Wine: Le P'tit Paysan 2016 Jacks Hill Chardonnay (Monterey County)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: In a region known for its Pinots Gris and Noir, this single vineyard Gamay takes your palate in a different direction. Sharp and tangy, it's packed with potent cranberry flavors and earthy tannins. Chill slightly and set it out with a picnic basket of cured meats and hard cheeses.
Wine: Leah Jørgensen Cellars 2016 Le Coeur de Tour Rain Gamay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Mendocino, Mendocino County, California, US
Review: This wine was blended from mostly Italian grape varieties and aged in 25% new French barrels It has a firm, tannic structure and a good dose of tart cranberry and raspberry flavors shaded by cinnamon and cedar nuances. It's medium bodied but has enough grip to pair with rich protein dishes.
Wine: Monte Volpe 2013 Peppolino Red (Mendocino)

Appellation: Rex Hill
Review: This Willamette Valley blend is a reliable benchmark for drinkable Pinot Noir. Its black cherry fruit is solid and substantial, the tannins are firm and chewy, and there's a light touch of stem, black olive and dark chocolate.
Wine: Rex Hill 2015 Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Aged in once-used and older French oak, this leads with aromas that draw you into the glass: dried and fresh herb, cherry, tobacco, flower and dark raspberry. The dark fruit flavors display concentration and depth, with a texture that heightens the appeal.
Wine: Structure 2015 Boushey Vineyard Cabernet Franc (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Three Thieves
Review: An almost unbelievably good buy, this wine is clean, fresh and appealing. It has a toasted oak nuance in the aroma and expansive fruit and baking spice flavors that fill out the palate. Well-balanced, it displays a ripe red-cherry flavor and a fairly crisp and appetizing texture.
Wine: Three Thieves 2016 Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Production of this wine has soared in this vintage, which is just beginning to display some integration of its complex fruit. Citrus, strawberry and raspberry notes are cloaked in cola and mocha. The tannins are lightly dusty, lacking the concentration of the 2014.
Wine: Van Duzer 2015 Dijon Blocks Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Santa Barbara County, Central Coast, California, US
Review: A touch of Mourvèdre was added to this blend of the Thompson and nearby White Hawk vineyards, which shows elderberry jelly, jasmine and wisteria on the intensely floral nose. Those florals float across the palate, with lilac and violet decorating the core full of black plum and peppercorn.
Wine: Vie Winery 2013 Les Amours Syrah (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This is principally Sauvignon Blanc, but the 20% Moscato Giallo lends the predominant aroma. Fermented in neutral oak barrels and finished totally dry, it's a leesy, creamy, richly-textured white with a strong flavor of wet stone, citrus rind and fresh-squeezed lemon. A distinctive and refreshing style that complements the winery's other whites.
Wine: Viola 2016 Bianco d'Allegre White (Columbia Gorge (OR))

Appellation: Z. Alexander Brown
Review: Fresh herb and melon aromas lead to a fairly rich mouthfeel and a combination of tangy, fruity and mineral-like flavors that add up to a well-rounded and well-made wine.
Wine: Z. Alexander Brown 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (North Coast)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: A blend of 54% Pinot Noir and 46% Chardonnay, this is tart on the verge of sour. Its mixed citrus fruit flavors recall grapefruit, orange and tangerine. Fresh to a fault, it has a long, zippy finish.
Wine: Anne Amie 2011 Marilyn Brut Sparkling (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This light-bodied Pinot Noir has watermelon, strawberry and raspberry fruit flavors. There are peppery herbal notes also, suggesting fairly low Brix. Aging in barrel for 16 months seems to have softened it without adding oak to the flavors.
Wine: La Randonnée 2015 Carlton Hill Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This blend of fruit from several of the winery's top vineyards is still tart and astringent, yet it provides an excellent snapshot of the higher-priced, single vineyard offerings. Its mixed berry flavors seem only lightly exposed to new oak and have plenty of snap and freshness.
Wine: Panther Creek 2015 Winemaker's Cuvée Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Ryan Rose
Review: Light leather and barnyard notes lead the way, suggesting this wine wine is starting to dry out. The fruit is leathery rather than fresh, and the tannins have a marked astringency. That said, the style emulates many Riojas—a fair standard. Drink now–2022.
Wine: Ryan Rose 2015 Tempranillo (Rogue Valley)

Appellation: Season
Review: Tropical fruits come through in abundance here, from mango and guava to peach and citrus. It's all about fresh, forward fruit and best enjoyed while it's still in the first blush of youth.
Wine: Season 2016 Viognier (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: Horse Heaven Hills, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Fennel, herb, spice and boysenberry and black fruit scents are followed by concentrated fruit flavors in this wine. An intriguing light meaty streak carries through the finish. The tannins bring a slight astringency, keeping it from fully coming together. Perhaps more time in bottle will help.
Wine: Structure 2015 Wallula Vineyard Syrah (Horse Heaven Hills)

Appellation: Tercero
Review: Deep red fruit meets with cedar and pepper dust on the nose of this bottling, which takes some time to come into its own and will probably be better in a year or two. Plummy flavors are framed by tight and sticky tannins, and lifted by peppercorns and crushed slate.
Wine: Tercero 2016 Carignane (Santa Barbara County)

Appellation: Paso Robles, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Nutmeg, baked cherry, Chinese five spice and cinnamon show on the nose of this bottling. The palate falls in line, with rounded red fruit, baking spice and a compelling texture.
Wine: Villa San Juliette 2015 Reserve Grenache (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Villa San Juliette
Review: Very light in the glass, this fresh bottling shows aromas of lime rinds, Anjou pear skins and rainy cement but also riper touches of passion fruit and gooseberry. There is a strong citrus tang to the sip, a ripe apple flavor and a crushed seashell minerality.
Wine: Villa San Juliette 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Sourced from 45-year-old vines, this is a creamy, accessible wine with pleasing fruit flavors. Lime, grapefruit and apple notes are set against ample acidity and barrel toast. Buttered nut and vanilla streaks come out on the finish.
Wine: Dominio IV 2015 Old Vine Wahle Vineyard Chardonnay (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Yamhill-Carlton, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's vanilla cream aromas waft from the glass. The fruit is centered on black cherry, with ancillary notes of forest floor, stem and earth. Give it a bit of aeration to help integrate the flavors.
Wine: Dominio IV 2015 Rain on Leaves Stermer Vineyard Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Dundee Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This deep rose-colored wine with silky cherry fruit was made entirely from old Pommard clone vines. Orange peel, sassafras and cocoa powder nuances embellish its dusty tannins. It's a tasty, genteel wine drinking quite nicely at this time.
Wine: Fox Farm 2014 Weber Vineyard Reserve Pinot Noir (Dundee Hills)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: Vibrant jasmine, honeysuckle and peach aromas lead to honeyed, ultrasweet stone and tropical fruit flavors in this wine. It tapers toward the finish, needing a bit more acidity to come together, but the price is hard to beat.
Wine: Frost Bitten 2016 Ice Riesling (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Lodi, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Hints of vanilla and milk chocolate dress up this amply fruity, nutty wine as it spreads across the palate smoothly and turns a touch sweet on the finish. It's deliciously rich and easy to sip, and will make a good dessert wine.
Wine: Klinker Brick 2015 Farráh Syrah (Lodi)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: The winery's flagship Pinot Noir, this is a blend from various vineyards. It's full and fleshy, with berry and plum fruit tones. Smooth through the midpalate, it turns granular by the finish, with a light touch of chocolate and caramel.
Wine: Brooks 2015 Janus Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Livermore Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Vibrant fruit flavors and a very firm tannic texture peg this wine as one to age for a few years. It combines cranberry and cherry aromas with deeper black-cherry and cassis flavors that stay lively due to good acidity.
Wine: Las Positas 2014 Estate Tempranillo (Livermore Valley)

Appellation: Le Vigne
Review: Dried blueberry, loamy soil, anise and roasting herbs of oregano, thyme and marjoram show on the nose of this bottling. Roasted blackberry flavors show on the slightly sweet-seeming sip, which is made complex by pepper and charred meat.
Wine: Le Vigne 2015 Petite Sirah (Paso Robles)

Appellation: Willamette Valley, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: Capturing the elegant aromas of both vineyard and vintage, this tickles the nose with rose petal and spring strawberry scents. Raspberry notes join the mix in the mouth, feeling clean and refreshing, though more delicate than powerful.
Wine: Dominio IV 2013 Mulberry Street Vitae Springs Vineyard Pinot Noir (Willamette Valley)

Appellation: Eola-Amity Hills, Willamette Valley, Oregon, US
Review: This wine's new French oak was reduced to 29% this vintage, and the alcohol is lower than it was in 2014. Nonetheless, it shows solid winemaking and evidence of an earlier pick. Its tight core of tart red berry fruit is laced with tomato leaf, citrus and pineapple scents and flavors.
Wine: Iota Cellars 2015 Pelos Sandberg Vineyard Pinot Noir (Eola-Amity Hills)

Appellation: Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Stewed black plum, licorice and milk chocolate show on the nose of this ripe red blend, packaged in a colorful label. Berry and strawberry flavors meet with dried anise on the palate, which is framed by somewhat sticky tannins.
Wine: Jalopy 2014 Happy Red (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Yakima Valley, Columbia Valley, Washington, US
Review: This wine's appealing plum, barrel spice, smoke and fresh herb aromas lead to well balanced black fruit flavors supported by lively acidity. It's quite enjoyable and should shine with steak.
Wine: Muret-Gaston 2015 Olsen Vineyard Petit Verdot (Yakima Valley)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: This big wine smells very potent and concentrated, and tastes ripe and broad and mouth coating. Full body and a thick but not chewy texture give it a lot of impact on the palate, carrying opulent blackberry and black-cherry flavors through the finish.
Wine: Sobon Estate 2016 ReZerve Tannat (Amador County)

Appellation: Amador County, Sierra Foothills, California, US
Review: A robust component of smoky aromas and flavors give a large personality to this concentrated, ripe and extremely full-bodied wine. It practically spills over with juicy blackberry and boysenberry flavors, and has a full but sleek mouthfeel backed by mild tannins.
Wine: Andis 2014 Estate Zinfandel (Amador County)

Appellation: Clarksburg, Central Valley, California, US
Review: This giant of a wine has more than enough oaky aromas, a full body and toasty, buttery flavors that coat the palate. The vanilla, lemon zest, butter cream and grilled baguette notes are delicious, so this will be a great choice for people who like an all-out oaky style.
Wine: Bogle 2016 Phantom Chardonnay (Clarksburg)

Appellation: Bud's Bloom
Review: Sourced from a single vineyard, this vintage blends clones 777 and 113. It's evolving gracefully into secondary flavors of raspberry pastry yet is still bright enough to bring spicy, claret-style Zinfandel to mind. There's a peppery kick to the finish, and it gives the sense that it's entering a prime drinking window.
Wine: Bud's Bloom 2013 Pinot Noir (Yamhill-Carlton)

Appellation: Dragonette
Review: Pomelo skin, grapefruit zest, chalk and a bit of reductive petrol and smoke aromas show on the nose of this appellation blend. The palate offers tremendous textural grip with tangy lime and underripe Pink Lady apple flavors.
Wine: Dragonette 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Happy Canyon of Santa Barbara)

Appellation: Adelaida District, Central Coast, California, US
Review: Elegant Asian pear, apple blossoms and wet stone make for a restrained take on Viognier by young winemaker Natalie Darr. It's a tad riper on the palate, with poached pear and hints of tropical fruit, but also a zesty acidity and firm chalky texture throughout.
Wine: Rococo 2017 Alta Colina Vineyard Viognier (Adelaida District)

Appellation: Simple Life
Review: This medium-bodied wine from Don Sebastiani & Sons. It has aromas and flavors of cherries, forest floor and cloves, plus a healthy streak of smoky, spicy oak. Moderate tannins give good grip on the palate and there is enough flavor concentration to fill the mouth and linger nicely on the finish.
Wine: Simple Life 2016 Pinot Noir (California)

Appellation: Edna Valley, Central Coast, California, US
Review: This stainless expression shows soft and supple aromas of candied honeydew, cotton candy and bubblegum, yet against a crushed chalk minerality. It's grippy on the palate, offering hints of guava soda and passion fruit, yet with a savory hint of sea salt from the nearby ocean.
Wine: Tangent 2016 Paragon Vineyard Albariño (Edna Valley)

Appellation: Columbia Gorge (OR), Oregon Other, Oregon, US
Review: This is bound to be controversial, because it incorporates a certain leathery funk in both aroma and flavor. The color is deep and the flavors punchy, showing full-bodied red fruit and potpourri. It was made from organic grapes and finished in stainless tanks.
Wine: Viola 2016 Allegre Vineyard Dolcetto (Columbia Gorge (OR))

Appellation: Agate Ridge
Review: This wine's juicy citrus flavors are amplified by varietally appropriate notes of cut grass and melon. There's a touch of celery, plenty of supporting acidity and an overall freshness that calls for drinking over the next year or two.
Wine: Agate Ridge 2016 Sauvignon Blanc (Southern Oregon)

Appellation: Russian River Valley, Sonoma, California, US
Review: This is a microscopic production, which shows itself to be medium bodied to full, with soft moderate structure. Dried cherry, raspberry and dried citrus round out the approachable, likable fruit-forwardness of the layered wine.
Wine: Arthur Cellars 2015 Pride and Joy Pinot Noir (Russian River Valley)

Appellation: Bellante
Review: The dank aroma of forest undergrowth meets with campfire smoke and red currants on the nose of this appellation blend. The palate is lightweight in body though lively with flavors of wild berries and pine forest spice, bolstered by solid acidity.
Wine: Bellante 2015 Pinot Noir (Sta. Rita Hills)

Appellation: Clarksburg, Central Valley, California, US
Review: Big and beefy, this wine has huge aromas of wood smoke, beef jus and cedar followed by generous blackberry and black-cherry flavors and a firm tannic texture. Earthy roasted elements indicate it's fully mature now.
Wine: LangeTwins 2013 Miller Vineyard Merlot (Clarksburg)
